webTitle: Councils' plea to Prescott for floods funding

fields.headline: Councils' plea to Prescott for floods funding
fields.trailText: The decision on whether local authorities should provide an extra £10.8m to pay for flood damage in one of the worst-hit areas of Britain was today deferred in a bid to secure extra funding from the government.
fields.body:
The decision on whether local authorities should provide an extra £10.8m to pay for flood damage in one of the worst-hit areas of Britain was today deferred in a bid to secure extra funding from the government.

A meeting of the Yorkshire Flood Defence Committee in York voted unanimously to postpone a decision on whether to give the Environment Agency a 63% increase in its levy to pay for essential work for flood defences caused by November's devastating flooding.

More than 2,500 homes were flooded in the region and more than a third of the total emergency response and repair costs for the whole of the country were incurred in the county.

If the flood defence committee agrees to the levy increase it could mean a hike in council tax bills in the region of £6 to £10 per household per year.

The Environment Agency told today's meeting it had submitted a bid for some of the £51m funding promised by deputy prime minister John Prescott during the crisis.

But committee chairman Roy Ward, who told the meeting the floods in Yorkshire were the worst for 400 years, said there had been no response from the government.

Councillor Peter Sowray, representing North Yorkshire county council and the City of York council, told the committee: "John Prescott came to Yorkshire and stood up to his waist in water and said 'Don't worry, we'll help'.

"We've got to keep him to his promises - he's not to be allowed to escape on that one."

The Environment Agency says the increase, an extra £10.8m on top of last year's levy of £17.2m, was needed to avert another disaster.

Emergency repairs to existing defences will cost £2.8m, while £7.8m has been added to the agency's existing £15.1m capital programme for flood alleviation schemes.

Recommending deferment of the decision, Jack Goodhand, a councillor representing Barnsley, Rotherham and Doncaster borough councils and Derbyshire county council, said: "Local authorities are not inhuman bodies - we are concerned about what happened but we also have a responsibility to ensure that we look after all areas of the community."

Environment Agency appointee Ian Bonas pointed out that any money the local authorities agree to provide will be reimbursed in their government funding next year.

A flood defence committee in Solihull, West Midlands, last week voted to impose an extra 12% levy, sparking calls for government assistance by Labour councillors.

The decision in Yorkshire has been deferred until a meeting in York on February 2.

webTitle: Salmond opts for Westminster in change of heart

fields.headline: Salmond opts for Westminster in change of heart
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Alex Salmond, Scotland's best-known nationalist politician, is poised to reverse his decision to stand down as a Westminister MP at the coming election - and instead stand down as an Edinburgh MSP.
fields.body:
Alex Salmond, Scotland's best-known nationalist politician, is poised to reverse his decision to stand down as a Westminister MP at the coming election - and instead stand down as an Edinburgh MSP.

The former leader of the Scottish National party, whose shrewd leftish populism pushed his party into second place in the Scottish parliament, is hoping to square the decision with his party's national executive and his constituency activists at Banff and Buchan this weekend.

It will mean persuading his official chauffeur, Stewart Stevenson, to stand aside as the SNP's prospective parliamentary candidate for the seat where he was adopted after Mr Salmond decided to leave the Commons.

Mr Stevenson was said last night to be ready to act "in the best interests of the party" - provided the executive and local supporters rallied to Mr Salmond's decision.

Behind the change of heart lies a mixture of political strategy and personal preference, SNP insiders say. But the idea that their best known champion may prefer the larger pool of Westminster politics may startle some SNP activists. "He's bored with Holyrood," crowed one Scottish Labour MP last night.

It is known that John Swinney, the moderate MP who succeeded Mr Salmond as SNP leader last summer, wants a "heavy hitter" to remain at Westminster when the party's other five MPs step down at the expected May election.

Mr Salmond, 46, certainly fits that bill. Since his farewell press conference at the Commons on July 21, Donald Dewar, Scotland's first minister and a big beast of the political jungle, has died - to be succeeded by Henry McLeish, a less tempting Labour target for Mr Salmond.

Mr McLeish has been moving to establish himself and is poised for a showdown with his fellow Fife MP, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, over his promise that the Scottish executive will pay for both medical and social care of old people confined to nursing homes.

That formula, which would cost Mr McLeish £100m of his budget - provided by the Treasury - is in line with the Sutherland report on care of the elderly. But Alan Milburn, health secretary, has rejected paying for social care on grounds of cost.

Labour's problems in Scotland, where it narrowly fought off an SNP challenge in last month's Falkirk byelection, were further underlined yesterday by reports that Mr McLeish wants to change the name of the Scottish executive - to the Scottish government.

webTitle: The BBC under fire over quiz show

fields.headline: New row over BBC prize
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: The BBC has come under fire for wasting licence fee payers money for a new quiz show on BBC Choice, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has come under fire for wasting licence fee payer's money for a new quiz show on little-watched digital TV channel BBC Choice.

The show, Rent Free, is offering prize money potentially worth £24,000 - more than is available to winners of hit BBC1 quiz The Weakest Link.

Shadow culture and media spokesman Peter Ainsworth slammed the payments on a non-mainstream channel that is only available to viewers with access to digital tv.

"It does not seem to me to be the type of programme the licence payer should fund," he said.

"If the BBC wants to make blatantly commercial programmes, those programmes should be funded commercially."

Rent Free is to be hosted by Big Breakfast star Richard Bacon, who was sacked as a BBC Blue Peter presenter for taking cocaine.

Teams of four will compete for the prize, which takes the form of a year's stay in a luxury apartment, which is expected to be made later this year.

Last year the BBC was accused of bending the rules after it doubled the top prize on The Weakest Link to £20,000, setting a new high for payouts.

While there is no limit on what prizes television shows can offer, the BBC guidelines for programme makers say that "cash prizes should be avoided. It is inappropriate to spend licence fee money on prizes of excessive value."

The BBC defended The Weakest Link prize level, saying that it was unlikely such a high prize would be won. Most contestants leave with a fraction of that.

webTitle: Sunday Sport publisher criticises Desmond

fields.headline: Desmond's top-shelf titles 'not worth tuppence' says rival
fields.standfirst: Jan 11: Desmond to sell top-shelf titles
fields.trailText:
4.30pm update: Daily Sport publisher David Sullivan has criticised Express owner Richard Desmond's decision to sell his top-shelf titles, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 11: Desmond to sell top-shelf titles
fields.body:
Sunday Sport publisher David Sullivan has slammed Express owner Richard Desmond's decision to sell his top-shelf titles.

Mr Sullivan said his rival's pornography magazines, which include x-rated publications such as Asian Babes and Forum, "are not worth tuppence".

"The whole adult magazine market is saturated and under pressure from TV and the internet," he said.

"The talk of getting £10m-£20m for them is absolute nonsense. I cannot conceive of anyone who would want to buy them."

Mr Sullivan added that the titles had too small a circulation and were of "minimum value".

"They were launched with little advertising or promotion and I will bet they are not doing well," he said.

Mr Desmond owns the Northern & Shell publishing group but keeps the porn titles at arm's length, producing them through his Portland Investments firm.

Portland turned over £21m in 1999, according to the latest published accounts, leaving a profit of just £1.7m.

But the accounts also show that the publishing arm of Portland made a loss of £860,000.

The television side of the company, however, does make money and registered a profit of £2.5m in 1999.

A successful sale of the titles, which would include various websites, would remove any chance of trade secretary Stephen Byers blocking last year's acquisition of the Express group on public interest grounds.

Mr Sullivan set an alarming precedent for Mr Desmond 10 years ago, when he was barred from buying the Bristol Evening Post group by the Monopolies & Mergers Commission. The commission ruled that his ownership "could harm the standing of the papers in their community".

Mr Desmond needs cash to invest in the ailing Express titles, and he has already embarked on a cost-cutting spree at Ludgate House.

The Express takeover was funded by a £97m loan from Commerzbank, and industry experts say it will take a minimum of £100m over the next three years to turn around the fortunes of the Daily and Sunday Express and the Daily Star.

Jan 11: Desmond to sell adult mags

fields.trailText:
5.15pm: The disgraced former Express columnist Stephen Pollard could be sued for bringing the paper into disrepute, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 11: Top-shelf titles 'not worth tuppence'
Jan 11: Desmond to sell adult mags
Jan 8: Pollard loses Times job
fields.body:
The disgraced former Express columnist Stephen Pollard could be sued by the newspaper's new owners, Northern & Shell, for bringing the paper into disrepute.

An Express spokesman confirmed that Mr Pollard "has been hit with a very heavy legal letter", adding that there was "a distinct possibility that he will be sued".

Mr Pollard, who resigned from his job in protest after the Express by Richard Desmond, hid an obscene goodbye message in a leader column about the farming industry.

The letter at the start of each paragraph spelled out "Fuck You Desmond".

Mr Pollard has already lost his job at the Times because of the message.

Now it is evident that Mr Desmond did not see the funny side of Mr Pollard's parting shot in last week's leader.

An insider said: "It might seem a bit heavy-handed, but maybe if he had come up with something a little more humorous it mightn't have had such dire consequences."

Mr Pollard was not available for comment.

webTitle: Where English can serve but not empower

fields.headline: Where English can serve but not empower
fields.standfirst: Although South Africa's language policy is in crisis, multilingualism must be defended, says Neville Alexander
fields.trailText: South Africa's schools should be using the home language of their students as the medium of instruction. This multilingual approach to education was made law in 1997, and is intended, among other things, to modernise the African languages for routine use in high-status functions. But two fundamental obstacles are standing in the way of this policy. One is a crisis in resources and infrastructure, and the other is a lack of political will on the part of the elite.
fields.body:
South Africa's schools should be using the home language of their students as the medium of instruction. This multilingual approach to education was made law in 1997, and is intended, among other things, to modernise the African languages for routine use in high-status functions. But two fundamental obstacles are standing in the way of this policy. One is a crisis in resources and infrastructure, and the other is a lack of political will on the part of the elite.

The result is that by default English - as elsewhere in Africa - is becoming the de facto official language and the only language of teaching and learning. So why should South Africa defend and implement its multilingual language policy, and not give way to an English-only or English-mainly policy?

English is currently the dominant language of teaching in South Africa. Indeed for most children from an African-language background almost all education after the first three years of schooling is in English.

Equally important is the fact that most schools are staffed by second- or third-language speakers of English, many of whom are not proficient enough in English to serve as good models for their students. There is little doubt that the language issue is one of the main factors explaining the disastrous drop-out and failure rates, which affect mainly black students.

The 1997 policy was intended to sustain the home language throughout the educational career of the learner, preferably as a medium, but in any case as a subject. In practice, however, it is not possible for children from an African-language background to receive instruction through the medium of their home language beyond Grade 3 or 4.

In fact one of the ineffable ironies of the new South Africa is that the only children who have mother-tongue education (L1-medium) are precisely those who have been advantaged in most other respects in the course of South Africa's history: English- and most Afrikaans-speaking children.

Before the first non-racial elections in April 1994 most people assumed that English would become the only, or at least the main language of teaching in educational institutions. This was, after all, what had happened in virtually all ex-colonial African countries in the English sphere of interest. Namibia is the latest example.

The dialectic of South African history, however, ordained otherwise. Because of the passionate commitment of white Afrikaans-speaking South Africans to their language, their political representatives during the negotiation process in the early 90s insisted on the continued equality of Afrikaans with English as a condition for ceding office to the representatives of the liberation movement. These, in turn, for obvious political reasons could not concede to Afrikaans what they did not also give to the indigenous languages. Hence, the 11 official languages of the new South Africa.

It should come as no surprise that all South Africans agree about the need for English as the second language, mainly because it is so obviously the key to economic empowerment. Yet for as long as the vast majority of people are not proficient in English, and without the promotion of multilingualism and the equitable treatment of all languages, democracy will remain a sham. This is so because most people would have to conduct all their important affairs, as they do at present, in a language they barely understand.

An English-only, or even an English-mainly, policy necessarily condemns most people, and thus the country as a whole, to a permanent state of mediocrity, since people are unable to be spontaneous, creative and self-confident if they cannot use their first language.

Even more important, however, is the fact that economic development, which in the modern world is dependent on high levels of scientific and technological know-how, will continue to be stymied because the English-knowing layer from which the expertise can be recruited will continue to be very thin.

To argue that a policy of multilingualism is too 'costly' to implement is disingenuous at worst and ill-informed and unexplored at best. On principle any polity has to be prepared to invest in the necessary infrastructure in those economic and social domains where it may have a comparative disadvantage. If it is a country where water resources are scarce, then boreholes, desalination plants and other equipment have to be invested in. If there are many languages, then investment has to be made in the different ways and means available for the facilitation of communication among the people of the country.

In our case such investment can either be directed towards the goal of making English the lingua franca of the entire population in the short term (despite the negative experience in this regard in most of the rest of Africa) or towards multilingual proficiency, or towards both. The official language policy in education promotes this third option.

It follows, then, that a system of bilingual education is an essential transitional strategy towards the normalisation of education, until the situation is reached where English is learned by most children as a subject at school rather than as an ineffectual medium of learning in general. But elitist policy orientations, the lack of political will and bureaucratic inertia have tended to promote the first option in practice.

These, then, are the factors that have to be resolved in the equation of language medium policy in South African education. In most schools there is no doubt that the basic principle of additive bilingualism - sustaining the home language (L1) as a medium, and, if this is impossible, as a subject - is the best way forward. Besides the findings of international research about the desirability and effectiveness of L1-medium education, the most recent authoritative language survey (commissioned by the Pan South African Language Board) tilts the balance in favour of the advocates of bilingual and Ümother-tongue" education, even if on the surface this would appear to buck the global trend.

Those of us who advocate bilingual education as an inescapable transitional strategy - which may, however, become the global norm because of the imperatives of globalisation - and of mother-tongue education as the most effective approach to education in most situations have the South African constitution as well as the official language policy in education on our side. If this approach is combined with effective L2 - in practice English-language - teaching, in the longer term the 'problem' will disappear, and our many languages will be seen for what they are: national resources, which are to be managed for the benefit of all citizens of South Africa.

Dr Neville Alexander is director of the Project for the Study of Alternative Education in South Africa, at the University of Cape Town.

webTitle: Yahoo! warning hits hi-tech shares

fields.headline: Yahoo! warning hits hi-tech shares
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Yahoo! set Nasdaq on another downward slide today after issuing a major warning about its profits in the coming year.
fields.body:
Yahoo! set Nasdaq on another downward slide today after issuing a major warning about its profits in the coming year.

Yahoo! met Wall Street expectations for its fourth quarter earnings per share - but slashed the targets for earnings in 2001. Wall Street analysts expected the company to post earnings per share of 13 US cents in the first quarter of 2001. But Yahoo! has now told investors to expect between just four and seven cents a share. The company announced a net income of $80.2m (£53m) for the fourth quarter 2000, on par with analyst expectations and up from $55.7m for the same quarter 1999. That news has not calmed investors worried about dwindling company profits.

Yahoo! - based in Santa Clara, California - lost 20% of its value in after-hours trading. Traders said Yahoo!, which ended official trading in New York yesterday at $30.5, slid to a new 52-week low of $24.75 after hours in the US, but recovered slightly to trade around $25 when Nasdaq opened this morning.

As one of the most successful internet companies trading on Nasdaq, any slippage from the $14bn Yahoo! can be expected further to shake investor confidence in the technology sector as a whole.

Tim Koogle, chairman and chief executive officer of Yahoo!, defended his company's performance. "By almost any measure Yahoo! continued to outperform the industry, and took market share despite a challenging environment," he said. He blamed the lowered earnings projections on a weak economy.

The news of Yahoo!'s difficulties coincide with that of another popular US internet portal, AltaVista, which today pulled its intended flotation and refused to set a new date. AltaVista had previously cancelled plans to float on the stock market in December 1999.

webTitle: Gills chairman denies financial irregularities

fields.headline: Gills chairman denies financial irregularities
fields.trailText: Gillingham chairman Paul Scally has vowed to defend his club against any allegations of financial irregularities.
fields.body:
Gillingham chairman Paul Scally has vowed to defend his club against any allegations of financial irregularities.

A private investigator has compiled a number of files allegedly relating to irregularities and illegal payments to players at the First Division club.

The files were taken to public relations expert Max Clifford and have been passed on to a national newspaper. Scally, who rescued the club from extinction in June 1995, issued a statement saying: "I am unaware as to the nature or substance of any allegations of financial irregularity.

"I strongly refute that any financial irregularities have occurred that I am aware of and will defend any allegations against the football club in the High Court in the appropriate manner and at the relevant time.

"I am consulting with lawyers today but note that these allegations have persisted since May 1999 and despite requests have never been clarified or substantiated to either me, the club's accountants, the FA or the Football League."

The FA are aware of the issue but stressed they have yet to be officially informed of any allegations.

However, an FA spokesman confirmed: "While allegations have been made to us about this case, so far nothing supportive has been produced. If anyone can bring substantial evidence we will gladly investigate it."

Clifford said he had urged the investigator to go to the FA but that the man "has very little faith in the FA" to conduct an investigation.

"The files have been passed on to a national newspaper because the private investigator wanted to be paid and felt a national newspaper would probably work a lot faster and possibly more thoroughly than the FA," said Clifford.

"Those were his views, not mine. From a conversation I had with him he told me 'You have exposed Jeffrey Archer, Jonathan Aitken and people like that - what about corruption in football?' I said if there is corruption in football I'm more than happy to show it up."

If the allegations are proven to be correct they could threaten Gillingham's position in the First Division gained through a play-off final win over Wigan at Wembley.

In the most high-profile case of its type Swindon were demoted two divisions after gaining a place in the old First Division by beating Sunderland 1-0 in the play-off final in May 1990. The club admitted to 36 breaches of league regulations but after an appeal were allowed to remain in the old Second Division.

"I've noted that all the recent new names end in friendly, international sounding vowels (Accenture, Consignia)," says Jamie Stephenson from Southport. "I've noted that all the recent new names end in friendly, international sounding vowels (Accenture, Consignia)," says Jamie Stephenson from Southport. "You will also need to keep some part of your current name to aid recognition. So Diaria it is then." I'm afraid we won't be sending you the large fee you suggest, Jamie.

In any case, Gùff has proved by far the most popular name. We even have a slogan: "The column that puts the Gùff in guffaw." Pretty good, eh? I think Matthew, wherever he is, will be pleased.

 Jack Straw chose the mean streets of King's Cross to launch his assault on violent crime yesterday - and probably wishes he hadn't. It wasn't just the Big Issue seller who was keen to keep the tenner the home secretary handed over for a copy. During his press conference, Mr Straw realised his flies were undone and let out a squeal of anguish. "You're not the first public figure to be caught in King's Cross with his flies undone," chortled one cynical scribe.

 A memo circulated in the BBC Wales newsroom earlier this week caused much hilarity. "The Pope's representative in Britain, the Apostolic Nuncio, has visited Cardiff to reassure the clergy and laity of the archdiocese in the wake of the convictions for sex abuse of two priests. This afternoon he'll meet with a group of nuns and lay people."

 Labour's new Homes Bill insists that the moment you tell anyone you might be selling your house, it's on the market, and you have to produce a "seller's pack" that will set you back more than £300. If you don't, you can be fined. Lucky that LibDem MP Don Foster was on hand with a late-night amendment "excluding casual conversations in premises licensed for entertainment or for the sale of intoxicating liquors". (Thanks to a Mr D Foster of SW1 for pointing out this timely intervention.)

 The Discovery Health Channel has invited proposals from independent production companies for a new 15-part health series. It makes only one stipulation about subject matter - "avoid sickness".

 Book news (1). The updated version of Times columnist Michael Gove's biography of Michael Portillo has been shelved. The biography originally appeared in 1995, perfect in every detail apart from Gove's reluctance to discuss his hero's gay experiences. The revised edition was supposed to appear this spring, but has now been scrapped. Gove says he doesn't have the time to do it. Pity, because when the Tories lose the election and Portillo takes a political back seat, a new biog would have been a hot proposition. Odd that Gove doesn't see that.

webTitle: PR Week round-up

fields.headline: PR Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 12
fields.trailText: January 12: The merger of GlaxoWellcome and SmithKline Beecham is expected to result in job losses.
fields.body:
The merger of pharmeceutical giants GlaxoWellcome and SmithKline Beecham is expected to result in a raft of jobs losses within the newly combined PR unit.

National Lottery firm Camelot is to shake-up its PR and public affairs function having secured a second seven-year term as the licence-holder.

BSMG Worldwide has replaced ousted UK chief executive Nan Williams with industry veteran David Brain.

Global communications giant Burson-Marsteller is in talks with young financial PR firm Tulcan about possible joint ventures.

Leading betting firm The Tote is losing its public relations chief of four years, Rob Hartnett, to a start-up Irish betting company.

Anheuser-Busch has replaced long-term agency GCI Group with Cake on a sponsorship brief for Budweiser.

The Labour Party is to hand voters in key seats free video cassettes as part of the forthcoming election campaign.

Online 'question and answer' search engine Ask Jeeves has handed its UK PR brief to Consolidated Communications following the decision to appoint a sole agency.

webTitle: The Bill, Pet Rescue, and The Da(ill)y Today

fields.headline: The Bill, Pet Rescue, and The Da(ill)y Today
fields.trailText: SMALL CLUB, BIG NOISE
fields.body:
SMALL CLUB, BIG NOISE

It's got all the ingredients: a chairman who likes to wear sunglasses in TV studios; a litigious ex-manager; the nation's foremost moralising PR exec; the threat of enforced relegation; and Peter Taylor in a bath. Yes, it's Gillingham FC, the club that puts the "odd" into modest First Division outfit.

This morning, the Daily Express reported that an unnamed private investigator has prepared a "secret dossier" containing allegations of Swindon-style financial irregularities at the Kent club during last season's successful promotion campaign (we checked the article for hilarious hidden messages, by the way, but couldn't find any). The report claimed the dossier had been prepared on behalf of ex-boss Tony Pulis, who is currently suing the Gills for unfair dismissal. And to ensure that justice was done, the investigator took the dossier straight to... Max Clifford.

Clifford was calm today despite holding a potential time-bomb etc. that, if proven correct, could see the Gills consigned to the Second Division. "[The investigator] told me: 'You have exposed Jeffrey Archer, Jonathan Aitken and people like that - what about corruption in football?'" said the man who represented Mandy Allwood. "I said if there is corruption in football, I'm more than happy to show it up." With this paragon of justice on board, all criminals better look out.

Fortunately for Gillingham chairman Paul Scally, he's no criminal. (Although his wife, who was sent to jail for breaching bail conditions on a cocaine possession charge is. Scally said at the time: "Prison is probably the best place for her now. It's the only place she's safe from drug dealers." Right.) Possibly wearing shades, Scally today strongly refuted the allegations and insisted he "will defend any allegations against the football club in the High Court in the appropriate manner and at the relevant time". Only the High Court, mind. The Fiver suspects there might be more in this story yet.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CLICK YOURSELF UP

Things are already looking rosy for top internet startup www.let'ssellhim.com, a division of Bradford City new-media holdings. OK, so they may not yet have pushed through the deal with Udinese for Benito Carbone, and the only person to visit the Stanley Collymore page works for Stafford Rangers, but you can't faff around on a ridiculous child's metal scooter before you can walk. And in any case, it looks as though Bradford have found an £800,000 buyer for Dan Petrescu in the super-surfin' shape of Glenn Hoddle.

"Petrescu is talking to Southampton at the moment so we will wait and see what develops," announced no-nonsense Bradford visionary Jim Jefferies, looking tougher than a line of hard code. "It is a situation which suits both clubs. He's got three-and-a-half years left on his contract so we're making a saving on that side and obviously that will help the club. But it's not about Dan going for financial reasons. He is a good player."

That being the case, you may wonder why Bradford are prepared to sell the 32-year-old Romanian. But like any new-media guru, Jefferies can make a supremely idiotic idea which is certain to go disastrously wrong sound great in the short term. "We are bottom of the league after 21 games and [Petrescu, Carbone and Collymore] have been playing regularly, but that has not worked. I feel we've a better chance of beating relegation without them and that's no disrespect to them or their talent." Uh-huh.

+++ STOP CONTENT-MANAGEMENT SYSTEM+++ Bantams crowd favourite Dean Windass is "confused" and "disappointed" after reports that he's on his way to Middlesbrough or Leicester. Take our word for it, you want to get in on the ground floor with this Bradford thing before it all goes stellar!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

APOLOGY (AGAIN)

We pressed the wrong button again yesterday. And while it was undoubtedly Jon "Fowl-Up" Fowler's fault, he wasn't actually in the office at the time, and isn't here today either. So we will have to say sorry on his behalf for bombarding some of you with a message from New Zealand-based Formway Furniture about how one of their staff wanted off the Fiver mailing list.

We apologise for any inconvenience caused. But then again, if you live in Auckland, you now know where to get a nice new chest of drawers - swings and roundabouts, innit?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Though he wants to play attacking, attractive football, his priority will be to get the defence right. He wants them to concentrate on defending like the Italians do. He wants them to be more pragmatic, pay closer attention to detail and, above all, to take care" - Does that mean no more of the Neville brothers? Roberto Mancini makes a few predictions for Svennis's England.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FAMILY AFFAIRS

When East End Arry is on the rampage, no-one is safe. Not even his second-favourite son Paolo Di Canio, who after missing the New Year's Day mauling against Manchester United with the flu, has faced insinuations that he'd prefer the Uncle Bert (shirt) of Lazio to the claret and blue of West Ham. And Arry's even stuck it up his captain, Steve Lomas, who a day after claiming he was "settled here and have never asked for a transfer", was stunned to find they were trying to 'appeny dip (ship) him up North just to make a few bob (bob).

But say what you like about Harry's style - it gets results. Because today, as one of Arry's henchmen hovered menacingly in the background, Di Canio and Lomas both pledged their loyalty to the club. A sweating Di Canio was first, telling West Ham's official website: "I have no intention of leaving West Ham and I want the supporters to know that. I have two-and-a-half years remaining on my contract and I intend to stay here ... I love this club." Of course he does, and he loves Arry too, we wager.

Steve Lomas quickly followed suit. "I must admit it has been unsettling but the club made the decision to accept the fee and things do go through your mind," he stuttered. But a hard prod of something metallic in the back from one of Arry's men soon got him singing the right tune: "I want to forget all about this now and get on with the job of helping West Ham into Europe." And so the good ship West Ham sails on, and East End Arry's on the prowl.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Norway midfielder John Arne Riise is wanted by four English clubs, according to his agent Einar Baardsen. "We are talking to Leeds, but there are now three more clubs very interested in Riise," Baardsen said. "We cannot say who the teams are as they have told us to keep very quiet, but because of their interest we will be talking to Monaco next week."

Monaco will turn to Aston Villa defender Gareth Southgate if their £3m bid for Chelsea's Frank LeBoeuf is turned down, according to reports.

Lazio are interested in Rangers defender Lorenzo Amoruso. "Lazio want him and the departure of Sven-Goran Eriksson has changed nothing," said West Ham manager Harry Redknapp.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Carlisle chairman Michael Knighton has claimed that a local man is interested in buying his remaining stake in the club: . The news comes a day after Scottish "businessman" Stephen Brown - who drives a battered old Vauxhall, lives in sheltered housing and used to work as a barman in a curry house - failed to stump up the £250,000 needed to buy Knighton's shares in the club's parent company CUFC Holdings Ltd.

Nottingham Forest have agreed a fee of around £3m for Ipswich striker David Johnson. Forest manager David Platt will meet the player tonight and hopes that 24-year-old Johnson will agree personal terms and pass a medical within the next 24 hours.

Tayside Police have confirmed that Motherwell midfielder Steven Hammell has been charged with a breach of the peace over an alleged incident at St Johnstone. Hammell was involved in a skirmish with Saints wing-back Momo Sylla during the Fir Park's side 3-2 win in Perth two days before Christmas.

Everton striker Duncan Ferguson could miss Saturday's Premiership match with Tottenham after breaking a bone in his hand during the break-in at his home last weekend.

Manchester City's Tony Grant is talking over a £400,000 move to Barnsley, while team-mate Ian Bishop is set to join Sheffield Wednesday on a free transfer.

Huddersfield are hoping to agree a deal with Birmingham City for striker Peter Ndlovu, who recently scored four goals in seven games while on loan at the McAlpine Stadium.

Spanish referees will be the first in Europe to wear advertising on their shirts, the Spanish Football Federation have announced. Referees in the First and Second Divisions will carry the name of broadcasting platform Quiero on the front of their shirts during league and cup matches.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.10am) "I used to work for a mail-order wine company," writes Alastair O'Neill.

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12midnight) "Lawrie McMenemy called to moan and whinge about how his wine hadn't been delivered to Alan Green."

Dutch Football (12.30am) "He said it was a gift and it wasn't good enough and did I not know who he was."

Argentine Football (2.10am) "A few days later, I answer another call."

Brazilian International Football (3.55am) "The voice says 'Hello, I'm David Vine', just like he's presenting the opening day of the World Snooker Championship."

Footy Shorts (5.30am) "I take his order, quoting the delivery period (seven to 14 days standard delivery, although most orders arrive within a week)."

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.30am) "His response is more than a little curt, claiming to have preferential treatment, in the same do-you-know-who-I-am way as McMenemy."

Spanish Football (8pm, 1am) "After asking management sorts, I find out he's right! He has free 24-hour delivery, owing to status as a minor celebrity."

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3.30am) "Curiously, the next day Dinah Sheridan called to have a case delivered to her daughter Jenny Hanley, ex of TV's Magpie and sister of bulbous ex-chairman of the Conservative Party, Jeremy Hanley."

Australian Soccer League (11pm) "No plonk for fatty, I remembered noting."

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 12midnight SS1, 3am SS1) "Dinah also had the same preferential treatment."

Sky Sports 3: Football League Gold (10pm) "Which makes it all a little more tragic for poor old Lawrie, who clearly can't even scrape into a list of strictly c-list celebrities, which I later found to also include Dave Prowse."

British Eurosport: Live Football (7.30pm) If you've brushed past a celeb in the street, we want to know about it. Email the.boss@theguardian.com, and don't worry if it's dull, we're simple folk and easily pleased.

webTitle: Racist firms keep black unemployment high

fields.headline: Racist firms keep black unemployment high
fields.standfirst:
Ethnic minorities are not sharing in the new prosperity, despite growing labour shortages, as legislation fails to prevent employer discrimination

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Ethnic minorities are not sharing in the new prosperity, despite growing labour shortages, as legislation fails to prevent employer discrimination
fields.body:
Black men are up to five times as likely to be unemployed as white men, according to government figures released today which suggest that ethnic minorities face widespread discrimination looking for jobs.

Eight years of steady economic growth has reduced the number of people out of work to just over 1m - a 20-year low. But while fewer than 6% of white men are unemployed, the figure for some groups of black men is as high as 27%, according to the office for national statistics.

Among women, the worst affected are those of Pakistani and Bangladeshi origin, nearly five times as likely as white women to be unemployed.

Labour market experts say these discrepancies show that equal opportunities legislation has failed to combat racism by employers.

Michael Oyeniyi lives in east London, a stone's throw from the City where the long economic boom has left firms short of skilled labour. But the 24-year-old personal computer technician has spent more than a year looking for work.

"Firms don't give me a chance to prove that I can do the job," he said. "At least 20% of it is being black. I know I can do the work."

Mr Oyeniyi left his job as a Burger King manager and started looking for a job at the end of 1999 - when the government was proclaiming the healthy state of the labour market. With a computer qualification from Tower Hamlets College, completed part-time while at Burger King, he was confident he would find work.

During 12 months of determined hunting he has travelled as far as Gatwick for interviews but he has had no job offers, despite taking a further course which qualifies him as a Microsoft technician. He fixes computers for friends and neighbours, but what he really wants is to work in industry.

The frustration of failing to get jobs for which he has all the requirements is showing. He wants companies to give him a chance. "If I get to an interview, test me. I can do the work. If I don't pass that's OK."

The problem which men such as Mr Oyeniyi face is often not lack of skills. Black men are likely to have higher qualifications than white men, according to government data.

David Blackaby, an expert on the labour market at the University of Swansea, says legislation designed to combat racial discrimination has failed. In the 30 years since the Race Relations Act was passed the position of black people in the labour market appears to have got worse.

"We assume in Britain that we don't discriminate and that there is a level playing field," he said. "But when you look at the numbers, it's quite frightening."

Black people suffered disproportionately in the recession of the early 1990s. The unemployment rate for ethnic minority men soared to 25%, nearly two and half times the rate for white men, and the gap between the two has remained steady since then, despite the recovery in the economy.

The recession hit black people harder, according to Dr Blackaby, because it gave firms the chance to discriminate. "When there are lots of people out of work, it's easier for them to pick white workers over black or men over women."

But Dr Blackaby is puzzled by why the gap between black and white workers has not closed as the labour market has improved. He thinks the government and firms are complacent about equal opportunities.

Firms are paying lip service to equal opportunities and diversity issues, according to a report published today by the Industrial Society. Employers say tackling racism and sexism is a priority yet fewer than half of the firms the society surveyed had a strategy for it.

"Our findings reveal that the rhetoric has yet to be translated into reality," said Angela Ishmael, the report's author. "Good intentions are simply not matched by sustained commitment in practice."

The Trades Union Congress wants to see the provisions of the Race Relations Act toughened to make it harder for firms to favour white workers. "These figures show that racism still blights the working lives of thousands of black and Asian people," said John Monks, the TUC's secretary general.

But not everyone agrees that the problem is racism. Iftikhar Ahmed came to Britain from Pakistan eight years ago and is looking for a job as a marketing manager. "This country has less discrimination than many others," he said. "Usually it's too easy to blame others rather than looking at ourselves."

Despite a masters degree in international business, Mr Ahmed's job hunt has been unsuccessful. But he remains convinced that with more IT skills, he will find work. "If I don't update my qualifications, I shouldn't blame others or discrimination," he said.

 The unemployment rate for white men was 6.9% of the workforce in spring 2000, while the rate for all ethnic minorities was 13%.

 Black men from countries other than Africa or the Caribbean have the highest unemployment rate at 26.6%. Bangladeshi men are next at 20.4%.

 Indian men have the lowest unemployment rate of any ethnic minority, at 7.2%.

 The unemployment rate for white women was 4.7%, while the rate for all ethnic minority women was 12.3%.

 Bangladeshi and Pakistani women have the highest rates of unemployment among ethnic minority women at 23.9%.

webTitle: Met ready to settle £1m claim by activist

fields.headline: Met ready to settle £1m claim by activist
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan Police is preparing to settle a £1m damages claim brought by a black activist whose allegations of "systematic harassment" have been supported by a secret report compiled by London's top Asian officer, the Guardian can reveal.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan Police is preparing to settle a £1m damages claim brought by a black activist whose allegations of "systematic harassment" have been supported by a secret report compiled by London's top Asian officer, the Guardian can reveal.

Ten senior officers, including the Met's deputy commissioner Ian Blair, have concluded that the dossier, seen by the Guardian, leaves the force "incredibly vulnerable" to litigation because it highlights "negative stereotyping" of Delroy Lindo and his wife Sonia by officers in Hornsey, north London.

A lack of professionalism also threatened to undermine the confidence of the ethnic minority community, the report warned.

Mr Lindo said last night: "I am pleased it seems to have vindicated what we have been saying about police harassment. My family has suffered horrendously. Me, my wife and my children. It has ruined our lives."

The findings, though, have provoked a poisonous internal battle at Scotland Yard.

Some high-ranking officers - and the Met's solicitor David Hamilton - are "incensed" with the report. They believe its author, the Met's deputy assistant commissioner Tarique Ghaffur, was "naive" and, in parts, ill-informed.

Their main concern is that Mr Ghaffur did not interview any of the 47 officers who came into contact with Mr Lindo to test his allegations against their own.

The report's conclusions, they believe, were drawn without proper analysis, leaving the Met with what one source called "a very large poisoned chalice".

"Perhaps he did not fully realise the legal implications or the political fallout," the source said.

Mr Ghaffur is standing foursquare behind his report and its conclusions.

He was instructed to conduct an inquiry in July last year following numerous complaints by the Lindos about the way they were being treated.

Mr Lindo, 41, has been stopped 37 times since 1992. He has been charged 17 times and cleared 17 times of offences including assaults on police officers.

He has described being arrested for sucking his teeth in the presence of a police officer, driving with a dirty number plate and carrying a copy of the Observer newspaper.

Mr Lindo has launched five civil suits against the Met, which are all outstanding.

With a team of 16 officers, Mr Ghaffur was asked to investigate the claims and whether Mr Lindo's support for Winston Silcott, who was wrongly convicted of murdering PC Keith Blakelock during the Broadwater Farm riots, was a significant factor.

In the summary of the 50-page report, Mr Ghaffur said there was "no evidence of an organised conspiracy" to harass Mr Lindo, and ruled out racial discrimination as an issue.

But it added: "There was evidence that harassment has taken place because of negative stereotyping of the Lindo family. This has been caused by police officers in Hornsey focusing on the fact that Mr Lindo has spent convictions."

The report goes on to describe a "collective organisational failure of policing of incidents" and warns that "the failures have put the MPS [Metropolitan Police Service] in serious risk of undermining the confidence of the ethnic minority community".

Mr Ghaffur is also critical of the Lindos.

The report said they were "partly instrumental in creating a spiral of deteriorating relationships.

"At times [they] exhibited extremes of behaviour that led to over-reaction of the police and punitive use of the criminal justice system."

One Scotland Yard source said: "There's fault on both sides of this. We are paid to be professional. They [officers] have got to learn to act professionally.

"Delroy Lindo got in their face a bit. They should have acted coolly, calmly and professionally and they did not."

Mr Lindo, who has still not seen the report, said it was "ludicrous" to blame him for inciting trouble, and felt sure his friendship with Mr Silcott was the cause of so much antipathy from the police.

Mr Lindo wants the report to be published in full but the Met has refused. A shortened version, stripped of details of officers, is being put together.

The Met is now likely to offer the Lindos some form of mediation linked to an out of court financial settlement. Mr Lindo has claimed £1 million damages for harassment and malicious prosecution.

webTitle: Net activism has the power to change the world

fields.headline: Net activism has the power to change the world
fields.standfirst: A new generation of campaigners is just a few clicks away, writes Mark Flannagan, director of Advocacy Online
fields.trailText: A new generation of campaigners is just a few clicks away, writesMark Flannagan, director of Advocacy Online.
fields.body:
What do a former wrestler, Christian Aid and McDonald's have in common?

Answer: They are all - in their own way - winners, users or losers of net activism.

In the case of former pro wrestler Jesse Ventura, he used the net to collect, organise and inform volunteers in support of his bid to be Governor of Minnesota. He won and his site still exists - www.jesseventura.com - containing news and views from Governor Ventura.

Christian Aid urges visitors to its site to send virtual postcards to Waitrose and is seeking to build support online for this and future campaigns.

And activists working on the internet to challenge McDonald's business ethics continue to be a thorn in its corporate side.

However, anyone who takes a look at the websites of a whole range of campaigning organisations can see there is no consensus about what constitutes "net activism". Getting involved with organisations via their websites means different things on each site. Some organisations just want you to donate funds; others want you to download information about how to lobby your MP while others seek limited, single participation through one specific action - such as virtual postcards.

In the wider world - away from websites run by organisations - it is impossible to gain a clear view about who is doing what, which individuals are banding together to become online campaigning communities and what difference anyone is making using the power of the internet.

In the US, where the belief is that everyone is ahead on new technology, the debate about the impact of net activism is in progress. In his book VOTE.com, former Clinton aide Dick Morris presents a view of a world where the internet returns power to the people. He argues that as the internet allows and indeed requires politicians to communicate more directly with voters, the power will pass to individuals who are prepared to get involved via the internet, if only by voting about issues online.

Morris notes that the political parties in the US are catching on. He cites Louisiana, where Republicans contracted with an internet company to allow online voting in the presidential nominations - and not a "dimpled chad" in sight.

Here in the UK, some commentators say that initial success of last year's fuel protests was down to the use by activists of new technologies - including email - to join together quickly in the right place at the right time. And the media have repeatedly stated that the emergence in Seattle - and other cities - of groups of dedicated activists prepared to cause massive disruption was down to use of the internet to communicate without the state intervening.

For some, there is already a real threat from net activism - one they are seeking to deal with. A number of PR companies have established "net intelligence" units that monitor damage being done to companies by net activists and then take steps to deal with that on behalf of clients.

Thus although we cannot say net activism is already changing the world, we can sum up net activism in one word - potential.

The internet has potential to turn visitors to websites into online campaigners. Particularly the young, who use the net more but get involved less, have the potential to become activists within three clicks on their PCs. Instead of donating money they can be encouraged to get involved. As one observer of the US voluntary sector has said: "While the direct mail universe is aged, online activists are young."

So, can we really use the internet to activate supporters and change the world?

The answer is yes. Many organisations just need to pursue to a logical conclusion the small steps they have already taken. By developing their websites in a positive, activist friendly way, they can tap into the potential of net activism. They can build in all the campaign functions they would ordinarily use in their offline activities. And, importantly, they can build databases of committed online supporters who can be contacted instantly on any issue.

With almost one third (32%) of UK households connected to the internet and 45% of British adults - equivalent to more than 20m people - having accessed the internet at some time, it is time for the potential of net activism to be unlocked. Who knows where it may lead? Maybe one day, with the power of net activism, we will see the inauguration of President Ventura?

webTitle: Camelot hires top marketeer

fields.headline: Camelot hires top marketeer
fields.trailText: 5pm: Camelot has appointed its first board-level PR guru since David Rigg resigned three years ago, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Camelot has appointed its first board-level PR guru since communications director David Rigg resigned three years ago in the wake of the "fat cats" pay scandal.

Sue Slipman takes on the new role of external affairs director, responsible for government affairs, regulation and the media.

The company is still basking in the glory of its National Lottery victory, but she has been charged with softening Camelot's image as it gears up for another seven years running the lottery.

Ms Slipman, who will report to chief executive Dianne Thompson, is described by Camelot as a "stakeholder specialist".

She has been director of social responsibility at Camelot since 1998. She is also vice-president for the charity One Parent Families and sits on the Better Regulation Taskforce.

Ms Slipman's appointment coincides with the departure of government affairs chief Richard Brown and director of public affairs Louise White.

Ms White is taking maternity leave while considering a freelance career, while Mr Brown has no immediate employment plans.

Andrew Jones, director of corporate communications, said Camelot needed different skills sets now it had won the licence and was increasingly dealing with a mature lottery.

David Rigg, the last board-level communications specialist at Camelot, resigned in 1998.

He left shortly after the media uproar over his 40% hike in pay and perks to £333,000 a year.

webTitle: Campaign round-up

fields.headline: Campaign
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 12.
fields.trailText: January 12: Lowe Lintas has won Agency of the Year 2000 title.
fields.body:
Lowe Lintas has won Agency of the Year 2000 title.

Diesel, the fashion label, is putting its pan-European advertising business out to pitch, and is talking to international agenies about its multimillion-pound account.

McKinsey & Co, the global management consultancy, has acquired Envision, the branding consultancy based in Chicago.

The Dutch agency 180 has scooped the multimillion-pound pan-European business for Dunlop Tyres in a move which sees Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO ousted from the account.

The Publicis group is pulling down the curtain on its troubled FCA! Subsidiary in the UK and folding it into its London agency.

The Comfort Zones, a new creative resource that aims to link foreign ad agencies with UK production talent, is launching this month.

Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters is setting up two new divisions as part of a restructure, which also sees the agency appointing two joint managing directors.

Leagas Delaney has hired the industry veteran Alfredo Marcantonio as the creative director for its Rome office.

The award-winning commercials director Steve Reeves is leaving Stark Films to set up his own production company with Tim Marshall, Chris Palmer's former producer.

webTitle: First GM primate to aid human disease research

fields.headline: First GM primate to aid human disease research
fields.standfirst: Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Researchers at America's Oregon Health Sciences University have created the world's first genetically modified primate.
fields.body:
Researchers at America's Oregon Health Sciences University have created the world's first genetically modified primate.

The male baby rhesus monkey, whose name ANDi stands for 'inserted DNA' spelled backward, was born in October last year.

ANDi carries a tiny extra bit of DNA in a gene introduced as a marker that can be seen under a microscope because it actually glows green. ANDi's creation is described in the current issue of the journal Science.

Researchers hope they now can introduce other genes in rhesus monkeys that could trigger a host of human diseases such as Alzheimer's, diabetes, breast cancer or HIV in order to find a way to block them at the genetic level.

The technique for inserting the gene has been used for more than a quarter century in mice, but comparing a mouse to a human being has limits, said Dr Gerald Schatten. He is leading the research at the university's Oregon Regional Primate Center.

Because monkeys are close cousins to humans in terms of DNA, they may give scientists a better picture of how human disease develops.

"We're at an extraordinary moment in the history of humans," Dr Schatten said.

A year ago, Dr Schatten reported the first monkey successfully cloned by embryo splitting. That monkey is named Tetra. ANDi and his surrogate mother, as well as Tetra, remain healthy, according to Dr Schatten.

ANDi received an extra gene while he was still an unfertilized egg. Dr Schatten, lead author Anthony W.S. Chan and other researchers modified and then fertilized more than 200 rhesus monkey eggs.

Forty embryos were produced, and resulted in five pregnancies and three live births. Of the three baby monkeys, only ANDi proved to have the modified genes.

fields.trailText: Yahoo!, the web portal, was expected to give an update on the state of the online advertising market last night in keenly anticipated fourth quarter results.
fields.body:
Yahoo!, the web portal, was expected to give an update on the state of the online advertising market last night in keenly anticipated fourth quarter results.

Investors were nervous ahead of the results amid signs of a sharp slowdown in the US economy in general and advertising revenue in particular. Almost all of Yahoo!'s top line sales come from advertising.

Wall Street analysts have raised concerns that more than 40% of group revenue is derived from the struggling dot.com sector. Several have downgraded the company in recent weeks amid expectations of a weakening outlook.

Since reaching a high of more than $225 last spring, shares in Yahoo! have lost more than 90% of their value. They were up slightly at midday yesterday at about $30.

According to a First Call survey, analysts' consensus was that Yahoo! would report fourth-quarter earnings of 13 cents per share and revenue of about $315m.

For the full year, revenues are expected to reach $1.1bn, up from $588m in 1999. Analysts also expect Yahoo!, one of the few profitable internet companies, to double annual earnings.

In a research note published earlier this week, Henry Blodget, the once bullish internet analyst at Merrill Lynch, said he expected overall online advertising spending to be flat at about $8bn this year. This marks a sharp deterioration from his previously held view of a 30% growth rate.

webTitle: Whitehall chaos over depleted uranium paper

fields.headline: Whitehall chaos over depleted uranium paper
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText:
Armed forces minister John Spellar admits he did not know how widely a paper warning of the risks of cancer had been distributed within the Army.
Special report: depleted uranium
fields.body:
Whitehall confusion over depleted uranium weapons deepened today as armed forces minister John Spellar admitted he did not know how widely a paper warning of the risks of cancer had been distributed within the Army.

The 1997 paper, an internal medical report that warned of a heightened risk of lung, lymph and brain cancer from the weapons, had earlier been dismissed by the Ministry of Defence as the "discredited" work of a junior officer.

But it later emerged that a covering letter from the office of the quartermaster general had recommended the paper should be circulated to military and civilian personnel likely to come into contact with depleted uranium (DU) ammunition.

"It will be of particular interest to the RAC (royal armoured corps), REME (royal electrical and mechanical engineers) and RLC (royal logistics corps) crew men and associated civilian workers involved in reclamation and decontamination work," the letter said. In an interview with BBC, Mr Spellar was forced to concede that he had "no idea" whether the report and covering letter, dated April 17 1997, had in fact been sent out.

But he insisted the Army medical report had been flawed and that there was no scientific evidence linking DU with cancer or the other symptoms reported by Gulf war and Balkans veterans. "The paper on the hazards of depleted uranium munitions has a number of errors in it. Much of it is actually correct. Certain elements are scientifically incorrect or misleading," he said.

"All the data from the various countries shows no evidence linking depleted to cancers or the more general ill health being experienced by some Gulf veterans."

The latest disclosures will come as a further embarrassment to the government, which has been desperate to stem the flow of damaging claims and allegations that Downing Street had hoped to kill off the story by forcing a reluctant MoD to offer medical tests to veterans.

It followed a wave of concern sweeping across European nations with troops in the region after it emerged that eight Italian soldiers who had served in Bosnia had since contracted leukaemia. Despite claims that their illnesses may have been the result of inhaling DU dust from exploded rounds fired by American A10 "tankbuster" aircraft, both Britain and the US have resisted Italian and German calls for a moratorium on the use of DU weapons.

At today's Cabinet meeting, the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, told ministers that although the government was now offering medical tests to veterans it did not accept that DU weapons posed a "significant health risk" to British troops.

"He simply made the point that as the government we have a clear duty of care to our personnel and we take that duty very seriously. That's why we have offered the screening programme," the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said.

The Tories and Liberal Democrats have demanded that Mr Hoon makes a full statement to the House of Commons explaining exactly what ministers had been told about the risks associated with DU.

webTitle: Consumer: Cybershopping for dietary supplements

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Dietary supplements
fields.trailText: Dietary supplements
fields.body:
They say it's never too late for new year resolutions, but if the will is weak, dietary supplements may give you that added impetus to succeed.

1. I will quit smoking: Thinknatural can supply Nicobrevin, which, with its blend of quinine and valerate, might just do the trick on the fags. If quitting depresses you, try the company's St John's wort, and if it depresses the dog, get a Bach remedy from the pet section.

2. I will become more attractive to the opposite sex: Hartleystraditional is an olde worlde apothecary specialising in own-brand tinctures. Its "world famous" herbal hair tonic promises an offensive on that receding brow. If 32B is failing to impress and the thought of a boob job leaves you cold, hit Virtuvites, which ships Growbust, the herbal alternative to breast enlargement. The firm also does human growth hormones. But don't start letting down the hem of your jeans in preparation for supermodel status - it's merely an anti-ageing preparation. Try a diet instead, from Weightloss-supplements. Formula Power by Nutrihealth will "burn fat, enhance body shape and even reduce stress".

3. I will give up booze: as well as touting milk thistle, Pharmacy2you is an excellent all round health dispensary. Email its pharmacists with any queries.

4. Out with the old, in with the new: cod liver oil is so 2000 - try shark liver oil from Nulife.

webTitle: Consumer: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... a fridge
fields.trailText: ... a fridge
fields.body:
So, the bachelor pad is a shoe-box with its own postcode? The bedsit has got a kitchen so en-suite you can reach the kettle from the futon? Fret not. LG Electronics has introduced the ultimate space saver - the internet fridge.

The two key components for male domesticity, the fridge and the TV, have finally fused, forming the electronic equivalent of football and beer. But there's more. The LCD touch-screen internet access takes food porn to a whole new dimension, while email ensures step-by-step instructions from mum on how to boil that egg. In the event that you pull more than a chicken korma, the built in MP3 player takes care of those all-important seduction tracks.

Should any food find its way over the threshold, a scanner will read the barcodes so the fridge's contents can be viewed on the screen alongside the (ha ha) nutritional content. (NB Design fault - half-eaten curries rarely come with barcodes.) And should anyone be mug enough to live with you, you can message them using the built-in video facility, which includes a camera and microphone.

Failing that, you can always message yourself or the cat - if it hasn't left home. At £6500, this glorified icebox may not come cheap, but it's less expensive than an extension, a lot less hassle than moving somewhere larger and, unlike a girlfriend, it won't answer back.

 LG Electronics, stockists 01753 500400.

webTitle: Consumer: Secure drop-off points for deliveries

fields.headline: Boxing clever
fields.standfirst:
Internet shopping is booming, but there is still one thing holding it back - we are not always at home to take deliveries. Now companies are pioneering secure drop-off points outside our houses, and three firms are vying to make theirs the standard. Sean Dodson signed up for one
Net news
fields.trailText: Internet shopping is booming, but there is still one thing holding it back - we are not always at home to take deliveries. Now companies are pioneering secure drop-off points outside our houses, and three firms are vying to make theirs the standard. Sean Dodson signed up for one.
fields.body:
Burntwood Grange Road near London's Wandsworth Common may not appear a likely location for an experiment in 21st-century shopping. But the leafy cul-de-sac is the site of a pilot scheme that, if successful, could alter the landscape of every street in the country.

About a month ago, a number of smart aluminium boxes, roughly the size of picnic hampers, began to appear on the doorsteps of the road's 1950s townhouses. The boxes belong to Homeport, an internet start-up that thinks it has found the answer to the biggest problem in home shopping: how to deliver goods to our homes when we are out at work.

According to the Post Office, home shopping on the internet is about to explode. A recent internal survey predicted that more than six million of us would have shopped online by the new year. In the run up to Christmas, the Post Office allowed 1,000 of its high-street counters to be used as pick-up points for goods ordered over the net. And if the postie can't help you, no worries: companies as diverse as Express Dairies and Pizza Hut are vying for a slice of the home-delivery pie.

Still, the main thing restraining internet shopping is that most people want their goods at the same time - between seven and eight in the evening. But, for a part-time antiques dealer and full-time mother like Melissa Foks, being in at a set time is not always an option. So, although she had never shopped online before, she volunteered to be one of the first to try out the Homeport system.

Homeport sells a small metal panel (measuring 12cm by 15cm) that is bolted to the side of your house. This houses three "ports" to which the cables that secure Homeport's delivery boxes can be attached.

My Homeport was delivered last week. Four deep holes had to be drilled into the side of my flat, but the installation took only five minutes. I ordered aproximately £60 worth of shopping via the internet, and when I came home from work the following lunchtime, an aluminium box was waiting for me.

After about five minutes of fiddling with the controls, I managed to unhook the cable and carry my bounty upstairs. The company knew that I was a journalist writing about the Homeport, but the customers I have spoken to had few complaints. Like most of the best ideas, it's dead simple.

Foks says she is quite proud of the Homeport that is bolted to the side of her house in Burntwood Grange Road. She uses a swipe card to release the cable and take in her goods. She doesn't own the box, and it is automatically taken away the next day after she has unpacked all her shopping.

Foks was hesitant about using the Homeport delivery service at first - until one occasion when she was stuck in Exeter and used it to order the ingredients for a dinner party. "A box full of chicken breasts, sun-dried tomatoes and bottles of Rioja were waiting for me when I drove back," she says. The dinner party was saved and she was convinced that the Homeport was worth keeping.

Homeport has been under development for three years. Initially the company built prototypes that involved complicated sets of padlocks and keys. But earlier this year it was introduced to card technology and its plan began to fall into place. An initial pilot scheme with fewer than 100 boxes has been running in London since September.

"There is quite a lot of inertia initially," says Mark Lunn of Homeport. "It takes quite a lot of time and effort to get people to have one fitted, and once fitted, it then takes quite some time to get them to actually order, but once you have used one, people seem to use it every week." Only a third of people in the pilot scheme choose to order on the internet. The rest prefer phone and fax. About 10% have used the system for dry cleaning.

"We want to have an open system that can be used by many, many retailers and delivery companies," says Lunn. The company has already signed up with Jeeves of Belgravia, Food Ferry and Berry Brothers. Homeport started its first major trial with Sainsbury's on January 2. The scheme will be piloted in 50 postcode areas across London and the Thames Valley. An installation charge of £30 will be waived for the pilot scheme.

Apart from this fee, the use of the Homeport is free, save for the delivery costs that are usually added to online shopping bills. The retailers pay Homeport £1 per delivery to use its boxes, and the hope is that the retailers will save money because they will be able to spread out deliveries through the day - or night - and, crucially, spend less time at each house. "They can double park, plug in and be gone in three minutes," says Lunn. Traditional deliveries take about 10 minutes while the driver parks, rings the doorbell and politely delivers the goods.

Homeport's main advantages are that it is flexible and cheap to install. But it is only the first generation of home-delivery boxes. Already, other more permanent boxes are being touted as potential rivals. Fellow start-ups Dynamid and BearBox are developing permanent cool boxes for the outside of houses. Both companies have tested 100 units each at homes around London in the run-up to Christmas and hope to launch fully by the spring.

Of course, consumer confidence has to be built before any kind of secure box finds its way into every street in the UK. One obvious problem is security; another is getting the supermarkets to sign up. Sainsbury's has already announced a partnership with Homeport, but Tesco.com, the UK's largest online food retailer, says it is yet to be convinced that either home-delivery box system - removable or permanent - is reliable enough. Tesco claims that its customers (who spend around £90 per shop) like to be around when their groceries arrive and, what's more, have built relationships with its delivery people.

Whether we are really so fond of the man in the white van is debatable, but don't write off the out-of-town retail centre yet: the next big net retail scheme in the pipeline is rumoured to include drive-though pick-up points. As for Foks, she took herself and her two children to the supermarket last week "just for a change".

Dynamid
Bearbox

webTitle: MPs off-message on internet revolution

fields.headline: MPs off-message on internet revolution
fields.standfirst: Our elected representatives are hypocrites when it comes to getting wired, says  David Walker
fields.trailText: Our elected representatives are hypocrites when it comes to getting wired, says David Walker
fields.body:
If the general election takes place in spring, as confidently predicted, it will not be an online contest. Too few party politicians are web- connected and a sudden explosion of political sites during the next few months is unlikely.

The political parties all have official websites but their leading members do not. Only 16% of Westminster MPs have websites, an extraordinarily low figure given the government's (and the Tories') public enthusiasm for the medium. Though the Liberal Democrats, with four out of 10 of their MPs running their own sites, are a stronger presence, it is remarkable that their own IT spokesman has no online presence.

The line-up in the Commons for MPs' websites is Labour 16%, Tories 12% and Lib Dems 42%. The nationalists at Westminster are 15-20% online. A Plaid Cymru official's judgment that "for us the web has not superseded traditional forms of communication" seems to hold true for all the parties. Gender does not seem to be an issue: one in six women MPs have websites, the same proportion as their male colleagues.

Our elected representatives' internet backwardness is demonstrated at www.parliament.uk, a staid and starchy affair. The official House of Commons site lists MPs contactable by email (many are not) and the minority who have websites. The list is badly out of date, an indication of the lack of enthusiasm of individual MPs as well as Westminster's corporate lack of interest in web communications.

Getting web addresses can involve a complicated journey via party headquarters and regional sites. And when you get there, few MPs' sites make anything like proper use of the interactive properties of the web: to be greeted with a picture of MP, spouse and children and the recent utterances of party leaders Tony Blair or William Hague is not enough.

Blair tells schools to get online but he is internet-invisible. Neither prime minister nor chancellor have their own sites, though of course Number 10's official site is state of the art (www.number-10.gov.uk).

A not-for-profit company working at www.faxyourMP.com offers a way of sending comments to MPs for free, for the sake of lubricating democracy. It has to use fax because so few MPs can be emailed or have sites to which messages can be sent.

It is hard not to convict some MPs of hypocrisy The public accounts committee regularly roasts Whitehall departments for their failings on the IT front. Yet barely one in five members of the PAC have their own websites and its chairman, the Tory MP David Davis, is not even listed as having email.

MPs who do try stand out. Labour MP Sally Keeble ( ww.cwd.co.uk/sally.keeble ) runs a formidable site with useful links and full contact information. Other Labour enthusiasts include Austin Mitchell, who lets visitors see his prowess as an amateur photographer. Chris Smith, culture secretary is one of the few ministers with a personal site. Fiona Jones, the Labour MP for Newark was alert enough to put a Christmas tree and seasonal greetings on her site.

Among Tories Nigel Evans, the MP for Ribble, stands out for a website offering a free bottle of House of Commons whisky personally signed by William Hague as a reward for entering his online quiz at www.nigelmp.com. Who could refuse such an offer? Colin Breed, the Liberal Democrat MP for SE Cornwall, is online at www.forsiteuk.com/ColinBreed with all the gen on the campaign for a bypass at Dobwalls. But in the neighbouring county of Devon, Lib Dem Nick Harvey has no site. Party HQ says it is a matter for individuals.

The creation of new representative bodies outside Westminster has had an energising effect on online politics. The Scottish parliament offers its members training in running websites and live webcasts of proceedings. The Welsh assembly, Scottish parliamentand the Northern Ireland executive all offer generic contact services for their members, along with biographical details and - something missing at Westminster - mugshots. Facial hair may have been forbidden by Labour's HQ at Millbank but, at least on men, it seems to be sprouting on the UK's periphery.

But only a minority of members of the new assemblies and parliament have their own websites, among them Geraint Davies, the Plaid Cymru aassembly member for Rhondda. Staff at PC's headquarters describe it as an extra means of communication but not transforming.

Another is Roy Beggs, an Ulster Unionist member of the Northern Ireland Assembly who has an informative site, www.roy-beggs.fsnet.co.uk (He has gone online "to utilise modern methods to provide a responsive constituency service to all the people of East Antrim" .)

As a group, Tory members of the Scottish parliament have got their internet act together at www.tory.msp.org.uk. MSP David Mundell says "the website is a good way of getting information out. The web will become increasingly important but will not replace traditional methods. Here in Scotland the most important medium is the local newspaper." But the web is an excellent way of getting through to young people, he says.

"Modernisation" has figured in Labour's rhetoric in recent years but it is no guarantee that Labour members will seize their net opportunities. Ideology and use of the net are not easy to correlate. Some reactionaries have good sites; many liberal modernisers are still, it seems, internet virgins.
