webTitle: Your Christmas turkeys

fields.headline: Your Christmas turkeys
fields.standfirst:
We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here are some of your entries

If yours was worse than these, enter our competition to win a palmtop computer here
fields.trailText: We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here are some of your entries
fields.body:
Worst present came this Christmas, and was from my wife to add to the insult. I resolved that from Xmas eve I was going to give up smoking. My present - a lovely tobacco tin engraved with my initials. She said she had ordered it months ago and couldn't send it back as it was personalised!
John Marlow

My worst pressie was all the extra weight and cellulite I now have to shift throughout the year after well meaning people bought me tonnes of chocolate and biscuits!
Claire Gibbs

My husband is an expert in buying the strangest pressies! This year I received a Barbie Doll, complete with hundreds of tiny beads to put in her long blonde hair, little brushes, combs etc. She is currently wearing purple knee length boots and a wild multi-coloured dress!! This would have been a dream present when I was younger but not at age 31!!
Delly Johnson

My worst Christmas presents this year were; one of those cheap little helicopters that flies round in circles suspended from the ceiling. Seven boxes of chocolates (everyone in the family knows that I am allergic to milk and dairy products) and a £10 voucher to an online furniture shop. When I looked up the store on the net I found that the cheapest item available was £200. I think that I will pass up this offer!
Dave Brown

I'm sure that my mother has finally hit the menopause. I asked last year for a cheap watch for work (I'm 28). On Christmas Day I unwrapped the gift to find a round tin. Inside this was a watch, but no ordinary one. This was special, with just the press of a button the face moved up by aid of hydraulic pistons. You could not see the time as it was obscured by the pistons. My partner made me wear it and has ridiculed me ever since. One year went by and so at last I could dispose of it at the local charity shop.
James Baker

Last Xmas, we had a big family-do with my auntie, cousin and my auntie's grand-children coming over from France. Before Christmas, my mum had said to me on the phone: "I think your Auntie got you a very special present. It's something you've always wanted". ?? Excellent I thought...was I getting the laptop of my dreams? Naa...probably too expensive. A horse? That for sure was my life dream. Mum back on phone: "It's something you spotted at her house when you were a child (I'm 32 thank you!) and now she finally decided to give it to you!" Oh my God! This was starting to get pretty scarey...was it a horrible old-fashioned cushion, one of the few remains of a long-forgotten doll? I really hadn't a clue!!

When Christmas came, I was pretty excited but even more intrigued. At last I was going to know what I had been longing for in my childhood...There it was wrapped in bright red paper with the label "Happy Christmas. You have been wanting this for so long!" This was too much...I ripped the paper off and there it was in it's pencil-case like plastic box....an old huge cigar!!!! A CIGAR!!! I'm not even a smoker! And how the hell could I have been praying to get this when I was a kid ??? An old, not-even-famous-mark cigar that had apparently been bought in Switzerland by my now-deceased Uncle!! I tried to solve the mystery but to that day, only my Auntie ever heard me claiming I wanted The cigar...although she now reckons she might have got it wrong and got confused with my other Uncle...Still, this cigar made me and everyone else enjoy the most laughable Christmas morning. I have still got a picture of my puzzled face, and as for the cigar? Well it is well kept in a drawer and I am impatiently waiting for my niece to be 32 before giving it to her...in 10 years time!
Catherine Thieffry

The worst present received at Christmas is usually something you have never, ever wished to own or something you own several hundred times over. NOT IN MY CASE. Wanting to try and keep up-to-date with the gadgets of today, I wished for a digital camera. My wife, never showing any interest in anything related to a computer, actually found one which seemed so much cheaper than what I had tried to budget for.

Now this digital camera must have been designed before Kodak had perfected their Brownie - somebody had never thought it might be a good idea to allow for changing the focus. The result is a mass of colours, nicely blending into one another, which resemble the neck of the Christmas turkey. There is a bonus though - it is impossible to identify a picture of King Kong from one of the mother-in-law.
Alan Edgar

A BUMPER COLOURING BOOK. I'm a 39 year old professional and it was sad. It showed my aunt's ageing problems, she had been so bright. Sadder still was the pleasure I got from it when it was placed next to the phone. I began to take pride in my colouring as I hung on the telephone waiting to talk to humans rather than the robotic call managers.
Stewart

There is a saying we all know that goes a little something like this "It's the thought that counts". In most cases it's true and we hide our disappointment behind a painted smile. People harp on about those tacky socks and jumpers. But they happen to be useful on a cold winter nights. But there are people who buy Christmas presents with no thought at all, so that old saying goes straight out of the window. There is one present I was given by the modern day Mr Scrooge who happens to be my father, that still humours me and angers at the same time.

My father never lived with us and my mother had to raise five children on her own. One Christmas Day as a small boy. I was thrilled at the prospect of opening my stocking and finding the little black and white TV that my father had promised. After opening my mothers' presents, I asked my mother where my fathers' presents were. "On the coffee table!" she replied.

On the table sat a poorly wrapped object that was no bigger than a matchbox. I remember thinking "This is too small to be a television" and wondered what it was. On opening the present, inside was a porcelain thimble that had 'Welcome to Wales' and a little red dragon on it. I was heart broken and also confused as to 'What the hell is a nine year-old boy supposed to do with a thimble'. At first I thought it must be a joke, but months disappeared and so did the thimble. Hard to believe I know! But true.
David Cannon

The worst present I received this year was from my mother in law. It was an electric can opener. My wife and I asked why she had bought us one and she said because my wife told her to. This puzzled me, for only two months earlier I went out and bought an electric can opener for the house !!!.
Anonymous

The worst, unwanted present I have ever received was from my father - a fishing rod. Not only am I female (sorry, not trying to be sexist, just a bit squeamish over maggots). I am also allergic to fish, which my father knew. To top it all he kept it, even though he has never been fishing in his life.
Gill Hampton

My aunt is quite a character and selecting presents is not one of her talents. Knowing this, my wife had been hinting to her for weeks for prezzies we would like; Body Shop products for her, a book for me and a particular learning activity toy for the baby. However, it wasn't just me, but the whole family who were given Christmas Turkeys one year (well, mine wasn't just a turkey.....it was an Ostrich!). My wife received a rack for holding spice jars and a spaghetti container (we had both already). My daughter received a pack of 3 baby grows aged 3 to 6 months. She was 7 months old at the time. And now for the real Christmas Turkey.... What did she buy for me? A toupee and clip on pony tail. She said she had noticed my hair loss over the past few months and "you young men like pony tails". It was obviously a joke set she had bought (although she didn't realise this) and I wasn't actually balding, I had my hair cut into a grade 2 by choice!!!
Graham Kelsall

When I was 10 my gran knitted the most horrendous, unfashionable purple cardigan in acrylic wool with huge purple buttons she said I would grow. My gran has been dead for 3 years now, i am now 42 years old and a size 16 - it's still too big!
Kathy Keegans

Not a present as such but I've not been happy about everyone having great slap-up dinners at Christmas while I'm fasting for Ramadam.
Nadeem Faruque

Last year I received a Playstation console and played it all Christmas right up until the new year. Well because I liked the puzzle games last year so much, this year I was given a cobination padlock with no combination to amuse myself with.
Michael Williams

It was this Christmas I recieved what I call a christmas turkey of a present. I am a bit of a gadget freak and every year I usually recieve a gadget or something which is usually realy usefull,of my wife. So this year she gave me this gift wrapped box, I opened it with excitement and inside was a picnic hamper, just what I have always wanted, never mind there is lways next year.
P A Hunt

I was having a relaxing time over Christmas with family having just broken my leg skiing. I am a keen runner and had always wanted a particular pair of running shoes but never been able to afford them. So, what do my brothers do - yep, they club together to buy them for me for Christmas, so now all I can do is look at them until my leg heals.
Caroline Sayers

My auntie Madge, an eccentric but practical private mobile nurse, came back from holiday in Cornwall with my Christmas present on Christmas eve. Because she had to be on duty the next day she rushed round to exchange gifts that night. She apologised for being in a rush and for not wrapping mine up and handed me one of her infamous brown paper bags. On Christmas Day while she was on duty I telephoned her to thank her for the present, although amused at the unusual practical nature of her gift on this occasion. She burst in to laughter and informed me that Mr Tomlins whom she had visited earlier was really happy with the jars of preserves from Cornwall. I as not to dissapoint the old man Mr Tomlins had to be content, this year, with his specimen bottles.
Naomi Towers

A few Christmases ago for some reason known only to her self, my wife's auntie alice sent us a magazine picture of the children's TV character barney the dinosaur as a genuine xmas present. I still haven't figured out why.
Stevie Curry

Last Christmas my miserable grandmother gave me an ashtray (I don't smoke). Not such a bad present one might think, but it was the same one I gave to her three years earlier. (It wasn't even washed properly!)
Mark Hollingsworth

I got an electric toothbrush from my dad, but that's proved useful! It pales compared to the massager "device" I also got form him.It looks like a computer mouse, and buzzes when pressed.But it doesn't massage anywhere in any useful way, because it's got a really weak pulse! The best use I've found is for entertaining my baby sister in law, who loved it and wouldn't let it go.
Derrick Smith

I believe my Christmas gift from my dearest hubby must be the worst one ever! The jobs around the home had been building up and I kept complaining they never got done, and I remarked I would do the jobs myself if the power tools weren't so heavy and akward to use. His answer was he just didn't have the time and what little time he had he wanted to relax not turn into Handy-Andy! Christmas morning I awoke to a big box wrapped in lovely paper with a nice big bow, I was quite surprised and excited, that was until I got the paper off then my face was one of shock, yep my wonderful Christmas pressie was a Black and Decker Quattro. I wasn't sure if it was a joke at first and waited for him to give me my real gift but I realised it was no joke when he said "I saw this and thought of you, now you will be able to do the jobs yourself" Hmm..... I wonder what I'm getting for my birthday (the complete DIY book??)
Dawn Sanders

This year my grandparents gave me 10 thermostatic valves for the radiators in my house!!
Claire Dennis

The worst (and cheapest) present I ever had for Christmas was a bag of bright-green, scented rocks. The label read 'alternative to potpourri; suitable for smokers'. I don't smoke (and never have). The person who bought them must hate me a lot.
Tony Nixon

This is going back about 10 years - I was about 15 (I'm not sure if that's cheating). I had a favourite aunt who always bought me very interesting Christmas presents. One year she bought me a lemon and a packet of sticking plasters. Nicely wrapped and everything. I'm not sure why she did it - I think she had had a rough year. Anyway, it didn't affect my opinion of her... I can't even remember thinking it strange until a few years later.
Suzi Wells

Please don't publish my name on this one. This year I got sent a wedding photo in a frame from a couple I'm friends with. I was unable to get to the wedding, so she thought this might make up for it in some way. The only problem is that I'm still totally in love with the man in question, it breaks my heart to look at the picture and I'm going to have to put it up somewhere so as not to offend them.
Anonymous

My wife received a hair dryer as a Christmas present, from my mother, unfortunately. "Not too bad," you may think, but it is identical to one she already has at home. Without offending my mother by asking her for the receipt, we decided to take the hair dryer back to Boots. The customer services woman was very helpful and said that it was no problem, she just had to scan the barcode to find the original price and give us vouchers to the same value. Imagine how embarrassed I was when she informed us that the hair dryer had been a free gift given with other goods bought earlier in the year.
Sean Lilliott

My mum and I had been collecting Coca-Cola ring pulls for the Coke auction. I had bid for a holiday but missed out by a couple of ring pulls, so I bought something else. Mum sent me the present at the start of December and there it was under the tree. Lo and behold, on Christmas day when I opened it up there were 700 ring pulls. As I had lost out on the holiday, my mum thought she would surprise me so that I could buy something else. I daren't tell her that it all finished on December 10. This was my main present too...
Craig Dearden

I was a touch surprised to find the new Vodaphone sponsored Man Utd shirt I had been waiting for had mysteriously metamorphosed into a silver pen with inbuilt lighter on Christmas morning. Very strange indeed, given that I can't wear a pen, and have a hundred lighters lying around the house and don't really need a fake silver one that writes.
Luge Pravda

My worst Christmas present ever: A years membership to 'slimmers world' from my (ex!)Boyfriend.
Bernadette Hancock

Worst Christmas present actually arrived this year. A Playstation 2. "Turkey?" I hear you cry? My mother had pre-ordered it and collected it on release day in November (bless her), and then to keep it top secret she hid the PS2 in the loft. Where it suffered the variations in temperature that a lot of lofts are exposed to in Winter. So on Christmas Day when it was opened, firstly I was stunned that my mum would think of such a wonderful present for me, then stunned again whilst taking it out of its box and finding water trickling out of it. Now I can't get a replacement until March. Being a gaming addict, this is sheer torture.
Michael Scoates

This year I received a vase which had been dropped, broken and super glued back together. This in itself would have warranted an entry at maybe number 8 on my all-time top 10 list of corking presents. What catapulted it to the top of the tree, however, was the fact that several vital pieces of pottery had obviously gone astray and the search had been called off due to a lack of resources.
Andy

I seem to do very well or should I say badly out of naff Christmas presents. One was a very disgusting tortoise boot scraper and a man-made fibre jumper with very tasteful bunches of cherries on. Probably very popular in Eastern European states about 10 years ago.
Matthew Pearl

On the night before Christmas Eve I was driving home with some friends when a black cat darted out in front of the car and didn't quite make it. I stopped the car and got out to take a look but there was nothing I could do for it. I placed the cat on the side of the road and went on my way, all the while thinking about the poor feline and the people who would miss it. I woke up on Christmas morning, having nearly forgotten about the cat accident and went to open my presents with my family. After the usual presents of socks and toilet joke books I got to a shoebox size present. To my surprise (and horror) I found a pair of those oversize fun slippers in the style of two black cats. I was made to wear them but they soon became 'lost' on Boxing Day.
Philip Sharp

I was 20 years old and had just started seeing this lad, we had been going out for about three months. Christmas day came and much to my amazement, he had bought me an encyclopaedia and a pair of pink suede, fur lined slippers! For Christmas, he received the ELBOW!!
Kathryn Cox

On receiving a beautifully wrapped present from my husbands' grandmother I was well impressed. It was a lot larger and heavier than the usual gifts she had given me. So I duly put it under the festive tree and resolved that however much I wanted to peek I would resist the urge. Christmas morning (after the kids had opened their pressies) it was my turn! Usual gifts from Granny-in-law were bath salts (genuine victorian!) and a bale of tea towels..But that year she surpassed herself. I pick up the parcel only to discover that the wrapping and the carpet underneath were soaking wet and smelt dubious. I could not believe it when I open it to find a whole cooked chicken that was once frozen! I later found out that Gran had cooked the chicken for us and frozen it thinking that it would come in useful over Christmas. Still it's the thought that counts...not! This years present went straight in the freezer even though it turned out to be a cordless phone!
Karen

For some people my Christmas presents this year would represent a slice of heaven. I received a total of 600 cigarettes (duty free of course) from my friends and family. Nothing else. Unfortunately I had foolishly given up, two weeks previously. As I was amused/shocked that so many people had the same idea but I had no other choice but to give them all away.
Nalu

This year I was given a jazz CD, some coffee beans, and various other sundries from my Mom-in-law. Nice stuff, according to my wife, who had all these things on her list of desired gifts!
K Belluz

My worst Christmas pressie that I can remember is getting the sound of Bread LP and when I opened it to play it on Christmas Day the wrong album was inside. It was Donny and Marie Osmond.
Angela Williams

I am used to my mother giving me a pair of marigolds every year, but this year I really feel my whole family feel I have something lacking in my life. My sister sent me a second hand butter dish complete with receipt and my mother gave me a pack of dish cloths and a pack of floor cloths. She didn't even include the marigolds this year!
Vanessa

My Grandmother is 92 years old. She looks like Margaret Rutherford and for the last 10 years has obviously decided to play up to her eccentric image by bestowing on her grandchildren some very odd gifts. Last year, I got a Haze air freshener. Very useful, except that I'm allergic to perfume. The year before, she gave me a model horse with only three legs. When I complained, she replied, 'What's the problem? It still looks like a horse, doesn't it?' This year, she promised me something nice. I got a golfing umbrella. Definitely an improvement, you might think...except it's the one she grabbed off me in June when I wheel-chaired her in the rain to a relative's funeral...
Lesley Wilkinson

500 personalised address labels was probably the worst Christmas present I ever received.The phone number was wrong!
Sue Nicholson

Going back a few years, my Grandmother (bless her), knowing I was a fanatical Newcastle United fan bought me the latest football shirt. She packaged the shirt for posting and sent it to me. A couple of days later and my postman arrived in pouring rain with my present. Unfortunately, my loving Grandmother had wrapped the shirt in red paper and the rain had made the red dye run onto the sacred black and white top. The result, a football shirt in the colours of Sunderland. Thanks Gran!
Craig Anderson

It is a mistake for my mother to buy me presents: she lives exactly 423 miles away from me, and is 40 years my senior; we communicate, by phone, tersely, once a month. This year a parcel from her arrived which contained for a technophile like me the dubious gift of an Arthurian-themed address book, in which each letter of the alphabet was decorated with portraits and legends of the various knights of the round table, each page with William Morris bordering and panels. Preferring my WAP phone and laptop, this was not a good choice for me, so I forwarded it, re-wrapped, to a distant friend, who had once expressed modest enthusiasm for attending the Glastonbury Festival. At New Year my mother rang and asked if I liked my present and as I pondered various easy lies she interrupted me saying: "I hope you noticed that I wrote my address in there - perhaps I'll get some letters from you this year!"
Paul McClure

My worst Christmas present ever was a set of wind chimes - but I have had the last laugh, I put them up outside the house on Boxing Day and boy are they driving everyone mad!!
Paul Sharman

When I was about 13 years old I received the following from my mum for Christmas: school uniform, a satchel, and a geometry set. As you can guess I was disappointed.
Kathy Spendel

A couple of years ago I fell in love with those tiny Ixus cameras - so compact, so stylish, so covetable! As my old camera was on its last legs, the ideal solution was at hand: convey to my ever-loving partner that this was to be my next Christmas present. Accordingly I seized every possible opportunity to point the camera's desirability out to him; drawing attention to newspaper adverts and stopping meaningfully in front of camera-shop windows, where I would rhapsodize about the perfection of the design and the fact that I longed to possess one. My big error was this: I didn't actually say BUY ME AN IXUS CAMERA. Come Christmas morning, he produced (with a flourish) an enormous parcel that must have measured about 4 feet by 1 foot. On unwrapping it I discovered a keyboard - yes, a keyboard - which I could plug into my computer and play as a digital piano. Apparently I had once, in the dim and distant past (so distant I couldn't even remember it) said something about wishing I'd learnt the piano as a child.
Penny Gore

I bought my boyfriend an all-singing all-dancing top of the range DVD player and received a box of Milk Tray in return...
Demir Sayiner

Come into my house and a singing plastic fish hanging in my hallway will greet you. If you get past that, watch out for the singing, dancing lobster that is sitting in front of the door reciting Otis Redding. In the main room, you'll discover a talking donkey that moans about the weather, perched next to a farting teddy bear that apologises profusely following its outbursts. All this is because I mentioned to a couple of people that I sometimes get lonely as a student. A new DVD or palm top would have eased the pain. Still, there's the birthday to come.
Jason Wood

My worst ever gift was a petrol cap for my husband's car! It may have been my fault as I was always complaining that I couldn't undo the one on the car but insult was added to injury as this one came wrapped in the carrier bag from the motorists shop.
Anonymous

On Boxing Day we all go to my dear nana's and every year we never know what she's going to get us. She came into the living room as she always does dragging two white santa sacks, smiled and said "santa's been!" with the same silly grin. Me and my sister slowly turned our heads and laughed. We began opening out presents with my nana and granda looking on. After I had opened the usual bath bubbles and plastic beaded necklace, I came across a very small parcel in my treasures. "It feel's like....." I said slowly peeling the paper "IT'S A PLUG!" I cried out laughing. "AN ELECTRIC PLUG!" Everyone else looked on in disbelief before joining in with the laughter. Nana just tapped her nose and said "you won't be laughing in a minute". I continued opening, afraid of what I would come across next. After a purse and a box of chocolates I saw nana's face light up when I pulled an oblong shaped parcel out of the bag. I took off the paper to reveal a battery recharger. Sure enough the thing didn't have a plug on the end. Again the room erupted in hysterics. I don't know which was the worst gift, the plug or the recharger.But it has come in useful for recharging my son's Christmas toys, considering I had to buy nearly 30 batteries I suppose it wasn't that useless after all......poor Nana!
Madeline Gibson

My worst Christmas present ever has got to be a Shawaddywaddy single.
Ged Carroll

A 'hanging basket' kit - everything you would want to produce flowers in hanging baskets, including a guide book and special basket to get you started. For a 31 year old bloke with no interest in gardening, this was a prize turkey.
Adam Brooks

I tried to solve the mystery but to that day, only my Auntie ever heard me claiming I wanted The cigar...although she now reckons she might have got it wrong and got confused with my other Uncle...Still, this cigar made me and everyone else enjoy the most laughable Christmas morning. I have still got a picture of my puzzled face, and as for the cigar? Well it is well kept in a drawer and I am impatiently waiting for my niece to be 32 before giving it to her...in 10 years time! Catherine Thieffry The worst present received at Christmas is usually something you have never, ever wished to own or something you own several hundred times over. NOT IN MY CASE. Wanting to try and keep up-to-date with the gadgets of today, I wished for a digital camera. My wife, never showing any interest in anything related to a computer, actually found one which seemed so much cheaper than what I had tried to budget for. Now this digital camera must have been designed before Kodak had perfected their Brownie - somebody had never thought it might be a good idea to allow for changing the focus. The result is a mass of colours, nicely blending into one another, which resemble the neck of the Christmas turkey. There is a bonus though - it is impossible to identify a picture of King Kong from one of the mother-in-law. Alan Edgar A BUMPER COLOURING BOOK. I'm a 39 year old professional and it was sad. It showed my aunt's ageing problems, she had been so bright. Sadder still was the pleasure I got from it when it was placed next to the phone. I began to take pride in my colouring as I hung on the telephone waiting to talk to humans rather than the robotic call managers. Stewart There is a saying we all know that goes a little something like this "It's the thought that counts". In most cases it's true and we hide our disappointment behind a painted smile. People harp on about those tacky socks and jumpers. But they happen to be useful on a cold winter nights. But there are people who buy Christmas presents with no thought at all, so that old saying goes straight out of the window. There is one present I was given by the modern day Mr Scrooge who happens to be my father, that still humours me and angers at the same time. My father never lived with us and my mother had to raise five children on her own. One Christmas Day as a small boy. I was thrilled at the prospect of opening my stocking and finding the little black and white TV that my father had promised. After opening my mothers' presents, I asked my mother where my fathers' presents were. "On the coffee table!" she replied. On the table sat a poorly wrapped object that was no bigger than a matchbox. I remember thinking "This is too small to be a television" and wondered what it was. On opening the present, inside was a porcelain thimble that had 'Welcome to Wales' and a little red dragon on it. I was heart broken and also confused as to 'What the hell is a nine year-old boy supposed to do with a thimble'. At first I thought it must be a joke, but months disappeared and so did the thimble. Hard to believe I know! But true. David Cannon The worst present I received this year was from my mother in law. It was an electric can opener. My wife and I asked why she had bought us one and she said because my wife told her to. This puzzled me, for only two months earlier I went out and bought an electric can opener for the house !!!. Anonymous The worst, unwanted present I have ever received was from my father - a fishing rod. Not only am I female (sorry, not trying to be sexist, just a bit squeamish over maggots). I am also allergic to fish, which my father knew. To top it all he kept it, even though he has never been fishing in his life. Gill Hampton My aunt is quite a character and selecting presents is not one of her talents. Knowing this, my wife had been hinting to her for weeks for prezzies we would like; Body Shop products for her, a book for me and a particular learning activity toy for the baby. However, it wasn't just me, but the whole family who were given Christmas Turkeys one year (well, mine wasn't just a turkey.....it was an Ostrich!). My wife received a rack for holding spice jars and a spaghetti container (we had both already). My daughter received a pack of 3 baby grows aged 3 to 6 months. She was 7 months old at the time. And now for the real Christmas Turkey.... What did she buy for me? A toupee and clip on pony tail. She said she had noticed my hair loss over the past few months and "you young men like pony tails". It was obviously a joke set she had bought (although she didn't realise this) and I wasn't actually balding, I had my hair cut into a grade 2 by choice!!! Graham Kelsall When I was 10 my gran knitted the most horrendous, unfashionable purple cardigan in acrylic wool with huge purple buttons she said I would grow. My gran has been dead for 3 years now, i am now 42 years old and a size 16 - it's still too big! Kathy Keegans Not a present as such but I've not been happy about everyone having great slap-up dinners at Christmas while I'm fasting for Ramadam. Nadeem Faruque Last year I received a Playstation console and played it all Christmas right up until the new year. Well because I liked the puzzle games last year so much, this year I was given a cobination padlock with no combination to amuse myself with. Michael Williams It was this Christmas I recieved what I call a christmas turkey of a present. I am a bit of a gadget freak and every year I usually recieve a gadget or something which is usually realy usefull,of my wife. So this year she gave me this gift wrapped box, I opened it with excitement and inside was a picnic hamper, just what I have always wanted, never mind there is lways next year. P A Hunt I was having a relaxing time over Christmas with family having just broken my leg skiing. I am a keen runner and had always wanted a particular pair of running shoes but never been able to afford them. So, what do my brothers do - yep, they club together to buy them for me for Christmas, so now all I can do is look at them until my leg heals. Caroline Sayers My auntie Madge, an eccentric but practical private mobile nurse, came back from holiday in Cornwall with my Christmas present on Christmas eve. Because she had to be on duty the next day she rushed round to exchange gifts that night. She apologised for being in a rush and for not wrapping mine up and handed me one of her infamous brown paper bags. On Christmas Day while she was on duty I telephoned her to thank her for the present, although amused at the unusual practical nature of her gift on this occasion. She burst in to laughter and informed me that Mr Tomlins whom she had visited earlier was really happy with the jars of preserves from Cornwall. I as not to dissapoint the old man Mr Tomlins had to be content, this year, with his specimen bottles. Naomi Towers A few Christmases ago for some reason known only to her self, my wife's auntie alice sent us a magazine picture of the children's TV character barney the dinosaur as a genuine xmas present. I still haven't figured out why. Stevie Curry Last Christmas my miserable grandmother gave me an ashtray (I don't smoke). Not such a bad present one might think, but it was the same one I gave to her three years earlier. (It wasn't even washed properly!) Mark Hollingsworth I got an electric toothbrush from my dad, but that's proved useful! It pales compared to the massager "device" I also got form him.It looks like a computer mouse, and buzzes when pressed.But it doesn't massage anywhere in any useful way, because it's got a really weak pulse! The best use I've found is for entertaining my baby sister in law, who loved it and wouldn't let it go. Derrick Smith I believe my Christmas gift from my dearest hubby must be the worst one ever! The jobs around the home had been building up and I kept complaining they never got done, and I remarked I would do the jobs myself if the power tools weren't so heavy and akward to use. His answer was he just didn't have the time and what little time he had he wanted to relax not turn into Handy-Andy! Christmas morning I awoke to a big box wrapped in lovely paper with a nice big bow, I was quite surprised and excited, that was until I got the paper off then my face was one of shock, yep my wonderful Christmas pressie was a Black and Decker Quattro. I wasn't sure if it was a joke at first and waited for him to give me my real gift but I realised it was no joke when he said "I saw this and thought of you, now you will be able to do the jobs yourself" Hmm..... I wonder what I'm getting for my birthday (the complete DIY book??) Dawn Sanders This year my grandparents gave me 10 thermostatic valves for the radiators in my house!! Claire Dennis The worst (and cheapest) present I ever had for Christmas was a bag of bright-green, scented rocks. The label read 'alternative to potpourri; suitable for smokers'. I don't smoke (and never have). The person who bought them must hate me a lot. Tony Nixon This is going back about 10 years - I was about 15 (I'm not sure if that's cheating). I had a favourite aunt who always bought me very interesting Christmas presents. One year she bought me a lemon and a packet of sticking plasters. Nicely wrapped and everything. I'm not sure why she did it - I think she had had a rough year. Anyway, it didn't affect my opinion of her... I can't even remember thinking it strange until a few years later. Suzi Wells Please don't publish my name on this one. This year I got sent a wedding photo in a frame from a couple I'm friends with. I was unable to get to the wedding, so she thought this might make up for it in some way. The only problem is that I'm still totally in love with the man in question, it breaks my heart to look at the picture and I'm going to have to put it up somewhere so as not to offend them. Anonymous My wife received a hair dryer as a Christmas present, from my mother, unfortunately. "Not too bad," you may think, but it is identical to one she already has at home. Without offending my mother by asking her for the receipt, we decided to take the hair dryer back to Boots. The customer services woman was very helpful and said that it was no problem, she just had to scan the barcode to find the original price and give us vouchers to the same value. Imagine how embarrassed I was when she informed us that the hair dryer had been a free gift given with other goods bought earlier in the year. Sean Lilliott My mum and I had been collecting Coca-Cola ring pulls for the Coke auction. I had bid for a holiday but missed out by a couple of ring pulls, so I bought something else. Mum sent me the present at the start of December and there it was under the tree. Lo and behold, on Christmas day when I opened it up there were 700 ring pulls. As I had lost out on the holiday, my mum thought she would surprise me so that I could buy something else. I daren't tell her that it all finished on December 10. This was my main present too... Craig Dearden I was a touch surprised to find the new Vodaphone sponsored Man Utd shirt I had been waiting for had mysteriously metamorphosed into a silver pen with inbuilt lighter on Christmas morning. Very strange indeed, given that I can't wear a pen, and have a hundred lighters lying around the house and don't really need a fake silver one that writes. Luge Pravda My worst Christmas present ever: A years membership to 'slimmers world' from my (ex!)Boyfriend. Bernadette Hancock Worst Christmas present actually arrived this year. A Playstation 2. "Turkey?" I hear you cry? My mother had pre-ordered it and collected it on release day in November (bless her), and then to keep it top secret she hid the PS2 in the loft. Where it suffered the variations in temperature that a lot of lofts are exposed to in Winter. So on Christmas Day when it was opened, firstly I was stunned that my mum would think of such a wonderful present for me, then stunned again whilst taking it out of its box and finding water trickling out of it. Now I can't get a replacement until March. Being a gaming addict, this is sheer torture. Michael Scoates This year I received a vase which had been dropped, broken and super glued back together. This in itself would have warranted an entry at maybe number 8 on my all-time top 10 list of corking presents. What catapulted it to the top of the tree, however, was the fact that several vital pieces of pottery had obviously gone astray and the search had been called off due to a lack of resources. Andy I seem to do very well or should I say badly out of naff Christmas presents. One was a very disgusting tortoise boot scraper and a man-made fibre jumper with very tasteful bunches of cherries on. Probably very popular in Eastern European states about 10 years ago. Matthew Pearl On the night before Christmas Eve I was driving home with some friends when a black cat darted out in front of the car and didn't quite make it. I stopped the car and got out to take a look but there was nothing I could do for it. I placed the cat on the side of the road and went on my way, all the while thinking about the poor feline and the people who would miss it. I woke up on Christmas morning, having nearly forgotten about the cat accident and went to open my presents with my family. After the usual presents of socks and toilet joke books I got to a shoebox size present. To my surprise (and horror) I found a pair of those oversize fun slippers in the style of two black cats. I was made to wear them but they soon became 'lost' on Boxing Day. Philip Sharp I was 20 years old and had just started seeing this lad, we had been going out for about three months. Christmas day came and much to my amazement, he had bought me an encyclopaedia and a pair of pink suede, fur lined slippers! For Christmas, he received the ELBOW!! Kathryn Cox On receiving a beautifully wrapped present from my husbands' grandmother I was well impressed. It was a lot larger and heavier than the usual gifts she had given me. So I duly put it under the festive tree and resolved that however much I wanted to peek I would resist the urge. Christmas morning (after the kids had opened their pressies) it was my turn! Usual gifts from Granny-in-law were bath salts (genuine victorian!) and a bale of tea towels..But that year she surpassed herself. I pick up the parcel only to discover that the wrapping and the carpet underneath were soaking wet and smelt dubious. I could not believe it when I open it to find a whole cooked chicken that was once frozen! I later found out that Gran had cooked the chicken for us and frozen it thinking that it would come in useful over Christmas. Still it's the thought that counts...not! This years present went straight in the freezer even though it turned out to be a cordless phone! Karen For some people my Christmas presents this year would represent a slice of heaven. I received a total of 600 cigarettes (duty free of course) from my friends and family. Nothing else. Unfortunately I had foolishly given up, two weeks previously. As I was amused/shocked that so many people had the same idea but I had no other choice but to give them all away. Nalu This year I was given a jazz CD, some coffee beans, and various other sundries from my Mom-in-law. Nice stuff, according to my wife, who had all these things on her list of desired gifts! K Belluz My worst Christmas pressie that I can remember is getting the sound of Bread LP and when I opened it to play it on Christmas Day the wrong album was inside. It was Donny and Marie Osmond. Angela Williams I am used to my mother giving me a pair of marigolds every year, but this year I really feel my whole family feel I have something lacking in my life. My sister sent me a second hand butter dish complete with receipt and my mother gave me a pack of dish cloths and a pack of floor cloths. She didn't even include the marigolds this year! Vanessa My Grandmother is 92 years old. She looks like Margaret Rutherford and for the last 10 years has obviously decided to play up to her eccentric image by bestowing on her grandchildren some very odd gifts. Last year, I got a Haze air freshener. Very useful, except that I'm allergic to perfume. The year before, she gave me a model horse with only three legs. When I complained, she replied, 'What's the problem? It still looks like a horse, doesn't it?' This year, she promised me something nice. I got a golfing umbrella. Definitely an improvement, you might think...except it's the one she grabbed off me in June when I wheel-chaired her in the rain to a relative's funeral... Lesley Wilkinson 500 personalised address labels was probably the worst Christmas present I ever received.The phone number was wrong! Sue Nicholson Going back a few years, my Grandmother (bless her), knowing I was a fanatical Newcastle United fan bought me the latest football shirt. She packaged the shirt for posting and sent it to me. A couple of days later and my postman arrived in pouring rain with my present. Unfortunately, my loving Grandmother had wrapped the shirt in red paper and the rain had made the red dye run onto the sacred black and white top. The result, a football shirt in the colours of Sunderland. Thanks Gran! Craig Anderson It is a mistake for my mother to buy me presents: she lives exactly 423 miles away from me, and is 40 years my senior; we communicate, by phone, tersely, once a month. This year a parcel from her arrived which contained for a technophile like me the dubious gift of an Arthurian-themed address book, in which each letter of the alphabet was decorated with portraits and legends of the various knights of the round table, each page with William Morris bordering and panels. Preferring my WAP phone and laptop, this was not a good choice for me, so I forwarded it, re-wrapped, to a distant friend, who had once expressed modest enthusiasm for attending the Glastonbury Festival. At New Year my mother rang and asked if I liked my present and as I pondered various easy lies she interrupted me saying: "I hope you noticed that I wrote my address in there - perhaps I'll get some letters from you this year!" Paul McClure My worst Christmas present ever was a set of wind chimes - but I have had the last laugh, I put them up outside the house on Boxing Day and boy are they driving everyone mad!! Paul Sharman When I was about 13 years old I received the following from my mum for Christmas: school uniform, a satchel, and a geometry set. As you can guess I was disappointed. Kathy Spendel A couple of years ago I fell in love with those tiny Ixus cameras - so compact, so stylish, so covetable! As my old camera was on its last legs, the ideal solution was at hand: convey to my ever-loving partner that this was to be my next Christmas present. Accordingly I seized every possible opportunity to point the camera's desirability out to him; drawing attention to newspaper adverts and stopping meaningfully in front of camera-shop windows, where I would rhapsodize about the perfection of the design and the fact that I longed to possess one. My big error was this: I didn't actually say BUY ME AN IXUS CAMERA. Come Christmas morning, he produced (with a flourish) an enormous parcel that must have measured about 4 feet by 1 foot. On unwrapping it I discovered a keyboard - yes, a keyboard - which I could plug into my computer and play as a digital piano. Apparently I had once, in the dim and distant past (so distant I couldn't even remember it) said something about wishing I'd learnt the piano as a child. Penny Gore I bought my boyfriend an all-singing all-dancing top of the range DVD player and received a box of Milk Tray in return... Demir Sayiner Come into my house and a singing plastic fish hanging in my hallway will greet you. If you get past that, watch out for the singing, dancing lobster that is sitting in front of the door reciting Otis Redding. In the main room, you'll discover a talking donkey that moans about the weather, perched next to a farting teddy bear that apologises profusely following its outbursts. All this is because I mentioned to a couple of people that I sometimes get lonely as a student. A new DVD or palm top would have eased the pain. Still, there's the birthday to come. Jason Wood My worst ever gift was a petrol cap for my husband's car! It may have been my fault as I was always complaining that I couldn't undo the one on the car but insult was added to injury as this one came wrapped in the carrier bag from the motorists shop. Anonymous On Boxing Day we all go to my dear nana's and every year we never know what she's going to get us. She came into the living room as she always does dragging two white santa sacks, smiled and said "santa's been!" with the same silly grin. Me and my sister slowly turned our heads and laughed. We began opening out presents with my nana and granda looking on. After I had opened the usual bath bubbles and plastic beaded necklace, I came across a very small parcel in my treasures. "It feel's like....." I said slowly peeling the paper "IT'S A PLUG!" I cried out laughing. "AN ELECTRIC PLUG!" Everyone else looked on in disbelief before joining in with the laughter. Nana just tapped her nose and said "you won't be laughing in a minute". I continued opening, afraid of what I would come across next. After a purse and a box of chocolates I saw nana's face light up when I pulled an oblong shaped parcel out of the bag. I took off the paper to reveal a battery recharger. Sure enough the thing didn't have a plug on the end. Again the room erupted in hysterics. I don't know which was the worst gift, the plug or the recharger.But it has come in useful for recharging my son's Christmas toys, considering I had to buy nearly 30 batteries I suppose it wasn't that useless after all......poor Nana! Madeline Gibson My worst Christmas present ever has got to be a Shawaddywaddy single. Ged Carroll A 'hanging basket' kit - everything you would want to produce flowers in hanging baskets, including a guide book and special basket to get you started. For a 31 year old bloke with no interest in gardening, this was a prize turkey. Adam Brooks Read more entries

webTitle: Comment: end of an era for BBC News

fields.headline: End of an era for BBC News
fields.standfirst:
BBC news chief Tony Hall's failure to win over the board of governors in the battle to become director-general meant his departure was inevitable.
Fat lady finally sings
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: 'BBC lifer' Tony Hall's departure for the Opera House marks the end of an era for the corporation's news coverage, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Fat lady finally sings
fields.body:
The departure of Tony Hall from BBC News marks the end of an era for the corporation's news coverage.

A classic example of a BBC "lifer", he was as fond of management theory and attention to administrative processes as his former boss Sir John Birt.

After entering the BBC through the traditional route as a news trainee, Mr Hall progressed through the ranks, and was plucked from relative obscurity as a programme editor to become editor of news and current affairs in 1987.

It was widely accepted that Mr Hall, known in the BBC as "head boy", would leave following his failure to win over the board of governors in the battle to become director-general.

And he has been tarnished by persistent talk that his aides briefed against rival candidates during the leadership campaign.

Many in the BBC will welcome the opportunity for a change at the top.

Mr Hall's skills as a journalist and news manager are not questioned. The BBC unquestionably still retains its reputation for journalistic excellence, and Mr Hall has handled one of BBC News's toughest PR battles, News 24, with dexterity.

His career as director of BBC news has spanned two general elections, the largest conflict on European soil since the second world war, the introduction of a controversial new electronic newsgathering system and the move of the BBC institution the Nine O'Clock News.

Mr Hall can also take the ultimate credit for launching Radio 5 in the face of massive opposition and for launching the hugely successful BBC Online news.

His lifelong interest in economics has yielded two books, one on the miners and another on nuclear power.

But some of Mr Hall's managerial judgements have come in for strong criticism, notably his role in the decision to ship BBC journalists from Broadcasting House to White City, and the introduction of the unpopular "super-editors", a decision that led to open mutiny among journalists.

Former BBC radio boss Liz Forgan described the move to White City as a "mad idea", and revealed that Mr Hall and Mr Birt kept information about the move, including budgets, a secret.

His successor will inherit one of the toughest jobs in British broadcasting, facing growing competition from the plethora of new news services springing up on new digital channels and the internet.

The chosen candidate will also face a consolidated attack from commercial broadcasters on new licence-fee funded services.

And moves begun under John Birt to make the news more "user-friendly" face a challenge from two directions.

The BBC's news services have to combine authority with usability, but without attracting charges of dumbing-down.

webTitle: Desertification in the Karoo

fields.headline: Desertification in the Karoo
fields.standfirst: South African sheep farmers in the Karoo are facing the loss of their pastures to arid scrubland, writes land degradation expert Dr John Boardman
fields.trailText: South African sheep farmers in the Karoo are facing the loss of their pastures to arid scrubland, writes land degradation expert Dr John Boardman.
fields.body:
Driving eastward out of the Cape, through the winelands around Paarl and away from the region of winter rainfall the landscape becomes arid. Sheep grazing replaces the vineyards except in irrigated areas where fruits can still be grown.

This is a hostile landscape to which early European colonisers originally brought cattle, but moved-on in search of better pastures. The settlers learned to live with the periodic droughts and unfamiliar wild animals, building homesteads near sources of water, replacing cattle with hardier sheep, and establishing towns like Graaf Reinet in the 1820s.

Sheep-ranges were fenced and protected and jackal predators eradicated. As the control of nature increased, so did populations of sheep.

The great semi-arid area stretching eastwards from the Cape is called the Karoo. Typically, it is flat dry shrubland with grass-growth restricted to the moistness of the occasional mountain ranges. Rainfall is sporadic, less than 500 mm a year, in some places a great deal less.
Periods of drought last for several years, affecting the region and its plant growth. Notable droughts occurred in the periods 1919-31, 1944-49 and 1962-73. Since 1974 has been a relatively wet period.

Karoo lamb is succulent herby meat, much appreciated on the braais, or barbecues, of South Africa, but the vast region of the Karoo produces little else of note. In a time of farm incomes that are falling, there is much talk of developing game parks and attracting overseas tourists to provide a living.

White farmers making a precarious living from sheep in the Karoo. They feel marginalised in a country with politically different and largely urban priorities.

Of great concern to the farmers is the suggestion that the landscape is becoming more hostile to farming, and eventually unsuitable for livestock.

First suggested by a French-forester named Aubréville in the late nineteenth century, and forcibly advocated in South Africa by J.P.H.Acocks in the 1950s, the term 'desertification' implies the advance of desert-like conditions - a growing aridification. Acocks described a desert margin advancing northeastwards towards Pretoria - a powerful image since this is the seat of South African government.

In the days when public values were Boer farming values, desertification was seen as a threat to rural livelihoods and a cause for concern. Government spent large sums of money subsidising farming systems that arguably, as in other parts of the world, were unsustainable.

Sheep prices were high, and grants were available for fencing, water conservation and anti-erosion measures such as dams. These subsidies and measures further enabled farmers to overstock with sheep.

Nowadays, there is an additional cause for concern. Desertification implies soil erosion. Soils are washed into streams and eventually silt-up reservoirs. South Africa has a water resource problem  and loss of water storage in reservoirs contributes to the scarcity.

The concept of desertification has been the subject of fierce debate. The vegetation of the Karoo has changed from a mix of livestock-edible grasses and shrubs, to undesirable shrubs which are less palatable to sheep.

One of the problems with the loss of grasses is that a patchy shrub-dominated landscape has much bare ground, causing increased potential for rainfall runoff and soil erosion. Controversy rages around why these changes have occurred. Is it climate-induced, detrimental human impact, climate and human impact, or just a natural process in marginal-arid areas of the world?

Semi-arid areas are notoriously sensitive to climate variability and the Karoo has had many droughts, but much of the Karoo has also had very high numbers of sheep, until fairly recently.
Overgrazing is recognised worldwide as an impact on vegetation that leads to the land degradation that is soil erosion. Together with occasional droughts, the Karoos dense sheep populations could explain the cause of desertification in the region.

If drought alone were the cause of the vegetation change, then relating change to cycles of drought would test the hypothesis. Recent research confirms that the vegetation type has changed, but it does not provide reliable dates for the changes.

The landscape of the Karoo shows evidence of desertification in that systems of deep gullies and crazy-paved badlands scar much of the landscape. These are likely to have formed when vegetation decline produced bare ground through loss of grasses that enables soil erosion by rainfall and runoff.

Dating the gullies and badlands is crucial to explaining the causes of desertification in the Karoo.

In the Sneeuberg uplands, gully systems developed when the first Europeans moved through the area in the early nineteenth century. At that time, cattle drank in streams that now lie at the bottom of six metre deep gullies, and hippopotami wallowed in pools that no longer exist. The gullies have continued to deepen to the extent that small dams built in the 1950s quickly filled with sediment.

Fences built on flatlands in the 1930s now cross deep gullies. Similarly, the badlands seem rather recent in age. During present-day storms, considerable erosion occurs. Once formed the badlands appear very difficult to revegetate, even with greatly reduced sheep numbers.

The desertified areas of the Karoo, gullied and lacking vegetation or growing unpalatable shrubs, seem likely to be a product of dense sheep populations in the 100 years from 1860 to 1960.

If this is the case, the desertification of the Karoo is an indictment of the introduction and development of European farming systems in fragile semi-arid landscapes that are subject to drought. Similar stories are told in the arid farming regions of western USA, Australia and New Zealand, and the controversy over the causes remain.

• Dr John Boardman is a researcher at the environmental change institute, Oxford university. He has worked on land degradation problems for twenty years.
fields.bodyText: Driving eastward out of the Cape, through the winelands around Paarl and away from the region of winter rainfall the landscape becomes arid. Sheep grazing replaces the vineyards except in irrigated areas where fruits can still be grown. This is a hostile landscape to which early European colonisers originally brought cattle, but moved-on in search of better pastures. The settlers learned to live with the periodic droughts and unfamiliar wild animals, building homesteads near sources of water, replacing cattle with hardier sheep, and establishing towns like Graaf Reinet in the 1820s. Sheep-ranges were fenced and protected and jackal predators eradicated. As the control of nature increased, so did populations of sheep. The great semi-arid area stretching eastwards from the Cape is called the Karoo. Typically, it is flat dry shrubland with grass-growth restricted to the moistness of the occasional mountain ranges. Rainfall is sporadic, less than 500 mm a year, in some places a great deal less. Periods of drought last for several years, affecting the region and its plant growth. Notable droughts occurred in the periods 1919-31, 1944-49 and 1962-73. Since 1974 has been a relatively wet period. Karoo lamb is succulent herby meat, much appreciated on the braais, or barbecues, of South Africa, but the vast region of the Karoo produces little else of note. In a time of farm incomes that are falling, there is much talk of developing game parks and attracting overseas tourists to provide a living. White farmers making a precarious living from sheep in the Karoo. They feel marginalised in a country with politically different and largely urban priorities. Of great concern to the farmers is the suggestion that the landscape is becoming more hostile to farming, and eventually unsuitable for livestock. First suggested by a French-forester named Aubréville in the late nineteenth century, and forcibly advocated in South Africa by J.P.H.Acocks in the 1950s, the term 'desertification' implies the advance of desert-like conditions - a growing aridification. Acocks described a desert margin advancing northeastwards towards Pretoria - a powerful image since this is the seat of South African government. In the days when public values were Boer farming values, desertification was seen as a threat to rural livelihoods and a cause for concern. Government spent large sums of money subsidising farming systems that arguably, as in other parts of the world, were unsustainable. Sheep prices were high, and grants were available for fencing, water conservation and anti-erosion measures such as dams. These subsidies and measures further enabled farmers to overstock with sheep. Nowadays, there is an additional cause for concern. Desertification implies soil erosion. Soils are washed into streams and eventually silt-up reservoirs. South Africa has a water resource problem  and loss of water storage in reservoirs contributes to the scarcity. The concept of desertification has been the subject of fierce debate. The vegetation of the Karoo has changed from a mix of livestock-edible grasses and shrubs, to undesirable shrubs which are less palatable to sheep. One of the problems with the loss of grasses is that a patchy shrub-dominated landscape has much bare ground, causing increased potential for rainfall runoff and soil erosion. Controversy rages around why these changes have occurred. Is it climate-induced, detrimental human impact, climate and human impact, or just a natural process in marginal-arid areas of the world? Semi-arid areas are notoriously sensitive to climate variability and the Karoo has had many droughts, but much of the Karoo has also had very high numbers of sheep, until fairly recently. Overgrazing is recognised worldwide as an impact on vegetation that leads to the land degradation that is soil erosion. Together with occasional droughts, the Karoos dense sheep populations could explain the cause of desertification in the region. If drought alone were the cause of the vegetation change, then relating change to cycles of drought would test the hypothesis. Recent research confirms that the vegetation type has changed, but it does not provide reliable dates for the changes. The landscape of the Karoo shows evidence of desertification in that systems of deep gullies and crazy-paved badlands scar much of the landscape. These are likely to have formed when vegetation decline produced bare ground through loss of grasses that enables soil erosion by rainfall and runoff. Dating the gullies and badlands is crucial to explaining the causes of desertification in the Karoo. In the Sneeuberg uplands, gully systems developed when the first Europeans moved through the area in the early nineteenth century. At that time, cattle drank in streams that now lie at the bottom of six metre deep gullies, and hippopotami wallowed in pools that no longer exist. The gullies have continued to deepen to the extent that small dams built in the 1950s quickly filled with sediment. Fences built on flatlands in the 1930s now cross deep gullies. Similarly, the badlands seem rather recent in age. During present-day storms, considerable erosion occurs. Once formed the badlands appear very difficult to revegetate, even with greatly reduced sheep numbers. The desertified areas of the Karoo, gullied and lacking vegetation or growing unpalatable shrubs, seem likely to be a product of dense sheep populations in the 100 years from 1860 to 1960. If this is the case, the desertification of the Karoo is an indictment of the introduction and development of European farming systems in fragile semi-arid landscapes that are subject to drought. Similar stories are told in the arid farming regions of western USA, Australia and New Zealand, and the controversy over the causes remain. • Dr John Boardman is a researcher at the environmental change institute, Oxford university. He has worked on land degradation problems for twenty years.

webTitle: Press Gazette round-up

fields.headline: Press Gazette
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 12.
fields.trailText: January 12: Jonathan Holborow and Ian Monk are thought to be in the running for the new editorship of the Express.
fields.body:
Jonathan Holborow and Ian Monk are thought to have joined the running for the new editorship of the Daily Express, along with News of the World deputy Andy Coulson, as speculation mounts about the departure of Rosie Boycott.

Former Q editor Andy Pemberton has been lured to New York to launch Blender, a new music magazine backed by Dennis Publishing.

BBC journalists have blamed the "all white, all male" management culture at the corporation for claims of racism raised by director-general Greg Dyke.

Former City Slicker James Hipwell is poised to take Phil Hall's slot at Max Clifford Associates if the former News of the World editor takes the job of editor at the celebrity magazine Hello! as predicted.

Several national newspapers have approached the astrologer Jonathan Cainer , believing he will fly the Express coop when editor Rosie Boycott leaves.

Executive chairman of News International , Les Hinton, was the man responsible for pointing out to Richard Desmond that his outgoing columnist, Stephen Pollard, had created his infamous hostile acrostic.

webTitle: Property supervision is a question of brain power

fields.headline: Property supervision is a question of brain power
fields.standfirst: Helping residents on council estates to solve their own problems is the the hands-on approach that housing assistant Claire Taylor relishes
fields.trailText:
Name Claire Taylor
Age 26
Job Housing assistant, Daventry district council
Salary £15,012
fields.body:
Name Claire Taylor
Age 26
Job Housing assistant, Daventry district council
Salary £15,012

Claire Taylor is not someone with ambitions to sit behind a desk all her life - but then you wouldn't expect that of a young woman who took a security job on a tough housing estate in her early 20s and was unfazed by a drive-by shooting.

After leaving school with just one A-level, Ms Taylor worked in shops and hotels but wanted to do "something more worthwhile". She took a job managing two blocks of flats for Rugby district council and then moved to be a concierge at Coventry city council, operating the CCTV system and patrolling 10 blocks of flats.

Realising there was no obvious route for promotion, Ms Taylor then moved to her present job in Daventry. She lets council houses, deals with neighbour disputes, and generally keeps an eye on the council's properties in nine "villages" and one estate in the town.

The main difference from the Coventry job ­ apart from being less scary ­ is the need "to use your brain", says Ms Taylor. Procedures have to be followed but, most importantly, you have to be able to help people sort out their own problems.

Ms Taylor is midway through an HNC course in housing and hopes for promotion to housing officer. She has studied the brochures for degree and diploma courses, but while that would open access to the higher reaches of the profession, she is not yet sure whether she would want to give up the hands-on work that she currently enjoys.

webTitle: The Way You See It

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: Are Palace on their way to Cardiff?
fields.body:
Are Palace on their way to Cardiff?

After Crystal Palace's Worthington Cup victory over Liverpool last night, we weren't surprised when several ecstatic Eagles fans wrote in to celebrate. None, however, managed to celebrate quite as enthusiastically as Marc McNabb.

"What can I say? Except PALACE ARE ON THEIR WAY TO CARDIFF!!!" he wrote. "What a result, the second leg will be a mere formality, more than likely a 0-0 draw, and yes, you can quote me on that."

OK then, we will. And we'll include your BIG capital letters too. But look, there's more. "We are more than capable of producing the goods against Premiership opposition, credit to the fans who were electric on the night, Emile WHO?? Michael WHAT??" he continues.

"It's all about Clinton Morrison and Andrejs Rubins. Every Palace player gave their all and we were rewarded. Liverpool grabbing a goal was a bit disappointing but that's a minor! The Eagles have landed. TRUST ME!"

Svennis is not a menace

Elsewhere, we've had a number of letters agreeing with Sean Ingle's piece on Sven-Goran Eriksson. "Good old Guardian!!!" says Mats Carlsson (a, Swede in case you're wondering) "for your very balanced look upon Svennis's coaching."

And Michael Rose agrees: "I am writing to say that I thoroughly agree with your comments on the appointment of Sven Goran Erickson as England team coach. How refreshing it is to read a balanced and unprejudiced article. As you pointed out, his record is one of the best of any current manager and is certainly better than any England manager in recent memory.

However, Michael has his doubts whether Eriksson will be given a fair chance by the English press. "Although it is no guarantee of success, let him be judged on results," he says. "It may also take some time to build the team he wants, and I fear he may not be given the time."

You can read the full article here.

The FA are mad: discuss

Most football fans are appalled by the FA's decision not to take Richard Prokas's brutal two-footed tackle on Patrick Vieira any further.

"The apparent injustice of the FA's disciplinary system is astounding," says David Kerr. "The difference (if there is one) between Leeds [where Vieira has been cited for kicking Dacourt in the face] and Carlisle [where Vieira was fouled] seems to revolve around the referees' eyesight. If the ref sees an incident, then the FA cannot interfere - but if he doesn't, then they can.

"The FA needs a sense of proportion in these matters," David continues. "The tackle at Carlisle was far more serious than anything that happened at Leeds. Indeed, I thought there were other more serious issues in the Leeds game from a misconduct perspective, not least Smith's blatant verbal abuse to a referee's assistant. In recent times other players have received straight red cards for such offences but in this case Smith's only punishment was to be named Man of the Match!

And Richard Jones agrees. "The FA are a bunch of arses," he claims. "The fact that Prokas IS NOT being punished whereas (using the same method of video evidence) Vieira IS being punished is crazy. It reeks of discrimination against the Frenchman, and any other person condemned to a suspension through video evidence."

webTitle: Yorkshire faces 63% hike in flood defence levy

fields.headline: Yorkshire faces 63% hike in flood defence levy
fields.trailText: The environment agency is today asking councillors in Yorkshire to spend an extra £10.8m to bolster flood defences and pay for damage to historic towns and villages in the wake of devastation caused by torrential downpours in October and November.
fields.body:
The environment agency is today asking councillors in Yorkshire to spend an extra £10.8m to bolster flood defences and pay for damage to historic towns and villages in the wake of devastation caused by torrential downpours in October and November.

The request for more money - which represents a 63% increase on last year's levy - is to be made in the second of a planned series of nationwide flood defence committee meetings called by the environment agency to discuss the need for additional funds from local government.

A defence committee in Solihull voted last Friday to impose an extra 12% levy, sparking fears of a rise in next year's council tax bills and calls from angry Labour councillors for government assistance.

The agency hopes to raise £256m from councils in England and Wales, a rise of 13.5% on last year's budget. Increases will vary across regions, with Yorkshire expected to incur the largest. In the Thames Valley, the agency is seeking an increase of just 4%, and in the south-west, 22.5%.

Agency chiefs in Yorkshire say the 63% increase is necessary to avert another disaster. At today's meeting - held at York racecourse - they will urge agriculture ministry officials, local councillors and members of the environment agency to back the £10.8m increase on last year's levy of £17.2m.

Emergency repairs to existing Yorkshire defences damaged by flood will cost about £2.8m, while £7.8m has been added to the agency's existing £15.1m capital programme for flood alleviation schemes.

Defence committee chairman Professor Roy Ward said: "Our task is more difficult than ever before because of the overwhelming financial impact of the recent floods, which were the worst ever recorded in many parts of Yorkshire.

"They affected the region far worse than any other of the 10 flood defence committees in England and Wales. More than one-third of the total emergency response and repair costs for the whole of England were incurred in Yorkshire.

"Local councils have many competing demands for their limited resources but the consequences for flood-risk communities in Yorkshire may be very severe unless we approve this levy."

webTitle: Petrescu in Saints talks

fields.headline: Petrescu in Saints talks
fields.trailText: Bradford defender Dan Petrescu is in talks with Southampton over a possible transfer.
fields.body:
Bradford defender Dan Petrescu is in talks with Southampton over a possible transfer.

The Romanian international has been informed by Bantams manager Jim Jefferies that he does not have a future at Valley Parade, and along with Benito Carbone and Stan Collymore, is up for sale.

Petrescu, 33, has three-and-a-half years remaining of a contract worth £15,000-a-week at Valley Parade, which he signed only last summer after joining the club from Chelsea.

Bradford manager Jim Jefferies said: "He is talking to Southampton at the moment so we will wait and see what develops. It is a situation which suits both clubs.

"He's got three-and-a-half years left on his contract so we're making a saving on that side and obviously that will help the club.

"But it's not about Dan going for financial reasons. He is a good player.

"Along with the other two [Carbone and Collymore], it is purely a football matter because facts are facts, we are bottom of the league after 21 games and they've been playing regularly, but it has not worked."

Paris St Germain are understood to have made tentative enquiries concerning Collymore, who recently saw a move to German club VfB Stuttgart fall through, while Italian outfit Udinese are interested in Carbone.

Jefferies added: "I feel we've a better chance of beating relegation without them and that's no disrespect to them or their talent."

webTitle: Police investigate deaths of more Shipman patients

fields.headline: Police investigate deaths of more Shipman patients
fields.trailText: A new investigation will open into the deaths of 62 patients of serial killer GP Harold Shipman, police announced today.
fields.body:
A new investigation will open into the deaths of 62 patients of serial killer GP Harold Shipman, police announced today.

An incident room has been set up in Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester, and detectives are starting the task of contacting relatives.

The dead are among the 297 patients highlighted in a government report last week, who are thought to be victims of the killer doctor.

The report, a clinical audit commissioned by the department of health, discovered that Shipman issued a total of 499 death certificates while at his practice in Hyde, Greater Manchester.

A comparison between Shipman and other GPs in the town showed that 297 of these were "excess" certificates - deaths which were statistically unlikely to occur among his patients. Of these, 236 patients died at home - the vast majority women over 65-years-old.

The 62 deaths are cases not covered by the original police inquiry into Shipman, who is serving life after being convicted a year ago of murdering 15 elderly women patients by injecting them with diamorphine.

webTitle: Beattie loses underwear clients

fields.headline: Beattie loses his underwear
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Trevor Beattie, who masterminded the Wonderbra ads, has been left without an underwear client after parting company with Pretty Polly, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Trevor Beattie, the best-known creative in adland and mastermind of the infamous Wonderbra campaign, has been left without an underwear client for the first time in years after parting with Pretty Polly this week.

Beattie's agency, TBWA GGT Simons Palmer, has created a series of raunchy ads for Pretty Polly including a recent press campaign showing a young woman with her hand down her knickers, with the slogan, "Go on treat yourself".

Last year the ITC allowed a TV ad based on a saucy holiday postcard to remain on air despite 43 public complaints.

Neither party was available for comment on the split but it is thought that Pretty Polly wants to put its advertising on hold until it works out a new strategy.

Pretty Polly hired TBWA four years ago and has since transformed itself from a tights manufacturer into a racy lingerie brand, most recently with the launch of its Almost Naked range.

It surely won't be long before Mr Beattie, who made his name with the Eva Herzigova 'Hello Boys!' poster for Wonderbra, signs up another sexy lingerie client.

Meanwhile, he continues to produce cheeky FCUK ads for French Connection.

webTitle: TV ratings January 10

fields.headline: No 1 spot eludes Popstars
fields.trailText: 12.15pm TV overnights: ITV's much-hyped Popstars got off to a solid but not spectacular start last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV's much-hyped Popstars got off to a solid but not spectacular start last night.

The show won its 8-9pm slot with a 7.6m audience and a 32% share, but in the process lost nearly 7m of the viewers inherited from Coronation Street, according to unofficial overnights.

The first episode of Popstars featured LWT entertainment head Nigel Lythgoe and other showbiz gurus auditioning young hopefuls for the pop band they are putting together.

It comfortably beat BBC1 opposition Celebrity Ready Steady Cook, which took 5.5m, and docu-soap Escape to the Sun, with 4.9m.

But nearly 7m Coronation Street viewers switched off when with Popstars came on.

The big turn-off is traditional following the soap, which got 14.3m viewers.

Last Wednesday in the same slot, A Touch of Frost repeat averaged 9.1m and a 37% share, following on from a 15.5m Coronation Street audience.

The show is set to make a screen star of Mr Lythgoe, king of showbiz at LWT, who is one a panel of judges alongside a former Take That publicist and a Polydor A&R boss.

TV critics described the showbusiness world it exposed as "a savage jungle".

However, ITV director of programmes David Liddiment will have been heartened that Popstars' audience grew over the hour it was on air, from 7.2m to 8.3m.

Placing the first episode of Popstars after ITV ratings flagship Coronation Street was a scheduling ploy to allow as wide an audience as possible to sample the show before it moves to its regular 5.55pm Saturday night slot, where the key target demographic will be 16 to 34-year-olds.

Last night the opener had a 42% share among 16 to 34s. This compares favourably with ITV's most popular show among this age group, Cold Feet, which had a 47% share of 16 to 34s for its third series last autumn.
