webTitle: Staff development at heart of NHS reforms

fields.headline: Staff development at heart of NHS reforms
fields.standfirst: Government strategy recognises the growing importance of human resources in creating an environment for improving patient services
fields.trailText: Government strategy recognises the growing importance of human resources in creating an environment for improving patient services
fields.body:
"HR used to be a purely administrative function," said NHS Confederation head of human resources Andrew Foster. "You would recruit people, pay them, fill in their P45 and deal with disciplinary procedures. What is happening now in the NHS is the realisation that organisations that think about their staff and try to get the best out of their staff are more successful. So the NHS is expanding its HR function."

This change has been strongly encouraged - demanded, even - by the Labour government. Since coming to power, Labour has introduced the first ever HR strategy for the NHS, and made the way staff are treated a core measure of an organisation's performance, linked to the funding it receives. As a result, HR directors are gaining equal status with other board level "heavy hitters" such as finance directors. They are planning the future of their organisations as well as looking after staff. According to Mr Foster, the increase in responsibilities and status is overdue: "We spend 70% of NHS money on staff. HR managers should be involved in everything."

Until recently, the most an NHS HR manager could expect to earn was in the mid-£40,000s. Now it is not unusual for senior managers to earn £60,000 plus, with a few working in large, acute trusts, topping the £70,000 mark. A junior manager entering HR can expect a starting salary of just under £20,000, while a middle grade manager is likely to be on £30,000 plus.

To get ahead in HR in the health service it is increasingly necessary to hold the right qualifications. The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) is the key training body in the field, offering a range of courses at graduate and non-graduate level. "You would certainly need a CIPD qualification and then marry that up with one of the health-specific qualifications provided by several universities," said Mr Foster.

That said, there is no fixed career path in HR. Many managers have private sector backgrounds or come from other public sectors, moving in and out of the NHS at different stages in their careers. "It's rare to bring someone from the outside into a senior general management role in the NHS, but in HR it's quite common. There is a flexible set of opportunities," said Mr Foster.

The key to success in HR, according to Jim McCaffery, director of personnel and development, Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, is the ability to get the basics right - and the imagination and drive to do something different. "It's being able to get things done," he said. "The people who don't do well are those who don't push for change."

webTitle: 50,000 organs secretly stored in hospitals

fields.headline: 50,000 organs secretly stored in hospitals
fields.trailText: he true scale of the scandal of human organ retention by hospitals will be revealed today by the government's chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, who will tell parents and professionals that 50,000 organs are being stored in hospitals in England alone.
fields.body:
The true scale of the scandal of human organ retention by hospitals will be revealed today by the government's chief medical officer, who will tell parents and professionals that 50,000 organs are being stored in hospitals in England alone. The number far exceeds expectations.

Liam Donaldson will say that what was done in the name of the NHS over many years was an affront to families who had lost their loved ones.

Addressing a public seminar, whose audience will include top pathologists and other senior doctors, he will say "some of the past practices around organ retention belong to an era where decisions were made by the NHS for patients, but not with patients.

"This has caused a period of immense distress for families, especially in places like Bristol and Liverpool, when they found out their children's organs were taken without their knowledge. Something went seriously wrong in the way the health service dealt with the issue of organ retention."

Prof Donaldson will pledge that the government "will do whatever it takes to put things right, changing the law if necessary to ensure that relatives are given the right kind of information so they can give consent in a fully informed way if they choose to do so."

At Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, where an inquiry will report shortly, more than 3,000 children's organs have been discovered; other hospitals were not thought to have anything like that number.

The chief medical officer will offer an unmitigated apology and assurances for the future to the parents of the Alder Hey children and those whose children died and had organs removed at the Bristol royal infirmary who have been invited to today's seminar. None of the parents knew that hearts, brains and other whole organs would be removed and kept after the autopsy on their son or daughter.

Ian Kennedy, chairman of the inquiry into children's deaths following heart surgery at Bristol, published an interim report into organ retention at the hospital last May. He found that the law was complex and obscure. Different laws covered hospital autopsies - which help doctors find out about the progress of disease - and those ordered by the coroner to find out the cause of death. Prof Kennedy recommended at least a new code of practice and preferably a new law.

Prof Donaldson has issued interim guidance to hospitals, requiring them to tell parents and relatives exactly what an autopsy involves and get their explicit permission if there is any need to remove organs.

Today's seminar is part of his information-gathering process on the way to producing his final report to the health secretary, Alan Milburn. That is expected, along with the Alder Hey inquiry report, before the end of the month.

Ed Bradley, chairman of the Alder Hey parents' support group, said more than 140 parents and relatives had travelled to London for the seminar and were glad of the opportunity to give evidence, "however, we do question how much benefit can be gained from a one-day conference where we have only been given five minutes to represent our views." They also felt it would be more appropriate to discuss the way forward after the Alder Hey inquiry had reported.

Alder Hey hospital is generally considered a special case, because whole organ systems were found to have been collected by a consultant pathologist, Dick Van Velzen, who is facing disciplinary hearings at the General Medical Council.

Bristol parents at the seminar will be asking for Prof Kennedy's recommendations to be implemented and questioning why there has been no action since his report was published. "It was quite clear the law was in a mess," said Steve Parker, chairman of the Bristol Heart Children's Action Group.

webTitle: TV ratings Jan 10 update

fields.headline: C4's bottoms not as big as breasts
fields.standfirst:
Jan 11: No 1 spot eludes Popstars
Digital take-up hits BBC/ITV
fields.trailText:
1.45pm TV overnights update: C4's documentary about bottom-related illnesses proved not as big a ratings triumph as Tuesday's Perfect Breasts. By Jason Deans.
Jan 11: No 1 spot eludes Popstars
Digital take-up hits BBC/ITV
fields.body:
Last night's Channel 4 documentary about bottom-related illnesses proved, unsurprisingly, not as big a ratings triumph as its Perfect Breasts programme on Tuesday.

Bottoms, the first instalment of Channel 4's Embarrassing Illnesses series, was billed in the Radio Times as a look "at the problems often obscured by the shame surrounding piles and anal fistulas".

It drew 2.1m and a 9% share from 8.30-9pm, according to unofficial overnights.

On Tuesday night Perfect Breasts, which looked at the growing trend for British teenagers to have breast implants, had 3.4m and a 19% share.

Later on last night, raunchy US comedy Sex and the City returned to Channel 4 for a new run with a double bill from 10-11.15pm.

The show, about the lives and loves of four thirtysomething New York women, drew 2.1m and a 12% share.

Major BBC2 drama In a Land of Plenty opened last night, with a steady 2.2m and 9% share from 9pm.

The epic sweep of the TalkBack Productions show, which follows the fortunes of the Freeman family over 40 years from the early 1950s, will unfold over 10 episodes.

Other BBC2 shows debuting last night included Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen makeover vehicle Fantasy Rooms. The show, which featured Mr Llewelyn-Bowen creating a Jane Austenesque drawing room in a seventies semi, drew a healthy 2.6m and 11% share.

On ITV, Scottish detective drama Taggart proved its enduring appeal with 8.4m and a 39% share over two hours from 9pm.

At the same time, BBC1 honoured its public service commitments with programming from its On the Edge mental health season.

Secret Life of Happiness, which featured celebrities including actress Julie Christie and athlete Steve Backley talking about what true happiness means, drew 4m from 9.10-10pm.

webTitle: Human side of a changing health service

fields.headline: Human side of a changing health service
fields.standfirst: Greatest pleasure is seeing individuals fulfil potential
fields.trailText:
Name Jim McCaffery
Age 46
Job director of personnel and development, Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust
Salary around £95,000
fields.body:
Name Jim McCaffery
Age 46
Job director of personnel and development, Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust
Salary around £95,000

Jim McCaffery says HR skills are generally transferable - and he should know. Before embarking on a successful career in the NHS, he worked for blue chip private sector companies including Rolls-Royce.

He joined the health service in 1992, when the multinational company he was working for closed its London HR office. Mr McCaffery moved to Scotland to work for Grampian Healthcare, where he was director of personnel, and later deputy chief executive. He took up his current post in Leeds two years ago, following a stint at Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.

A fellow of the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development, he entered HR because he thought it would suit his degree, a BA in social sciences.

Mr McCaffery says he has a big salary for a big job: "I'm responsible for all the change management in the organisation. The most difficult part is the level of demand and the pressure of individuals," he says. "The vast majority of people understand that things will change, but they would rather they change for someone else."

Holding on to his personnel managers is also hard: "The NHS has some of the most dedicated and competent personnel people - and other organisations know that." In an effort to beat the headhunters, Mr McCaffery is involved in a project (along with PricewaterhouseCoopers, Harvard University in the US, and Manchester University) to persuade talented HR professionals they can fast track to chief executive level if they stay within the NHS.

Despite being at the heart of the trust's strategic planning, Mr McCaffery most enjoys seeing staff who have been helped to develop and fulfil their potential.

webTitle: A core role in health

fields.headline: A core role in health
fields.standfirst: Complex demands afford a great sense of achievement
fields.trailText: Case study: NHS head of human resources
fields.body:
Name Iain Patterson
Age 33
Job head of human resources, Newham primary care group
Salary around £35,000

Iain Patterson was working in an administrative post at the Department of Health when he was offered the chance to move within the organisation to become a project officer supporting the NHS human resources director.

In this job he assisted in the creation of the NHS regional office for London. He left the DoH a year-and-a-half ago to head up HR for the fledgling Newham primary care group (PCG) in east London.

Now, instead of being a cog in an HR wheel, he is inventing the wheel. "I work with the 67 general practices in Newham, helping recruit staff and build up the HR function," said Mr Patterson.

The basics of the job are identifying staffing needs, recruitment, training and development, and ensuring the PCG stays within employment law. But he also has to think beyond the basics. "Everyone in HR now has to see the strategic links between what they do and where the health service wants to be. It's about improving access, quality and services."

As the HR role in the NHS becomes more complex, the demand for well-qualified managers increases. Mr Patterson has a law degree and a masters in HR from Kingston University.

The ability to have a direct impact on patient services is one of two things he likes best about the job; the other is dealing with people on a daily basis. And the worst bit? "People asking 'what's HR? Isn't that glorified personnel?'."

His advice to anyone seeking a career in health service HR is to get the basics right first. "And never lose sight of what we are here for, which is principally to support the business of the organisation," he added.

webTitle: BA sticks with Premier Media Partners

fields.headline: BA sticks with Premier Media Partners
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: British Airways has retained Premier Media Partners to relaunch its High Life and Business Life magazines. By Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
British Airways has retained Premier Media Partners to relaunch its High Life and Business Life magazines after a six-way pitch.

Having fought off fierce competition from upmarket publisher Conde Nast and Redwood Publishing, Premier will now revamp both magazines from April.

High Life, which launched more than 30 years ago and has a circulation of 285,000, will get a "radical redesign".

New columnists - including the acerbic Julie Burchill - will be added to a line-up that already includes novelist Will Self and BBC world affairs journalist John Simpson.

Mark Jones, Premier editorial director, said that Business Life, which has a circulation of 130,000, would be remoulded as the "definitive European business magazine".

He has drafted in Alex Finer, editor of rival Virgin Atlantic's Hot Air magazine, as its new editor.

"We don't believe there is a really sharp European business mag. It will now be written for modern executives who are increasingly forced to juggle their lives," said Mr Jones.

The publisher is charged with boosting the magazines' advertising revenues with a target of £20m in ad sales over the next three years.

webTitle: That's infotainment

fields.headline: That's infotainment
fields.standfirst: Rebecca St Johnston is MD of content for Trinity Mirror's new entertainment website icShowbiz.com
fields.trailText: Rebecca St Johnston is MD of content for Trinity Mirror's new entertainment website icShowbiz.com
fields.body:
How do you think women's surfing habits differ from men's? This makes me think of the guys in my office who would quite happily sit playing on a Wap site for half a day trying to set up their Wap phones. I don't think any woman I know would bother doing that. A woman's view is that she'll use Wap when it works. Women are less tolerant in their surfing habits and less likely to meander around.

How much will unmetered access change surfing habits in the UK? Not having to worry about the cost of surfing will benefit people who are cash poor and time rich such as students and children. Given that most people connected at the moment are ABC1 demographic then an extra 10 minutes online at the weekend isn't going to make that much difference.

Is the net community generally less concerned with gender? The dotcom world tends to have teams who are younger and more liberal but at board level you can still find the old executives in grey suits. A lot of people feel everyone's taking the internet so seriously and trying so hard to make money out of it that a lot of the fun is going.

Can portals and websites ever create a real sense of community? Definitely. You can have a global, single-issue community. What the internet does best is put one fanatical person in touch with another fanatical person, whether it's pigeon fanciers, kite flyers or whatever.

How is the advent of broadband going to change things? It will enable internet publishers to move into the TV domain and it's going to allow a mass of richer content. So much of what we can do at the moment is limited to how long it might take to download.But it wouldn't suprise me if broadband ends up getting log-jammed too.

Will internet access via TV and mobile bring about a shift away from the PC? Not really because PCs will continue to develop. The one thing that puts me off the PC is how long it takes to start it up. That's a real barrier to people using the net as a reference tool. Once you get a PC that you can switch on quickly it will complement TV. They'll have different types of content delivered in different ways. If the instructions are long and boring then blokes will be playing with it and if it's really simple to use then women will.

Any favourite websites? It's a bit boring but I like Amazon because I'm an avid e-consumer and there are so few decent sites. Google is brilliant for finding specific information. Yahoo uses Google now and it seems to have the users' interest in mind. I use Jakob Nielsen's Alert Box a lot for usability issues.

For further information visit: www.icshowbiz.com

webTitle: World War 3.0: Microsoft and its Enemies by Ken Auletta

fields.headline: Chilly Messiah with a mission to blank out the competitive world
fields.trailText: On the day he rails against the courts, Gates forgets to say he has just become a father again.
fields.body:
Bill Gates's office, housed in number 8 of the 45 buildings on Microsoft's campus, has few personal flourishes. At any other Fortune 500 company, it might house someone of the rank of, say, vice president for community relations.

The desk is a slab of plain oak, and the only pictures on a wall are two framed covers from the Economist given to him by his sister Libby: they show a diagram of an Intel chip and a chart describing the bandwidth of various radio frequencies.

His PC is a Toshiba laptop with a docking station and two oversized monitors (one screen is separated into four quadrants, which stream information from selected websites all day).

A nubby grey upholstered couch rests on a beige industrial carpet in front of a square maple coffee table surrounded by four chrome-based, green and blue wool-covered Breuer-style chairs.

The only ostensible personal touches are several family pictures on a credenza behind his desk and a single picture of a doe-faced Gates beside Paul Allen, encircled by the handful of employees who helped launch Microsoft. This familiar picture, with its innocent faces, speaks to a basic Microsoft contradiction. On the one hand, it captures the youthful zeal, the idealism of people who embraced software as a tool to change the world, to do incredibly cool things. Less apparent in those unlined faces is the competitive zeal that helped trigger a government lawsuit.

On this day in the middle of the anti-trust lawsuit, Gates wore a handsome, royal blue open-necked dress shirt buttoned at the sleeves and embroidered with WHG, navy slacks, unpolished black loafers, and clear-framed oval glasses. His skin was the colour of an eggshell, a pallor born of having spent too many hours indoors.

The previous afternoon, Melinda Gates had given birth to their second child, a son, and Gates had spent part of the day at the hospital. On the day I saw him, Microsoft would announce the birth; yet even though I was not a stranger, Gates uttered not a word about this happy event.

With Gates, impersonal behaviour is the norm. Visitors are often amazed that he fetches a soda for himself and neglects to offer one to them. Upon greeting me, Gates plopped on to one of the chairs, leaned forward and folded his arms across his thighs, and began rocking rapidly back and forth, slapping the carpet with the soles of his loafers, creating the impression that his body was a metronome.

As Gates rocked back and forth in his chair during my visit, he was as agitated at what he thought of as the ludicrousness of the government's case as he had been a year before. "There is no monopoly," he told me. "Even with all the great people we have we face probably more intense competition now than ever before."

Did he sometimes feel, as a friend had said, like Joseph K, accused of crimes he did not comprehend? "I don't know Joseph K, sorry." On being told that Joseph K was the main character and victim in Franz Kafka's The Trial, Gates said, "He sounds like my kind of guy!"

The Justice Department believed Microsoft was a monopoly whose intent was to hurt Netscape. They believed Gates and his employees often behaved like thugs. Now, a year after he had failed to reach an out-of-court settlement that could have avoided this trial, did Gates regret having gone to court?

"I wish we could have settled. I wished that at the time. I wish that now." The stumbling block, he said, was that he couldn't go back to the government for permission each time he wanted to add a new feature, just because a competitor like Netscape whined about it. What about coercion, I asked - the charge that Microsoft muscled Intel to stay out of the software business? "I don't know what muscle means," he said.

What if his daughter came to him some years hence and asked, "Dad, how do you explain some of these e-mails and things like the threat to cut off Netscape's air supply?"

Gates was composed, but he answered in a shrill voice. "A great lie! A great lie!" he cried out. "An unbelievable lie!" It was secondhand hearsay, he said. His voice rising, yet controlled, he went on, "Did anyone utter those words? Our e-mail, every piece of it has been searched. I wish we had found somebody who had said it. Then we could take him out, and we could hang the guy, then we'd say, 'OK, mea culpa. We found him - the guy who said I'll cut off your oxygen'."

"First of all, there's no law against saying that. Second of all, I never heard anybody say it. Third of all - hey, if there's any company that you know damn well whether it was said or not, this is the company. Every piece of e-mail I have ever sent for the last 10 years has been read and read, and if there is any way that people can misconstrue any statement that I've ever made it has been done. You look at any e-mail sent by me or received by me and tell me what it is you think is at all inappropriate?"

Microsoft executives don't see themselves the way they are portrayed in a courtroom 3,000 miles away. By contrast, to a monopolist who has the luxury of sitting back and behaving in a leisurely fashion, Microsoft executives feel embattled.

Dr James Allchin, who supervised Windows, said: "I feel like we're on the brink of disaster every day. If you're reading newspapers and watching what's happening - new devices, new operating systems, attacks that claim intellectual property means nothing - it's like a massive attack all the time."

External threats

He worried about an attack from Sony and its "fixed game machines, because they're growing up", about cable boxes that could control all home electronics, about handheld personal digital assistants that can perform multiple tasks, about open-source software, about the "megaserver threat" posed by an AOL online operating system where "once you're in an AOL environment, you're in it holistically", about how the distinction between hardware and software companies blurs as Intel and Dell and IBM invest in software, and AT&T is now a cable and an internet-access as well as a telephone company.

Microsoft in 1999 spent an extraordinary $3bn on research and development. This represented about 17% of its revenues, a figure that dwarfs the 6% IBM spent, or the 10% of revenues expended by such companies as Intel and Sun.

A sizable portion of this budget is earmarked for pure research - for recruiting and funding the best physicists and mathematicians and electrical engineers to undertake theoretical work that does not have a clear product payoff. In an era when such theoretical research is usually sacrificed as impractical and companies strive to cut costs and drive up their stock price, Microsoft is a rare oasis.

It is also, needless to say, a place seeking to dominate the realm of new products: an electronic encyclopedia on Africa, Encarta Africa; browsers for wireless devices; web television, which brings e-mail and the web to television sets; PCs that accept voice commands and translate handwriting into type; PCs in cars that function as radios and CD players; and navigation devices that offer voice instructions.

Rick Thompson, vice president of the hardware group, described his 225-employee division as "my own little sandbox". Most of their research efforts fail after they come to market. "It's a lot like the movie business. There are a lot of flops."

Doug Heinrich, who is director of business development and is working on speech and handwriting recognition, said the plan was to include at least some of these innovative features in a version of Windows 2000.

At Microsoft, what the US government calls "bundling" is referred to as "integration", and not without reason. Integration lets programs running on Windows interact seamlessly, allowing users to switch back and forth with greater speed and ease than ever before.

Microsoft claims such additions serve consumers. The US justice department claims they were intended to solidify Microsoft's monopoly. They probably do both. After all, Microsoft benefited consumers by reducing the price of browsers, and at the same time they undermined Netscape.

Microsoft executives see themselves as upright, public-spirited citizens. Three quarters of all Microsoft employees made philanthropic gifts that were matched by the company, resulting in up to $30m in corporate donations to support homeless shelters, zoos, and efforts in 20 cities. Another $70m-$100m of software was donated by Microsoft to schools and libraries.

While Gates's company has been quietly generous, Gates himself was at first reluctant to part with his money. Like his friend Warren Buffett, he said that philanthropy takes effort and time, which he didn't have. He was planning to wait until he was old and then would give most of his fortune away.

In the last several years, Gates has dramatically altered this stance and become the world's foremost philanthropist, having by January 2000 pledged $21.8bn to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, making it the world's wealthiest charitable foundation.

In today's currency, Rockefeller's donations would have totalled $6bn and Carnegie's $3bn. Both Buffett and Gates Senior attribute the change to Melinda, who has more time to devote to charity. "Melinda has spurred him," said Buffett.

Cynics attribute these gifts to a Gates public-relations offensive designed to offset the black eye he has received from the trial. While press considerations may have been a factor in the timing of some gifts, that's a pretty steep price to pay for publicity.

At Microsoft, executives and programmers speak of their work with genuine reverence - they can be as pious as mullahs or priests. When Ben Waldman, who oversaw relations with Apple, is asked to describe the culture of Microsoft, he says with utter solemnity, "People are very passionate about creating great products... We do things to help people solve problems."

New frontiers

What is surprising is that one would be hard-pressed to find an employee who frankly admits that Microsoft is a for-profit company in the business of making money, not a beneficent foundation serving the public interest.

Yusuf Mehdi, who directs marketing for Windows, talks of his work as if it were the frontier of medical science. "There's the same feeling you have in college - I can do something great!" How did he square these sentiments, I asked, with the sometimes John Gotti-like behaviour described in court? "What I would say is that a lot of this legal stuff comes from competitors, not from end users. What the trial is is sensationalist bits and pieces. The trial was supposed to be about bundling. I'm not saying we're not aggressive. We get after it. But it's in the interest of doing what's best for customers."

Such sanctimony is common at Microsoft, from Bill Gates down. "What we aim to do is to make tools to make people's lives better," Gates once told a congressional hearing. There is a tendency at Microsoft to talk about consumers, not profits. No doubt, Microsoft could not recruit the best and brightest without conveying a belief that it is waging a holy war to better serve consumers, improve computing, do 'cool' things.

But it is weird that Microsoft executives rarely speak of fat profits or rich stock options, although executives in their twenties drive BMWs and those in their thirties establish private foundations and often retire, and Microsoft hogs as profit an extraordinary forty cents of each revenue dollar it collects. Jean-Louis Gassée, the CEO of rival software firm Be, once likened Microsoft's behaviour to that of believers in a religious order, "The Jesuits have this concept of holy effrontery - in defending their cause it's OK to use any means."

webTitle: Homing in on the frontline of housing

fields.headline: Homing in on the frontline of housing
fields.standfirst: Good organisation, well honed people skills and a sense of humour are more important than paper qualifications when working as a housing officer
fields.trailText: Good organisation, well honed people skills and a sense of humour are more important than paper qualifications when working as a housing officer, writes Rosalynd Bayley
fields.body:
The ad runs something like this: "Good promotion prospects for a well-organised person with experience of dealing with customers face to face."

If you saw such an advertisement, you'd probably run a mile, picturing yourself frying burgers on the minimum wage until you finally flip and quit. But if the job in question is at the frontline of housing management, the words may be a surprisingly reliable guide to what lies in store. Certainly, people skills are at a premium.

A housing officer (or housing assistant, tenant services or community housing officer - or whatever other title the job may have) will be expected to interview prospective tenants, chase up rent arrears, intervene to resolve disputes between neighbours.

All too often people's contact with the housing office may be at a point of crisis, for example when their home is flooded, they are experiencing domestic violence or they are about to be evicted. It is life in the raw.

To survive as a housing officer, a strong personality and a good sense of humour will count for a lot more than paper qualifications. And though qualifications are becoming more important, the housing profession has tried to ensure that those who start on the frontline have the chance of promotion.

The most common route to qualification is a part-time degree or diploma on a day release basis. Often people start courses in their late 20s and 30s. There are also BTEC and HNC courses for those with a less academic background. According to Chartered Institute of Housing (CIH) head of education Roger Keller: "People come into housing from a wide range of backgrounds. We are trying to find the right pathways so that no one is debarred from getting qualifications."

At least as challenging is making sure that courses remain appropriate for a rapidly evolving profession. National Housing Federation (NHF) head of housing management and support Kathleen Boyle says housing management has changed out of all recognition. Where it was once a mainstream tenure for people in work, people living in social housing are more likely to be poor and have other problems. The NHF also runs short courses and training programmes.

"Social landlords have to see housing management as about making a neighbourhood a viable place for people to live," Ms Boyle says.

In organisations that have embraced this social inclusion agenda, housing officers may be expected to become like community workers, combining with residents to develop child care facilities or job training, or setting up partnerships with the police or youth service to cut crime or provide activities outside school hours.

If that doesn't appeal, there are plenty of other jobs to move to, particularly as the CIH professional qualification of the future will be all about providing people with interchangeable skills. Developing new homes, providing housing for people with special needs, helping homeowners improve their homes, working in housing policy or even taking up an academic career - take your pick. Perhaps it is time to put that burger bar experience to good use.

Housing courses - the facts

 27 universities offered courses validated by the CIH in 1999/2000

 a total of 4,500 students were on housing education courses of all kinds in 1999/2000

 part-time undergraduate courses, including HNC: 1600

 part-time post-graduate courses: 700

 full-time undergraduate courses: 464

 full-time post-graduate courses: 177

 ethnic background of students: 70% white, 15% black, 4% Asian, 12% other

Source: CIH

 To a receive a copy of the Chartered Institute of Housing prospectus, email education@cih.org

webTitle: Ability and keenness build a first class housing career

fields.headline: Ability and keenness build a first class housing career
fields.standfirst: Filled with enthusiasm - but no formal qualifications - former housing trust secretary Sue Black has progressed to senior management
fields.trailText:
Name Sue Black
Age 50
Job director of operations, Notting Hill Housing Trust
Salary £70,000
fields.body:
Name Sue Black
Age 50
Job director of operations, Notting Hill Housing Trust
Salary £70,000

Sue Black's first housing job was as a secretary, in 1974. Based in the development department of Notting Hill Housing Trust, the team she worked with was converting rundown Victorian houses - which are now worth a minister's ransom.

As Ms Black says, maybe it was her enthusiasm, or simply that "the chaps - as they all were in those days ­ were a bit lazy", but she ended up running the department.

Her first housing management experience came a few years later when she was promoted to manage an area office. After having a baby and returning to work, she was given the job of running a trust subsidiary providing homes for sale. At one point was responsible for the trust's charity shops.

Her current job involves overseeing management of the trust's 14,000 homes as well as supported housing and temporary lettings for homeless people.

Ms Black feels lucky that the Notting Hill Housing Trust was an organisation keen to promote talent and she was able to rise to the top despite having only two A-levels - having always been "too busy" to pick up any further qualifications.

Ms Black is optimistic that despite the profession attracting many more graduates, others with a similar background can still achieve what she has - if they are bright and keen. Indeed, Ms Black feels there is a positive advantage in not having climbed the housing management ladder the conventional way. "Coming from outside, I say, 'Why do you do it like that?'. That gives an impetus to improve the service," she says.

webTitle: Ken's Manhattan transfer

fields.headline: Ken's Manhattan transfer
fields.standfirst:
As New York's Mayor Giuliani prepares to bow out, his opposite number in London visits the Big Apple for a few tips, writes Jane Martinson.
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: As New York's Mayor Giuliani prepares to bow out, his opposite number in London visits the Big Apple for a few tips, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
As a farewell, it was more "you ain't seen nothing yet". In his last State of the City address in New York this week, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani offered a blueprint for his final year in office that included proposals for a new opera house and a baseball hall of fame.

Before a backdrop of a sparkling city skyline, Giuliani also laid out plans for a skating rink in Queens and a military academy in the Bronx.

These more lasting monuments to his eight-year legacy in charge of the city that never sleeps were joined by a plan to make sure schoolchildren stay awake more too. Giuliani called for $34m (£22m) to be set aside from the city budget to allow schools to stay open at the weekend for extra classes as well as the immediate construction of 12 new schools and more summer school places.

It was an oddly emotional event by all accounts. Speaking without notes for almost two hours, the usually hard-hitting Mayor received a standing ovation from a packed council chamber.

This bravura performance came on the eve of the first visit to the city by London's own most senior representative. Ken Livingstone arrives in New York on Monday to meet Giuliani as part of a two-day visit across the Atlantic.

A spokesman for the greater London authority said Livingstone wanted to "look particularly at the way New York has accelerated economic regeneration and growth". So a trip to the fancy new dockside development of Battery Park is planned, as well as a stopover in Harlem and a chat with the New York police department. There will also be time to visit a homegrown dot com trying to make it in the Big Apple.

The problem is, Giuliani seems less keen on his old favourite zero-tolerance policies than he was. This document, mandated by the act that established the mayoral post, will use some of the findings of a Mori poll conducted by the GLA to find out what Londoners really want.

The two men will sign a partnership agreement next week although officials in both cities were less than clear about what this would entail yesterday. An obviously discomfited British mandarin said it was 'not going to be a twin town' with its connotations of school exchange trips.

Imagine how long it would go on for in London, what with the tube and the weather and the oil blockades.

Before a backdrop of a sparkling city skyline, Giuliani also laid out plans for a skating rink in Queens and a military academy in the Bronx. webTitle: Chile proves truth will out

fields.headline: Chile proves truth will out
fields.standfirst: Serbia and China must eventually confront their past horrors, argues foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: Serbia and China must eventually confront their past horrors, argues foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
This week saw three very different countries struggling to come to terms with their past. In each case, the debate is taking place against a recent historical backdrop of bloodshed, deep political divisions, and social turmoil.

But although the context may be similar, these national inquests show there are many, varied paths to truth and reconciliation. - and none of them is easy.

In Chile, the process was in one sense thrust upon the country by events beyond its control. The key event was a Spanish judge's issuance of an arrest order for the country's former military dictator, General Augusto Pinochet.

That unexpected initiative led, famously, to Pinochet's arrest in London during a private visit and to subsequent extradition proceedings that ended last year with his return to Chile on medical grounds.

The controversy surrounding Pinochet's detention in Britain brought to the surface a long-suppressed debate in Chile about terrible legacy of the years of military-led rule from 1973 to 1990.

Contrary to the expectations of many, relatives of thousands of Pinochet opponents who disappeared without trace were emboldened to press their case for a full accounting. They found support from an investigating magistrate, Judge Juan Guzman.

Far from being the end of the matter, Pinochet's release by Britain proved to be only the start of Chile's hunt for the truth. A can of worms had been opened and now refused to be shut.

Amid continuing attempts by Pinochet to take refuge behind amnesty laws enacted by his own regime, Chile's recently-elected socialist president, Ricardo Lagos, went on national television last Sunday and weighed in to the debate.

What he had to say was explosive. Lagos gave blood-curdling details of the fate of 180 detainees missing from the Pinochet years, including the dumping of bodies from helicopters into the Pacific. He revealed the existence of a mass grave in Santiago. He said he was asking the supreme court to investigate the new information with despatch.

Lagos's action has effectively ensured that not only will inquiries into past atrocities not be buried in legal argument - but that they will expand in scope and detail. Even if 85-year-old Pinochet, who claims to be ill, does not live to see it, it now seems more likely than ever that Chile will eventually confront the truth about itself.

Serbia provides a quite different story. Nearly a month after the democratic opposition confirmed its ascendancy in parliamentary elections following last autumn's overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, there is still no consensus about what to do about Milosevic and other individuals indicted by the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Although Biljana Plavsic, a former aide to Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, flew voluntarily to the Hague this week, there have been no arrests of war criminals wanted in connection with Serbia's wars in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo for more than six months.

Vojislav Kostunica, the new Yugoslav president, is on record as saying that Serbia must examine its past and punish the guilty. But when it comes to arresting and handing over Milosevic and other top suspects like Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general, he havers and stalls. No m echanisms have yet been created in Serbia itself for examining more broadly what happened during the Milosevic years.

There is as yet no South African-style truth and reconciliation commission, no investigating magistrate like Judge Guzman. Many Serbs, duped by Milosevic's propaganda machine and misled by state-controlled television and radio, still have no idea of the extent of the crimes committed in their name during more than a decade of strife.

And tentative discussions about setting up a Hague subsidiary tribunal inside Serbia to try Milosevic have so far come to nothing.

Unlike Chile, where the threat of "communism" (the pretext for Pinochet's coup) has long since receded, Serbs apparently still feel threatened by hostile forces. In their case, it is the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo and southern Serbia and to a lesser extent, secessionists in the Yugoslav republic of Montenegro.

For these reasons among others, Serbia's ability to move forward to a better future looks like being hampered for some time to come by its limited willingness to open its eyes to the past.

China, on the other hand, or at least China's rulers, present a picture of total denial when it comes to certain events in their recent history. This was amply illustrated this week by Beijing's angry rejection of documents published in the US purporting to shed light on the massacre in Tiananmen Square in June 1989.

The "Tiananmen papers" detailed for the first time disputes within the Communist leadership over how best to deal with the pro-democracy student movement. It is still not known to this day how many people died in the square when party hardliners prevailed and the tanks went in. But the toll was undoubtedly in the hundreds.

Discussion of these events, and the subsequent suppression of political dissent, is banned in China. The official view is almost that it did not happen at all. Hence the foreign ministry's furious denunciation of the Tiananmen papers as fakes put about by China's enemies.

For a moment, after the papers' publication, it had seemed that China might finally be ready to talk about this national trauma.

Then the lid slammed shut again. Who knows when the accounting will finally take place? But one thing is certain: it will one day. Ask the people of Chile.

webTitle: Charities grill the government on volunteer plan

fields.headline: Charities grill the government on volunteer plan
fields.standfirst: Charities question whether challenging the government will affect their chances of receiving funding.
fields.trailText: Charities question whether challenging the government will affect their chances of receiving funding. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
Charities broadly welcomed the announcements made today but questioned the role of the government in promoting volunteering and showed anxiety about whether voluntary organisations could continue to challenge government and still rely on receiving funding.

Lord Brian Rix, of Mencap, said: "While I welcome the news, there is a lack of mention of people with disabilities in the announcement of funding. Disabled people should be given addition resources to help them volunteer."

Home Office minister Paul Boateng replied: "We recognise that there are many people among those with disabilities who want to volunteer and we are determined to work with organisations like yours to ensure this happens. It has to be looked at as part of achieving the aim set out by the prime minister last year of encouraging one million more volunteers by the year 2004."

Lord Ralf Dahrendorf, former director of the London School of Economics, said: "Although I give my unconditional support to the proposals there is the vexed question of how you give money at arm's length. I regret that we do not have large private organisations like the Ford Foundation in the USA which could give money to voluntary organisations rather than the government."

Chancellor Gordon Brown replied: "We have reformed the charity tax law and hope Britain will now see the development of foundations in the same way as the US."

Paul Boateng added: "I agree with you that it is very important to safeguard the independence of the voluntary sector. We are not senior partners and the compact between the government and the voluntary sector is a guarantee of that independence."

Claire Rayner asked: "Will this create a tension as part of the work of the voluntary is to provide constructive criticism - does it have to bite its tongue in order to get funding?"

Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer replied: "The voluntary sector has to be separate from government. It emphatically does not have to bite its tongue, otherwise it can't be independent."

Gordon Lishman, chief executive of Age Concern, asked: "There will be a substantial increase in older people from ethnic minorities - is the government specifically addressing this? And how joined up will these initiatives be, for example will the New Deal for over 50s be linked with regeneration and the promotion of positive health?"

Paul Boateng replied: "I am well aware of the needs of older people from ethnic minority communities and we are seeking within the Active Community Unit to put in place the infrastructure to address capacity issues."

Local government minister Hilary Armstrong added: "You would be surprised by the amount of time we spend making sure we know what each other is doing. Next week there will be further announcements about how we are seeking to integrate national strategy and how this can be coordinated at a local level."

There was a further plea for consistency across government from Elisabeth Hoodless, executive director of CSV. She followed on from a question about making the application process simple, by asking for money to be paid monthly in advance rather than in arrears. Some government departments pay up to 10 weeks in arrears, forcing voluntary organisations to rely on friendly bank managers and paying interest. "This excludes a number of agencies."

Gordon Brown promised to look into this matter.

The final question focused on the impending charge to be levied on voluntary organisations for police checks on volunteers who will be working with vulnerable people. Paul Boateng said the government would shortly be coming to a conclusion about this matter but they had taken on board the concerns of the voluntary sector.

webTitle: Obituary: Stuart Lancaster

fields.headline: Stuart Lancaster
fields.trailText: Stuart Lancaster was best known for his roles in Russ Meyer's "sexploitation" films. One of the stalwarts of Meyer's "repertory company", he was invariably the older figure of authority and could play nice or nasty.
fields.body:
Stuart Lancaster, who has died aged 80, was best known for his roles in Russ Meyer's "sexploitation" films. One of the stalwarts of Meyer's "repertory company", he was invariably the older figure of authority and could play nice or nasty. He was a lecherous, crippled ranch-owner in Faster Pussycat! Kill!Kill! (1966), now regarded as a classic of the exploitation genre. (For director John Waters, it is "beyond a doubt, the best movie ever made".) As the narrator of Beneath the Valley of the Ultravixens (1979), Lancaster encapsulated Meyer's anti-establishment ethos.

Yet his passion throughout his life was theatre. He spent most of an inheritance producing plays at his own theatre in Florida and at the end of his career was a member of a studio theatre in Los Angeles, where he acted, directed, and, on occasion, did the lighting. Other company members were only vaguely aware of his shady past in soft porn.

Lancaster was born in Evanston, Illinois, the grandson of one of the Ringling brothers, circus pioneers, and grew up in Sarasota, Florida, where the circus had its winter quarters. While studying art at college in 1936, he appeared in a play and decided to study acting at the Cleveland Playhouse in Ohio.

After the second world war, during which he flew with the Naval Air Force, he continued training with the American Theatre Wing, a scheme for demobbed GIs.

In 1952, with money left to him by his mother, Lancaster opened the Palm Tree Playhouse in Sarasota. He told film producer David Friedman that the first payment from the trust, $400,000, was gone in two months. Towards the end of its life, Lancaster further propped up the doomed enterprise by appearing in a local TV series, Tallahassee 7000 (1961).

It was when he closed the Playhouse in 1962 and left for Hollywood that he met Meyer and went on to appear in six of his films. There was a lull in the partnership from 1967 to 1971 because he had upset Meyer by asking him when he was going to make "a really good picture".

In 1969, during the feud, Lancaster played a sleazy film producer in Starlet! and Capulet in The Secret Sex Lives of Romeo and Juliet. In the 80s he appeared in Batman Returns and Edward Scissorhands, both for director Tim Burton.

By this time Lancaster was working mainly with the Colony Studio Theatre in Los Angeles. As the company's elder statesman he starred in classics of the American repertoire, playing Willy Loman in Death of a Salesman, Reverend Casey in The Grapes of Wrath, and Big Julie in Guys and Dolls. His biography in the programmes never mentioned the Meyer films.

In 1993, while on stage in the comedy You Can't Take It With You, he suffered a stroke, but went on to finish the performance. He later had small non-speaking roles in Incident at Vichy (1995) and City of Angels (1996), his last stage appearance.

His sixth wife, actress Ivy Bethune, whom he married in 1971, survives him. He was the father of four sons and a daughter.

 Stuart Lancaster, actor, born November 30 1920; died December 29 2000

webTitle: DoubleClick foresees advertising slowdown

fields.headline: DoubleClick foresees advertising slowdown
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Online ad group DoubleClick is bracing itself for a rocky ride as the US economic slowdown hits revenues, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online advertising group DoubleClick is bracing itself for a rocky ride in the first half of the year as the US economic slowdown hits revenues.

DoubleClick today reports its fourth quarter results amid a climate of mounting panic over advertising trends, as dot.com startups run out of cash and revenues fail to meet the heights of last year.

"With an economic slowdown, advertising budgets will be hit," said Eric Stein, head of DoubleClick's international media operations.

"Advertising across the whole media industry will be affected as people cut back their spending in the first and second quarter of 2001."

Mr Stein added that the long-term future for online advertising was positive, and DoubleClick's share of the overall media advertising market will increase.

"The effects of a slowdown in the US will be short-term, and in the long-term we intend to capture a significant proportion of the market," he said.

Analysts are expecting DoubleClick to announce fourth quarter losses, and expect rivals such as ValueClick and Mediaplex to announce similar results over the coming month.

The global new media sales house is insulated by a £600m war chest, and is seen as one of the strongest players in the sector, although the coming months will test its mettle.

DoubleClick plans, runs and tracks advertising campaigns for firms over the internet, and hopes to make its DART technology the standard tool for the sector.

Meanwhile, the company's European operations have undergone a management reshuffle, which will see Adrian Baker become managing director of DoubleClick UK and Mark Gibson head up the marketing of DoubleClick's technology arm in northern Europe.

fields.headline: Colin Farrell's career continues to skyrocket
fields.standfirst: Plus: Gary Oldman shows his artistry in Milos Forman biopic; Anthony Hopkins joins Chris Rock in Jerry Bruckheimer buddy movie
fields.trailText: Plus: Gary Oldman shows his artistry in Milos Forman biopic; Anthony Hopkins joins Chris Rock in Jerry Bruckheimer buddy movie
fields.body:
 Irish actor Colin Farrell (pictured) looks set to star alongside Tom Cruise in the new £50m (£33.6m) thriller Minority Report to be directed by Steven Spielberg. According to ananova, Cruise wants Farrell to play the role originally slated for Matt Damon, who dropped out of the project last year. Farrell, who has already received much critical acclaim for his performance in Joel Schumacher's Vietnam saga Tigerland, is likely to receive $1m (£672,000) for the role. According to a 'senior source' close to the production: "Cruise saw some cuts of Farrell from Tigerland and was bowled over. He thinks the guy is incredible. There is absolutely no doubt that he will soon be in the A list."

 ananova reports that Gary Oldman is rumoured to have signed up to appear in a new biopic about the Spanish artist Goya. Oldman, who has previously played Sid Vicious in Sid and Nancy and playwright Joe Orton in Prick Up Your Ears, is apparently fascinated by the 18th-century painter, engraver and one-time bullfighter who died in 1828. The film will be directed by Milos Forman and produced by his long-term working partner Saul Zaentz, who previously worked together on 1975's One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest and 1984's Amadeus, and the pair are hoping for another hit. Forman told ananova: "I don't know how we both came to think Goya would be a wonderful subject but we have a pretty good success rate. So, it will be third time lucky again for us. We hope!"

 Anthony Hopkins is to play a veteran CIA agent in Jerry Bruckhemier's latest film, Black Sheep. According to popcorn, Hopkins will star alongside Chris Rock in the project which will go into production in March. Hopkins will next be seen on our screens in the Silence of the Lambs sequel Hannibal which is scheduled for release in the UK on February 16

webTitle: In brief: Angelina Jolie signs on for two more Tomb Raiders

fields.headline: Angelina Jolie signs on for two more Tomb Raiders
fields.standfirst: Plus: Guy Pearce turns his back on Hollywood to direct in Australia; Roddy Doyle movie given thumbs up at Toronto Film Festival
fields.trailText: Plus: Guy Pearce turns his back on Hollywood to direct in Australia; Roddy Doyle movie given thumbs up at Toronto Film Festival
fields.body:
 Angelina Jolie (pictured) has confirmed that she has signed up to play Lara Croft in two more Tomb Raider films. Jolie told Empire magazine that she is not the only one of the cast of this summer's highly anticipated blockbuster who will be returning. "Quite a few of us are signed up for two more," she told the magazine.

 Memento star Guy Pearce has rejected Hollywood offers in favour of the chance to direct a low-budget movie in his native Australia. A source close to Pearce says the actor was keen to "return to his roots" adding, "Guy is very much an Australian and he loves being at home just outside Sydney with his family living in seclusion." He has decided to direct Blood and Guts even though Hollywood producers have apparently offered him a lot of money to stay in Los Angeles. "They were willing to throw buckets of the stuff at him," the source continued, "but he just jumped on a plane and politely said 'no way'"

 When Brendan Met Trudy has won rave reviews at the Toronto Film Festival where Canadian critics have hailed the film, which features Roddy Doyle's first original screenplay, as the funniest film to come out of Ireland since 1998's Waking Ned. The film stars Peter McDonald as a dull history teacher named Brendan whose life changes dramatically when he meets fellow teacher Trudy. It also features Pauline McLynn and Flora Montgomery, who starred in the short movie The Perfect Blue.

webTitle: UK advertisers spending less

fields.headline: Falling ad spend sparks fears of slowdown
fields.standfirst:
Click here for table
11.15am: Traditional media spend falling
fields.trailText:
12.45pm update: Spending by the UK's top 30 advertisers fell £64m last year prompting fears of a slowdown, writes Daniel Rogers.
Click here for table
11.15am: Traditional media spend falling
fields.body:
Spending by the UK's top 30 advertisers fell £64m last year prompting fears of a serious slowdown in the sector.

The fall was partly due to dramatic cutbacks at soap giant Procter & Gamble.

Overall spend on brands such as Ariel and Pampers dropped by staggering 25% from £153.5m to £114m in just 11 months.

And arch-rival Lever Brothers, which is responsible for brands including Persil and Lynx, cut back its ad spending by 17%.

The 5% year-on-year decline to November 2000 for the top 30 is even worse when a 3.2% increase in UK inflation over the same period is taken into consideration.

ACNielsen MMS's survey shows that car companies also dramatically reduced their spend. Vauxhall made a 32% (£26m) cut and the troubled Rover Group reduced ad spend by 33.5% (£14m).

The figures would have been much worse had it not been for the media and telecoms companies.

Vodafone increased its spend by more than 100% (£22m), BSkyB by 41.6% (£13m) and BT 25% (£20m).

The government has also controversially increased its spending on advertising, through the Central Office of Information, by 16.4% (£13.5m).

ACNielsen's report shows that the 2.3% overall growth in advertising on traditional media over the same period lags well behind inflation, revealing the first fall in real ad spend since the recession in the early 1990s.

Some observers believe the fall can be attributed to a diversion of marketing spend towards new digital media. But the author of the report, Jeremy Ridgway, believes this does not make up the shortfall.

"There has been some change in direction, but I don't have evidence that P&G is investing as much as £40m in new media ad spend," said Mr Ridgway, associate director of AC Nielsen.

Many big advertisers have cut back dramatically on TV ad spend, blaming over-inflated airtime.

One reason for this was the sudden surge of advertising by new dot.com brands which didn't have the buying power to negotiate good rates with ITV.

webTitle: Hall confirms Royal Opera House post

fields.headline: Hall confirms Royal Opera House post
fields.standfirst: Jan 11: Top opera job for BBC news chief
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Tony Hall has confirmed to BBC staff that he has accepted the top job at the Royal Opera House, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 11: Top opera job for BBC news chief
fields.body:
Tony Hall has confirmed to BBC staff that he has accepted the top job at the Royal Opera House.

In a press statement, Sir Colin Southgate, chairman of the Board of the Royal Opera House, said Mr Hall's "extensive experience of managing complex budgets and working in a fast moving creative environment make him ideally suited to this position."

Mr Hall's departure is believed to have been co-ordinated to allow him to collect his BBC pension, estimated to be worth £100,000, as he joins the Royal Opera House.

A senior broadcast journalist said that the pension would not "fructify" until Mr Hall's 50th birthday in March.

Discussions over the appointment are believed to have stalled over money, as Mr Hall earns £251,000 including bonuses, and the previous incumbent, Michael Kaiser, is understood to have earned around £150,000 per annum.

Mr Hall said in his announcement: "It's going to be hard to leave the BBC".

His departure clears the way for the BBC to appoint a successor to the role.

The front-runner is widely acknowledged to be deputy director of news Richard Sambrook, with head of television news Roger Mosey and assistant director of news Mark Damazer also in the running.

BBC sources played down new speculation that the head of ITV news at ITN, Nigel Dacre, was also a candidate for the post.

Mr Hall, who has been director of BBC news since 1990, is associated with the regime of the previous incumbent, John Birt.

He was a candidate for the job of director-general, taken by Greg Dyke, and is thought to have briefed the press against Mr Dyke.

webTitle: Coup for war crimes tribunal but big fish remain free

fields.headline: Coup for war crimes tribunal but big fish remain free
fields.standfirst: The war crimes tribunal faces a crucial year as its head tiptoes through Balkan politics to try to bring the worst offenders to justice, writes Ian Traynor
fields.trailText: The war crimes tribunal faces a crucial year as its head tiptoes through Balkan politics to try to bring the worst offenders to justice, writes Ian Traynor in Zagreb
fields.body:
The new year has got off to a promising start for the international human rights lobby with the surrender to the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague of the Bosnian Serb biologist, politician, and nationalist, Biljana Plavsic, to face charges of genocide against Bosnia's Muslims in the 1992-95 war.

Mrs Plavsic was one of the key political players orchestrating the orgy of ethnic pogroms in Bosnia. But there are bigger Balkan names waiting to be extradited to a cell on the North Sea. This year will be crucial in deciding whether Carla Del Ponte of Switzerland, the chief prosecutor in the Hague, can net the big fish.

The politics of war crimes in the Balkans are acute and getting trickier by the week. Things were black-and-white when Serbia and Croatia were ruled by the brutish megalomaniacs, Slobodan Milosevic and Franjo Tudjman.

But the democratic revival in Croatia a year ago following Tudjman's death and Serbia's October revolution overthrowing a decade of despotism under Milosevic turn things various shades of grey.

The war crimes issue is so delicate that it could trigger the collapse of the Croatian government of the prime minister, Ivica Racan, and jeopardise the stability of the new Serbian administration under Zoran Dzindzic and Vojislav Kostunica.

In Belgrade, the big issue is the biggest of them all - the fate of Milosevic, already indicted by the Hague for war crimes against Kosovo but also being investigated for licensing and sponsoring the Bosnian bloodbath.

In Zagreb, the trickiest problem is the earlier Croatian war of independence, with senior military figures being investigated for alleged crimes against Serbs within Croatia during the whirlwind offensives that won Croatia its war against Belgrade in the summer of 1995.

Del Ponte is poised to go on the offensive. She goes to Zagreb on Monday for difficult negotiations with the Croatian leaership. She wants to see the Croatian army chief of staff, Petar Stipetic, in the Hague in connection with Operation Storm, the Croatian blitzkrieg of August 1995 which essentially ended the war against Belgrade and the Yugoslav army.

After four years of partitioning Croatia and occupying a quarter of its territory, the Serb rebels were forced to beat a hasty retreat and 150,000 Serb civilians were forced to flee in a mass exodus from lands they had settled for hundreds of years. That atrocities occurred is not in doubt.

But Operation Storm is a source of Croatian national pride and a rallying point for the bitter nationalists who see the popular post-Tudjman President Stipe Mesic as a traitor and are bent on making maximum trouble for the Racan government.

Under Mesic and Racan, Croatia has undergone a sea-change, has been co-operating fully with the Hague, investigating its own citizens for crimes against Serbs, and Mesic even went to the Hague to provide secret testimony.

But the democrat Mesic also appointed Stipetic his army chief of staff last year and the government is deeply uncomfortable with the notion that its officers could face charges when no Serbs have been arrested or prosecuted for the atrocities perpetrated in the main 1991 phase of the Serb-Croat war, notably at the destroyed Danube town of Vukovar in November 1991.

Three Serb officers have been indicted for the mass murder of scores of patients taken from Vukovar hospital that November and buried in a farmyard mass grave. But they remain at large in Serbia.

First things first, says Zagreb. the Hague should concentrate on "the chronology and gravity" of the war crimes. Otherwise, it warns, it could revert to Tudjman-style obstruction and block cooperation with the tribunal.

If Del Ponte faces delicate negotiations in Zagreb on Monday, the challenge is even greater when she moves on to Belgrade a week later. President Kostunica of Yugoslavia is a trenchant critic of the tribunal which he views as an American plaything and a political, not a judicial instrument.

If the Bosnians, Croats, and Albanians see the Serbs as the villains, the Serbs see themselves as the victims in the wars of the past decade. The Croats have extradited several suspects to The Hague. The Serbs have not sent anyone.

Milosevic is at the top of Del Ponte's manhunt along with Radovan Karadzic and General Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb leaders. As in Croatia, any concessions to The Hague by Belgrade provide ammunition for nationalist troublemakers to threaten the democrats. Kostunica's contempt for the Hague is one of the reasons for his popularity at home.

But given time, things may change. No Serb can be free, while Milosevic remains at liberty, said the new Serbian justice minister-designate, Vladan Batic.

"We have been a Balkan banana republic. We need new institutions... No law-based state can be established if lawlessness, crime, corruption, and abuses are its foundations and if those responsible for this people's sufferings continue to be free."

It is clear that the new Serb leaders want to put Milosevic on trial at home for crimes against Serbs, not least for political reasons. But Batic said that the Hague dilemma could be settled within two months.

If war crimes and how to deal with the Hague are dividing the Croatian government, the Milosevic case could also bring the first big split in the new Serbian government.

Kostunica has yet to agree to see Del Ponte when she finally gets to Belgrade.

webTitle: Brown's volunteer army targets over 50s

fields.headline: Brown's volunteer army targets over 50s
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown announced a £300m package today to support the voluntary sector and promote volunteering, particularly among people over 50.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown announced a £300m package today to support the voluntary sector and promote volunteering, particularly among people over 50.

Some of the money has already been announced such as the £70m for the Children's Fund announced last year. However, the new tranche of money promised today includes £60m, which will be used to develop mentoring and modernise the infrastructure of voluntary and community groups and £50m, which will be allocated to community groups in deprived areas. More details on this will be announced shortly.

The largest chunk of money will be spent on a new National Experience Corp to encourage the over 50s to volunteer in the public services. The government wants older people to pass on their skills and experience to young parents and children as well helping older people in need.

Lady Sally Greengross, former chief executive of Age Concern, will be heading up an advisory panel of experts to develop ways of tapping into the resources of the ageing population. The government is particularly keen to channel the free time of the post-war baby boomers into supporting the work of hospitals, schools, libraries and prisons.

Chancellor Gordon Brown said: "This is partnership with the voluntary sector not a cut-price alternative."

He added: "The next five years will see the role of government shift even more from the old 'directing and controlling' to enabling and empowering voluntary action. Increasingly the voluntary sector will be empowered to play a critical role ranging from under-five provision and preventative health, to adult learning and the war against unemployment and poverty." Adding in an unscripted aside: "If that is it's choice"

This is the point which concerned chief executive of the National Centre of Volunteering, Sir Christopher Spence, who told SocietyGuardian.co.uk after the event that he was worried about whether the money would be used for "support or control". "It will be interesting to see how far the government can let go and enable the voluntary sector to do what it is good at - harnessing the spirit of volunteering."

Sir Christopher also questioned whether there would be money available for entrepreneurial voluntary action at a local level or whether the money would only be spent on specific schemes chosen by the government. "It takes investment in infrastructure at a local level to encourage good social entrepreneurs," he said.

Money has already been allocated to schemes from the new funding, including £420,000 to the Merseyside Friends of the Fire Service to develop a volunteer scheme. The work of volunteers will complement the role of firefighters by distributing information and visiting victims of fire.

Over the next three years the government will fund a £1.3m programme to involve volunteers, especially those aged over 50, to promote the independence of older people.

The specific aims of the programme are to prevent unneccesary admissions to hospital, to support older people when they leave hospital and to help older people live in their own homes rather than going into nursing or residential care. The funding will be awarded to one or more national voluntary organisations to devlop local projects. The government envisages older volunteers helping with small household repairs, befriending and relief for carers as well as running a 24 hour helpline.

The money cuts across government with different departments taking the lead on projects accounting for £60m of the funding. The ministry of defence is leading on a £510,000 project for personal development training for disaffected 12 to 14-year-olds. The department of education and employment is leading on a £27m project to extend the community links among higher education institutions and enhance student volunteering.

Some of the money has already been announced such as the £70m for the Children's Fund announced last year. However, the new tranche of money promised today includes £60m, which will be used to develop mentoring and modernise the infrastructure of voluntary and community groups and £50m, which will be allocated to community groups in deprived areas. More details on this will be announced shortly. The largest chunk of money will be spent on a new National Experience Corp to encourage the over 50s to volunteer in the public services. The government wants older people to pass on their skills and experience to young parents and children as well helping older people in need. Lady Sally Greengross, former chief executive of Age Concern, will be heading up an advisory panel of experts to develop ways of tapping into the resources of the ageing population. The government is particularly keen to channel the free time of the post-war baby boomers into supporting the work of hospitals, schools, libraries and prisons. Chancellor Gordon Brown said: "This is partnership with the voluntary sector not a cut-price alternative." He added: "The next five years will see the role of government shift even more from the old 'directing and controlling' to enabling and empowering voluntary action. Increasingly the voluntary sector will be empowered to play a critical role ranging from under-five provision and preventative health, to adult learning and the war against unemployment and poverty." Adding in an unscripted aside: "If that is it's choice" This is the point which concerned chief executive of the National Centre of Volunteering, Sir Christopher Spence, who told SocietyGuardian.co.uk after the event that he was worried about whether the money would be used for "support or control". "It will be interesting to see how far the government can let go and enable the voluntary sector to do what it is good at - harnessing the spirit of volunteering." Sir Christopher also questioned whether there would be money available for entrepreneurial voluntary action at a local level or whether the money would only be spent on specific schemes chosen by the government. "It takes investment in infrastructure at a local level to encourage good social entrepreneurs," he said. Money has already been allocated to schemes from the new funding, including £420,000 to the Merseyside Friends of the Fire Service to develop a volunteer scheme. The work of volunteers will complement the role of firefighters by distributing information and visiting victims of fire. Over the next three years the government will fund a £1.3m programme to involve volunteers, especially those aged over 50, to promote the independence of older people. The specific aims of the programme are to prevent unneccesary admissions to hospital, to support older people when they leave hospital and to help older people live in their own homes rather than going into nursing or residential care. The funding will be awarded to one or more national voluntary organisations to devlop local projects. The government envisages older volunteers helping with small household repairs, befriending and relief for carers as well as running a 24 hour helpline. The money cuts across government with different departments taking the lead on projects accounting for £60m of the funding. The ministry of defence is leading on a £510,000 project for personal development training for disaffected 12 to 14-year-olds. The department of education and employment is leading on a £27m project to extend the community links among higher education institutions and enhance student volunteering.

webTitle: Smiths' sale of TI unit runs into trouble

fields.headline: Smiths' sale of TI unit runs into trouble
fields.trailText: Smiths Group yesterday warned former shareholders in the TI engineering group that they might receive less than expected from the sale of TI's automotive division.
fields.body:
Smiths Group yesterday warned former shareholders in the TI engineering group that they might receive less than expected from the sale of TI's automotive division.

When Smiths acquired TI at the end of last year it said that the company's investors would receive a share in any sale proceeds above £900m.

Speculation that the sale was in difficulty yesterday wiped 7% off Smiths shares which were suspended by the stock exchange pending a statement from the company.

Smiths, which had to consult trustees handling the sale, later said second-round bids for the automotive business had been received. But it added: "These bids are subject to significant conditionality and have been affected by current conditions in financing and automotive markets. Any reduction in the final sale price will affect the value of the payment to former TI shareholders."

Under the terms of the £1.9bn takeover, Smiths will keep any sale proceeds up to £900m. The former TI shareholders are entitled to all proceeds between £900m and £1.2bn, and 50% of any thereafter.

Smiths is determined to complete the sale. "The automotive division does not fit into our strategy and we do not want to return to the motor industry which we were in 20 years ago," a spokesman said.

The latest bidders are all buyout specialists hoping to improve the unit's performance and then sell it on.

webTitle: Government urges academic staff and students to volunteer for community work

fields.headline: Government urges academic staff and students to volunteer for community work
fields.trailText: The government today announced £27m over three years to help university staff and students in England to participate in voluntary and community work.
fields.body:
The government today announced £27m over three years to help university staff and students in England to participate in voluntary and community work.

The money is part of a government drive, spearheaded by Chancellor Gordon Brown, to increase the numbers of people volunteering for local community work. Ministers hope that within five years every individual will be giving a two hours a week to the community.

Education minister Tessa Blackstone said that the higher education sector already had a long tradition of involvement in volunteering, but that there was scope to encourage more students to participate in volunteering and community outreach work.

"Voluntary work helps to develop employment skills among students, but it can also help to enhance the quality of life of disadvantaged sections of the community," she said. "This money will provide more opportunities for students to get involved in the communities they live in. The additional money will help higher education institutions to work effectively within their communities and increase the numbers of higher education students doing voluntary work."

The three year scheme, funded jointly by the Treasury and the Department for Education and Employment, will be allocated through the Higher Education Funding Council for England.

Grants for voluntary and community work will form a part of the 'third mission' for universities - to work with industry and the wider community, alongside their teaching and research activities. The funding council will consult academic institutions on applying for and utilising the funds.
