webTitle: Mancini: Eriksson impressed by Robinson

fields.headline: Mancini: Eriksson impressed by Robinson
fields.trailText: Roberto Mancini has picked out Leeds goalkeeper Paul Robinson as one of the five Englishman who have most impressed Sven-Goran Eriksson in recent months.
fields.body:
Roberto Mancini has picked out Leeds goalkeeper Paul Robinson as one of the five Englishman who have most impressed Sven-Goran Eriksson in recent months.

Robinson turned in a superb display in the Leeds' shock 1-0 Champions League with over Lazio in the Olympic Stadium, which contributed to Eriksson's downfall.

"If there is one player who has caught Sven's eye it is Robinson," said Mancini, who was Eriksson's assistant at Lazio. "He came here with Leeds in the Champions League and was outstanding. The whole Leeds defence played well, but he did not make one mistake.

"His handling was brilliant, he read crosses well and looked to be very safe with shots. When we were told how young he was, we could hardly believe it. The Olimpico is not an easy place to come to but Robinson handled it magnificently.

"Sven saw David James play for England in Turin and he did well enough but he really had a surprise when Robinson came to Rome with Leeds."

Manchester United midfielders David Beckham and Paul Scholes are also much admired by Eriksson, who will almost certainly stick with his favoured 4-4-2 formation

"Sven believes in 4-4-2 and will stick to it. He knows Manchester United play that way and thinks it will be the best system for England," said Mancini.

"Of course, he knows all about Beckham - probably more than any other player in England. So the fact that Beckham will be fundamental to his plans for the future is a statement of the obvious.

"Yet the one player he is really looking forward to working with is Paul Scholes. We have seen him many times in the Champions League with Manchester United and Sven thinks he is an absolutely fantastic player.

"He has a superb touch, he scores spectacular goals and is a real competitor. Very hard but also quite disciplined.

Eriksson has also been impressed with Liverpool's in-form striker Emile Heskey. "He made a big impression on Sven in Turin," admitted Mancini. "He played on his own up front and caused a lot of trouble for the Italian defence.

"And, remember, this was an Italian side that had six of the players who had reached the final of Euro 2000. Alessandro Nesta, our skipper here at Lazio, is one of the best defenders in the world and even he said he had trouble with Heskey.

"Sven also liked the young guy on the right - Dyer. He thought he had a lot of skill, moved well and - with some special attention - could become a real international player."

"Sven came away from Turin smiling. The young players really made an impact with him. He told me there was some real quality for him to work with.

Mancini also stressed that Eriksson would concentrate heavily on improving England's defence.

"Though he wants to play attacking, attractive football, his priority will be to get the defence right," said Mancini. "He believes you can only go out and express yourself if you are confident in the players behind you.

"So he will reinforce the back four with players who concentrate on defending. You all saw the Italian defence at Euro 2000 - well, that is what Sven wants to bring into the English game.

"He wants them to concentrate on defending like the Italians do. He wants them to be more pragmatic, pay closer attention to detail and, above all, to take care."

webTitle: Comment: MoD hides from truth about depleted uranium

fields.headline: The ministry that hides from truth
fields.standfirst:
Gulf war veterans deserve better treatment and we need honesty

Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Gulf war veterans deserve better treatment and we need honesty.
fields.body:
On April 21 1999, I telephoned the Ministry of Defence and asked its press office whether Nato was using weapons tipped with depleted uranium in Kosovo. "Certainly not," I was told. I phoned Nato on the same day, and was told that these weapons were in fact being deployed. Yesterday the MoD's press officer confirmed to me that his department knew DU was being used at the time. So had the MoD lied to me? "You shouldn't read anything into it," he assured me, "it certainly wasn't intentionally misleading." A definitive denial was issued by mistake.

Perhaps we should view the ministry's current position paper on the testing of Gulf war veterans for depleted uranium as another unfortunate accident. Or perhaps we simply shouldn't read anything into it. Otherwise we'd have no choice but to conclude that the mistakes it contains are a series of lies.

The fine particles of dust released when a DU-tipped weapon hits its target, are, the MoD insists, "rapidly diluted and dispersed into the environment by the weather", soon becoming "difficult to detect". Yet samples taken over Kuwait City in 1993, two years after the end of the Gulf war, found depleted uranium particles in the air. This result appears to have been corroborated both by the preliminary findings of the UN team in Kosovo and by the results obtained in Iraq by the researcher Dr Chris Busby. He found that levels of radiation in the air over the Gulf war battlefields were 20 times higher last year than the levels in Baghdad.

No one "other than those in an armoured vehicle penetrated by a DU projectile", the MoD paper insists, would be exposed to enough uranium "to receive a radiation dose greater than 20 to 30 millisieverts". In the most "extreme and unlikely cases", such as working for 30 or 40 hours inside a tank which had been hit by one of these missiles, a serviceman might receive "a radiation dose of the order of 50 millisieverts." Such radiation levels should present little cause for concern, the paper argues, as the "safe dose" for people working in the UK is calculated at 50 millisieverts a year. Servicemen receiving this dose from "extreme and unlikely" exposure "would be at a slightly increased risk of developing cancer". For everyone else the risk would be "negligible".

These conclusions, the MoD admits, are based on speculation, as "no UK Gulf veterans have so far been specifically tested for the presence of uranium" by the government. This is true, as far as it goes. But other Gulf veterans have been tested by independent researchers. And their findings, based not upon speculation but upon hard fact, suggest a very different level of contamination.

Urine samples taken from veterans and measured by mass spectometry have been analysed by the medical researchers Professor Hari Sharma and Dr Rosalie Berthell. Their results suggest that the doses received by soldiers inhaling the dust are in the order not of 20 or 30 or 50 millisieverts, but of 778.

As Malcolm Hooper, emeritus professor of medicinal chemistry at the University of Sunderland has shown, fine particles of DU entering the lungs are likely to stay in the body for between 10 and 20 years. The fact that DU is still appearing in some Gulf veterans' urine suggests he may be right. If this is the case and the samples taken so far are representative, then instead of a "negligible" or "slightly increased" risk of cancer, we could, he argues, expect between 1,500 and 10,500 of the UK's 53,000 Gulf war soldiers to develop fatal cancers as a result of their exposure to DU.

Now no one can put her hand on her heart and say that the diseases beginning to emerge among both Iraqi civilians and ex-servicemen are the result of exposure to DU. But neither can anyone put her hand on her heart and say they are not. Yet this is precisely what the MoD has sought to do. Like certain other government departments, it has deployed not the precautionary principle, but the improvidence principle: shoot first, ask questions later.

It's not hard to see why it should do so. Were the MoD to express any doubts about the safety of its procedures, the potential compensation claims would make the BSE disaster look cheap. DU dust is likely to have become so widespread that an effective clean-up operation in the Gulf and the Balkans would cost some trillions of pounds. The UK could also find itself firmly on the wrong side of the Geneva convention.

So we can expect the unfortunate mistakes the MoD has made to continue for as long as possible. Statistics, as far as government departments are concerned, will remain not a science, but an art.

webTitle: Nato brings out big guns to kill off cancer scare

fields.headline: Nato brings out big guns to kill off cancer scare
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Nato yesterday launched a massive damage limitation exercise it hopes will defuse growing concern that its use of armour-piercing depleted uranium-tipped shells in Kosovo may be the cause of unexplained cases of cancer among its troops.
fields.body:
Nato yesterday launched a massive damage limitation exercise it hopes will defuse growing concern that its use of armour-piercing depleted uranium-tipped shells in Kosovo may be the cause of unexplained cases of cancer among its troops.

In a carefully orchestrated publicity campaign at the alliance's Brussels headquarters, Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, told reporters that "no link of any kind" had been discovered between the use of depleted uranium (DU) shells and leukaemia or other illnesses.

"I do not believe the public should have been as excited as it has been. We are confident that there is little risk from DU munitions, but we refuse to be complacent," he said after a meeting of the alliance's top policy making body, the North Atlantic Council.

However he was adamant that even temporarily banning the use of such shells would be a grave mistake. "We must base our analysis on facts and not be swayed by perceptions," he said. "I would not agree to the use of the munitions if I believed there was a hazard."

Italy, Germany and Greece all pushed for a moratorium on the use of DU yesterday, but opposition from Britain and the US meant that the proposal was stillborn. Norway later said it too wanted a ban.

Nato's 19 ambassadors did agree to set up a working party to coordinate information on DU shells, a move which will go some way to assuaging Italy and other states which are pressing for a full inquiry. But the alliance will not conduct its own inquiry, preferring to leave it to organisations such as the UN, which it believes are better equipped for the job.

It has, however, already passed on the location of 112 sites in Kosovo where DU shells were used against Serb armour, and which it suspects may be contaminated. The UN said yesterday that it would consider marking and possibly sealing off these sites, and Nato has pledged to help with a clean-up.

Acutely aware of public anger in countries such as Italy over the perceived dangers of the shells, the alliance yesterday distributed a thick dossier of scientific reports debunking claims that DU was dangerous to health, and wheeled out two US medical experts from the Pentagon who claimed that the metal was practically harmless.

A former BBC defence correspondent, Mark Laity, now a Nato spokesman, also did his best to dampen rising alarm, in front of the biggest turnout of journalists since the Kosovo conflict in 1999.

Seated behind a 30mm DU-tipped shell of the kind fired by American tank-busting A-10 planes, Mr Laity criticised the media for blowing the issue out of all proportion. He said DU also had several civilian applications and was used as ballast in airliners and in the keels of many yachts.

But the concerns refuse to fade and have been fuelled by the death of six Italian Balkan peacekeepers from cancer.

Iraq yesterday demanded an inquiry into the use of DU shells in the 1991 Gulf war, suggesting that its cancer rates have soared in the aftermath.

webTitle: MoD knew shells were cancer risk

fields.headline: MoD knew shells were cancer risk
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Army doctors warned four years ago that exposure to  depleted uranium, which is used in US and British  anti-tanks shells, increased the risk of developing lung,  lymph and brain cancer.
fields.body:
Army doctors warned four years ago that exposure to depleted uranium, which is used in US and British anti-tanks shells, increased the risk of developing lung, lymph and brain cancer.

The warnings, in an internal MoD document, are in marked contrast to persistent public assurances - repeated by the armed forces minister, John Spellar, to the Commons on Tuesday - playing down the risk from DU.

Its publicly stated view is that there is a potential but extremely small risk from soluble DU, a toxic chemical that could damage the kidneys. But an unpublished document by MoD medical experts, dated March 1997 and seen by the Guardian, paints a very different picture.

"Inhalation of insoluble uranium dioxide dust will lead to accumulation in the lungs with very slow clearance - if any," it says: "Although chemical toxicity is low, there may be localised radiation damage of the lung leading to cancer."

In a devastating passage under the heading "Risk assessment relating to Gulf war uranium exposure", it warns: "First and foremost, the risk of occupational exposure by inhalation must be reduced."

It goes on to say: "All personnel... should be aware that uranium dust inhalation carries a long-term risk... [the dust] has been shown to increase the risks of developing lung, lymph and brain cancers."

It adds: "Working inside a DU dust-contaminated vehicle without adequate respiratory protection will expose the worker to up to eight times the OES [the occupational exposure standard or accepted exposure level]."

Mr Spellar excluded Gulf war veterans from his offer of voluntary tests even though many more DU weapons were fired in the Gulf than in the Balkans.

It is not clear how widely the paper, a UK land forces document, was distributed among British commanders and to those in charge of DU weapons firing ranges in Cumbria and Scotland. Judging by the wording of the 1997 document, earlier precautions were insufficient. The MoD has admitted that even those official warnings were not passed on to soldiers in the 1991 Gulf war.

Dr Malcolm Hooper, emeritus professor of medicine at Sunderland University and adviser to Gulf war veterans, said last night he was "absolutely appalled" that the report had been in the hands of the MoD while it claimed there was nothing to worry about.

Questioned earlier yesterday in the wake of the MoD's embarrassing u-turn over the screening of Balkan veterans for DU contamination, ministry officials admitted it had not yet identified ways of testing them for DU exposure. They said they were awaiting a report by the Royal Society expected this summer.

The British Legion yesterday called for a public inquiry into health problems facing Gulf war veterans. It described the government's offer of voluntary screening as belated and insufficient.

"If a member of the public suffered from chronic fatigue, hair loss, severe bouts of depression or cancer, they would ask for and receive assessment, answers and treatment," the Legion's secretary general, Ian Townsend, said.

Britons living close to depleted uranium firing ranges or factories producing the ammunition are also at risk, it was claimed yesterday.

MoD sources said last night the document was a summary of another one and did not reflect the ministry's position on DU.

webTitle: Depleted uranium

fields.headline: Depleted uranium
fields.standfirst:
In a ground-breaking policy change, the Ministry of Defence is set to announce that medical tests will be carried out on tens of thousands of Gulf and Balkan military veterans, to check for possible contamination caused by depleted uranium shells used by British and allied forces. Derek Brown explains

Depleted uranium: an interactive guide
fields.trailText: In a ground-breaking policy change, the Ministry of Defence is set to announce that medical tests will be carried out on tens of thousands of Gulf and Balkan military veterans, to check for possible contamination caused by depleted uranium shells used by British and allied forces. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
What is DU and what is it used for?
Depleted uranium is essentially a waste product of nuclear power generation. It is mildly radioactive and, more importantly, immensely dense. It is installed in tank-busting shells, which it helps to punch through even modern high-tech armour.

Does that make the shells nuclear weapons?
Strictly, no. They are classed as conventional munitions. But even so, the heat and blast they generate cause horrific injuries, especially in the confined space of an armoured vehicle. And there are persistent worries about the effects of low-grade radiation, and what the World Health Organisation calls the "chemical toxicity" of the weapons.

How often are they used, and where?
Apart from training exercises, DU shells have been fired in anger in two main conflicts: Operation Desert Storm in the Gulf in 1991, and more recently in the Balkans.

How many were fired?
More than 100,000 DU shells were fired during the Gulf war, to knock out Iraqi armour and strongpoints. More than 30,000 rounds were fired by Nato forces during the 1999 Kosovo conflict, most of them by US tank-busting A10 ground support jets. Around 10,000 rounds were fired in operations around Sarajevo in the latter stages of allied operations in Bosnia.

What side-effects have been suffered by allied personnel?
There lies the controversy. The British and US governments have long denied that DU ammunition is harmful, although since Labour came to power in 1997, the Ministry of Defence has been chivvied into providing more information to serving and former service personnel. Up to this week, however, the authorities have resisted calls for thorough and wideranging tests on soldiers who were literally in the firing line.

What do the veterans themselves say?
The British Gulf Veterans and Families Association has for years called for systematic testing. It claims that "hundreds" of Gulf warriors have died of cancers and other illnesses contracted during active service.

And the Ministry of Defence?
It has conducted its own survey of the 53,462 servicemen who were deployed in the region during the Gulf war. As of November 1999, it has established that 413 individuals have since died. The cause of death is known for 387 of them. They include 56 cases of leukaemia and other cancers, and 67 suicides or apparent suicides.

Why is the Ministry about to change its tune?
There has been a swelling chorus of concern among ex-service personnel, and in the nations which contributed forces to the Gulf and Balkan conflicts, about apparently abnormal death rates. Italy has launched an inquiry into the illnesses of 30 soldiers, five of whom have died of leukaemia. Germany is to review all cases of leukaemia in the military. Portugal is screening 10,000 personnel who served in the Balkans, and Norway has offered checkups to 20,000 soldiers.

What does the USA say?
The Pentagon is sticking to the line that DU may not be good for you, but isn't especially harmful either - except, of course, if it's fired at you. Interestingly, however, there has been concern about the material within the military for at least ten years. One of earliest warnings came in the so-called Los Alamos internal memorandum, dated March 1991.

webTitle: Jon Voight already tipped for next year's Oscar

fields.headline: Jon Voight already tipped for next year's Oscar
fields.trailText: Insiders on Michael Mann's biopic of Muhammad Ali are already tipping Jon Voight for an Oscar for his performance as TV sports reporter Howard Cosell
fields.body:
Veteran actor Jon Voight is a last minute signing to Michael Mann's Muhammad Ali biopic, starring Will Smith in the title role, in a part which insiders are already saying could land him an Oscar nomination next year.

According to The Hollywood Reporter, Oscar-winning Voight, who has just finished filming Tomb Raider with his daughter Angelina Jolie, will play the late Howard Cosell, a television sports broadcaster who followed Ali's career from the beginning and was one of the first established sports figures to publicly acknowledge the boxer's Muslim name.

The $105m (£70.5m) film, which starts shooting today, ran into problems last year when Mann, the director of Heat and The Insider, fell out with Columbia pictures over the film's proposed budget (see earlier story) but after fraught negotiations and an agreement by both Smith and Mann to reduce their fees the project was given the green light in October.

An insider on the film told gossip site Ain't It Cool News that Voight's portrayal is already worthy of an Oscar nomination. "He's fantastic! You cannot recognise him!" the 'source' told the site. "Come next year, I predict, an Academy Award nomination for him! He's that impressive!"

The film, to be called simply Ali, will also star Mario Van Peebles as Malcolm X and Ron Silver as trainer Angelo Dundee.

Voight will next be seen in the big budget second world war epic, Pearl Harbour.

webTitle: Consumer: Dear Anna

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Called to account

All Anne Thorne of Teddington wants is for Oreck to take her money. She has been pleadingwith the company to do so for the past two-and-a-half years. In summer 1998 she bought a vacuum cleaner and chose to pay by direct debit in interest-free, monthly instalments. A year later Oreck wrote demanding money.

She repeated her account details in 12 phone calls and two letters and eventually Oreck helped itself to three instalments as planned. Then, last autumn she received the first of two letters from a debt-collection agency. Once again she explained and repeated her account details. The agency concluded, however, that Oreck had given it the responsibility to resolve the matter and that it would have to add a fee to her bill for their trouble.

 Oreck certainly knows how to move fast when it is goaded. Half an hour after Consumer alerted it to Thorne's plight, customer services phoned back promising immediate redress. "It was an error on our behalf and we sincerely apologise," said a spokeswoman. "We're sending her a letter and a free gift." A fortnight on, all Thorne had received was another letter from the debt-collection agency. Back to Oreck, which promised to call the agency off and get its own letter to Thorne in the post.

Arrested warranty

Three years ago P Critchley of London also bought a vacuum cleaner from Oreck, after responding to an advert offering a fortnight's free trial. A few days before the three-year warranty expired last autumn, the motor exploded and Critchley was assured that it would be repaired free of charge.

A week later he was informed that the warranty had actually started on the day he responded to the advert, not the day he received the machine. "They eventually conceded, but with very bad grace, and I was without my cleaner for over four weeks while I tried to sort it all out," says Critchley.

 It is, of course, nonsense to claim that warranties begin on the day the customer first considers a purchase. "It starts at the end of the 15-day trial period," a customer service manager confirmed. "The misinformation is an internal matter which I'm taking up with my staff. If Mr Critchley is still awaiting a repair, tell him we'll replace the cleaner."

Card confusion

Beware the special deals, cover plans and store-card offers thrust at you by overzealous salesmen. Unless you hold up the checkout queue while you squint at the small print you could find that you have let yourself in for more that you imagined. Earlier this year Claude Saint Arroman of London bought a dishwasher from Comet and paid for it with her Switch card. She was then invited to become a Comet member and apply for a store card, which she did.

A month later she was contacted by Time Retail Finance, which runs the card scheme, and told that she owed £14. She refuted this, but Time Retail promptly set up a direct debit in her name and helped itself to £28. When she rang her bank to cancel it she was told that her original Switch payment had not yet gone through and that she could not cancel that transaction. Since then she has received increasingly threatening letters from Time Retail Finance and her letters, pointing out that the Switch transaction still stands, have been to no avail.

 Comet blames a misunderstanding at the point of sale. "Ms Saint Arroman did in fact sign a Timeplan application using her Switch card as identification, but it seems she did not intend paying by Timeplan," said a spokeswoman. "Time Retail Finance will now cancel the Timeplan agreement and arrange for the payment to be made without interest by Switch."

Where credit is due

What do you do when lenders refuse you credit without any obvious reason? Yvonne Temple and her family of Bromley, Kent, find it impossible to secure credit, and yet her bank's credit check gave them an all-clear and the credit reference agency Experian holds an unblemished credit record for her. "My husband, children and myself have no unpaid bills or outstanding county court judgments," she lamented. "Where do we go from here?"

 It is worth trying the other principal credit reference agency, Equifax, on 08705 783783, since not all lenders file data with both agencies.The main reason people are refused credit is that they are not on the electoral register. Otherwise, the Consumer Credit Trade Association professes itself baffled. "If her record with both agencies is clear than it's possible that there's something wrong with her income or outgoings," said a spokesman. "Or has she changed name or address at some point, which might mean that there's a file that Experian didn't trace?"

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours still don't understand what "chazbaps" means
fields.trailText: Leicester looked to have pipped West Ham for Blackburn defender Christian Dailly. Hammers manager Harry Redknapp admitted: "Leicester have matched our offer of £1.7m, and it now looks as though he will be joining them. I was sure I had him in the bag and to miss out like this is a real sickener."
fields.body:
Leicester looked to have pipped West Ham for Blackburn defender Christian Dailly. Hammers manager Harry Redknapp admitted: "Leicester have matched our offer of £1.7m, and it now looks as though he will be joining them. I was sure I had him in the bag and to miss out like this is a real sickener."

Bradford midfielder Dean Windass is at the centre of a "three-way tug-of-war" between Leicester, Middlesbrough and Birmingham, reports the Star - even though he has all but agreed a new £10,000-a-week deal to stay at Valley Parade.

Meanwhile, Stafford Rangers are the latest club to express an interest in Stan Collymore, reports the Sun. The Dr Marten's club, who sold Collymore to Crystal Palace for £100,000 ten years ago, are hoping the wayward striker will return on loan to help their promotion push. Manager Ian Painter said: "We couldn't afford Stan's wages. But if Bradford would let us have him on loan for a month, we would make a small contribution towards their costs." However, Planet Football claims that Stafford will face a little competition from Paris St Germain.

Coventry have agreed a £2.5m cash plus pay-as-you-play instalments deal for Wimbledon striker John Hartson, reports the Sun. But the Star reckons Hartson's on-off off-on move could still "come unstuck over personal terms".

Manchester City are lining up a £1.5m bid for Argentinian defender Julian Maidena, reports Planet Football.

Former Manchester United keeper Peter Schmeichel is considering a move back to Denmark after losing his place at Sporting Lisbon.

Fulham manager Jean Tigana has rejected Newcastle's offer of a straight swap deal between Lee Clark and Alain Goma.

webTitle: Traditional media ad spend falling

fields.headline: Traditional media ad spend falling claims report
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Advertising spend in traditional media is falling for the first time since the early 1990s, according to ACNielsen MMS. By Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Advertising spend in traditional media is falling for the first time since the recession in the early 1990s, according to a report from ACNielsen MMS.

Observers are split as to whether the downturn is the result of an economic slowdown or a shift in marketing spend.

ACNielsen said that spend on media such as TV, cinema, press and outdoor has risen only 2.3% in the year to November 2000, failing to keep up with the 3.2% headline inflation rate.

The figures, to be published by ACNielsen next week, show cinema advertising falling by 7.8% and outdoor advertising by 31.2%.

Some analysts expressed concern because advertising is one of the first expenses to be cut by companies when they lose confidence in the business outlook.

Others believe there has been a sea change in the marketing sector with big companies shifting spend from traditional media towards the internet, other interactive media and PR.

Procter & Gamble, the world's biggest advertiser, last year cut its UK traditional ad spend by 26%. However, early in the year it took the strategic decision to shy away from TV, where airtime inflation has soared, and diverted marketing funds into new channels.

webTitle: ITV and BBC1 lose out as digital take-up rises

fields.headline: ITV and BBC1 lose out as digital take-up rises
fields.trailText: 11am: 2000 saw digital TV viewing take off with BBC1 and ITV the main casualties, according to Barb viewing figures. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
2000 was the year in which digital TV viewing really took off with BBC1 and ITV the main casualties, according to just-released Barb audience share figures.

Non-terrestrial channels, including digital TV services, took a 16.7% share of viewing across all hours of the day last year, up by nearly three percentage points from 14% in 1999.

This was the biggest year-on-year increase in multi-channel viewing since Barb began tracking the sector in 1991.

Viewing of multi-channel services grew steadily throughout the year, from 15.1% in the first quarter to 17.7% in the last three months of 2000.

ITV was the biggest loser in share terms in 2000, dipping below 30% for the first time. The leading commercial broadcaster dropped two percentage points, from 31.2% in 1999 to 29.2% last year.

This slide in ITV's share comes after a strong rearguard action in 1999, when the broadcaster lost just half a share point compared with the previous year.

BBC1 was the other big loser in share terms in 2000. The BBC's flagship TV service slipped by 1.3 percentage points from 28.4% in 1999 to 27.1%.

The growth in Channel 5's audience share slowed markedly last year, rising by only 0.3 of a percentage point to 5.7%. This after the fledging terrestrial broadcaster had increased its share from 4.3% to 5.4% between 1998 and 1999.

BBC2 and Channel 4 both maintained their viewing shares, year-on-year, which is no mean feat given the multi-channel onslaught.

BBC2 held firm at 10.8% last year - the same share as 1999 - while Channel 4 inched up from 10.3% to 10.4%, year on year.

Channel 4 was no doubt boosted by a massive Big Brother month in August, when it took a 12.2% share.

webTitle: Rough ride as Hague spins out of control

fields.headline: Rough ride as Hague spins out of control
fields.trailText: Why does William Hague get it so wrong these days? He used to be very effective. He could toy with Tony Blair at question time, teasing him into a tremendous snit, making him sound both arrogant and peevish.
fields.body:
Why does William Hague get it so wrong these days? He used to be very effective. He could toy with Tony Blair at question time, teasing him into a tremendous snit, making him sound both arrogant and peevish.

He would then sit back with a big happy grin, like William Brown after he'd knocked off a silk hat with a catapult.

Now young Hague resembles one of those model aeroplanes you see people flying in parks. Up in the gallery, his press secretary, Ms Amanda Platell, is working the controls. The plane buzzes aggressively, then soars round in a circle before banking into a steep rightward climb.

But suddenly she's confused the rudder with the joystick (not a mistake you'd expect the writer of an erotic novel to make) and before she can tug on his flaps (sorry, the style is catching) Hague is spiralling down towards the ground!

Admittedly, Mr Hague wasn't prepared for Nigel Hastilow. Mr Hastilow is Tory candidate for Edgbaston, and appears to have said some rum things. "The Conservative party is a lost cause" was one. "We've never had it so good," Mr Blair quoted him as saying, "people are prosperous, unemployment is falling, there's nothing much to worry about."

(I am told that before setting out on his - doubtless brief - career in the party, Mr Hastilow was a political journalist. But, on the whole, getting the story in the first paragraph is not the way to write election addresses: "Hague doomed" makes a good headline, but not in a Conservative pamphlet.)

Mr Blair kept quoting Mr Hastilow. "Some people might think it is madness to nail your colours to the mast of the Conservative party at this time of crisis," he had apparently also said.

By this time the exchange had gone on for almost half the whole 30-minute period. It was rapidly becoming Nigel Hastilow's question time. Where was he? Are we to hear his entire collected works between now and the election? And how much had the Labour party paid him? ("Two million pounds," shouted a Lib Dem.)

But even without Mr Hastilow, Mr Hague was in trouble. One word of advice I'd give him is never, ever, put a decimal point in your questions or speeches. Nobody follows decimal points. Even astro-physicists can't understand decimal points if they're not written down. So when Mr Hague began by saying, "if the tax burden is 36.9% of national income in one year, and 37.3%the next year, is it rising or falling?" we all switched off. Ms Platell grappled with the controls, but the plane was swerving towards that tree.

"Confusion reigns. Support is slipping away from the party nationally!" Mr Blair was reading from the Book of Hastilow again. Tories kept holding up their hands, backs out but with the thumb tucked behind the palm. This was meant to indicate the four years of Labour tax rises, but instead they looked like impatient restaurant guests waving for the bill.

Mr Blair quoted Ann Widdecombe who, he insisted, had said she would pay for extra policemen by sacking the home office press staff (of whom there are perhaps enough to patrol half a dozen villages, if provided with bikes and trouser clips.)

Mr Hague tried to fight back with a great peroration: the crisis in the police, in the recruitment of teachers, the NHS, the standstill on the railways on the roads. "You are all spin and no delivery!" he ended. But it was him who was spinning. Ms Platell had lost control, and the Tory leader was reduced to a sad little pile of splinters and string.

webTitle: 50,000 organs secretly stored in hospitals

fields.headline: 50,000 organs secretly stored in hospitals
fields.trailText: The true scale of the scandal of human organ retention by hospitals will be revealed today by the government's chief medical officer, who will tell parents and professionals that 50,000 organs are being stored in hospitals in England alone. The number far exceeds expectations.
fields.body:
The true scale of the scandal of human organ retention by hospitals will be revealed today by the government's chief medical officer, who will tell parents and professionals that 50,000 organs are being stored in hospitals in England alone. The number far exceeds expectations.

Liam Donaldson will say that what was done in the name of the NHS over many years was an affront to families who had lost their loved ones.

Addressing a public seminar, whose audience will include top pathologists and other senior doctors, he will say "some of the past practices around organ retention belong to an era where decisions were made by the NHS for patients, but not with patients.

"This has caused a period of immense distress for families, especially in places like Bristol and Liverpool, when they found out their children's organs were taken without their knowledge. Something went seriously wrong in the way the health service dealt with the issue of organ retention."

Prof Donaldson will pledge that the government "will do whatever it takes to put things right, changing the law if necessary to ensure that relatives are given the right kind of information so they can give consent in a fully informed way if they choose to do so."

At Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, where an inquiry will report shortly, more than 3,000 children's organs have been discovered; other hospitals were not thought to have anything like that number.

The chief medical officer will offer an unmitigated apology and assurances for the future to the parents of the Alder Hey children and those whose children died and had organs removed at the Bristol royal infirmary who have been invited to today's seminar. None of the parents knew that hearts, brains and other whole organs would be removed and kept after the autopsy on their son or daughter.

Ian Kennedy, chairman of the inquiry into children's deaths following heart surgery at Bristol, published an interim report into organ retention at the hospital last May. He found that the law was complex and obscure. Different laws covered hospital autopsies - which help doctors find out about the progress of disease - and those ordered by the coroner to find out the cause of death. Prof Kennedy recommended at least a new code of practice and preferably a new law.

Prof Donaldson has issued interim guidance to hospitals, requiring them to tell parents and relatives exactly what an autopsy involves and get their explicit permission if there is any need to remove organs.

Today's seminar is part of his information-gathering process on the way to producing his final report to the health secretary, Alan Milburn. That is expected, along with the Alder Hey inquiry report, before the end of the month.

Ed Bradley, chairman of the Alder Hey parents' support group, said more than 140 parents and relatives had travelled to London for the seminar and were glad of the opportunity to give evidence, "however, we do question how much benefit can be gained from a one-day conference where we have only been given five minutes to represent our views." They also felt it would be more appropriate to discuss the way forward after the Alder Hey inquiry had reported.

Alder Hey hospital is generally considered a special case, because whole organ systems were found to have been collected by a consultant pathologist, Dick Van Velzen, who is facing disciplinary hearings at the General Medical Council.

Bristol parents at the seminar will be asking for Prof Kennedy's recommendations to be implemented and questioning why there has been no action since his report was published. "It was quite clear the law was in a mess," said Steve Parker, chairman of the Bristol Heart Children's Action Group.

webTitle: Scotland must do more in battle for equality

fields.headline: Scotland must do more in battle for equality
fields.standfirst: Can the Scottish parliament win its war against inequality while neglecting the socially excluded?
fields.trailText: Comment: The Scottish executive's attempt to become a role model on all aspects of equality is noble, but its three-phase action plan fails to mention the socially excluded, writes Mark Irvine
fields.body:
The Scottish parliament is putting a few reputations on the line with ambitious plans to push equal opportunities higher up the political agenda. Working together for equality, unveiled in November, commits Scotland's government to act as a role model on equality issues, as an employer, a service provider and policy maker. Hold your breath, politicians are asking to be judged on performance as well as fine words. Where will it all end?

Equal opportunity policies are derided in some quarters as a cottage industry for the politically correct. In the 1980s, the Greater London Council and other Labour councils provided an unending supply of ammunition for satirists and cynics. Tabloid newspapers had a field day, caricaturing the subject in the most grotesque fashion; lambasting policy makers for promoting separate bus shelters for black lesbians.

Positive action to tackle discrimination is always a controversial issue, particularly among people who do the discriminating, and their allies. "Who, me? I'm no racist" is the common response of oppressors - even those caught red-handed. Scotland likes to think of itself as a friendly nation, but the police recorded 2,242 racist incidents last year - up 70% on 1998-99.

Discrimination is a problem in other areas: gender, sexuality, disability and age are mentioned in the strategy document. Its three main objectives are to make better policy and provide better services, to promote equal opportunities and to be a good employer.

The strategy has three phases. Phase one is about gathering information, consulting, training and developing proposals (2000-01). Phase two will implement the agreed programme and raise public awareness (2002-03). Phase three will review and evaluate its effectiveness (2004-07).

Mainstreaming is the name of the game, which means that equality becomes the property of the whole government. Ministers and their departments will be expected to deliver; decisions makers will be under the spotlight where they belong. Social partners will be expected to support and sign up to the strategy's aims. In the past, equality issues have often been sidelined and responsibility handed to small policy teams full of enthusiasm and ideas, but no political clout.

This time, the Scottish executive says clear objectives and benchmarks will be used to assess performance: targets for employing more women at senior levels in the civil service, for example. Others will follow after widespread consultation. Change is being demanded. What are the barriers to employment for ethnic minorities and the disabled?

A key weakness of the strategy is that it defines equal opportunities too narrowly; social class and background are almost entirely ignored. The point is that gender, race, sexuality, disability and age are not the end of the equality debate. Social inclusion is a defining policy for the Labour-led Scottish executive, but the socially excluded hardly merit a mention in the strategy document. Mainstreaming should be forced to tackle these difficult issues instead of concentrating on relatively safe ground.

Scotland's quangos would be a good place to start. They are incredibly elitist organisations, stuffed full of the professional middle classes. Business people, academics, doctors, lawyers and senior managers account for 99% of public appointments. Restricting positive action to well-trodden areas leaves an enormous credibility gap. The great and the good that sit on Scotland's 151 quangos spend £10bn of public money every year. Getting more women onto quangos would be a small victory; making them properly representative of all walks of life, all social classes is the real challenge.

Commendably the Scottish executive has put itself in the firing line; we now wait to see if it has the courage of its convictions.

webTitle: Prince Edward's pet project fails to impress

fields.headline: Prince Edward's pet project fails to impress
fields.trailText: An attempt to launch Ardent Productions on to the big screen is unlikely to succeed after executives at Sky Pictures reject its latest script
fields.body:
It looks as if Prince Edward's ill-fated company, Ardent Productions, has received another setback in its quest to become a major player in the film industry after its latest script was rejected by producers.

According to entertainment site PeopleNews, the Prince's pet project was given a frosty reception from executives at Sky Pictures and is unlikely to ever be made into a film.

The screenplay focuses on three schoolfriends who go on an adventurous backpacking trip which goes disastrously wrong when one of the friends dies from the killer Ebola virus. The two survivors bring home a sample of the virus only to have it stolen by terrorists.

A source close to the production is quoted as saying: "It was pretty unoriginal and not very well written. I think he (Prince Edward) should stick to making programmes about his relatives."

Prince Edward has not been taken as seriously as he would have liked as a "working royal". Ardent Productions has mainly produced television documentaries, usually about the royal family, but is reportedly keen to expand into film production. To date it has produced two Canadian movies, Once Upon a Christmas, which was released last year, and a second world war drama, Varian's War.

webTitle: Palace punish the aristocrats

fields.headline: Palace punish the aristocrats
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace relived the glories of their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool 11 years ago last night as the First Division side pulled off an unlikely first-leg victory.
fields.body:
Crystal Palace relived the glories of their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool 11 years ago last night as the First Division side pulled off an unlikely first-leg victory.

Although the Premership team scored a late away goal, they paid the price for their earlier profligacy in their pursuit of a place in the final against Birmingham or Ipswich and their first trophy in six years.

The day had started badly for Palace when the Football Association charged them with bringing the game into disrepute for their players' part in a Boxing Day brawl at Gillingham.

They had already been fined £20,000 after a 15-man skirmish during a game against Nottingham Forest in August and this time the club face a £150,000 fine if found guilty

This is not the sort of fighting spirit that Palace need as they try to pull themselves out of the mess left by the previous owner Mark Goldberg.

The resurgence of the south London club under their new young millionaire owner, Simon Jordan, has been built on commitment and the new confidence instilled by the returning manager Alan Smith.

The potential of his young side is such that they have already seen off two Premiership teams, Leicester and Sunderland, in this competition. So they approached the visit of Liverpool with less trepidation that would be expected from a team sitting below midtable in the First Division.

However, Liverpool cut open their defence early on and spurned two clearcut chances in the first 22 minutes. First, Emile Heskey beat Dean Austin down the right and found Michael Owen on his own in front of goal. Somehow the England striker ballooned the ball over from seven yards. Then Heskey was embarrassed as he fired over from an identical position after being put clear by Steven Gerrard's through ball. The disgruntled Robbie Fowler, left in Liverpool amid growing rumours of an impending move, would have been excused a wry smile.

Despite the absence of the midfielder Tommy Black and the experienced Neil Ruddock because of suspensions, Palace's undeniable spirit soon kicked in and they began to threaten the Liverpool goal.

They almost took the lead on 26 minutes when Mikael Forssell found Clinton Morrison in a central position on the edge of the area. The striker has been a revelation since he was removed from the transfer list earlier this season and his bullet of a shot seemed destined to succeed until diverted by Sander Westerveld's flying save.

But the danger to Liverpool was not over. From the corner Sami Hyypia had to clear off the line from Forssell and Westerveld saved the follow-up shot from the Finnish striker on loan from Chelsea. Palace were now giving as good as they got but the underdogs still had to be careful.

A careless pass from Hayden Mullins eight minutes into the second half allowed Liverpool to show their speed on the break. Gerrard's shot was poor but seconds later indecision by the Chinese defender Fan Zhiyi let Owen through and only a block by the onrushing keeper Aleksandrs Kolinko denied Liverpool the lead.

A minute later Palace took the lead in spectacular fashion. The Latvian Andrejs Rubins picked the ball up on the left of the area and from about 16 yards uncorked an unstoppable shot past the despairing Westerveld into the far top corner.

So Liverpool digested conclusive proof that they now had a game on their hands. They replaced the hapless Owen with the new signing Jari Litmanen, playing his first game since signing from Barcelona. It was quite a baptism.

On 77 minutes Palace, amazingly, increased their lead. A cross came in from the left, Markus Babbel swung at it and missed. But Morrison swung at and connected, firing past Westerveld from 12 yeards.

A minute later Liverpool earned a lifeline for the second leg when Litmanen reached the byline and pulled the ball back for his fellow substitute Vladimir Smicer to convert from close range.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

The resurgence of the south London club under their new young millionaire owner, Simon Jordan, has been built on commitment and the new confidence instilled by the returning manager Alan Smith. The potential of his young side is such that they have already seen off two Premiership teams, Leicester and Sunderland, in this competition. So they approached the visit of Liverpool with less trepidation that would be expected from a team sitting below midtable in the First Division. However, Liverpool cut open their defence early on and spurned two clearcut chances in the first 22 minutes. First, Emile Heskey beat Dean Austin down the right and found Michael Owen on his own in front of goal. Somehow the England striker ballooned the ball over from seven yards. Then Heskey was embarrassed as he fired over from an identical position after being put clear by Steven Gerrard's through ball. The disgruntled Robbie Fowler, left in Liverpool amid growing rumours of an impending move, would have been excused a wry smile. Despite the absence of the midfielder Tommy Black and the experienced Neil Ruddock because of suspensions, Palace's undeniable spirit soon kicked in and they began to threaten the Liverpool goal. They almost took the lead on 26 minutes when Mikael Forssell found Clinton Morrison in a central position on the edge of the area. The striker has been a revelation since he was removed from the transfer list earlier this season and his bullet of a shot seemed destined to succeed until diverted by Sander Westerveld's flying save. But the danger to Liverpool was not over. From the corner Sami Hyypia had to clear off the line from Forssell and Westerveld saved the follow-up shot from the Finnish striker on loan from Chelsea. Palace were now giving as good as they got but the underdogs still had to be careful. A careless pass from Hayden Mullins eight minutes into the second half allowed Liverpool to show their speed on the break. Gerrard's shot was poor but seconds later indecision by the Chinese defender Fan Zhiyi let Owen through and only a block by the onrushing keeper Aleksandrs Kolinko denied Liverpool the lead. A minute later Palace took the lead in spectacular fashion. The Latvian Andrejs Rubins picked the ball up on the left of the area and from about 16 yards uncorked an unstoppable shot past the despairing Westerveld into the far top corner. So Liverpool digested conclusive proof that they now had a game on their hands. They replaced the hapless Owen with the new signing Jari Litmanen, playing his first game since signing from Barcelona. It was quite a baptism. On 77 minutes Palace, amazingly, increased their lead. A cross came in from the left, Markus Babbel swung at it and missed. But Morrison swung at and connected, firing past Westerveld from 12 yeards. A minute later Liverpool earned a lifeline for the second leg when Litmanen reached the byline and pulled the ball back for his fellow substitute Vladimir Smicer to convert from close range.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: CNN set to axe 1,000 staff

fields.headline: CNN staff braced for up to 1,000 job cuts
fields.trailText: 10.30am: CNN staff in London and the US are bracing themselves for up to 1,000 job cuts, writes Jason Deans
fields.body:
CNN staff in London and the US are bracing themselves for up to 1,000 job cuts.

The news outfit is expected to announce a reorganisation as early as next week that will result in a streamlining of its sprawling global TV and internet operations.

Deep cuts are expected on the internet division - an area that has seen some high-profile signings in the last year including former BBC political editor Robin Oakley.

Between 500 and 1,000 jobs - 25% of CNN's workforce - could go, according to reports in the US.

The cutbacks come 20 years after CNN was first launched, pioneering the rolling 24-hour TV news format in the 1980s.

At first Ted Turner's revolutionary venture was derided as 'Chicken Noodle Network'. But it came of age in 1991 later with the outbreak of the gulf war with reporters such as Peter Arnett becoming household names across the globe.

Now, however, it is facing stiff competition from upstart rivals including NewsCorp's Fox News and MSNBC, a joint venture between NBC and Microsoft.

CNN is part of the giant AOL/Time Warner empire and has 2,500 employees in its Atlanta headquarters with hundreds more staff worldwide.

In recent years the Atlanta-based outfit has expanded non-US news channel CNN International, in the process beefing up its European HQ in London.

A CNN spokeswoman in London said: "We don't comment on speculation."

webTitle: Roy Greenslade: Press reaction to Bulger judgment is deplorable

fields.headline: Filthy rags
fields.standfirst:
The reaction of some newspapers to the judgment on Venables and Thompson's future is deplorable

The Bulger case
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The reaction of some newspapers to the judgment on Venables and Thompson's future is deplorable, writes Roy Greenslade.
fields.body:
The scream of rage from various newspapers at the court decision to grant the killers of James Bulger lifetime anonymity was utterly disgraceful. Raising the banner of press freedom and shouting slogans about the people's right to know, these papers sought to gloss their bloodthirsty cries of vengeance by casting themselves as champions of the public interest.

In reality, their attempt to lift injunctions against publication of details about the youths Jon Venables and Robert Thompson showed a streak of venality, even barbarism, which besmirches Britain's press. Let us name and shame the worst offenders: the Sun and Daily Mail, as one would expect, and sadly, the Times. Doubtless they will be joined by some Sunday tabloids too, and possibly even a broadsheet.

The owners and editors of these papers would do well to read the balanced and humane judgment handed down by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss. So far, their reactions have merely confirmed that the court's worst fears. The Butler-Sloss judgment relies entirely on factual evidence of past, and recent, excesses to illustrate that papers cannot be trusted.

The actor Gordon Kaye was being treated in hospital when a Daily Sport reporter and photographer burst into his room. There was no law to protect privacy at the time, though the Human Rights Act might now offer redress. But the Kaye incident was the catalyst which led directly to the creation of the editors' code of practice and the setting-up of the Press Complaints Commission.

Another notorious instance of intrusion was also mentioned: the News of the World photographed Countess Spencer while she was receiving treatment in a clinic. It was suggested that the resulting PCC censure on the paper and its then editor, Piers Morgan, showed that papers took the code seriously. It worked without inhibiting press freedom. This argument neatly overlooks the fact that the moment the paper published the picture the damage was done. If papers were ever given the chance to publish up to date pictures of Venables and Thompson and reveal their new identities, no PCC adjudication, however strong, could make amends. The youths would be at the mercy of the mob.

The Sun's editorial attacking the court's verdict claimed that it would "never" reveal the youths' new names because it is a "responsible newspaper". That high-minded claim sits oddly against the evidence cited in the judgment from lawyers acting for the youths and their relatives. Venables's solicitor told of "relentless inquiries from the media" over seven years, referring to various breaches of the existing injunctions. Due to the hostile publicity, after his release Venables was at risk of death or serious physical harm.

Venables's father spoke of media pressure on his family which had forced them to move several times. It had been necessary to make his younger children wards of court to prevent publicity. Thompson's solicitor told a similar story, arguing that press behaviour in the past poses a real risk to the boy's life. He produced a recent Mail report about vigilantes in Wales threatening to burn down the home of a woman wrongly identified as the mother of one of the youths. Thompson's mother said she had changed her name and moved home eight times.

As Butler-Sloss pointed out, it is newspapers who "provide the information that would lead to the risk that others would take the law into their own hands". That, surely, is the key point. These papers are not neutral purveyors of information. While proclaiming the public interest, they are inciting the mob, both feeding off the understandable grief of the Bulger family and taking every opportunity to stoke the embers of hatred.

Papers have gone to such lengths to discover information about the youths that it beggars belief that they would not publish it. The manager of the secure unit where Thompson is held said reporters had approached his staff. Photographers with zoom lenses had tried to get pictures of the premises. Butler-Sloss observed: "Not only is the media interest intense, it also demonstrates continued hostility towards the claimants." She pointed to a News of the World editorial stating "the public has a right to know" about the youths. The judge linked that threat to the paper's notorious "naming and shaming" exercise which revealed the identities of alleged paedophiles and led to vigilante acts.

In a further example of the press's obsession, and its willingness to foment prejudice on the slightest evidence, yesterday's Sun ran a front page story headlined "Bulger killer up for Diana award". This claimed Thompson's secure unit had nominated him for a Princess of Wales memorial award. Whether true or not, and it is highly doubtful, the award director made it clear that such a nomination was ineligible under current rules. She has also complained to the PCC that the reporter used subterfuge to interview her, pretending to be the mother of an inmate. The story included an outraged quote from Bulger's mother. It was anything but an exercise in responsible journalism and a further example of the misuse of press freedom.

Even if editors are right to point to the lifetime injunction being an unprecedented curb on freedom, it must be viewed in context. It clearly isn't, as they claim, the thin end of the wedge. An extraordinary case demands an extraordinary response and it is only the second occasion, mercifully, in which is has been necessary. Editors bleating about it being, to use the Mail's blustering phrase, an affront to the principle of press freedom, should think again. In the light of the catalogue of their own past crimes, did they not bring this on themselves?

Talk about it
What do you think?

webTitle: MPs demand protest over cash vetoed by Brussels

fields.headline: MPs demand protest over cash vetoed by Brussels
fields.standfirst: Urban revival under threat as six-year aid scheme is declared illegal
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is under growing pressure from Labour backbenchers to challenge a ruling by Brussels which has forced councils and developers to scrap a multi-billion pound programme designed to revive inner cities and create work in depressed regions and coalfield communities
fields.body:
Tony Blair is under growing pressure from Labour backbenchers to challenge a ruling by Brussels which has forced councils and developers to scrap a multi-billion pound programme designed to revive inner cities and create work in depressed regions and coalfield communities.

The Commons environment committee has warned that John Prescott's much-vaunted urban renaissance is at risk because the European commission has ordered the government to scrap its partnership investment programme (PIP). As a result, thousands of jobs are at risk in urban regeneration and job creation schemes.

The ruling strikes at the heart of New Labour policy because it questions the use of public-private partnerships which have been used extensively to fund a wide range of programmes once financed exclusively by the state. The six-year-old partnership programme provides grants for developers to kick-start regeneration schemes, from converting old warehouses into flats to clearing derelict and contaminated sites.

Since the mid-90s, around £1.1bn of PIP cash - known as gap funding - has been used to lever an extra £2.5bn from the private sector, transforming city centres in Leeds, Manchester, Liverpool, and Newcastle. In 1999 alone around 3,000 derelict acres were cleared and 8,000 new houses and flats provided in towns and cities. In addition, ministers reckon that 50,000 jobs have been created overall.

The programme fills a gap that opens up when the cost of renovating a site is much higher than its market value. But, to the horror of ministers, the Europe's competition commissioner, Mario Monti, says the scheme is illegal because it might give a windfall to a developer or a hidden subsidy to someone renting new premises. Although John Prescott's Department of the Environment argues that the subsidy is designed to cover a loss and not generate profits, the Commons environment committee says ministers have not been sufficiently aggressive with Brussels.

"They should have taken a much tougher line," said Andrew Bennett, chairman of the committee, and MP for the Greater Manchester constituency of Denton and Reddish. He said yesterday that Tony Blair should complain to fellow heads of state as a matter of urgency. Scores of schemes worth hundreds of millions of pounds were facing the axe.

"The revival of city centres in Liverpool, Leeds and Manchester could not have taken place without gap funding and, ironically, people from other parts of Europe were so impressed with our regeneration schemes that they have been coming to see what they could learn," he said.

Fears are growing that the EU ruling will also seriously undermine so-called objective one EU programmes, recently approved for the poorest parts of the country - South Yorkshire, Merseyside, and Cornwall - where GDP per head is 25% below the European average.

Louise Ellman, Labour MP for Liverpool Riverside, yesterday warned ministers that significant parts of the Merseyside programme were now threatened, including a new business centre in Liverpool's Toxteth district. She has been told by the government office for the north west that 30 other Merseyside projects have also been put on hold. "I am extremely worried about the implications of this," she said.

In addition to the PIP programme, Brussels has also vetoed a £150m venture capital fund, designed to create new businesses in depressed regions, and a £15m fund to revive old mining communities.

webTitle: Big issue seller disappointed by Straw

fields.headline: Charity has its limits
fields.standfirst:
Straw digs deep but waits for his change
SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: When Jack Straw brandished a crisp £10 note in front of a Big Issue seller yesterday, the homeless vendor believed his luck was in.
fields.body:
When Jack Straw brandished a crisp £10 note in front of a Big Issue seller yesterday, the homeless vendor believed his luck was in.

The smartly dressed home secretary, who stopped to chat to him during a walkabout in London's King's Cross, barely looked the type to demand change from someone so patently down on his luck, especially when surrounded by the press.

To Jaz Walter's surprise, however, it soon became clear that change was expected for the £1 magazine. While his advisers looked at their shoes in embarrassment, Mr Straw waited, and waited ... until Mr Walter volunteered that he could change the tenner.

Mr Straw was still left a pound short, but the proferred £8 was accepted. Last night Mr Walter, who has been selling the Big Issue for 18 months, said: "At first I thought, he is being generous. I could have done with the money, because I'm kipping on a friend's floor at the moment and I can't even get the dole."

webTitle: MPs upset by charity cash scandal

fields.headline: MPs upset by charity cash scandal
fields.trailText: The Charity Commission was under fire last night from David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, for its failure to act fast enough over the corruption claims involving the charity War Child UK
fields.body:
The Charity Commission was under fire last night from David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, for its failure to act fast enough over the corruption claims involving the charity War Child UK.

The national audit office, parliament's financial watchdog, disclosed that it has already started an inquiry into whether the commission is up to the job of protecting donors' cash from going astray or being swallowed up by administration bills.

Mr Davis said the case illustrated problems facing the commission. The law should be changed to separate its role of advising charities and their trustees from its role of policing their activities. "There is a case for this to be investigated thoroughly," he said.

His comments followed the Guardian and Channel 4 News investigation of War Child UK, which revealed that six celebrity patrons, led by Luciano Pavarotti, had quit the charity after it was revealed that the co-founder, Bill Leeson, had shared a £14,700 "bung" from the construction company building the Pavarotti music centre in Mostar, Bosnia.

The trustees demanded that the money be returned, but then disputes arose between the patrons, trustees and directors over whether all the money raised by the stars had reached the music centre project. War Child UK says that over £4m has been raised.

The commission agreed this looked appallingly low but said it had doubts about the way the work was being classified, and that some cases might not prove to be irregular at all.

Last night John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, said in a letter to the Guardian: "Because the trustees were ready when they called us in to recognise their problems and try to resolve them, the commission has been able to work with them without a statutory inquiry or publishing formal reports. The commission's involvement was prompt and intensive."

Ann Clwyd, a Labour member of the Commons international development committee, has asked for all the documents on the work of War Child UK obtained by the Guardian and Channel 4 News to be sent to the committee, which is looking into bribery and corruption in development aid.

Clare Short, international development secretary, is also to check the charity's work in Bosnia and Kosovo. Her ministry gave it a £350,000 grant to run the Kosovo bakery.

webTitle: How boom failed to bridge the Texan divide

fields.headline: How boom failed to bridge the Texan divide
fields.standfirst: US slowdown In the last in a series, we look at prospects for rich and poor in Bush's home state
fields.trailText: US slowdown In the last in a series, we look at prospects for rich and poor in Bush's home state
fields.body:
An ugly yellow cafe stands on a hill amid empty space and boarded buildings. But alongside the Victory Grill, a large billboard offers a sign of hope ahead - an artist's impression of a multi-million dollar redevelopment plan with "Coming Soon" plastered across it in bright red letters.

After several years of false starts, the redevelopment of the depressed eastern half of Austin is coming just as the US economy has hit the brakes. Yet few locals seem to care.

"I definitely see the signs of a recession on the horizon, but I just don't think it will affect us," says Mark Rogers, project director of the neighbourhood development corporation. "It's like my parents talking about the Depression. It wasn't as if they lost anything because they didn't have anything to begin with."

To an even greater degree than America as a whole, Austin has enjoyed phenomenal levels of overall economic growth for much of the past decade. But the strong performance has masked a widening gap between rich and poor, a gap highlighted by recent signs of a slowdown.

An interstate highway cuts Austin in half. On one side is the wealthy, western half of the city which is already showing the first signs of an economic downturn. On the poor eastern side, thing have remained more or less as they were a year ago.

The Centre for Public Policy Priorities, a non-profit research group in Texas, issued a report last year which suggested that low unemployment levels had done little to raise many of the black and Mexican families in the city above the poverty line over the past decade.

In addition, the Texas policy of raising funds through sales taxes and property taxes rather than through a tax on income disproportionately penalises the poor. Eva de Luna Castro, a researcher at the centre, says: "Gentrification is a real concern here, not recession."

Although oil revenues still contribute a quarter of the gross state product in Texas, much of the growth over the past five years has been driven by the expansion of hi-tech companies and exuberant consumer spending.

Most of the recent evidence in the home state of the president-elect, George W Bush, as well as in America as a whole is that the fast-paced local economy of the past few years is slowing down rather than reversing.

Texas Perspectives, a consultancy which provides an economic indicator, has estimated that this basket of economic measures would decline from 5% growth two years ago to 2% in 2000. The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas puts employment growth rates at similar levels, while unemployment in the state and nationally is still very close to a 30-year low.

Travis Tullos, a regional economist at Texas Perspectives, says: "People have started to talk of a recession. A recession is two quarters or more of negative growth and we simply do not see that happening in the US, much less in Texas."

What he does predict is a rapid decline in consumer confidence and falling sales for non-essential goods.

After just a year as a real estate agent for the luxury end of the market, Kevin Scanlan is also surprised at how quickly things have changed.

Having moved from Alaska, his first summer in Texas was hot in more ways than one.

One buyer so badly wanted a house that he signed a blank cheque and asked the seller to simply add $10,000 (£6,700) to the highest bid.

Another smallish two-storey home in the pretty neighbourhood of Cat Mountain attracted more than 10 offers on its first day and eventually sold for $359,000 - three times the average house price in the state and much more than its list price. "And it was nothing special," adds Mr Scanlan. "It wasn't like a mansion or anything."

Now, far fewer customers are phoning Mr Scanlan's number. "In the last three months of last year, things slowed down considerably. It's only homes in areas where things don't come on the market very often that are going very quickly."

Not that Mr Scanlan is complaining: "It's still a good real estate market, it's just not last summer."

Like some US economists, Mr Scanlan blames the sharp fall in the value of hi-tech shares for the slowdown in spending. "The fact that those types of companies are doing so badly has had a big impact on the market," he says.

The largest state employer is Dell, a homegrown company and the world's largest direct seller of computers. The increasing number of so-called "Dellionaires" in Austin helped push up house prices in the area as well as feeding many of the smartest shops, restaurants and car showrooms.

Michael Dell, the Texan founder of the company and a man who bought his first BMW at 17, has done his bit to boost spending levels in the state. But, the company, which increased sales by almost 60% a year for most of the 1990s, has been hurt by the marked slowdown in computer sales, and Mr Dell's own estimated net worth has shrunk by about 60% since last summer.

Undeterred by such statistics, Mark Rogers of the development corporation confidently predicts that building on the first phase of the redevelopment east of Interstate-35 will begin later this year after some $100m is found from the private sector.

Special report on Bush's America at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/bush

webTitle: Yahoo results meet expectations

fields.headline: Yahoo results meet expectations
fields.trailText: 4pm: Web portal Yahoo posted good results, but warned that it expects to suffer a drop in ad revenues in 2001, reports Guy Middleton.
fields.body:
Web portal Yahoo met analyst expectations when it announced its fourth quarter earnings last night, but sounded an alarm bell over its predicted earnings for the first quarter of 2001.

The company reported revenues of over $310m in the last quarter of 2000, up 53% compared with the same period in the previous year. The figure closes a year in which the company saw total net revenues of over $1.1bn, a figure that represents an 88% increase over 1999.

"Yahoo continued its strong performance in the final quarter of 2000, capping a year in which we grew revenues by almost 90% while expanding and strengthening the company," said chairman and chief executive of Yahoo, Tim Koogle.

"By almost any measure Yahoo continued to outperform the industry and took market share despite a challenging environment."

While Yahoo saw strong growth over 2000, the company, a bellwether of internet fortunes, is almost entirely dependent on advertising revenues. It said a weakening advertising market and the overall softening of the economy would likely have a "short-term effect" on the company's revenues.

Yahoo said it expected to see revenues of $220m and $240m in the first quarter of 2001 - a figure lower than the analysts' consensus. The announcement shaved around 15% off the company's value in after-hours trading, taking the stock to around $26, a little over a tenth of its value at the height of the internet stock frenzy in January of last year.

While Yahoo's results were on target, the fact that the portal giant expects to suffer from a drop in advertising revenues suggests that smaller players in the online advertising market can expect a difficult time over the next few months. When advertising budgets are squeezed, it is usually the smaller players that lose out.

Yahoo itself appears to have suffered in line with many internet investors in 2000: the company said it had downgraded the value of its investments in other companies by $165m over the year as the value of the companies was reassessed.

webTitle: MatchNet.com makes profit pledge

fields.headline: MatchNet.com makes profit pledge
fields.trailText: 1pm: Online dating agency MatchNet.com has said it will be profitable within the year, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Matchmaking has proved to be one of very few money-spinners on the internet.

British online dating agency MatchNet.com distanced itself from the current dot.com fallout by insisting it will be profitable within the year.

The details emerged as the Neuer Markt-quoted company announced its acquisition of SocialNet.com, a US-based online dating website, for an undisclosed sum.

It claims the deal will make it the number one global publicly listed dating service with a combined customer base of 3m.

According to Elmar Bob, executive vice-president of investor relations and managing director of MatchNet's German operations, the purchase has enabled MatchNet.com to slash customer acquisition costs by up to 75%, by inheriting a customer base that raises the current membership to around 2.5m from 1.5m.

SocialNet, which has approximately 1.5m registered members, says it "specialises in social matching by enabling busy people to make connections in all aspects of their social lives - networking, dating and activities".

"We had projected around $23m for marketing costs for 2001, but with the purchase of SocialNet, our customer acquisition targets have been met, costing between $5m and $6m instead," he said.

Mr Bob also cited "older, more experienced and not typical dot.com, executive officers and a radical cut in expenses", as reasons for the company's imminent profitability.

Three-year-old MatchNet also made revenues from membership fees, advertising and its singles travel service. Annual results will be released next month.
