webTitle: Just2clicks posts £38m loss

fields.headline: Just2clicks posts £38m loss
fields.trailText: 4pm: Business-to-business trading network Just2clicks has reported a pre-tax loss of £37.8m, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
A proposed name change and several acquisition offers could not prevent poor sales figures and a huge write-off for business-to-business trading network Just2clicks.com.

Just2clicks made a pre-tax loss of £37.8m in the 15 months to 30 September 2000. The deficit includes a write-off of £33.9m related to goodwill and amortisation.

Losses before the write-off were at £3.9m. Turnover for the period was £1.7m.

Karl Watkin MBE, chief executive, said that the write-off had not affected business and pointed out that the company has £45.2m cash in the bank at the end of the trading period.

Cost-cutting had also brought the cash-burn rate down to around £650,000 a month.

"Because the market doesn't value the business as with many others within the technology sector, we have written that value off," Mr Watkin said.

In response to various proposals of merger and acquisition since the company floated on Aim in February 2000, Mr. Watkin said that the board had so far not had any approaches "that offered shareholders a better return than the current strategy".

"Everything is always for sale at the right price, so if someone came along with the right proposal, we'd certainly look at it," he added.

The company, which will change its name to J2C by resolution at the annual general meeting on February 9, is seeking partnerships with bricks and mortar companies interested in establishing online trading communities.

It launched e-cement, a similar venture with giant cement manufacturer Blue Circle industries, which has generated sales of up to $700m since launch last May.

webTitle: Harold Evans analyses the Clinton years

fields.headline: The razzle dazzler
fields.standfirst: The Clinton years:  In the first of a three-part series,  Harold Evans in New York assesses the stunning popularity of an outgoing president
fields.trailText: Harold Evans assesses the stunning popularity of an outgoing president.
fields.body:
America does not want to say goodbye to its first baby boomer president. Very nearly 70% of the people approve of the way Bill Clinton has done the job. They haven't forgotten Gennifer, Monica, Paula, Dolly, Kathleen and Juanita, and funny Chinese money, and the renting of the Lincoln bedroom, and lying under oath, and so on. They know he is a bit of a lad, but they like a president who gets things done.

Even as the White House packers groan about the cubic footage of his beloved books, Elvis is centre stage with a grin and a wave. Between trying to rewrite the doomsday scenario for the Middle East, lighting a Christmas tree in Belfast, and wowing the young people in Vietnam, he has issued no fewer than 29,000 pages of executive orders in his sunset days.

Some sunset! In the last couple of months, he has created a vast new underwater nature preserve in Hawaii, given patients access to medical records, banned logging roads in some scenic areas, pardoned a bunch of malefactors, cut down on soot and smoke pollution and written new "ergonomic" rules to reduce office stress disorders.

None of this has done anything for the office stress disorder the new boy Bush faces with a rightwing eager to reverse all this liberal do-gooding. They don't like the way Bush emerged bemused from a briefing lunch with Clinton at the White House where Clinton put on what he calls his "razzle dazzle". Given an evenly divided Congress, GW will find it hard to rewind the sunset.

Clinton defies the laws of political gravity. That job approval rating is phenomenal. None of the popular postwar presidents - Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Reagan - had this level of public support in the waning months of their presidencies. Ike came closest; even the much loved Reagan slumped into the low 40s. But for the foolish 22nd Amendment of 1951, limiting presidents to two terms, a silvery-haired Clinton would be raising his right hand this month to take the oath of office for the third time. He could well have matched Franklin Roosevelt's unique four terms.

Is he in FDR's league? No. FDR was tested by greater events and rose to them, but in economic terms Clinton has been the most successful Democratic president in the history of the party. Of course, like FDR, he does not enjoy unanimous approval. About 20% of the population resents Clinton as a rock 'n' roll president who infected the 90s with the permissive moral values of the 60s. The haters, who are chorusing "Good riddance!" are something else again, a hard, unforgiving core of Republican rightwingers who have foamed at "slick Willie".

They are very like the crowd who went after FDR in the 30s, enraged that "their" White House had been usurped. Both in 1992 and 1996 Clinton won on a minority vote with the help of third party candidates. The right's sense of entitlement fed an incipient paranoia: When the deputy White House counsel Vincent W Foster Jr was found shot dead, he must have been murdered; when Hillary Clinton's Rose Law Firm billings could not be found, she had burned incriminating documents. The foamers were led by the Wall Street Journal, the Christian fundamentalists, moneybags Richard Mellon Scaife who financed the sleaze police, Rupert Murdoch's New York Post, Bill O'Reilly on Fox TV, a group of libertarian think-tanks, and Rush Limbaugh, epitomising a network of reactionary populists of radio who claim to vent for the real America. They are paler versions of Father Coughlin, who had audiences of 45m for his anti-FDR rants, but for eight years they have never stopped colluding to fit Clinton with a cement suit.

The surprising thing is that they failed. Houdini has nothing on the man from Hope. At the start of his first term, in 1992, he tied the knots himself. He promised he would be a new Democrat, not a prisoner of bureaucrats or the party's tax and spend core. He would raise the ethical tone of government. He would stop the military discriminating against gays. He would act swiftly and decisively on the economy.

The economy bequeathed him by George Bush senior was nothing like the great depression Franklin inherited from Herbert Hoover in 1932, but Bill, too, was going to have his hundred days of action on jobs and growth. And then he would match FDR's social security revolution with a national health service reform that would both lower medical costs and cover every American.

It was a grand vision of what the presidency might achieve, but his eye on the stars, Clinton stumbled badly. Given the smoothness of the White House operation of the last four years, it is easy to forget that when they came in the boys from Arkansas were the gang that couldn't shoot straight. Clinton insisted he must have a woman as attorney general, then nominated Zoe Baird knowing she had broken the law by failing to pay taxes for a housekeeper. The radio talk circuit blew its fuses. See, Willie was a liberal hypocrite, exploiting working people and excepting his friends from laws ordinary people had to obey.

Next, he gave the country the wrong idea of his priorities by getting into an immediate hassle with the military - his military - over gays. He had to retreat into accepting a "don't ask, don't tell" formula. It was, he himself now recognises, "a dumbass" thing to do.

He had led the country to expect rapid action on the economy, which had emerged from recession but was still throwing up record deficits, threatening inflation. "It's the economy, stupid" was his campaign theme, but seven months into office, and with a Democratic Congress, he was still unable to get a budget agreed. He was sandwiched between Democrats who wanted money for investment he had promised (including the much-mocked "information highway") and cross-party alliances in the Senate determined not to vote tax increases to pay for them. He had to fight his own party and its rooted protectionism.

It is to his enduring credit that he broke the Democratic mould. In August 1993, he at last persuaded enough Democrats to vote immediate tax increases and phased spending cuts - the first real attempt to contain the federal deficit in more than a decade and passed only on the casting vote of Al Gore. Not a single Republican in House or Senate voted for it. Its importance was underrated by almost everyone, but the wrangling left a bitter taste.

His success in enacting the North American Free Trade Area upset organised labour. The health reform he had provocatively delegated to Hillary was going nowhere, bogged down in such complexity it was easy for its enemies to misrepresent it as the Clintons telling you what doctor you could use. A fine initiative, well supported by the public and with the Republicans initially eager to trade, became vulnerable to a massive propaganda campaign by the special interests in health and insurance.

Clinton's popularity at this point slumped lower than any postwar president.

Tomorrow: The comeback artist who stole everyone's ideas.

webTitle: Waiting lists fall

fields.headline: Waiting lists fall
fields.trailText: Hospital waiting lists fell by 3,500 in December, figures published later today will show.
fields.body:
Hospital waiting lists fell by 3,500 in December, figures published later today will show.

Health minister John Denham claimed the drop was evidence that patients are benefiting from increased funding to the NHS.

December's figures show the ninth consecutive monthly drop but patients' groups and the opposition said they masked the true experience of people waiting for operations on the NHS.

There are 180,000 waiting to see consultants and so effectively waiting to go on to a waiting list, shadow health secretary Dr Liam Fox told the BBC.

Vanessa Bourne, of the patients association, said ministers should concentrate on waiting times, not waiting lists.

"If you are a patient what you want to know is when you will be treated, when will you will be taken out of pain, when you will be cured," she said.

Mr Denham hit back, saying that under Labour there 600,000 more operations are performed every year.

"However you look at it, waiting lists have come down, more patients are being treated and people are taking less time from being referred for an operation to actually getting one," he said.

"We are getting more doctors, we are getting more nurses and after years of cuts we are getting more beds."

Government investment was bringing results and had to be maintained, he said.

webTitle: Brown hails advance of Britain's volunteer army

fields.headline: Brown hails advance of Britain's volunteer army
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown will today mark another stage in the government's vision of a million-strong volunteer army by claiming Britain is on the brink of a new era of active citizenship. Patrick Wintour reports
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown will today mark another stage in the government's vision of a million-strong volunteer army by claiming Britain is on the brink of a new era of active citizenship.

Drawing on previous government pledges prepared by the government's active community unit sited in the Home Office, Mr Brown will claim that within five years every individual should be committed to giving a two hours a week to the community.

He will also suggest 100,000 over-50s could work in the voluntary sector, including hospitals and schools.

Most recent surveys have shown there has been a decline in volunteering by both older and younger people, threatening a major new pressure on the public purse.

Mr Brown is to present the change as part of a move towards the decentralisation of government and the handing of power to local areas.

Much of his thinking is derived from an analysis prepared on neighbourhood renewal developed by the social exclusion unit.

The 1m extra volunteers was set as a formal government target in a review established by the Treasury during the preparation of the summer comprehensive spending review.

Mr Brown claimed last night: "Instead of people looking always to Whitehall for solutions in locality after locality more and more people will themselves take charge of the decisions that most affect them. That is perhaps humbling for government, but quite the opposite for communities."

His remarks are likely to be met with scepticism in Labour local government, which believes it has suffered from ever greater centralisation and the loss of local government influence.

However some Labour analysts believe power needs to be devolved below formal local government representation to local estates and neighbourhoods, or parishes.

Previous research undertaken for the government has shown that volunteers rejected Tony Blair's vision of a new giving age, suggesting the phrase was patronising and failed to capture the dynamic in volunteering.

webTitle: Weakest Link creator offered £1m carrot to leave BBC

fields.headline: Young offered £1m carrot to leave BBC
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The man behind The Weakest Link is set to land a spectacular £1m-plus deal to leave the BBC, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
He transformed Anne Robinson's fortunes by making her a quiz show queen.

Now the man behind The Weakest Link is set to earn his own personal windfall with a spectacular £1m-plus deal to leave the BBC.

David Young, 32, the head of light entertainment, is getting a "seven figure" cash sum to join a new company being bankrolled by the Hat Trick, the company behind hits such as Have I Got News for You and Father Ted.

On top of that Mr Young will get a salary topping £200,000 a year over three years.

Some believe his £1m windfall was the cost of buying him out of his contract with with BBC, where he had a deal giving him a percentage of format sales on top of his £150,000 salary.

Mr Young's record-breaking transfer deal is the talk of the television industry and signals a new Hollywood-style era in commercial television, where behind-the-scenes talent can now command fees almost as big as those of the stars.

One commissioning executive said: "These days you can't hire a decent producer for less than £150,000."

But Mr Young's deal with Hat Trick has also sparked bitterness among rival executives who point out he did not come with the idea for The Weakest Link.

Top behind-the-scenes talent is hard fought for - Carlton Television was forced to go to arch-rival LWT to find somebody - Nigel Lythgoe - good enough and experienced enough to make a hit of its new reality show, Survivor.

Mr Young will head up a new joint venture company with Hat Trick, but he will not be investing any of his own cash.

He joined the BBC two years ago from Bazal Productions and before that spent nine years at Hat Trick.

He hails from Woking in Surrey, went to a comprehensive school and is the son of a gas engineer and social worker. He was at Bristol University but always wanted to work in television, and wangled his way into Hat Trick as runner while still a student.

webTitle: OK! signs Feltz as health columnist

fields.headline: OK! signs Feltz as health columnist
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Vanessa Feltz is joining OK! magazine as a star health columnist from January 20, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Vanessa Feltz is joining OK! magazine as a star health columnist from the issue of January 20.

Martin Townsend, editor of OK!, said the OK! editorial team was looking forward to working with Ms Feltz, who has just finished her two-year contract with the BBC.

webTitle: Top opera job for BBC news chief

fields.headline: Top opera job for BBC news chief
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera House is to announce today that Tony Hall, head of BBC news and current affairs, is to be its new executive director, writes Matt Wells and Rebecca Allison.
fields.body:
The Royal Opera House is to announce today that Tony Hall, head of BBC news and current affairs, is to be its new executive director.

The announcement will end weeks of speculation about the successor to Michael Kaiser, who left the post in December after two years. His predecessors lasted only seven and five months before resigning.

A BBC source confirmed that Mr Hall, director of BBC News for nine years, would be announcing his resignation today to head the ROH. His appointment comes after a wrangle over his salary and pension package.

He has no experience in arts administration and was initially regarded as a surprise outside candidate. But the ROH was determined to appoint him and is understood to have been frustrated at his last minute wrangling.

It is believed that the stumbling block was the big drop in salary. Mr Hall earns around £250,000 at the BBC, whereas the opera house salary is around £150,000. The deal was finalised at the ROH's board meeting yesterday.

Mr Hall, 49, beat off formidable competition from a shortlist thought to include high profile figures such as John Tusa, who runs the Barbican, Pierre Audi, artistic director of Netherlands Opera, and Richard Lyttelton, president of EMI Classics.

While Mr Hall can in no sense be called an opera expert, there is a logic to the choice.

Antonio Pappano, music director of the Monnaie Opera in Brussels, becomes music director at Covent Garden in 2002 and has been assured of artistic control. An opera heavyweight as executive director might have got in the way, leading to artistic clashes. Mr Hall's role is seen as strictly financial and administrative.

The board splits roughly between administrators and artists. The former had to convince the latter that employing an executive director with no experience of opera or ballet would not lead to a diminution in artistic standards.

The meeting, at which the nomination committee put forward Mr Hall's candidature to the full board, was lively, but it appears that his supporters were pushing at an open door.

Mr Hall will be expected to make the house work not least in public relations terms. He will work closely with Sir Colin Southgate, ROH chairman, who was rumoured to have clashed with Mr Kaiser.

The past five years have been a public relations disaster for the opera house, and there were times when it looked as if the government might pull the plug on its public funding.

The period in which the opera and ballet companies had to perform away from Covent Garden, during a £214m refurbishment, was financially disastrous; a fly-on-the-wall documentary about the opera house was a huge embarrassment; and the productions it has staged since the reopening have met with at best mixed reviews.

Mr Kaiser's resignation to join the Kennedy Centre in Washington was a blow which the ROH could ill afford. He cut prices and helped to attract audiences to what has been seen as an elitist institution. Tensions remain between those who want to widen its appeal and those who fear it may be "dumbed down".

Mr Hall is likely to stay at the BBC until the general election, expected in the spring. He applied for the job of director general last year, but was defeated by Greg Dyke. Although the two are said to get on well, insiders believe he may feel out of place in the new regime.

Mr Hall's departure will set off a succession battle at the BBC. Favourite to take over is his deputy, Richard Sambrook, who has impressed Mr Dyke.

webTitle: BBC man attacks 'beauty contest' for TV job

fields.headline: BBC man attacks 'beauty contest' for TV job
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Jon Silverman, a senior BBC correspondent consigned to radio after losing a controversial "beauty contest", has launched a withering attack on a colleague who survived the television test. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Hell hath no fury like a BBC reporter scorned, especially if his looks - rather than his professional integrity - are called into question.

Jon Silverman, a senior correspondent consigned to radio after losing a controversial "beauty contest", has launched a withering attack on a colleague who survived the television test.

Silverman is furious with Niall Dickson, the BBC's social affairs editor, who defended a recent reorganisation that assigned reporters to the BBC's radio, television and online news services. In an article for the BBC's staff newspaper, Dickson had dismissed suggestions that TV reporters were chosen for their looks.

But Silverman disagreed, and attacked his colleague for propagating a management line. "If his own on-air reporting was as self-serving and uncritical as this piece of management spin, it would never see the light of day," Silverman wrote in a letter to the journal.

The comments, published yesterday, have caused a stir at the BBC. "It's not as if either of them are God's gift to the viewing public," an incredulous colleague said.

It is understood that Silverman, who made his name uncovering Nazi war criminals in Britain, was furious at being consigned to radio, while correspondents such as Rosie Millard and Jane Peel were told they would work principally for television. The new arrangements, which were revealed at the end of last year, caused resentment within the BBC and attracted derision from the press.

In his letter, Silverman claimed the reorganisation was designed to satisfy the demands of television news bulletin editors who wanted TV-friendly reporters even if they knew they were unfamiliar with a particular story.

"The truth is that this exercise began with the premise that the editors of the main TV bulletins should dictate who they have on air - however limited their knowledge of the brief." He said some had been "hurt and bewildered at their shabby treatment".

A spokesman for BBC News said yesterday that the reorganisation had nothing to do with a beauty contest. "It's to do with working in the most efficient way. It is nonsense to suggest that any reporter was moved because of how they looked. The aim of the move was to create clarity about how reporters are deployed across television and radio bulletins."

webTitle: Desmond to get rid of adult magazines

fields.headline: Desmond to get rid of adult magazines
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Richard Desmond, whose Northern & Shell paid £125m for Express Newspapers at the end of last year, is seeking a buyer for his stable of top shelf magazines. By David Teather and Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
Richard Desmond, whose Northern & Shell paid £125m for Express Newspapers at the end of last year, is seeking a buyer for his stable of top shelf magazines.

The move appeared a clear attempt by Mr Desmond to distance himself from the pornography business which has been the focus of criticism since he took control of the Express. MPs have questioned Mr Desmond's fitness to run the newspaper titles because of his top shelf interests.

The sale would also raise much needed cash to invest in the Express titles. Mr Desmond borrowed £97m to acquire the newspaper group and has indulged in savage cost cutting since taking over.

He is trying to divest his entire portfolio of some 30 magazines which include titles such as Asian Babes, as well as his adult websites. The sale will leave him focused on the Daily and Sunday Express, the Daily Star and OK! magazine, although he will still retain the Fantasy Channel on television.

Stan Myerson, group managing director of Northern & Shell said: "It has long been considered that once we had the group's focus on rebuilding Express titles and the Star that the adult magazines, which represent only 5% of turnover would not remain part of Northern & Shell."

The sale comes at a delicate time for Mr Desmond. The office of fair trading has concluded its inquiry but the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, could still refer the takeover to the competition commission on public interest grounds.

A precedent was set 10 years ago when David Sullivan, publisher of the lurid Daily Sport newspaper, was prevented from buying the Bristol Evening Post on the grounds that his ownership "could harm the standing of the papers in their community".

The magazines are owned by Mr Desmond's Portland Investments. A management buyout is a possibility and several overseas buyers have also been approached.

Insiders said Mr Desmond had hoped the Telegraph group would exercise its right to buy Express Newspapers' 50% share in the West Ferry printing plant which could provide him with a lump sum estimated at £40m.

There has also been growing speculation that Mr Desmond intends to sell the Express titles to focus on the Daily Star.

Friends of Mr Desmond have said the businessman craves respectability.

Max Clifford, the public relations maestro, once said: "If there's a weakness in his character it's that he wants to be respected. He hates the soft porn tag. He would far rather be called a newspaper magnate."

webTitle: More Temptation Island controversy

fields.headline: Advertisers embroiled in Temptation Island controversy
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Advertisers have been drawn into the controversy surrounding new US 'reality TV' show Temptation Island, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Even companies advertising around the controversial new US TV series Temptation Island have been drawn into the firing line as the furore surrounding the show grows.

Conservative pressure groups, including the American Family Association, are encouraging the public to harass advertisers in their campaign to get the show banned due to its "promotion of illicit sex".

Temptation Island, which launched on Fox TV last night, centres on four couples who test their fidelity on a steamy tropical island overrun with scantily clad singles. It is the latest example of what observers are dubbing 'reality TV'.

Randall Murphree, spokesman for the American Family Association, said that even the trailers for the show were enough to upset his organisation and many religious groups.

"We will publicise who the advertisers are so that customers can get in touch," he said.

It emerged today that Fox screened contestants for sexually transmitted diseases before taking part in the show.

Sandy Grushow, chairman of the Fox TV Entertainment Group, countered this week, "This is not a show, as you will see, that is about sex. This is exploring the dynamics of serious relationships."

webTitle: Golden cuffs ITN deal for Sir Trevor

fields.headline: Golden cuffs ITN deal for Sir Trevor
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Sir Trevor McDonald has signed a multimillion-pound contract to present ITV's revived News at Ten for four years, after executives said he could "name his price".
fields.body:
Sir Trevor McDonald has signed a multimillion-pound contract to present ITV's revived News at Ten for four years, after executives said he could "name his price".

ITV was determined to keep "Britain's favourite newscaster" when its flagship bulletin goes head-to-head with BBC1's Ten O'Clock News. There were fears that Sir Trevor might defect at the end of his present contract.

His deal with the news organisation ITN, thought to be worth at least £2m, bolsters his position as Britain's highest paid news presenter and shores up ITN ahead of a planned stock market floatation.

ITV announced yesterday that News at Ten will return, with bongs, on January 22. Sir Trevor will front the programme on four nights a week, three of which will be broadcast at 10pm. The fourth will still be called News at Ten even if it is broadcast later, while the late Friday edition will be billed the "weekend news".

BBC executives branded it "news at when", saying their half-hour bulletin would command greater authority even if it lost out in the ratings. Sir Trevor hit back: "Ten o'clock is very much an ITV time."

News at Ten's two-year absence was dominated by tussles between ITV and the independent television commission. The broadcaster agreed to reinstate the programme after ratings fell for all its news programmes.

When the deal was announced last September, the BBC moved its main evening bulletin from 9pm to 10pm, to the fury of ITV and the culture secretary, Chris Smith. The corporation was accused of being unaccountable, after its move was waved through by a compliant board of governors.

Yesterday David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, said: "This is the second time we have moved the news in two years, and we have no intention of moving it again."

He conceded that viewers' choice would be limited but insisted that the onus was on the BBC to move its news back to 9pm if overall news audiences fell.

The BBC privately conceded that in the first few weeks of the new schedule it would lose out to ITV at 10pm. On the first day, ITV had scheduled the hit game show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? at 9pm, leading into its bulletin. The corporation insisted, however, that its news programmes were more popular overall than ITV's.

Tony Hall, director of news at the BBC, said it was committed to news at 10 o'clock six nights a week, and to "range, depth and breadth of coverage".

ITV is also reorganising its other bulletins. The 6.30pm news, presented until now by Sir Trevor, will be co-presented by Dermot Murnaghan and Mary Nightingale. When Kirsty Young returns from maternity leave she will take Ms Nightingale's place.

John Suchet will present ITV Lunchtime News alone. Katie Derham will remain as presenter of the weekend bulletins from Fridays to Saturdays, and Nicholas Owen will be a "floating presenter".

webTitle: Quentin to star in two ITV dramas

fields.headline: More ITV drama for Quentin
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Caroline Quentin is set to star in two more hard-hitting ITV dramas following her success in The Innocent. By Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
Caroline Quentin is set to star in two hard-hitting drama roles for ITV after her success in The Innocent.

In Blood Strangers, a four-part drama serial produced by Granada, she is to play a single mum whose daughter takes to prostitution.

Ms Quentin will also star in Hot Money, a factual drama also by Granada, about a group of women working for the Bank of England who decide to take it upon themselves to siphon off some of the old banknotes set aside to be incinerated.

Nick Elliott, ITV controller of drama, has hinted that ITV was keen to create more serious roles for Ms Quentin, who has made her name as a comedy actress.

He said:"Caroline is someone who could be extremely useful to ITV. She is very good at playing very ordinary women."

Mr Elliott added that he regretted that Ms Quentin was tied into a contract with the BBC.

Meanwhile Andy Harries, Granada controller of drama and comedy, said Ms Quentin "clearly had the potential to be a very big TV star".

Hot Money will start shooting next month, while Blood Strangers is to go into production in May or June.

Meanwhile, reports that Ms Quentin has been signed up to do a Men Behaving Badly spin-off for the BBC have been denied by the programme's creators, Hartswood Films.

webTitle: Versace's last collection

fields.headline: Versace's last collection
fields.standfirst: Murdered designer's art and furniture to go under hammer
fields.trailText: Murdered designer's art and furniture to go under hammer
fields.body:
Art and furniture from the Florida mansion where fashion designer Gianni Versace was murdered are to be sold at Sotheby's in New York, the auction house announced yesterday.

The eclectic collection, which features classical 19th century art as well as furniture upholstered in Versace's own designs, is expected to fetch up to £4.7m when it goes under the hammer in early April.

The auction comes more than three years after the 50-year-old designer was murdered at his mansion in Miami Beach.

The collection includes period furnishings from Europe and India, neo-Classical paintings, mosaics and ornate carvings.

Paintings include Antione Dubost's Le Retour D'Helene and Sophie Rude's The Death of Cenchirias, Son of Neptune, which hung in the designer's bedroom.
PA

webTitle: Brown hails advance of Britain's volunteer army

fields.headline: Brown hails advance of Britain's volunteer army
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown will today mark another stage in the government's vision of a million-strong volunteer army by claiming Britain is on the brink of a new era of active citizenship.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown will today mark another stage in the government's vision of a million-strong volunteer army by claiming Britain is on the brink of a new era of active citizenship.

Drawing on previous government pledges prepared by the government's active community unit sited in the Home Office, Mr Brown will claim that within five years every individual should be committed to giving a two hours a week to the community.

He will also suggest 100,000 over-50s could work in the voluntary sector, including hospitals and schools.

Most recent surveys have shown there has been a decline in volunteering by both older and younger people, threatening a major new pressure on the public purse.

Mr Brown is to present the change as part of a move towards the decentralisation of government and the handing of power to local areas.

Much of his thinking is derived from an analysis prepared on neighbourhood renewal developed by the social exclusion unit.

The 1m extra volunteers was set as a formal government target in a review established by the Treasury during the preparation of the summer comprehensive spending review.

Mr Brown claimed last night: "Instead of people looking always to Whitehall for solutions in locality after locality more and more people will themselves take charge of the decisions that most affect them. That is perhaps humbling for government, but quite the opposite for communities."

His remarks are likely to be met with scepticism in Labour local government, which believes it has suffered from ever greater centralisation and the loss of local government influence.

However some Labour analysts believe power needs to be devolved below formal local government representation to local estates and neighbourhoods, or parishes.

Previous research undertaken for the government has shown that volunteers rejected Tony Blair's vision of a new giving age, suggesting the phrase was patronising and failed to capture the dynamic in volunteering.

Mr Brown is to present the change as part of a move towards the decentralisation of government and the handing of power to local areas. Much of his thinking is derived from an analysis prepared on neighbourhood renewal developed by the social exclusion unit. The 1m extra volunteers was set as a formal government target in a review established by the Treasury during the preparation of the summer comprehensive spending review. Mr Brown claimed last night: "Instead of people looking always to Whitehall for solutions in locality after locality more and more people will themselves take charge of the decisions that most affect them. That is perhaps humbling for government, but quite the opposite for communities." His remarks are likely to be met with scepticism in Labour local government, which believes it has suffered from ever greater centralisation and the loss of local government influence. However some Labour analysts believe power needs to be devolved below formal local government representation to local estates and neighbourhoods, or parishes. Previous research undertaken for the government has shown that volunteers rejected Tony Blair's vision of a new giving age, suggesting the phrase was patronising and failed to capture the dynamic in volunteering.

webTitle: Straw to scrap £118m computer

fields.headline: Straw to scrap £118m computer
fields.trailText: The Home Office is to scrap a £118m computer system, condemned as virtually useless by probation officers, after a damning national audit office report found that equipment orders had been placed unlawfully.
fields.body:
The Home Office is to scrap a £118m computer system, condemned as virtually useless by probation officers, after a damning national audit office report found that equipment orders had been placed unlawfully.

A draft of the NAO report heavily criticises Jack Straw's department and the operation of the probation service's information service, a system bought from French company Bull.

The report, published yesterday in Computer Weekly magazine, reveals that costs rose 70% above the original budget, despite the system's failure to perform as well as expected.

The deal made with Bull has been declared legally suspect, and the NAO warns: "Legal advice received by the Home Office suggests that any new purchase orders raised under the enabling agreement are unlawful.

"As a result, for example, the Home Office is unable under the existing agreement to fund any expansion in the capacity of the current network to accommodate increased electronic traffic."

The indictment is a severe embarrassment for the Home Office after its installation of a computer system into the passport office was criticised when it led to long delays.

The Home Office has also been criticised for failures of its computer system for the immigration service.

The National Probation Service Information Systems Strategy (NPSISS) and a Common Case Management System (Crams) were intended to revolutionise the tracking of offenders.

The Home Office also spent £16m to avoid disruption from a millennium bug and £10m on maintenance, but now a new system is expected to be ordered.

The NAO records significant defects, including problems in transferring cases between local probation services.

Probation officers complain that the system is difficult to use, is unable to list dangerous offenders separately, is confused by similar first and surnames such as "John" and "Johnson", and mixes up people with the same date of birth.

A number even claim that it slows down on national lottery days, insisting that it uses the same electronic circuits as the game.

Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers, said: "The investigation vindicates the campaign that probation staff have run for the last six years.

"Crams has been a complete waste of taxpayers' money.

"It is crucial that the Home Office now learns from past mistakes to ensure that the new system is efficient and effective."

An NAO spokesman said yesterday: "This report has yet to be agreed with the Home Office, and we do not comment on draft reports."

The Home Office said it did not want to comment until the report was officially published this year.

webTitle: Obituary: Catherine Storr

fields.headline: Catherine Storr
fields.standfirst: Author who wrote children's books now deemed classics
fields.trailText: Author who wrote children's books now deemed classics.
fields.body:
Catherine Storr, who has died aged 87, was a prolific and successful author, mostly for children but also for adults. She wrote plays, short stories, and most recently had adapted one of her novels into an opera libretto. But she is known in particular for two outstanding children's books: Clever Polly and the Stupid Wolf and Marianne Dreams.

The first is a collection of stories for young children in which the resourceful and kind Polly outwits the enthusiastic but dim wolf over a number of encounters which are close enough to be alarming while funny enough to be reassuringly safe.

The second, for older readers, is an extended fantasy, as Marianne, convalescing and so with time on her hands, creates and enters a dream house where she meets Mark and faces the threat of destruction. Both are timeless and, though published in 1955 and 1958 respectively, are in print as "classics", with Clever Polly and the Stupid Wolf remaining a staple of the curriculum in primary schools.

Though externally so different, they show Storr's skill and enthusiasm as a story teller as well as reflecting her ability to create characters of remarkable insight, whose stories she tells in parallels of fantasy and reality.

This particular characteristic may come directly from Storr's professional background. Educated at St Paul's Girls' School, she went on to read English at Newnham College, Cambridge, and then qualified as a doctor and trained as a psychiatrist, working in London hospitals through the 50s and early 60s, before combining the two educational backgrounds by becoming an editor for Penguin Books.

Her clinical training enabled her to capture so surely the child's-eye view of the world. It also encouraged her analytic approach to writing and her concern to show the possibilities of explaining events in more than one way, both scientific or "real", and magical.

Sometimes this takes the traditional form of a ghost story as in The Mirror Ghost or of a mysterious puzzle as in The Chinese Egg. More interestingly, as in one of Storr's earliest titles, Polly and the Giant's Bride, it allows for a story in which there is no way of telling exactly what happens, allowing readers to interpret for themselves - a remarkable feat to bring off in a story for the very young.

Storr was married first to writer and psychiatrist Anthony Storr, with whom she had three daughters. But, like many other writers for children, Storr always claimed that she wrote for herself more than for children in general or even for any particular child.

While she was careful to keep up to date with contemporary externals, checking facts about schools, clothes, hobbies and, above all, speech, with her grandchildren and their friends, the impetus for what she wrote came from within herself.

She never forgot what it felt like to be a child, retaining the details of her own childhood absolutely. (Her father was a barrister and she was brought up in Kensington, with two brothers, one of whom was Hugo Cole, former music critic of the Guardian.) In particular, throughout her life Storr was captivated by the special, private make-believe world of dolls and their owners, knowing how "real" they could be. She kept forever her own favourite doll, Ruthy, who inspired her first book, Ingeborg and Ruthy (1940). For a few lucky children, she made the most elaborate dolls' clothes which carefully mirrored the owners' own tastes as to jeans or corduroy trousers, pyjamas or night-dresses.

Though Storr may not have written directly for her own daughters, they did inspire her to write specific stories, especially Polly, for whom the stories about the wolf were written and whose name was used so freely. From Emma came the inspiration for the tomboy Lucy stories, while Marianne Dreams was written for Sophia, with the name taken from a close schoolfriend. Much later, her grandson Hugo came to feature in Hugo and his Grandma and Hugo and His Grandma's Washing Day, two stories in which Storr parodied herself as an incompetent grandmother.

Storr's second husband was the economist Thomas Balogh, whom she married in 1970. Her own children having left home, she moved with him to a different house in Hampstead and continued to write, inspired partly by her own grandchildren and by her new extended family.

Storr did not like throngs of children, but forged very strong relationships with the individual ones she knew. She was never patronising or condescending to children, either in her writing or in person. With them, as with adults, she combined serious discussion with brilliant and infectious humour.

She is survived by her three daughters.

webTitle: Obituary: Elizabeth Anscombe

fields.headline: Elizabeth Anscombe
fields.standfirst:
An exhilarating philosopher, she took to sporting a monocle and smoking cigars

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: An exhilarating philosopher, she took to sporting a monocle and smoking cigars.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Anscombe, who has died aged 81, was considered by some to be the greatest English philosopher of her generation. She was professor of philosophy at Cambridge from 1970 to 1986, having already, as a research fellow at Oxford in the 50s, helped change the course of moral philosophy. Also influential in philosophy of mind, she pioneered contemporary action theory, and the pre-eminent philosopher Donald Davidson called her 1957 monograph Intention the best work on practical reasoning since Aristotle. The philosophical world owes her an enormous debt, too, for bringing Wittgenstein, probably the greatest philosopher of the 20th century, to public knowledge.

Anscombe went to Sydenham high school, where her reading between the ages of 12 and 15 led her to convert to Roman Catholicism. She got a first in Greats at St Hugh's College, Oxford, but came to inveigh against the dryness of Oxford philosophy. This was because she had come under the spell of Ludwig Wittgenstein, for whose classes she travelled to Cambridge every week. She became Wittgenstein's close friend and proselytiser, even adopting his mannerisms - the anguished head in hands, furrowed brow, long silences - and the tinge of an Austrian accent.

After his death in 1951 (she was at his deathbed), she became one of his three notoriously intractable literary executors, and co-edited his posthumous works. Her translation of his greatest work, the Philosophical Investigations, was remarkable. It is quoted all over the world as if it were verbatim Wittgenstein rather than a translation, being written in an English style which is itself compelling.

Wittgenstein famously said "philosophical problems arise when language goes on holiday", and spoke of trying to cure such problems by examining the way we use concepts. Anscombe applied a Wittgenstein-type analytic therapy to philosophy of mind. But her application was far more systematic and thoroughgoing than Wittgenstein's cryptic, suggestive hints, and was also distinctively her own. In Intention, she criticised the way philosophers since Descartes have had a conception of knowledge, even knowledge of one's own actions, as "incorrigibly contemplative", passive, speculative. In fact, she said, we know what our intentions are without observation; and between someone observing, and someone intending and performing, an action, there is what she called a difference in the "direction of fit" (of action to thought).

She gives the famous illustration of the contents of a basket which a shopper fills according to a list, and which a detective compiles a list of. If the shopper finds any discrepancy between his list and what is actually in the basket, he rectifies this not by altering the list (practical thought) but by altering what's in the basket (the action performed). If the detective wants to rectify discrepancies between his list (observational thought) and what's in the basket (the other's action observed), then he can indeed do so merely by altering the list. But our actions are intentional only under a description, said Anscombe, so that under one description ("I wanted to help") an action may be intentional, under others ("I interfered", "I stopped play") unintentional.

Anscombe thought that modern philosophy had also misunderstood ethics. In her seminal paper Modern Moral Philosophy (1958), she argued that notions like "moral obligation", "moral duty", "morally right", and "morally wrong", are now vacuous hangovers from the Judaeo-Christian idea of a law-giving God. Anscombe, of course, firmly believed in God herself, but she was examining the way language was actually used, and ethics done. She argued that "ought" has become "a word of mere mesmeric force", since it no longer has the corollary "because we are commanded by God".

Philosophers, however, have tried to find content in the deracinated ethical concepts, and failing to, have been induced to supply "an alternative (very fishy) content", such as that the right action is the one that produces the best possible consequences. However purportedly different, in fact, all contemporary moral philosophies lead to this sort of "consequentialism" (it was Anscombe who coined that now-indispensable term), which blithely countenances the execution of an innocent person as a potentially right action. Anscombe famously asserted of someone who thought in this way, "I do not want to argue with him: he shows a corrupt mind." She urged the abandonment of "the law conception of ethics" and a return to the avowedly secular Aristotelian concepts of practical reasoning and virtue. And she insisted that it was no longer possible to do moral philosophy without doing philosophy of mind, thoroughly investigating concepts such as "action", "intention", and "pleasure" in their non-moral sense.

Two years earlier, in 1956, she had demonstrated in a very practical way her opposition to consequentialism. When it was proposed that Oxford should give President Truman an honorary degree, she and two others opposed this because of his responsibility for the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Although overruled, they forced a vote, instead of the customary automatic rubber-stamping of the proposal. "For men to choose to kill the innocent as a means to their ends is always murder," declared Anscombe's pamphlet, Mr Truman's Degree. It sarcastically condoled with the Censor of St Catherine's for having to make a speech "which should pretend to show that a couple of massacres to a man's credit are not exactly a reason for not showing him honour".

Anscombe was never afraid to voice unpopular views, scandalising liberal colleagues such as Bernard Williams with her paper against contraception (later published in revised form by the Catholic Truth Society) and condemnation of homosexuality.

Outspoken, often rude, she was sometimes dubbed "Dragon Lady". For a time she sported a monocle, and had a trick of raising her eyebrows and letting it fall on her ample bosom, which somehow made her yet more daunting. But, while giving short shrift to pretension and pomposity, she took endless pains with those students she considered serious. Her exhilarating tutorials went on for hours, leaving everyone exhausted; students could drop into her house at any time to discuss philosophy among the dirty nappies. Married to Peter Geach, a fellow-philosopher and Catholic, she was always called "Miss Anscombe", which caused some consternation at the Radcliffe Infirmary whenever she turned up to give birth (she had seven children).

Perhaps Anscombe's best work was done in the 50s, but her three-volume Collected Philosophical Papers (1981) contain trenchant papers on epistemology, metaphysics, history of philosophy, and philosophy of religion. Causality and Determination, her inaugural lecture on becoming professor of Cambridge in 1970, presented an extraordinarily original and controversial view of causation.

An affectionate tribute on her retirement in 1986 called her "a modern Daniel in the lions' den", but, although doggedly Catholic, Anscombe could also be radical and was never straitlaced. She was notorious for a forthright foulmouthedness which was only enhanced by the beauty of her voice. When presenting a paper on pleasure, she distinguished extrinsic pleasures - things we enjoy because of the description they fall under - and intrinsic pleasures - things we enjoy regardless of how they are described; and she cited, as an example of the latter, "shitting", strongly pronouncing the double "t", and with such sternness that her academic audience were too daunted to laugh. (Unfortunately this was probably one of the many papers she threw away as insufficiently good.)

Once, threatened by a mugger in Chicago, she told him that that was no way to treat a visitor. They soon fell into conversation and he accompanied her, admonishing her for being in such a dangerous neighbourhood. She chain-smoked for some years, but bargained with God, when her second son was seriously ill, that she would give up smoking cigarettes if he recovered. Feeling the strain of this the following year, she decided that her bargain had not mentioned cigars or pipes, and took to smoking these.

Except when pregnant, she wore trousers, often under a tunic, which, in the 50s and 60s, was often disapproved of. Once, entering a smart restaurant in Boston, she was told that ladies were not admitted in trousers. She simply took them off. When she threatened one of her children, "If you do that again, I'll put you on the train to Bicester", and he did, she felt obliged, given her views on fulfilling promises, actually to put him on the train. Bluff, courageous, determined, loyal, she argued that the word "I" does not refer to anything, but she certainly believed in the soul.

She is survived by her husband and their four daughters and three sons.

webTitle: Oil profits at 15-year high

fields.headline: Oil profits at 15-year high
fields.standfirst:
North Sea returns reach 36% while manufacturing flounders

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The profitability of British oil companies climbed to a 15-year high in the third quarter of last year, dwarfing the meagre gains made in manufacturing, according to official figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
The profitability of British oil companies climbed to a 15-year high in the third quarter of last year, dwarfing the meagre gains made in manufacturing, according to official figures published yesterday.

The rise in oil and gas prices in 2000, which has since gone into reverse, boosted the rate of return of the North Sea sector to 36.4%, up from 34.8% in the second quarter, said the office for national statistics.

The figures square with company results such as Shell's showing of record levels of profitability last year as the price of crude oil hit its peak of more than $35 (£24) a barrel in the autumn and are likely to reignite the debate about a windfall tax on oil companies.

Petrol prices have been at the top of the political agenda in recent months, stoked by last year's oil blockade. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, said this month that he was keeping a watchful eye on the oil companies to make sure they pass on the falling price of crude oil to consumers at the petrol pump, though he qualified his remarks by saying he would not do anything to damage investment and job creation in the sector.

"He is determined not to make short-term decisions on taxation based on short-term movements in the oil price," a Treasury spokesman said.

Richard Walton, an ONS statistician, said the third quarter figures for oil companies were the highest for 15 years. "Other factors contributing to the increase in profits were the sav ings in operation and exploration costs," he said.

webTitle: Film: The best sword scene

fields.headline: The best sword scene
fields.standfirst: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.trailText: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.body:
The Yuan Compound, Western China. Having returned earlier that day, the great warrior Li Mu Bai (Chow Yun-Fat) is visiting the home of Yu (Michelle Yeoh).

"Monk Zheng said you were at Wudan Mountain," says Yu. "He said you were practising deep meditation."

"Yes."

"The mountain must be so peaceful. I envy you."

"I left the training early."

"Why? You're a Wudan fighter. Training is everything."

"During my meditation training, I came to a place of deep silence. I was surrounded by light. Time and space disappeared. I had come to a place my master had never told me about."

"You were enlightened?"

"No. I didn't feel the bliss of enlightenment. Instead, I was surrounded by an endless sorrow. I couldn't bear it. I broke off my meditation. I couldn't go on. There was something pulling me back."

"What was it?"

"Something I can't let go of. You are leaving soon?"

"We're preparing a convoy for a delivery to Peking."

"Perhaps I could ask you to deliver something to Sir Te for me."

Li produces a long package; unwrapping it, he reveals an ancient, beautifully engraved sword. Yu gasps.

"The Green Destiny Sword? You're giving it to Sir Te?"

"I am. He has always been our greatest protector."

"I don't understand. How can you part with it? It has always been with you."

Slowly, Li shakes his head.

"Too many men have died at its edge. It only looks pure because blood washes so easily from its blade."

See also: The Krays, Pulp Fiction, Blade.

Don't see also: Excalibur.

Pointless trivia: Michelle Yeoh was 1983's Miss Malaysia.

webTitle: Ulster scraps league tables for schools

fields.headline: Ulster scraps league tables for schools
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: School performance tables in Northern Ireland were scrapped yesterday by the executive's education minister, Martin McGuinness, delighting teaching unions and angering the opposition.
fields.body:
School performance tables in Northern Ireland were scrapped yesterday by the executive's education minister, Martin McGuinness, delighting teaching unions and angering the opposition.

The decision comes just a few weeks before the national assembly for Wales launches its own consultation on the performance tables.

Mr McGuinness made the move after consulting 1,036 people, including parents, teachers and school governors. It was found that three-quarters were opposed to the continued publication of the tables.

"Many respondents felt the tables were divisive and failed to offer schools the opportunity to give parents a rounded picture of the school," Mr McGuinness said.

The education department is to review the information schools are required to publish in their prospectuses, in order to ensure "meaningful comparisons" can be made between schools.

Mr McGuinness said: "I am convinced that this decision is the right one for our schools and our parents. It's about increasing the morale of teachers rather than damaging it. In future schools will be able to set their performance in the context of information on the school as a whole.

"Parents will receive all the information they require on any given school from a single source and be in a better position to take a decision on the school's overall performance."

But Sammy Wilson, deputy chairman of the education committee in the Northern Ireland assembly, said: "Martin McGuinness is intent on destroying the education system in Northern Ireland and in doing so creating a disadvantage for a generation of young people.

"The dismantling of any central measurement of performance is yet another step down that road."

Mr McGuinness has moved quickly after the end of the consultation, which he launched in October last year. Of three options presented, 51% backed the idea to require schools to provide parents with a copy of their prospectus, with details of exam results, either at open nights or on request.

Some 23% supported the idea of providing details of exam results in booklets for pupils transferring to secondary school and the same proportion wanted the system to remain the same.

The performance tables were first published in 1993 and cost £45,000 a year to produce in Northern Ireland.

The move by the Sinn Fein minister brings Northern Ireland closer to the policy in the Irish republic, which bans the publication of statistics of school performance.

Jane Davidson, assembly minister for education and lifelong learning in Wales, announced her own review of performance tables in November. She said she has an open mind on the issue but is keen to introduce a "value added" element into the published information.

But in London, the Department for Education said: "Ministers in England are fulIy committed to the continued publication of performance tables which provide valuable information for parents on performance, which is an essential part of our standards agenda." Performance tables are also published in Scotland.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "Northern Ireland leads the way in abolishing a system which has been extremely unfair and has been used erroneously to define the quality of schools."

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers said: "I'm absolutely certain it was the right thing to do and I'm pretty convinced it won't have any adverse impact on standards in Northern Ireland's schools."

webTitle: Exclusion threat to poor pupils not in uniform

fields.headline: Exclusion threat to poor pupils not in uniform
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Children from poor families are being threatened with exclusion from school because they cannot afford the cost of uniforms, the Citizens' Advice Bureau said today.
fields.body:
Children from poor families are being threatened with exclusion from school because they cannot afford the cost of uniforms, the Citizens' Advice Bureau said today.

In a report, Uniform Failure, it has called on the government to order councils to provide school uniform grants for low income families.

Of 125 local education authorities surveyed, 36 did not provide any financial help, it said. Only 49 provided help at both primary and secondary school level.

"Not having the proper uniform can mark out a child as being poor or even as being a troublemaker," said David Harker, chief executive of the National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux.

Uniform costs ranged from £105 to £274, but the average grant available when a child started secondary school was £49, the report said.

Many authorities restricted the number of times parents could receive financial help for uniform, in some cases to only once in a school career. Some schemes excluded parents on income support and jobseeker's allowance unless they could demonstrate exceptional hardship.

The Department for Education said yesterday it was up to councils to decide whether to fund uniform grants.

Headteachers could exclude pupils for "persistent breaches of school policy", said a department spokeswoman. But schools were "expected to be reasonable" in setting uniform standards.

webTitle: Bill Gates derided as a dinosaur

fields.headline: Gates derided as a dinosaur
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of Microsoft
More net news
Chilly Messiah with a mission to blank out the competitive world
fields.trailText: Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, has been derided as a "dinosaur" by rivals and an arrogant "miscreant" by the US judge which ordered the break up of the company.
fields.body:
Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, has been derided as a "dinosaur" by rivals and an arrogant "miscreant" by the US judge which ordered the break up of the company.

In an exclusive serialisation of his new book, World War 3.0: Microsoft and Its Enemies, starting in the Guardian today, Ken Auletta, examines the steps leading up to last year's landmark decision that the software giant was guilty of breaking US anti-trust laws and should be split into two.

Several competitors attack Microsoft in the book. Nobuyuki Idei, the head of Sony, says, "Gates is an OS [operating system] dinosaur ... He wrote a book about the road ahead, but it is really the road back."

Rob Glaser, a former Microsoft executive, tells Mr Auletta, that the Seattle-based company is "the IBM of today" - referring to the mainframe computer group which lost out to nimbler rivals in the 1980s.

Microsoft has appealed against last year's decision by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. In astonishing comments at this stage of the case, Judge Jackson describes the appeal court judges as "supercilious" and lacking trial experience.

The book also contains exclusive comments from Richard Posner, the anti-trust expert appointed to mediate between Microsoft, the US government and 19 US states. The government files its case in the appeal tomorrow.

webTitle: Israel accused of policy of murder

fields.headline: Israel accused of policy of murder
fields.standfirst:
Palestinians say Barak is giving the military a free hand for assassinations

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinians say Barak is giving the military a free hand for assassinations.
fields.body:
The Israeli government last night stood accused of sanctioning the systematic hunting down and assassination of Palestinian activists it deems to be security threats in the West Bank and Gaza.

As Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, clings to the tattered shreds of his reputation as a peacemaker before next month's elections, Israel's Peace Now movement broke a long silence to allege that he is giving the army a free hand to eliminate suspected opponents.

The eruption of anger against Israel's assassination campaign follows the slaying on New Year's Eve of a middle-aged dentist who was a senior official in the West Bank health service, and a leading figure in Yasser Arafat's Fatah organisation, Thabet Thabet. For many peace activists, Thabet was a friend, and trusted ally. He was among the first Palestinians to dare to reach out to Israelis during the late 1980s.

The shock of his death - delivered by long-range automatic weapons fire outside his home in broad daylight - has brought belated scrutiny to a military strategy for containing the intifada in the West Bank and Gaza that has been in force since November 9.

There is no accurate count of those systematically targeted for elimination as the military does not always own up to specific killings. Mr Arafat's Palestinian Authority says 19 people have been assassinated; other Palestinian sources put the figure as high as 30.

Israel has always claimed the right to selectively assassinate its enemies. But the new strategy threatens not only combatants, but those coordinating attacks. With Thabet's death, even the political leaders of Fatah are potential prey, although until the outbreak of the intifada, the group was Israel's main partner in the peace process, and cooperated with Israeli security services in arresting Hamas and Islamic Jihad bombers.

The new assassination policy is confirmed by Israeli officials, who have owned up to some of the killings, and have not denied a hand in Thabet's death. "I can tell you unequivocally what the policy is," the deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, told Israel Radio last week. "If anyone has committed or is planning to carry out terrorist attacks, he has to be hit. It is effective, precise, and just."

But after weeks of stunned silence, the Israeli left is no longer willing to tolerate that argument - especially when applied to Thabet. "Gunning down a person coming out of his house in broad daylight is a mafia-style action and it is not legitimate for any government," said Yehudith Harel.

The outcry corresponds with a deepening sense of betrayal among the Israeli left, who accuse Mr Barak of squandering a chance to negotiate peace, and of resorting to military firepower and economic punishment to end the uprising.

Ms Harel, a peace activist, worked closely with Thabet from 1988 to foster talks between Israelis and Palestinians. In 1994, when her soldier son was killed in a road accident, Thabet came to his funeral at a military cemetery - a generous act for a Palestinian nationalist who had been sentenced to three years' house arrest in the early 1970s.

"What kind of military activity is this?" she asked. "This is absolutely illegal."

On Tuesday, a lawyer acting for Thabet's widow set out to prove just that, lodging an injunction in Israel's supreme court to stop the army from killing activists of Yasser Arafat's Fatah organisation, and Hamas and Islamic Jihad. Israel does not have capital punishment.

"All these killings are against Israeli law," said Naila Attiya, a Palestinian citizen of Israel. "There are assassination plans, and maybe by going to the court we can stop them from being carried out."

Yesterday, Palestinian officials said they were gathering evidence to try Mr Barak and his government for war crimes.

"We consider the Israeli government, the prime minister and all members of the Israeli government as criminals who should be prosecuted," Yasser Abd Rabbo, the Palestinian information minister, told a press conference. He said the assassinations could derail what little is left of the peace process.

'Initiated attacks'

Israeli military officials obliquely announced the new policy in early November, saying they were moving towards "initiated attacks" to stop Fatah militia, known locally as tanzim , from firing on Jewish outposts or settlers in the West Bank, or placing roadside bombs. The first to die under the policy, Hussein Abayat, was killed on November 9.

Soon after, the military stepped up the liquidation policy, calculating that the targeting of Fatah activists would be less damaging to Israel's international image then the bombardments of Palestinian cities ordered earlier in the intifada.

Until Thabet was killed on December 31, the Israeli public was broadly supportive. But the assassination of such a high-profile figure was too much for many to stomach.

"He was a man of peace," said Uri Avnery, who has been active in the Israeli peace movement for nearly 30 years. "He cooperated with us for years. Even when he was under arrest years ago, he spoke about a peace. But he was also a patriot, and when the war of liberation started, I suppose he was part of the mass movement."

Ms Attiya's appeal to the supreme court, which she says is based on the Geneva Convention as well as Israeli law, marks the first time a prime minister has been asked to answer in court for Israel's decades-old policy of assassinating opponents it accuses of plotting acts of terror.

A former commando, Mr Barak famously put on a blond wig and a dress to sneak into Beirut 27 years ago to assassinate three Palestinians suspected of the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics. He was also involved in the 1988 killing in Tunis of Abu Jihad - one of the most romantic figures of the Palestinian movement.

Mr Barak - who doubles as Israel's defence minister - told a recent meeting of the foreign and defence committee of the parliament that he had given his approval to the operations. Several MPs asked Mr Barak to stop. He refused.

In an interview on Newsnight, he issued a coy denial of a new assassination policy, but admitted: "There is a clear kind of permanent policy here to hit those who hit you."

For Israeli peace activists, Thabet's killing is especially tragic as he was directly responsible for saving the lives of 20 Israeli soldiers only weeks ago. In mid-October, days after a Palestinian mob hacked to death two Israeli reservists who strayed into the West Bank city of Ramallah, Thabet intervened with the Israeli army to arrange the return of soldiers who had blundered into Tulkaram.

"This is a reward for people who save the lives of Israeli soldiers," said Bassam Eid of the Palestinian Human Rights Monitoring Group.

webTitle: US aid worker seized as chaos rules in long fight for Chechnya

fields.headline: US aid worker seized as chaos rules in long fight for Chechnya
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: An American charity worker has been kidnapped in Chechnya in a daylight ambush - apparently by Chechen rebels - that gives the lie to claims by Russia that it controls the battered republic.
fields.body:
An American charity worker has been kidnapped in Chechnya in a daylight ambush - apparently by Chechen rebels - that gives the lie to claims by Russia that it controls the battered republic.

Kenneth Gluck, 38, who heads the mission of the Dutch branch of Médecins Sans Frontières in the Chechnya region, was abducted by masked gunmen while travelling out of the village of Starye Atagi south of the Chechen capital, Grozny, on Tuesday, MSF announced yesterday.

A fellow American, Jonathan Little, who heads the Moscow office of the Paris-based Action Contre la Faim charity, evaded capture and was believed to be nursing slight wounds.

Hundreds of people have been kidnapped in Chechnya in recent years, causing the major charities and aid organisations to pull out international staff. Only over the past 15 months have the charities hesitantly started to return.

The kidnapping came amid increasing evidence of disarray in the Russian campaign to tame the Chechen rebels, 15 months into what has become a savage war of attrition.

Two Russian local government chiefs in northern Chechnya have just resigned in disgust at the policy of the Kremlin and the Russian military, complaining that Russian tactics are inflicting a "war without end" on Chechnya.

Sergei Ponomarenko, one of the two who resigned, told the newspaper Izvestia yesterday that the Russian or loyalist Chechen administrators are using their positions to line their pockets. He also said that the rebels are able to move freely, distribute their propaganda across Chechnya with impunity, and have seized the initiative from the Russians.

President Vladimir Putin said last week that his priority in Chechnya was "social rehabilitation and economic recovery". But a senior Kremlin aide told Mr Ponomarenko that "there is no programme yet for restoring the republic, so there's no point putting any money in".

The guerrillas are killing Russian troops, police, and "collaborationist" members of the pro-Moscow Chechen administration on a daily basis, as well as its local supporters.

A village Muslim religious leader was shot dead while praying on Tuesday. Two relatives of another imam murdered last summer were also killed. Three Russian policemen died in a booby-trap bomb blast. An aide to Akhmad Kadyrov, the pro-Moscow Chechen leader, was wounded. Seven Russian soldiers were injured by a mine in Grozny.

Such is the daily litany of casualties from a war that the Russians long ago claimed to have won. In October Moscow said that 2,472 Russian servicemen had died in Chechnya. The defence ministry and the office of the Chechnya war spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, yesterday refused to provide an updated tally.

In a recent detailed report to the Russian government after a visit to Chechnya, Ruslan Khasbulatov, a former Russian parliamentary leader and himself a Chechen, complained that the Russian forces were systematically looting Chechnya and deliberately prolonging the war to sabotage any political settlement.

"This has turned into a war against an entire civilian population. That's a fact."

Mr Khasbulatov called for a "radical shift" in Kremlin policy towards Chechnya, while liberal Russian MPs have been exploring peace talks with the Chechen separatist leader, President Aslan Maskhadov.

But Mr Putin last week condemned Mr Maskhadov as illegitimate, offered no hint of a political settlement, and insisted Russia "has to bring the process to its logical end from the military point of view".

Tuesday's kidnapping occurred as Mr Gluck was leaving Starye Atagi in a convoy of four vehicles. Masked gunmen opened fire on the convoy.

"They were stopped. Kenny was singled out and taken away," said Wouter Kok, an MSF colleague in Amsterdam who yesterday was organising contacts to secure Mr Gluck's release.

The Russian authorities instantly declared that Mr Gluck deserved his fate since the aid workers were travelling without permission and without a Russian military escort.

"Part of the blame for this tragedy lies with the international organisation," said Lieutenant-General Ivan Babichev, the Russian military commander in Chechnya. "Such conduct by foreign citizens and international aid workers in Chechnya is dangerous. Unfortunately that's been proven in the case of Kenny."

But Jim Lewis of MSF in Moscow said Mr Gluck had all the required paperwork from the Russian authorities, adding: "The Russians are issuing misinformation."
