webTitle: Ten targets of Israeli campaign

fields.headline: Assassinated
fields.standfirst:
Ten targets of Israeli campaign

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ten targets of Israeli campaign.
fields.body:
1 Hussein Abayat, 33, father of six. Killed on November 9 at Beit Sahour, West Bank.

Abayat, the first victim of the "initiated attacks", was a baker by day and said by Israeli army to be a senior "terrorist" and a merchant of illegal weapons. He was was killed by missiles fired from Israeli helicopter gunships on a street in Bethlehem. Two Palestinian women nearby were killed, and nine others injured. Israel admitted the killing within hours. "We hit somebody very senior. We will hit anyone who tries to hit us," an Israeli general said.

2 Jamal Abdel-Razak, 30. Killed on November 22 at Morag junction in the Gaza Strip.

Abdel-Razak, a well-known Fatah activist during the first intifada, was travelling in a friend's car to college at Khan Yunis when he was ambushed by soldiers. Abdel-Razak's head was blown off in the resulting fire, which also killed the driver of his car, and two other Palestinian men in a nearby taxi.

The Israeli army claimed that it had killed four members of a Fatah cell, who had opened fire to avoid arrest.

3 Ibrahim Bani Odeh, 34, father of five. Killed on November 23 in Nablus.

Odeh, a leader of the military wing of Hamas, was killed a day after his release from jail, by a bomb planted in the headrest of the car he was driving, detonated by remote control from an Israeli military helicopter, according to the Palestinian governor of Nablus. Israeli military officials said he was killed in a "work accident" - code for deaths caused when assembling bombs.

4 Mahmoud al-Mughrabi, 24. Killed on December 11 at Beit Jala, a suburb of Bethlehem.

Mughrabi was shot in the head and chest by an Israeli undercover unit operating on a bypass road . Witnesses said he was in the area to plant a bomb on the tunnel road leading from the Jewish settlement of Gilo when they were caught by an Israeli patrol. Mugrabi's comrades fled, but he was shot in the leg. A few minutes later, they heard three gunshots.

5 Anwar Hamran, 28, father of one. Killed on December 11 in Nablus

Hamran, a leader in the military wing of Islamic Jihad, had just stepped out of his bookshop when he was attacked by Israeli forces opening fire from Mount Gerizim, which overlooks Nablus. Doctors said his body was riddled with 19 bullets. Witnesses said Hamran was unarmed and the shooting continued long after he fell to the ground. The Israeli army said he was armed, and they were returning fire.

6 Yusuf Abu Swayeh, 28, father of one. Killed on December 12 at al-Khader village, near Bethlehem.

Abu Swayeh, a well-known Fatah activist, was ambushed by a white Subaru with Israeli licence plates. Four men from Israel's elite Kingfisher undercover unit opened fire, and were backed up by machine-gun fire from a nearby Israeli army checkpoint. Palestinian newspapers said he had 17 separate bullet wounds.

7 Abbas al-Ewiwi, 26. Killed on December 13 at Hebron

Ewiwi, a member of the military wing of Hamas who had served five years in an Israeli jail, was shot dead moments after leaving the family's shoe repair shop to visit a neighbour. Doctors said he had been hit by three high-velocity bullets, suggesting he was targeted by snipers. Palestinian witnesses said there was no shooting in the area at the time. The Israeli army said Ewiwi had been armed with a pistol.

8 Hani Abu Bakra, 31, father of three. Killed on December 14 at Deir al-Balah in the Gaza Strip

A taxi driver and a student at the Islamic University in Gaza City who was suspected of belonging to the military wing of Hamas, Abu Bakra was going to town with six passengers when he was stopped at an Israeli military checkpoint. Soldiers ordered a woman out of the car, then opened fire with automatic rifles and from a tank. Abu Bakra took more than 20 bullets. Israeli newspapers said the operation was carried out by an anti-terror police unit.

9 Samih Maliabi, 25, father of two. Killed on December 17 at Kalandia refugee camp, near Ramallah.

A Fatah activist, Maliabi was killed by a bomb in an isolated area of the camp. According to some reports, he was killed by a booby-trapped mobile phone - mirroring the way Israeli agents killed a leading Palestinian bombmaker known as the engineer in 1996. Fatah says Maliabi was blown up by the Israeli security services. Israeli security officials say he was killed in a "work accident".

10 Thabet Thabet, 50, father of three. Killed on December 31 at Tulkaram.

The most controversial of Israel's assassinations. Thabet had links with Israeli peace activists stretching back 12 years. He was cut down by M-16 rifle fire from an Israeli car. Doctors said he was shot 15 times in the upper body. According to the Yediot Aharonoth newspaper, Israeli security sources admitted that their snipers selected Thabet for assassination, accusing him of ordering attacks against Israelis.

 Source: The Palestinian Human Rights Monitoring Group

webTitle: Defeatist Tory is mocked by Blair

fields.headline: Defeatist Tory is mocked by Blair
fields.standfirst:
'Lost cause' candidate target for MPs' ridicule ridiculed

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The good news for Nigel Hastilow, prospective Tory candidate for Edgbaston who admitted his party is widely regarded as a "lost cause", is that his will now be a high profile election campaign.
fields.body:
The good news for Nigel Hastilow, prospective Tory candidate for Edgbaston who admitted his party is widely regarded as a "lost cause", is that his will now be a high profile election campaign.

The bad news is that his admission - made in his monthly column on his website - has already brought him ridicule from the prime minister who yesterday enlisted him as ammunition during question time.

Referring to Mr Hastilow's admission that "for many voters and most of the media, the Conservative party is a lost cause", Mr Blair told MPs, to jeers and laughter: "If that's what their own candidates think of the Conservative party, I can't wait for the verdict of the country."

Last night, Tory central office sought to play down Mr Hastilow's apparent outburst, with a spokesman insisting his future was not in question. "You can't sack someone for being naive," he added.

But Julie Kirkbride, the Tory MP for nearby Bromsgrove, who is featured beaming alongside him on his website, declined to leap to his defence, and Mr Hastilow himself hastily posted a message on his website insisting the so-called monthly column was written nearly a year ago, and that William Hague had "taken our party a long way since I wrote this article".

The former Birmingham Post editor worked in the lobby in the early 90s and is described by a former lobby colleague as "one of the best journalists I have come across".

Former employees believe he will not regret his frankness.

As one said: "He's a vigorous, whole-hearted guy who believes a lot of the people around William Hague should get their fingers out, and if he seems to be slagging them off it probably just reflects his private views."

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Sketch

fields.headline: Rough ride as Hague spins out of control
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Why does William Hague get it so wrong these days? He used to be very effective.
fields.body:
Why does William Hague get it so wrong these days? He used to be very effective. He could toy with Tony Blair at question time, teasing him into a tremendous snit, making him sound both arrogant and peevish.

He would then sit back with a big happy grin, like William Brown after he'd knocked off a silk hat with a catapult.

Now young Hague resembles one of those model aeroplanes you see people flying in parks. Up in the gallery, his press secretary, Ms Amanda Platell, is working the controls. The plane buzzes aggressively, then soars round in a circle before banking into a steep rightward climb.

But suddenly she's confused the rudder with the joystick (not a mistake you'd expect the writer of an erotic novel to make) and before she can tug on his flaps (sorry, the style is catching) Hague is spiralling down towards the ground!

Admittedly, Mr Hague wasn't prepared for Nigel Hastilow. Mr Hastilow is Tory candidate for Edgbaston, and appears to have said some rum things. "The Conservative party is a lost cause" was one. "We've never had it so good," Mr Blair quoted him as saying, "people are prosperous, unemployment is falling, there's nothing much to worry about."

(I am told that before setting out on his - doubtless brief - career in the party, Mr Hastilow was a political journalist. But, on the whole, getting the story in the first paragraph is not the way to write election addresses: "Hague doomed" makes a good headline, but not in a Conservative pamphlet.)

Mr Blair kept quoting Mr Hastilow. "Some people might think it is madness to nail your colours to the mast of the Conservative party at this time of crisis," he had apparently also said.

By this time the exchange had gone on for almost half the whole 30-minute period. It was rapidly becoming Nigel Hastilow's question time. Where was he? Are we to hear his entire collected works between now and the election? And how much had the Labour party paid him? ("Two million pounds," shouted a Lib Dem.)

But even without Mr Hastilow, Mr Hague was in trouble. One word of advice I'd give him is never, ever, put a decimal point in your questions or speeches. Nobody follows decimal points. Even astro-physicists can't understand decimal points if they're not written down. So when Mr Hague began by saying, "if the tax burden is 36.9% of national income in one year, and 37.3%the next year, is it rising or falling?" we all switched off. Ms Platell grappled with the controls, but the plane was swerving towards that tree.

"Confusion reigns. Support is slipping away from the party nationally!" Mr Blair was reading from the Book of Hastilow again. Tories kept holding up their hands, backs out but with the thumb tucked behind the palm. This was meant to indicate the four years of Labour tax rises, but instead they looked like impatient restaurant guests waving for the bill.

Mr Blair quoted Ann Widdecombe who, he insisted, had said she would pay for extra policemen by sacking the home office press staff (of whom there are perhaps enough to patrol half a dozen villages, if provided with bikes and trouser clips.)

Mr Hague tried to fight back with a great peroration: the crisis in the police, in the recruitment of teachers, the NHS, the standstill on the railways on the roads. "You are all spin and no delivery!" he ended. But it was him who was spinning. Ms Platell had lost control, and the Tory leader was reduced to a sad little pile of splinters and string.

webTitle: Verdict takes official Shipman toll to 20

fields.headline: Verdict takes official Shipman toll to 20
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: A coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing yesterday after hearing that a 54-year-old patient of Harold Shipman died after the doctor visited her to treat an inflamed bunion.
fields.body:
A coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing yesterday after hearing that a 54-year-old patient of Harold Shipman died after the doctor visited her to treat an inflamed bunion.

The GP alerted relatives to Valerie Cuthbert's death when he returned to her home in Hyde, Greater Manchester, in May 1996, after calling to see her earlier that day, an inquest was told.

The ruling by the south Manchester coroner, John Pollard, takes Shipman's official death toll up to 20. The Hyde doctor was last year convicted of murdering 15 women patients. Since then Mr Pollard has ruled five other patients were unlawfully killed. He has yet to hear a further 22 inquests.

Mrs Cuthbert's sister-in-law, Susan Cuthbert, told yesterday's hearing that Shipman had telephoned her about the death and asked her to identify the body.

"He said he wanted to admit her to hospital but that she had refused and when he had come back later he found her dead," she said.

Once at her sister-in-law's house Mrs Cuthbert was reluctant to enter but Shipman said it would be all right because "she looked like she was asleep", sitting upright in a chair.

John Grenville, a GP, told the hearing that if the widow had died of heart failure she would have been gasping for air, trying to open windows and standing up, before collapsing to the floor.

He said that although it was "theoretically possible" for her to have died of heart failure it was unlikely.

When asked if an injection of morphine could lead to her dying in an upright position in a chair he replied: "The answer to that is yes because we know that has happened."

It was also revealed that Shipman had made as many as eight alterations to Mrs Cuthbert's cremation certificate and that an entry in the surgery visits books, made by Shipman, stated the widow was complaining of nothing more than a sore bunion.

John Grenville, a GP, told the hearing that if the widow had died of heart failure she would have been gasping for air, trying to open windows and standing up, before collapsing to the floor. He said that although it was "theoretically possible" for her to have died of heart failure it was unlikely. When asked if an injection of morphine could lead to her dying in an upright position in a chair he replied: "The answer to that is yes because we know that has happened." It was also revealed that Shipman had made as many as eight alterations to Mrs Cuthbert's cremation certificate and that an entry in the surgery visits books, made by Shipman, stated the widow was complaining of nothing more than a sore bunion.

webTitle: Bin Laden stars at Afghan wedding of the year

fields.headline: Bin Laden stars at Afghan wedding of the year
fields.trailText: Afghanistan's social event of the year was no match for the wedding of Madonna and Guy or Posh and Becks. But the atmosphere was as jolly as it ever gets in Kandahar.
fields.body:
Afghanistan's social event of the year was no match for the wedding of Madonna and Guy or Posh and Becks. But the atmosphere was as jolly as it ever gets in Kandahar.

Osama bin Laden - one of America's 10 most wanted men, with a $5m price on his head - beamed and shook hands with guests at the wedding of his son, Mohammed.

In what was claimed to be exclusive footage, the Arab satellite channel, al-Jazeera, yesterday showed father, son and male guests squatting on a carpet in a tent.

"It was such a simple wedding ... however, it revealed much," al-Jazeera said. There was, for a start, no hint of risqué jokes about the groom's bachelor life in the speeches.

Ayman el-Zawahiri, the most distinguished guest, made the first speech - about the Palestinian uprising. As leader of the Egyptian jihad, he is believed to have organised the assassination of President Anwar Sadat in Cairo in 1981.

He is also an absentee defendant, along with Bin Laden, in a trial which opened in New York on January 3. Both men are accused of involvement in the 1998 bomb attacks on US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania which killed 224 people. They face possible death sentences if convicted.

The bride is a daughter of Abu Hafas al-Masri, an Egyptian who fought alongside Bin Laden against Soviet forces in Afghanistan during the 1980s, and now serves as his military aide and deputy. She has not been named, but in a country where women are banned from working and from education beyond the age of eight, that is not surprising.

Both bride and groom were born in Pakistan while their fathers were fighting across the border in Afghanistan.

The ceremony, which took place on Tuesday, was attended by Afghan officials and Arabs living in the country, the television station said.

Last month the UN imposed fresh sanctions on Afghanistan's Taliban regime, demanding that they hand over Bin Laden for trial. The Taliban say it is against tradition to hand over a guest to his enemies.

Some observers yesterday saw the photo opportunity presented by the marriage as a further gesture of defiance against the US at a time when jurors are being sworn in for "We are not aware of the marriage," a spokesman said.

webTitle: 50,000 organs secretly stored in hospitals

fields.headline: 50,000 organs secretly stored in hospitals
fields.standfirst: More on the Bristol babies inquiry
fields.trailText: The true scale of the scandal of human organ retention by hospitals will be revealed today by the government's chief medical officer, who will tell parents and professionals that 50,000 organs are being stored in hospitals in England alone. The number far exceeds expectations.
fields.body:
The true scale of the scandal of human organ retention by hospitals will be revealed today by the government's chief medical officer, who will tell parents and professionals that 50,000 organs are being stored in hospitals in England alone. The number far exceeds expectations.

Liam Donaldson will say that what was done in the name of the NHS over many years was an affront to families who had lost their loved ones.

Addressing a public seminar, whose audience will include top pathologists and other senior doctors, he will say "some of the past practices around organ retention belong to an era where decisions were made by the NHS for patients, but not with patients.

"This has caused a period of immense distress for families, especially in places like Bristol and Liverpool, when they found out their children's organs were taken without their knowledge. Something went seriously wrong in the way the health service dealt with the issue of organ retention."

Prof Donaldson will pledge that the government "will do whatever it takes to put things right, changing the law if necessary to ensure that relatives are given the right kind of information so they can give consent in a fully informed way if they choose to do so."

At Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, where an inquiry will report shortly, more than 3,000 children's organs have been discovered; other hospitals were not thought to have anything like that number.

The chief medical officer will offer an unmitigated apology and assurances for the future to the parents of the Alder Hey children and those whose children died and had organs removed at the Bristol royal infirmary who have been invited to today's seminar. None of the parents knew that hearts, brains and other whole organs would be removed and kept after the autopsy on their son or daughter.

Ian Kennedy, chairman of the inquiry into children's deaths following heart surgery at Bristol, published an interim report into organ retention at the hospital last May. He found that the law was complex and obscure. Different laws covered hospital autopsies - which help doctors find out about the progress of disease - and those ordered by the coroner to find out the cause of death. Prof Kennedy recommended at least a new code of practice and preferably a new law.

Prof Donaldson has issued interim guidance to hospitals, requiring them to tell parents and relatives exactly what an autopsy involves and get their explicit permission if there is any need to remove organs.

Today's seminar is part of his information-gathering process on the way to producing his final report to the health secretary, Alan Milburn. That is expected, along with the Alder Hey inquiry report, before the end of the month.

Ed Bradley, chairman of the Alder Hey parents' support group, said more than 140 parents and relatives had travelled to London for the seminar and were glad of the opportunity to give evidence, "however, we do question how much benefit can be gained from a one-day conference where we have only been given five minutes to represent our views." They also felt it would be more appropriate to discuss the way forward after the Alder Hey inquiry had reported.

Alder Hey hospital is generally considered a special case, because whole organ systems were found to have been collected by a consultant pathologist, Dick Van Velzen, who is facing disciplinary hearings at the General Medical Council.

Bristol parents at the seminar will be asking for Prof Kennedy's recommendations to be implemented and questioning why there has been no action since his report was published. "It was quite clear the law was in a mess," said Steve Parker, chairman of the Bristol Heart Children's Action Group.

webTitle: Injustice laid bare by naked campaigner

fields.headline: Injustice laid bare by naked campaigner
fields.trailText: To the police and prosecutor, Vincent Bethell was a danger to public morals. To his friends and fellow members of the Freedom to be Yourself campaign he was a pioneer trying to make the world a better place.
fields.body:
To the police and prosecutor, Vincent Bethell was a danger to public morals. To his friends and fellow members of the Freedom to be Yourself campaign he was a pioneer trying to make the world a better place.

Yesterday a jury of two women and 10 men found in his favour, clearing him of causing a public nuisance by repeatedly stripping in crowded streets last summer.

Courtroom one at Southwark crown court, London, was the battleground for the debate on decency, morality and self-expression as Mr Bethell, 28, became the first person to stand trial in an English court naked.

As he heard the unanimous not guilty verdict yesterday he punched the air with both fists and shouted: "Being human is not a crime."

Judge George Bathurst-Norman responded darkly: "I would not go away too much with that idea. It is simply not a public nuisance in these circumstances."

Orlando Gibbons, for the prosecution, had told the court that Mr Bethell's behaviour was likely to "harm the morals of the public or their comfort, or obstruct the public in the enjoyment of their rights".

But Mr Bethell vowed to continue his campaign and insisted that far from trying to harm public morals, he sought to bring happiness and purity to a corrupted society.

"This is an historic day," he said outside the court, clutching his clothes in plastic bags and wearing only goose pimples.

"It's a great success but it will only be a true success when everyone overcomes their fears about their body. Life's too short to be ashamed of the human body and humanity.

"To view the human body as a sex object is an unreal perception of the human appearance."

Referring to his previous trials for public nakedness, he said: "On the other occasions I have been convicted by magistrates, but this is the first time I have been tried by members of the public. The jury trial is so important for justice."

His solicitor, Mike Schwarz, said the verdict had vindicated his client's belief that non-sexual public nudity was not a crime. "The public were at worst bemused and at best exhilarated by what he did."

But, in evidence, police officers said they had received a string of complaints about Mr Bethell's nakedness, resulting in his arrest six times, although none of the complainants gave evidence.

He was eventually refused bail because he insisted he would continue to protest naked if released and spent five months on remand at Brixton prison, held in the segregation unit because he would not put on clothes.

Russell Higgs, another member of the campaign, is still on remand at Brixton awaiting trial for a public order offence.

While few can doubt Mr Bethell's passion and conviction, even his family find it difficult to comprehend his willingness to face prison for the cause. "I can't understand that, but I think he's raised some interesting issues regarding how we treat other people and discriminate," said his father Michael from his home in Tyldesley, near Manchester, yesterday.

webTitle: Prince backs labels to conserve fish

fields.headline: Prince backs labels to conserve fish
fields.standfirst: Special report: global fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales yesterday called for a nationwide fish labelling scheme which would allow consumers to choose fish from sustainable sources and outlaw indiscriminate overfishing.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales yesterday called for a nationwide fish labelling scheme which would allow consumers to choose fish from sustainable sources and outlaw indiscriminate overfishing.

The prince is concerned about methods which cause the destruction of wildlife in fishing nets, and the throwing back into the sea of dead undersized fish.

In a magazine article he urges consumers to support the Marine Stewardship Council, a British-based body which is introducing a new product label for sustainably caught seafood.

None of the fish caught round Britain qualifies for the MSC label apart from Thames blackwater herring. The organisation does not believe that any of the EU's fishing policies are sustainable and so in effect the prince is urging people not to buy fish from the North sea or from British fishermen. Fisheries ministers from the EU, including Britain's Elliott Morley, are to meet next month to try to devise a rescue package for North sea cod, which is disappearing because of 30 years of overfishing.

Mr Morley endorsed Prince Charles's ideas last night. "The government is discussing the most comprehensive stock recovery plans for the North sea, which involve significant cuts in quotas, including measures that would allow juvenile fish to escape. The goal is to make the North sea and other areas sustainable resources for the benefit of consumers, fishermen and fish producers."

In an article on the fishing industry to be published in the Field magazine next week Prince Charles draws attention to the decline of the albatross population caused by long line fishermen in the Antarctic. Long liners are fishing to extinction the Patagonian tooth fish, sold in UK supermarkets.

After condemning fishing practices, the prince said: "The MSC's labelling scheme provides a real opportunity for individual consumers to make an informed choice. As more and more fisheries are certified, we will increasingly be able to purchase fish without worrying about the state of the fishery or the damage caused to other marine life."

John Gummer, the former Conservative fisheries minister who is the chairman of the MSC, said yesterday: "His royal highness has reminded us all of the paramount urgency of addressing the environmental crisis faced by the world's fisheries."

At present the MSC label offers a narrow choice - West Australian rock lobster, Alaskan salmon or the Thames herring - but 20 more and much larger fisheries are under evaluation for certification. The scheme is an independent charity but was originally set up in 1996 by WWF and Unilever, the largest buyer of frozen white fish in the world with 25% of the world market.

Unilever has put pressure on fishing fleets worldwide by setting a deadline of 2005 to buy all its fish from MSC certified sustainable sources.

webTitle: Lab creates killer virus by accident

fields.headline: Lab creates killer virus by accident
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Australian scientists who made a killer virus by accident have raised the spectre of biological weapons in the hands of terrorists or rogue states.
fields.body:
Australian scientists who made a killer virus by accident have raised the spectre of biological weapons in the hands of terrorists or rogue states.

The virus kills mice, not humans. The researchers were actually working on a mouse contraceptive vaccine for pest control, according to New Scientist today. But they started with a mousepox virus that normally made laboratory mice feel mildly ill. They inserted an extra gene, and ended up with a virus that wiped out all animals in nine days.

The news comes after years of increasing alarm about the potential of microbes - including modified forms of anthrax and smallpox - as weapons of war or terrorism. The US last year set aside $1.4bn (£940m) for protection against chemical or biological attacks.

Ron Jackson of CSIRO, the Australian research organisation, and Ian Ramshaw of the Australian National University in Canberra, chose the mousepox virus only because it was a standard way of transporting proteins into an animal to trigger antibodies. They inserted a gene from a natural molecule called interleukin-4 (Il-4) into the virus because this would boost antibody production.

The result astonished them: the Il-4 killed the mice by shutting down a vital part of their immune system. It also made the engineered virus unnaturally resistant to normal vaccines.

"It would be safe to assume that if some idiot did put human Il-4 into human smallpox, they'd increase the lethality quite dramatically," Dr Jackson said.

Smallpox was systematically eradicated worldwide during the 1970s. But there have been no vaccinations for decades, and one of the scientists who conducted the eradication warned in 1999 that a genetically-engineered version of the virus, in terrorist hands, would have a catastrophic effect on a population. The speed of modern communications would spread the infection all over the world in days.

Biological weapon research accelerated during the 20th century. There are treaties against the use of such weapons but a number of governments are known to have developed them. Britain and the US have backed research into protection against biological weapons, which inevitably involves handling potentially lethal microbes.

Campaigners have repeatedly warned that such knowledge is easily available to terrorist groups.

A report of the Australian experiment will appear in the Journal of Virology next month.

webTitle: Straw pledges crackdown on street crime

fields.headline: Straw pledges crackdown on street crime
fields.standfirst:
Labour plan tough action on muggings as mobile phone thefts bring sharp rise

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Labour plan tough action on muggings as mobile phone thefts bring sharp rise.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday promised a new mobile phone "summit" in an attempt to prevent the continuing surge in street robberies turning into the government's "achilles heel" in the debate on crime in the run-up to the general election.

The unveiling by Mr Straw of an "action plan" and "electronic toolkit" for police and community groups to tackle the problem of robberies and street crime, including the boom sector of mobile phone thefts, is designed to intensify the fight against violent crime, particularly in the five cities, London, Manchester, Birmingham, Bristol and Liverpool which account for 75% of street robberies in England and Wales.

The home secretary wants to discuss with mobile phone manufacturers ways in which they could adopt a more expensive new "chip" which would incapacitate stolen phones and the use of personal identification numbers for the newly popular pre-paid "pay as you go" phones, which have no registered owner and cannot be cut off the network.

Mr Straw's sudden interest yesterday in tackling the problem of street robbery may have as much to do with the publication next week of the annual recorded crime figures as to his determination to tackle the problem.

It is expected that overall the figures - the last to be published before the election - will paint a comfortable picture for the Labour government, with continuing falls in the the big volume offences such as burglary and car thefts.

But the exception is likely to be violent crime, and especially robberies involving personal property, which the last set of figures published in July showed had increased by 28% to March last year. If next week's figures show a further rise in street robbery it is likely to become one of the major flashpoints in the election. It also threatens to reopen the highly charged controversy over "stop and search" and undermine Downing Street's drive against "yob culture" which Tony Blair has already identified as a major theme of Labour's re-election campaign.

Mr Straw first raised the problem of mobile phone thefts last July when he also talked of calling in the manufacturers alongside proposing to clamp down on public drunkeness and other "yob behaviour".

Although violent crime accounts for only 13% of all offences, it is the surge in street robbery and the fear of being attacked by a stranger which most worry the public.

The action plan to tackle violent crime published by Mr Straw yesterday points out that while last year's British Crime Survey reported a 21% fall in violent crime between 1995 and 1999, there is still a long way to go to reverse the long-term rise over the past 20 years.

He argued that some of the long-term rise in violent crime can be regarded, in part, as good news because it represents increased reporting rates to the police by victims of domestic violence and racial attacks. He also stressed that Home Office criminologists claim that most of the long-term rise has been in what is called "acquaintance violence" and that violent attacks by strangers has risen at a much slower rate.

The Home Office analysis and "toolkit" to tackle robbery published yesterday suggests that while in London the typical robber and victim is a young teenage boy aged 15 to 16 at school-leaving time, outside the capital the typical robber is an older male student aged about 18 to 20, with the largest number of robberies taking place during the "hours of darkness". More than 80% of victims are male.

The Greater Manchester police yesterday offered an alternative explanation of the rise in street robberies, arguing that it is due in part to a "displacement effect" following successful campaigns against burglars and car thieves. The Manchester police think that now more homes are harder to break into because they have window locks and alarms burglars have turned to street robberies. This trend has been helped along by the fact that the rewards from bank and building society cash cards are much greater than simply the cash people carry on them and it is also much easier to get rid of the stolen property.

However, Mr Straw said that while there might be some displacement effect, he believed that different street robbery rates in different city neighbourhoods showed that it was possible to tackle the problem. As well as deploying police officers, the "robbery toolkit" advocates using closed-circuit television, improved lighting and other environmental measures to make it far harder for the street mugger to operate.

It also gives advice to those who are anxious about walking the streets at night such as walking closer to the kerb and against the oncoming traffic so you can be seen, to the police putting up notices in a high-crime area to ensure that people are aware that there is a danger they might be mugged.

The plan to renew the battle against street crime failed to impress the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe: "I am always listening to Jack Straw's announcing new initiatives, whether it is about police numbers or tackling youth crime. The fact is, so far none of them have had any success - indeed the reverse has usually happened."

She promised that the Conservatives would employ more police officers and send more people to jail and when challenged to explain how these measures would be paid for said she would cut the number of Home Office press officers.

It is expected that overall the figures - the last to be published before the election - will paint a comfortable picture for the Labour government, with continuing falls in the the big volume offences such as burglary and car thefts. But the exception is likely to be violent crime, and especially robberies involving personal property, which the last set of figures published in July showed had increased by 28% to March last year. If next week's figures show a further rise in street robbery it is likely to become one of the major flashpoints in the election. It also threatens to reopen the highly charged controversy over "stop and search" and undermine Downing Street's drive against "yob culture" which Tony Blair has already identified as a major theme of Labour's re-election campaign. Mr Straw first raised the problem of mobile phone thefts last July when he also talked of calling in the manufacturers alongside proposing to clamp down on public drunkeness and other "yob behaviour". Although violent crime accounts for only 13% of all offences, it is the surge in street robbery and the fear of being attacked by a stranger which most worry the public. The action plan to tackle violent crime published by Mr Straw yesterday points out that while last year's British Crime Survey reported a 21% fall in violent crime between 1995 and 1999, there is still a long way to go to reverse the long-term rise over the past 20 years. He argued that some of the long-term rise in violent crime can be regarded, in part, as good news because it represents increased reporting rates to the police by victims of domestic violence and racial attacks. He also stressed that Home Office criminologists claim that most of the long-term rise has been in what is called "acquaintance violence" and that violent attacks by strangers has risen at a much slower rate. The Home Office analysis and "toolkit" to tackle robbery published yesterday suggests that while in London the typical robber and victim is a young teenage boy aged 15 to 16 at school-leaving time, outside the capital the typical robber is an older male student aged about 18 to 20, with the largest number of robberies taking place during the "hours of darkness". More than 80% of victims are male. The Greater Manchester police yesterday offered an alternative explanation of the rise in street robberies, arguing that it is due in part to a "displacement effect" following successful campaigns against burglars and car thieves. The Manchester police think that now more homes are harder to break into because they have window locks and alarms burglars have turned to street robberies. This trend has been helped along by the fact that the rewards from bank and building society cash cards are much greater than simply the cash people carry on them and it is also much easier to get rid of the stolen property. However, Mr Straw said that while there might be some displacement effect, he believed that different street robbery rates in different city neighbourhoods showed that it was possible to tackle the problem. As well as deploying police officers, the "robbery toolkit" advocates using closed-circuit television, improved lighting and other environmental measures to make it far harder for the street mugger to operate. It also gives advice to those who are anxious about walking the streets at night such as walking closer to the kerb and against the oncoming traffic so you can be seen, to the police putting up notices in a high-crime area to ensure that people are aware that there is a danger they might be mugged. The plan to renew the battle against street crime failed to impress the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe: "I am always listening to Jack Straw's announcing new initiatives, whether it is about police numbers or tackling youth crime. The fact is, so far none of them have had any success - indeed the reverse has usually happened." She promised that the Conservatives would employ more police officers and send more people to jail and when challenged to explain how these measures would be paid for said she would cut the number of Home Office press officers.

webTitle: Women: Profile of Bush's failed labour nominee

fields.headline: The hand that rocked the boat
fields.standfirst:
As George W Bush's nominee for labour secretary is forced to step down, Martin Kettle reports from Washington on the woman behind her withdrawal

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: As George W Bush's nominee for labour secretary is forced to step down, Martin Kettle reports from Washington on the woman behind her withdrawal.
fields.body:
Linda Chavez started the week as a target because of her rightwing views and is ending it as a minor martyr to the "search and destroy" tactics of the American political press. As the latest woman politician to fall foul of the illegal nanny problem, the withdrawal of her nomination as US labour secretary has reignited a debate about the inequality of the public grilling process for male and female nominees.

What it has not done, however, is reopen public discussion of the position of women like Marta Mercado, the Guatemalan immigrant whose relationship with Chavez is at the heart of the latest American political bloodletting. Unlike Chavez, Mercado has a very ordinary tale to tell.

Mercado is one of thousands of central American women who have been willing to break immigration laws to make a living in the US. She says she was drawn by "the marvels of the country", but no one is in much doubt that she was also in an abusive relationship back home.

It is almost 10 years now since Mercado left her job as a worker in an ice cream factory and her home in Guatemala City to escape a husband who routinely drank too much and who "sometimes got crazy" as she put it to one interviewer this week.

Her first move, still in Guatemala, was to pay $2,000 to local counterfeiters to supply her with the false papers she needed to mislead America's tough immigration officers. Like many illegal immigrants, the first call on any income she obtained in the US was to the people who had lent her the money for the forgeries.

At first, she stayed with a friend from Guatemala in Washington's Maryland suburbs. Then another Guatemalan, Erica Deleon, took her in and helped to find her two childcare jobs in the archipelago of Latino nannies which provides the low-paid basis for millions of two-income American couples to go to work.

It was Deleon who led Mercado to Linda Chavez. Deleon asked a Washington couple whose house she cleaned whether they could help her friend Marta with some work. The couple suggested Chavez.

"Mrs Chavez offered Marta room and board but said there was no job," Deleon said this week, adding that Mercado's legal status was never mentioned. "No one asked."

Mercado moved into the Chavez house, living in a basement bedroom. According to Mercado, she would do "some things around the house" for Chavez, such as dishes, laundry, dusting. In the afternoon she would mind the children of Chavez's neighbour, Margaret Zwisler, for which she got around $120 per week.

"I felt good about myself doing these things," Mercado said. "I was living there but I was taking English classes, going to a women's support group and working for two other people in the neighbourhood."

Though Chavez at first denied it, there is no doubt in Mercado's mind that her landlady knew she was in the US illegally. "It wasn't like one day I told her I didn't have papers," she said this week. "Talking about my problems and things, she knew I had no papers." On Tuesday, Chavez finally admitted that was true.

Mercado stayed with Chavez for nearly two years. She went back to Guatemala in July 1993 and tried to have a reconciliation with her husband, but returned to the US, on a tourist visa, a year later. She met and married an American citizen in 1995 and now lives in the US legally.

Since the story broke at the weekend, Mercado has been catapulted into the media arena for her brief moment of notoriety. She has given several television interviews in her halting English, but has also continued with the cleaning and caring jobs she now does - legally - in the suburban town of Beltsville.

Mercado says Chavez gave her money, though she is hazy about how much - perhaps $1,500 she told one interviewer this week. "I feel very bad for what happened to Mrs Linda," she said, before going to ground yesterday and renewing her all too normal life and all too normal anxieties. "I never expected something like this to happen to me. I hope everything is going to be OK now."

webTitle: Bitter Branson bows out of fight for lottery

fields.headline: Bitter Branson bows out of fight for lottery
fields.standfirst:
Virgin chief rejects legal fight against 'cowardly' award to Camelot

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson yesterday abandoned his long campaign to win control of the national lottery, but not before a last bitter swipe at the commission which frustrated his ambition.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson yesterday abandoned his long campaign to win control of the national lottery, but not before a last bitter swipe at the commission which frustrated his ambition.

The founder of the Virgin empire said he had decided not to proceed with a judicial review to re-open the contest for the next licence. He said he feared that further delays and controversy could lead to good causes losing millions of pounds.

The decision, Sir Richard said, flew in the face of legal advice suggesting he had a strong case for overturning the national lottery commission's decision last month to award the next licence to Camelot.

"The interest of the good causes should be paramount and that it is why we will not be prolonging this sorry farce to appoint a new licensee any longer," he said. "At some stage, like Al Gore and the American election, you have to bow out."

His company, the People's Lottery, may now pursue legal action to recoup some or all of the £30m it claims it spent on the bid.

Sir Richard's rancour toward the commission chairman, Lord Burns, had clearly not cooled over the festive period. Both the commission and Camelot, he said, had "eroded trust" in the lottery.

Giving the lottery to Camelot "was a cowardly decision, made in a cowardly way on, to put it mildly, a dubious basis," Sir Richard said. "They took the easy option. It is somewhat ironic that such a totally risk averse man as Lord Burns should have been put in charge of an industry that involves some 30m players a week taking a fantastic risk every time they play."

Sir Richard repeated his statement last month that he would never again bid for the lottery and played down the chances of launching a rival game. Lord Burns welcomed Sir Richard's decision, saying: "The commission reached its decision after a thorough, careful and even handed evaluation of the two bids."

Sir Richard said a key factor in not proceeding had been Lord Burns's failure to extract a guarantee from Camelot that it would keep the lottery running should a new operator not be ready by October when the next licence starts. A spokeswoman for Camelot described the justification as "absolute rubbish". She said formal undertakings had been given to the commission that an interim licence would be signed.

Sir Richard said: "Were the People's Lottery to be successful in a judicial review, there would be a serious risk of the national lottery having to be suspended for a significant period of time or its credibility being irreparably damaged. We had to think realistically whether we were going to cause more damage by continuing the process than by bowing out. We are not just talking about winning a court action - the whole process would have had to be started again."

He called on the national audit office to review the process by which Camelot had been selected as a matter of urgency.

Simon Burridge, the People's Lottery chief executive, also conceded that the company had little faith in Lord Burns reversing his decision even if the contest were reopened.

Camelot's chief executive, Dianne Thompson, said she welcomed Sir Richard putting the lottery first. "We can now get on with finalising our plans," she said.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, welcomed the Virgin boss's decision: "Sir Richard's dignified withdrawal does him credit."

By backing away from a judicial review Sir Richard ended a process which has been shaken by controversy over the past 12 months. In August, after several delays, the commission named the People's Lottery as preferred bidder and excluded Camelot from the running. Sir Richard had been within one hour of signing the necessary documents before Camelot managed to muscle its way back in to contention through the high court.

webTitle: After hours violence spills into Manchester's mean streets

fields.headline: After the partying - violence spills out into Manchester's mean streets
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Manchester is struggling to stem the rise in violent assaults in the city. Between 1997-1999, there was a 225% increase in assaults, which coincided with a 241% rise in the number of licensed premises.
fields.body:
It is 2.25am in Manchester city centre on a cold night outside the Krunchy Fried Chicken takeaway in the heart of the gay village. Minicabs line up to take a steady stream of drunken young people home as they pour out of the pubs and clubs.

Suddenly, the atmosphere becomes tense and a man in the takeaway queue raises his fist. Inevitably, a fight breaks out and punches are thrown.

The police, patrolling the area in a marked car, intervene before the fight escalates. Back-up officers arrive in less than a minute.

"If we hadn't been here immediately, then we would have been left to pick up the aftermath of an assault a few minutes later, which would have been much worse," says PC Paul Crossley. Manchester is struggling to stem the rise in violent assaults in the city. Between 1997-1999, there was a 225% increase in assaults, which coincided with a 241% rise in the number of licensed premises. Between April 1999 and March last year there were 7,134 robberies of personal property, an increase of 9% from the previous year. Thefts of mobile phones have also increased.

A recently introduced bylaw in the city means officers now have the power to remove opened bottles and cans of alcohol from people. Two men with cans of lager are approached by Paul's colleague PC Nikola Jones, 26, and they reluctantly put the drinks in the bin.

PC Crossley, 35, says: "I believe that some of the lads who come out in the city centre do not think they have had a good night unless they have been involved in a fight."

Friday and Saturday nights are the busiest, but Thursday is also busy as it is student night. Many mobile phones and purses are stolen after being left behind in bars by intoxicated students visiting the toilet.

PC Jones says most of the people who create trouble are young men in their late teens or early to mid-20s. She has been assaulted twice.

Six hours into their shift, they had removed four cans of alcohol, arrested a violent drunk causing trouble on a bus, attended a burglary, three thefts from pubs or restaurants and been called to the aftermath of another fight.

Chief Inspector Garry Shewan, of Bootle Street police station, says the number of violent attacks remained static last year. "We hope in 2001 that we will be able to stop the rot and that we will see a decrease. Our two priorities are violent assaults and robberies. We must attack the root cause of crime and deal with low-level disorder before it escalates into violence."

Detective Superintendent Peter Minshall, who is in charge of Operation Hawk, which targets street robbery, said statistically there had been an upward trend in street robbery in 2000, but this had reversed once the initiative was launched last autumn. "We clearly have a long way to go and are not complacent," he says.

webTitle: Hackney to overhaul computerised services with new IT contractors

fields.headline: Software solution Hackney calls in Northgate
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The impoverished London borough of Hackney is to overhaul its troubled computerised services in a £10m deal with the IT contractor, Northgate Information Solutions.
fields.body:
The impoverished London borough of Hackney is to overhaul its troubled computerised services in a £10m deal with the IT contractor, Northgate Information Solutions.

Northgate will consult on ways in which the council, which is struggling to recover from a £40m deficit, can make efficiencies through changes in software and infrastructure.

The five-year contract will eventually include taking responsibility for the software behind the delivery of Hackney's housing benefit payments, though it will not interfere with rival IT contractor ITNet's responsibility for overall delivery of the service.

According to a survey released yesterday by local government watchdog the audit commission, Hackney takes an average of 150 days to process new housing benefit claims compared with an average of 44 days across England as a whole.

Last month, social security secretary Alistair Darling said he would be appointing "help squads" for councils that were "miserably failing" to deliver housing benefit services.

Other areas in which the commission said Hackney was under-delivering included collection of council tax receipts, housing repairs and rent collection. Northgate chief executive Chris Stone said he was undaunted by the challenge. "We are mindful of the difficulties facing Hackney, but we are confident we will be able to deliver."

He said the company would not be taking direct responsibility for service provision, but described reliable IT systems as "the first building block" in council managing director Max Caller's recovery plan.

webTitle: How the fad for phones is fuelling crime

fields.headline: How the fad for phones is fuelling crime
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The rapid growth in mobile phone culture, particularly among the young, is fuelling a new rise in street robbery.
fields.body:
The phenomenal pre-Christmas sales of 5m mobile phones, nearly all "pay as you talk" models, is clear evidence that many parents thought they were the perfect gift for their teenage children - if only because they wouldn't face any further bills.

But it has turned out that this rapid growth in mobile phone culture, particularly among the young, is fuelling a new rise in street robbery.

Even before this pre-Christmas sales surge it was estimated by the telecommunications industry that in October 2000, around half the population had a mobile phone and there were already an estimated 34m in circulation.

There are not as yet national figures to demonstrate this growth in mobile phone theft but the Metropolitan police have reported a four-fold rise in street crimes involving mobile phones over the last two years.

The Greater Manchester police say that in four of their sub-divisions the number of robberies involving mobile phones have risen from 3% to 12% over a similar period.

Industry sources estimate that more than 15,000 mobiles are now stolen every month and they expect the number to increase as mobile phone ownership explodes.

This increase has taken the police and many others by surprise yet the last British Crime Survey shows that a significant part - possibly as much as one-third - of a 14% rise in street robberies between 1997 and 1999 were down to mobile phone thefts.

The same survey showed that many involved children stealing other children's phones in and around school.

The police argue that the number of street robberies recorded by them is rising because while in the past an after-school scuffle might have led to somebody's pocket money being stolen or somebody being bullied, it was not reported to the police.

Now parents need a police crime number to claim the cost of a new mobile phone from their insurance company so they are usually reported. This, they say, has pushed up the robbery figures.

One problem which the home secretary, Jack Straw, said he wants to discuss urgently with mobile phone companies and manufacturers is the fact that 90% of those pre-Christmas sales involve pre-paid "pay as you talk" models which have no registered user.

Mr Straw wants to set up a "technical working group" with the mobile phone industry to crack the problem. They will be looking at using pin (personal identity numbers) and serial numbers as possible solutions.

But the pace of technological change has proved once again that the old criminological explanation that "there is more about to nick" is what lies behind the rise in violent crime.

webTitle: ALF suspected of hunt attack

fields.headline: ALF suspected of hunt attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Animal rights activists are suspected of planting an incendiary device that ignited early yesterday underneath a car owned by a member of a prominent hunt.
fields.body:
Animal rights activists are suspected of planting an incendiary device that ignited early yesterday underneath a car owned by a member of a prominent hunt.

Several cars were damaged but no one was injured when the device caught fire outside a house in Hurst Green, near Oxted, Surrey. The car elonged to a member of the Old Surrey, Burstow and West Kent Hunt, which has had a series of clashes with animal rights protesters and hunt saboteurs in the last four months.

webTitle: Red hot chilli feathers

fields.headline: Red hot chilli feathers
fields.standfirst: Maxine-Fay Miller on the spicy songbirds of New Guinea
fields.trailText: Maxine-Fay Miller on the spicy songbirds of New Guinea
fields.body:
Those who enjoy eating foods laden with chilli may find birds from the forests of New Guinea just too hot to handle.

According to locals, these birds taste hotter than chilli peppers. Even breathing fragments from their feathers causes watery eyes, burning, coughing and sneezing and the smell alone can make one nauseous. Jack Dumbacher and his colleagues of the Smithsonian Institution have discovered that skin and feathers of five species of brightly coloured pitohui songbirds, including the sour-smelling black-and-orange hooded pitohui and the blue-capped ifrita, contain poisons known as batrachotoxins.

These toxins are concentrated in the songbirds' feathers and skin in the belly, breast and leg, with lower amounts in the less fleshy head and back, and the tail and wing feathers. Until now, batrachotoxins were only known to occur in frogs such as deadly poison-dart frogs, which Colombian locals use to make blowgun darts.

So why would a bird go to so much trouble to be chilli-hot? Many of the 400 or so birds unique to New Guinea have developed a strikingly colourful plumage to attract females. The drawback of these bright displays and extravagant plumes is that they also lure hungry predators including hawks, which fly overhead and snatch the songbirds from tree branches. Once they have tasted the songbirds, though, the hawks soon associate these bright colours with an unpleasant chilli-hotness and avoid them in future.

Other predators such as green tree pythons and brown tree snakes hunt using smell and taste by flicking their tongue towards the prey prior to capture. The repugnant smell and taste of chilli-hot pitohui and ifrita birds acts as an effective deterrent. Since the chilli-hot birds nest beneath the forest canopy only a few metres from the ground, their eggs and nestlings are also vulnerable to predators. Ingeniously, breast and belly feathers, which contain the highest levels of toxins, rub off onto incubated eggs and nestlings thereby protecting them. The batrachotoxins also deal with parasites.

These can also be a problem for birds as they can damage their plumage and hamper their mating success. So, in addition to repelling predators, the toxins in the birds' skin and feathers ward off feather lice and other parasites. But it's not just the birds with batrachotoxins, who benefit. Other pitohuis and even the young of another bird species, greater melampittas, take advantage of their spicy friends by mimicking their warning colouration. Predators are fooled and will not risk burning their mouths by eating them.

webTitle: Some like it hotter

fields.headline: Some like it hotter
fields.standfirst: What's the link between extraterrestrial life and stonewashed jeans? Duncan Steel explains
fields.trailText: What's the link between extraterrestrial life and stonewashed jeans? Duncan Steel explains
fields.body:
The Earth formed 4.5 billion years ago from myriad smaller lumps of rock circuiting the Sun. Initially it was hot, very hot. Over the following 700m years stray projectiles bombarded our planet By 3.8bn years ago, the interplanetary environment had calmed down a little, most of the cosmic detritus having been swept up by the planets.

Some of the oldest terrestrial rocks, dating from that era, display fossil evidence of life having existed immediately after the heavy bombardment finished. This is both a puzzle and a significant clue for scientists investigating the origin of life. The point is this. If life - simple microbial life, such as blue/green algae (or cyanobacteria) - blossomed on Earth immediately the bombardment ceased, then maybe the origination of life is "easy" in the cosmos.

Given the right environmental conditions, perhaps life spontaneously generates. In consequence, extraterrestrial life could be abundant. If it were that easy, maybe there were multiple starts of life on Earth, but the first few were obliterated when massive impacts caused the sterilisation of the planet.

Until recently, this was a common idea. But then it was realised that life on Earth is stranger than we had imagined. Far from being killed, bacterial strains have been identified that do better at high temperatures. Textbooks mostly divide life forms into two domains: the prokaryotes and the eukaryotes. Prokaryotes (bacteria and some other single-celled organisms) have no distinct nucleus. Eukaryotes are mostly multi-cellular, and they have nuclei within their cells where the genetic material is stored. All plants and animals are eukaryotes.

In recent years microbiologists have recognised an additional domain, called the archaea. The archaeons have no cellular nucleus, but their genes act in similar ways to those of eukaryotes. The first archaeons were recognised in 1977 but - as is usual for any revolution in science - their acceptance has been slow.

Archaeons were not discovered earlier because they live in extreme environments, and so are termed extremophiles. More than 500 discrete types of archaeon have been described, but there may be a million more awaiting our perusal, in their peculiar habitats.

Research on these goes far beyond simple curiosity and the clues they can give us about life elsewhere. Archaeons are proving to be commercially valuable. The idea of extremophiles had actually been around for 50 years or so, but their very different nature was missed. If you look at hot sulphur springs, for example at Yel lowstone in Wyoming, or Rotorua in New Zealand, the multi-coloured rings of bacteria in the water are obvious. These correspond to strains that proliferate at different temperatures, and so different distances from the vents. Species living at temperatures above about 60 C are called thermophiles; push that up over 80 C and you are in the bailiwick of hyperthermophiles.

It was through research at Yellowstone that the first archaeon was recognised, and given the name Thermus aquaticus. This is also the archaeon that has had the most notable influence on our lives. DNA analysis requires the mass duplication, through the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), of small samples to render enough for testing. Splitting the strands of DNA in the multiplication process requires the temperature to be elevated, and this destroys most of the enzymes used in the PCR, making the process slow and expensive.

The breakthrough came when it was realised that enzymes produced by a hyperthermophile such as Thermus aquaticus could be used, because these are stable near water's boiling point. Another place to find thermophiles is in your compost heap. Within that steaming pile of grass clippings, bugs are at work, breaking down the plant material to make the nutrients available for re-use next year. Methanogens comprise an archaeon class that consumes hydrogen and carbon dioxide, rather than oxygen. It is hoped that these can be employed to detoxify waste, while tapping the methane they release to be used as fuel.

Thermophiles already have many other applications in industry - for example, in the manufacture of fragrances and food stuffs. Anywhere enzymes are needed for use at high temperatures, there is a likelihood that nature has already invented just the chemical factory we need. So where should we look? Early discussions of the possible nature of extraterrestrial life mistakenly assumed that it would derive its energy from the light of the sun, or whatever local star powered its planet. Archaeons show the error there. Their respiration is driven not by sunlight, but by chemical energy. They eat hydrogen and sulphur, or may use temperature gradients, and that is why they are found around hot springs.

Being on the surface of the Earth and therefore exposed to sunlight is coincidental. The solid ground way beneath our feet is teeming with microbes that eat rock. Other islands of life thriving far from the solar glare are found around oceanic hydrothermal vents. The heat and the sulphur released by these undersea volcanoes power a wide spectrum of organisms. Because of their appearance these vents are also called "dark smokers".

The name of one of the microbes discovered there, Pyrolobus fumarii, echoes that phrase. This is the record-holder for the temperature at which it will keep replicating: 113 C. (A hospital autoclave typically operates at about that temperature.)

Higher values have been claimed for other organisms, but are yet to be proven. Theoretical modelling indicates that chemical bonds within cells would break above about 150 C. No multi-cellular life is known that can withstand prolonged exposure above merely 50 C. Pyrolobus fumarii certainly likes it hot: if it cools below 90 C it stops reproducing. At the other end of the scale, organisms are known which prefer the cold. These are termed psychrophiles. Much work on these has been done by exobiologists, for example in the Antarctic, because the locales suspected as havens of life in the solar system tend to be chilly: places such as Mars, and Jupiter's moon Europa, which is thought to have an ocean under its icy crust.

Psychrophiles are also of commercial interest. It would be cheaper to do your laundry using cold water, so washing powders using enzymes from psychrophiles are desirable. Psychrophilic enzymes may also make food factories safer by allowing preparation at lower temperatures. There are other types of extremophile. Water from volcanic vents is not only hot, it is also acidic. Many acidophilic organisms have been identified, and these may also be useful in making food and medications. If a drug needs to withstand transit through the stomach, packaging it with an enzyme unaffected by the acid would be beneficial.

At the other end of the pH scale are the alkaliphiles. These are found in various types of salt lake and carbonate-laden soils. What use are they? We come back to the laundry again. Most washing powders use their enzymes inefficiently, because the alkaline solution breaks them down. The answer is to manufacture new enzymes from alkaliphilic microbes.

A particular application, because the cloth needs to take a chemical battering, is stonewashed jeans. No stones are used, despite the tag: the material is softened and faded using enzymes. The discovery of life forms unsuspected until the past few years may make your next pair of denims softer, paler, and perhaps even cheaper. But on the cosmic scale, these organisms thriving in extreme environments have also forced exobiologists to revise their notions of where life might exist elsewhe

webTitle: Autonomy steps up Bright Station feud

fields.headline: Autonomy steps up Bright Station feud
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Software maker Bright Station was threatened with legal action yesterday over a series of off the record briefings to journalists about its new partnership with Intel. It is alleged to have said the pact undermines the long-standing relationship rival firm Autonomy has with the American microchip group.
fields.body:
Software maker Bright Station was threatened with legal action yesterday over a series of off the record briefings to journalists about its new partnership with Intel. It is alleged to have said the pact undermines the long-standing relationship rival firm Autonomy has with the American microchip group.

Autonomy's chief executive, Mike Lynch, said his firm's lawyers had requested that Bright Station executives including boss Dan Wagner retract statements they are alleged to have made to reporters yesterday because they were "totally untrue".

"We have no quarrel with any press releases Bright Station has put out, but briefings that imply that Intel and Autonomy's relationship has somehow deteriorated as a result of this new agreement are simply untrue. In fact, it is stronger than ever.

"We have asked those [at Bright Station] making the untrue claims to clarify the truthful position. It they do not do so, we will have to deal with it through other remedies."

A spokesman for Bright Station denied that it had made any defamatory comments about Autonomy. "I can't think who they are referring to, all we have been doing is emphasising the key points in our statement. I'm very surprised by this. They are clearly rattled."

Autonomy's threat is the latest in a long-running war of words between the two firms.

Yesterday's quarrel centred on a bullish statement from Bright Station announcing a wide range of technology and marketing agreements with Intel. Bright Station's shares jumped 45% on news of the link-up, which will see one of its products that competes with Autonomy piloted by Intel in its new Itanium chip in northern Europe.

The deal is thought to worth up to £15,000 initially, but that could rise significantly if it is successful. Bright Station is also thought to be close to announcing a big contract with a leading British firm.

Last year BAA, which is a Bright Station customer, denied any connection with a Bright Station press release suggesting that the airports operator had compared Autonomy software unfavourably with Bright Station's.

The firms have seen sharply contrasting stock market performances. Autonomy, which was founded four years ago, has entered the FTSE 100 and made Dr Lynch a billionaire.

Bright Station last year changed its name from Dialog and bought the technology assets of Boo, the failed e-tailer. Last night its shares closed up 14.5p at 45.5p, compared to a 12-month high of 256p.

webTitle: French right urged to unite

fields.headline: French right urged to unite
fields.trailText: With new opinion polls ringing alarm bells for President Jacques Chirac's Gaullists, a former conservative prime minister yesterday unveiled his plan to forge France's fractured right into a single united movement ahead of next year's national elections.
fields.body:
With new opinion polls ringing alarm bells for President Jacques Chirac's Gaullists, a former conservative prime minister yesterday unveiled his plan to forge France's fractured right into a single united movement ahead of next year's national elections.

"Only a single merged party will make the opposition credible," said Edouard Balladur, prime minister for Mr Chirac's RPR party from 1993 to 1995.

Mr Balladur has sent the proposed statutes of his new party, the Union for Reform (UPR), to the leaders of France's four main rightwing parties. He has also drawn up a timetable that would see a UPR central office created next month, an official parliamentary group formed in March, and a party president elected before the summer.

The centre-right could not afford to wait for what many expect will be a humiliating defeat in March's local elections, he said.

The French right all but collapsed after Mr Chirac's disastrous decision to call snap general elections in 1997. It is now made up of half a dozen squabbling mini-parties, each ruled by a competing grandee.

Two polls have instilled near-panic in rightwing ranks. One, released on Monday, predicted that the left could well seize Paris from the RPR in March's local elections, putting the Socialists in charge of the capital for the first time since the 1871 Commune.

Meanwhile a second poll, released yesterday, showed that if the presidential elections scheduled for 2002 were held today, Mr Chirac would lose to the current prime minister, Lionel Jospin, his likely rival, in the second round.

Mr Balladur's planned UPR is the latest in a long series of attempted marriages on the right. But with local, parliamentary and presidential elections all looming over the next 18 months, some 90% of opposition MPs are convinced that a single conservative movement must be made to work.

fields.trailText: Biljana Plavsic, once known as the Iron Lady of the Bosnian Serb republic, turned herself over to the war crimes tribunal in the Hague yesterday and will answer charges of genocide and crimes against humanity for her role in the Bosnian war.
fields.body:
Biljana Plavsic, once known as the Iron Lady of the Bosnian Serb republic, turned herself over to the war crimes tribunal in the Hague yesterday and will answer charges of genocide and crimes against humanity for her role in the Bosnian war.

One of the most fervent advocates of ethnic cleansing, she was briefly courted by western governments in the mid-1990s when she broke with her colleagues, Radovan Karadzic and General Ratko Mladic.

Yesterday she became the first woman publicly indicted by the tribunal and the second key figure from the former Bosnian Serb leadership to come to the Hague. Her surrender is a major coup for prosecutors as they close the net on more powerful figures up the Bosnian Serb chain of command.

During the 1992-95 Bosnian war Mrs Plavsic was deputy to the Bosnian Serb leader, Mr Karadzic. She took over from him when he was forced from office in 1996.

Mr Karadzic and the Bosnian Serb military commander Gen Mladic are the top Bosnian Serb indicted by the tribunal and yesterday the war crimes tribunal's chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, urged them to follow Mrs Plavsic's example.

The 70-year-old former biology professor learned she was wanted and began negotiations with United Nations prosecutors a month ago. Her indictment was approved by the court last April, but was kept secret until yesterday.

Her lawyer Krstan Simic said his client was in good health. "She is a brave, strong woman. She is taking it well."

Mrs Plavsic, who often spoke in more virulently nationalistic terms than her colleagues, faces charges of genocide, crimes against humanity, violations of the laws and customs of war and grave breaches of the Geneva Convention in Bosnia in 1991 and 1992.

The chief prosecutor stressed that her office had not agreed any compromise as part of Mrs Plavsic's surrender. Prosecutors say plea-bargaining, such as offering immunity from prosecution in exchange for testimony, is not an option open to them.

"Mrs Plavsic was faced with the indictment, but the decision to surrender was her own. She is aware that this is the only place she can legally prove her innocence or her guilt and that's something she deeply believes in," he said.

She is likely to argue that she had acted as a patriotic Serb in wartime but bore no direct personal or command responsibility for atrocities.

But she was one of Mr Karadzic's staunchest wartime supporters and defended the siege of Sarajevo as "the defence of Serb homes". She publicly snubbed the Yugoslav strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, when he introduced sanctions in 1994 to press Bosnian Serbs into making peace. Later, she strongly opposed the 1995 Dayton peace treaty that ended the Bosnian war. She replaced Mr Karadzic as president when he bowed to western pressure in 1996 and quit public life.

However, by 1997, she had broken ranks with hardline nationalists and started an anti-corruption drive, winning some western support and perhaps hoping that she would escape indictment.

She will make an initial appearance in court today when the charges are expected to be made public.

Mr Karadzic and Gen Mladic are still at large, though there is speculation in Sarajevo and Belgrade that the Clinton administration, in its last days, might press for their arrest.

webTitle: A brief history of Microsoft

fields.headline: Staying in Seattle
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of Microsoft
More net news
fields.trailText: October 28, 1955: William Henry Gates III born in Seattle
fields.body:
October 28, 1955

William Henry Gates III born in Seattle

1975

Harvard sophomore Gates and school chum Paul Allen write a software language for a personal computer and establish a company, Micro-Soft

1979

Rechristened Microsoft with 28 employees and $2.5m in sales, head office moves to Seattle. Gates rebuffs bid from billionaire Ross Perot

1980

Develops MS-DOS (Microsoft Disk Operating System), licensing it to IBM for the first PC

1983

Microsoft unveils its first Windows operating system, using the point-and-click commands of a mouse

1986

With 1,400 employees and revenues of nearly two hundred million dollars, Microsoft's stock is sold to the public. Bill Gates becomes a billionaire

1988

Microsoft becomes the world's largest software company

1990

Windows 3.0 proves to be an instant success. Microsoft's revenues climb above one billion dollars

August 1995

Microsoft introduces its own free browser included with each copy of Windows

December 7, 1995

An alarmed Gates announces that the Internet compels Microsoft to alter its business model, and henceforth Microsoft will become internet-centric

May 1998

After settlement negotiations collapse, the justice department and 20 state attorneys general file a lawsuit charging Microsoft with antitrust (competition) violations

October 1998

Federal antitrust trial begins in Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's court and is expected to take six weeks

December 31, 1998

Microsoft's profits of nearly $4.5bn are twice those of the world's largest corporation, General Motors

November 5, 1999

Judge Jackson concludes that Microsoft was guilty of holding monopoly power

January 14, 2000

Bill Gates steps down as chief executive to become chief software architect. Steve Ballmer takes over as chief executive and president

April 3, 2000

Judge Jackson, after four months of mediation, issues his conclusions of law, finding that Microsoft violated the US's antitrust laws. Microsoft launches an appeal

June 7, 2000

Judge Jackson issues his final judgment, ordering that Microsoft be broken up into two companies and imposing conduct restrictions on the company's behaviour for several years
