webTitle: Step sideways to get ahead

fields.headline: Step sideways to get ahead
fields.standfirst: We need romantic failures to inspire the great changes, says  William Gosling
fields.trailText: We need romantic failures to inspire the great changes, says William Gosling
fields.body:
Until radio was invented in the first decade of the 20th century, most ships were unable to talk to land. Seafarers vanished over the horizon to an unknown fate. Yet as early as 1850 a few vessels managed to contact land from the high seas. Laying undersea cables for the new electric telegraph, they sent messages back over the wire to their point of departure.

Major advances in technology usually have precursors - noble failures that prove to be a technological blind alley.

Take Charles Babbage, who in 1833 built the first computer, and Ada, Countess of Lovelace, who pondered its software. Their "analytical engine" was entirely mechanical, and so doomed to failure.

A few years later, Charles Wheatstone built an electromechanical "gate", an early version of the building-block from which present-day computers are constructed, while in Ireland George Boole pioneered the binary arithmetic that underpins modern computer architecture. But Victorian electrical computers did not happen. Not until a century later did Tom Flowers built Colossus, the first successful electronic computer

Meanwhile, on the roads, first-generation steam- propelled horseless carriages were swept away by the internal combustion engine. Before 1914, airships provided a commercial passenger service inside Germany, yet kites, not balloons, are the ancestors of modern airliners.

Why are precursors like this so common? To get started, inventions have three basic requirements. They must be technically feasible, there must be an evident demand for what they do, but above all, they must have charm. Nobody will try something that seems impossible, and nobody will finance a development which does not answer a need. But charm is the crucial ingredient.

Charm is elegance, confidence and the sense of finding something long sought. It persuades young engineers to make a hunch their cause, and lures older professionals into staking all on raising the necessary backing. If any of these three essentials are missing or weak you get only a precursor. Until the coming of radio, ships at sea were isolated because communication with them failed on feasibility. The Victorian computer was feasible and would have met a need, but the idea was never articulated clearly enough to generate charm.

Airships have irresistible charm and met a need but were never entirely feasible, as their many disasters proved. All these things were just might-have-beens. By contrast, the mobile phone addressed a world of latent users, was made feasible by microelectronics, charmed the socks off its engineers and created the fastest growing industry in history.

Yet we ought to take seriously these romantic failures, because they point to the future. Most technological development is bigger, faster, more powerful, cheaper ver sions of what went before. But occasionally engineering takes a knight's move, out of the straightforward, creating something entirely different.

Such leaps of imagination are difficult to predict. Futurologists never spot them. But often they have precursors. So what do I tip as important precursors now? The first is nanotechnology, the technology of the very small. We can envisage versatile machines smaller than the eye can see. Nanotechnology has the prospect of advancing medi cine to an inconceivable point, solving pollution problems, and transforming manufacturing processes in an ecology-friendly way. It could save the planet, but it also has alarming military potential. Already on microelectronic silicon chips we fabricate things with dimensions down to a thousandth of the thickness of a human hair.

And my second precursor? We have been at it for half a century already, but even so my choice is space travel. It has great charm and fills a need but it still ranks as just a precursor because its present feasibility is only achieved at great cost. Space vehicles which are 90% fuel at takeoff cannot be right; they are the steam cars of space, the airships of the cosmos.The day we work out how to do it properly - using nanotechnology, for all I know - we shall make science fiction look tame.

 William Gosling is a past-president of the Institution of Electrical Engineers

The visual effects are stunning, as massed armies clash and lancers gallop past. If anyone awarded an Oscar for costumes in games, Kessen would win it by miles.

The gameplay is, unfortunately, less engaging. Kessen is a strategy war game of the sort that first became popular with boards and counters, only here your attempts to play the Japanese equivalent of Napoleon are continually interrupted by cut scenes and set-piece animations. There's nothing like the depth you get with Sid Meier games such as Civilization, or even Gettysburg. It is far too easy to win.

In the absence of a two- player challenge, you are unlikely to play the game more than twice. Western unfamiliarity with the characters and issues involved does not help.

Kessen could appeal to war gamers who are fed up with replaying with the usual scenarios - Eastern Front, Midway etc - and Japanese history boffs. But the stunning graphics are not enough to make this a compelling title for the rest of us. (JS)

Typing of the Dead
PC CD Rom £29.99 Sega/Empire ***
It's the oldest excuse in the book. Child pesters parent for new game, parent says no. Child claims software is "educational", parent shrugs and sneaks off for more Champ Manager. Well, with this new release, the young 'un may have a point.

Typing of the Dead is a perfect conversion of Sega's arcade and Dreamcast title, House of the Dead 2, but with one fundamental difference. Instead of blasting the zombies with a lightgun you now use a keyboard. Yup, simply reproduce the onscreen gibberish with nimble fingers and the undead die (again).

There are plenty of levels to work through but, with limited time allowed, it soon becomes clear that touch- typing skills are essential. The game includes a comprehensive tutorial, complete with numerous rewarding challenges, that makes learning touch-typing unexpectedly enjoyable. Even the most one-fingered laggard will improve, but to last more than a few minutes in the game proper you will need speeds resembling those on a PA's job description.

Of course the action itself is as simplistically short-lived as the original - blast pretty much anything that moves - but the end of level sections, which involve quick thinking as well as fingers, help keep you interested. Typing of the Dead won't appeal to everyone - after all, do you want to spend your free time bashing a keyboard if you spend your working day hunched in front of one? But, despite a steep learning curve, the graphical polish and respected arcade heritage mean you will improve your typing without realising it. A curious mix of chore and enjoyment, Typing of the Dead is a pleasingly different PC release. (GH)

Rainbow Six
Sega/Dreamcast £39.99 Swing/Red Storm **
One of the more anticipated Dreamcast releases, if only because it's been delayed more times than the Rolling Stones' retirement. Out on PC since time immemorial and long available on PlayStation and N64, Rainbow Six was scheduled to appear in DC form to coincide with the launch of the console. In the US. So what happened?

Well, in addition to adapting the PC game, Red Storm has kindly incorporated extra levels from the Eagle Watch missions disk - though this was compensation for, rather than the reason for the wait.

The programmers might have been held back by the task of converting the control set. A combination strategy/stealth/first-person shooter, R6 requires you to master no fewer than 35 commands - which on the Dreamcast joypad uses almost every conceivable combination of buttons. Even after several hours of manual-twitching, a momentary lapse can spell instant death.

The look, sound and feel of the game have been preserved remarkably well, although whether this was worth the effort is debatable. Surely this was the ideal opportunity for Red Storm to address the murky lighting, plasterboard environments and unimpressive sound effects? More welcome relics from the original are the cleverly designed levels and varied missions.

One thing that can't be blamed for the delay is the multiplayer code - there is none.

By the time you've memorised the innumerable controls, navigated the immense planning screens and drummed your fingers raw through the load times, Red Storm might even have finished converting the sequel. (AB)

webTitle: Games watch

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Go Nuon | Millions like us
fields.body:
Go Nuon
While the trend is for games consoles (PlayStation 2, Microsoft Xbox) to play movies on DVD, Americans can buy DVD players that also play games. The Toshiba SD2300 NUON-Enhanced DVD player has joined the Samsung Extiva DVD-N2000 in delivering games using the Nuon chip developed by VM Labs.

The first DVD movie to exploit Nuon technology - 20th Century Fox's remake of Bedazzled withLiz Hurley - will be released on March 13.

Millions like us
Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? topped the Christmas games chart, as expected, in what was the biggest bonanza in UK gaming history.

According to estimates from Computer Trade Weekly magazine, "an amazing 8.9 million titles" worth about £242 million were sold over the six-week "holiday season".

WWTBAM? could also go on to reach an even wider game-playing audience. Codeonline Ltd, a wireless specialist based in Espoo, Finland, is developing versions of the game for the SMS (short messaging service) and Wap (Wireless application protocol) mobile phones. Codeonline has also developed a wireless version of Trivial Pursuit Challenge.

PS2 is coming
Life should soon get easier for would-be PlayStation 2 buyers. Ray Maguire, who runs Sony's PlayStation business in the UK, says 400,000 consoles will be shipped here by March 31. Meanwhile, Microsoft has delayed the European launch of its rival Xbox games console, which may now not appear here until March 2002. The idea is to avoid the product shortages that have plagued Sony.

Girls on top
Although men make up 55% of the gaming audience in the US, most online gamers (50.4%) are now women, according to a report by research company PC Data. However, men and women prefer different types of games.

Men are much more likely to play first-person shooters (38% v 12%), real-time strategy games (33% v 11%), and sports games (30% v 10%). Women prefer board/card games (78% v 51%), gambling themes (36% v 26%), and quiz/puzzle/trivia contests (55% v 25%).

The most frequently played games, online and offline, are Solitaire, Free Cell and other games included as part of Microsoft Windows.

webTitle: What's new from Las Vegas

fields.headline: What's new from Las Vegas
fields.trailText: Elvis, the Rat Pack and Liberace
fields.body:
Elvis, the Rat Pack and Liberace
The citizens of Las Vegas are used to mixing it with the stars. However the folks of showbiz city USA were unprepared for an extraordinary double act that debuted at the Consumer Electronics Show earlier this week.

In the most unlikely pairing since Marilyn Monroe and Arthur Miller, Microsoft chairman Bill Gates teamed up with WWF wrestling star, Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson in a bid to reassure electronics dealers that in spite of the slide in the Nasdaq, digital technology was still the hottest act in town.

Playing Eric to Bill's Ernie, The Rock made the first formal outing of the real star of CES - Microsoft's Xbox console - an event to remember.

However, in spite of their showbiz antics neither Gates nor The Rock was willing to volunteer too many details about the games machine. The audience could make out a large (for a console) plastic black box with an X in moulded plastic at the top and a front-loading DVD tray.

Gates did confirm that the Xbox would ship in the autumn and that the four controllers that could be connected to it would all feature force-feedback so the gamer could experience the game's crashes and explosions. Among the first games for the Xbox are the UK-originated Malice and The Rock's favourite, WWF Raw is War.

Gates also treated the audience to a sneak preview of the Whistler operating system (the next version of Windows 2000) and demonstrated voice recognition software for Pocket PC Plus handhelds.

Intel's chief executive officer Craig Barrett had earlier kick-started the conference by urging dealers not to write off the PC. Barrett predicted that 2001 would be remembered as the start of an "extended PC" era where PC sales would be driven by hi-tech toys such as PDAs (personal digital assistants) and digital audio players.

To prove his point, Barrett unveiled a wireless tablet PC that allows several users to surf the net from a single connection, and Intel's debut audio player, the Pocket Concert. The player, which goes on sale in the US next month, will retail for around $300. It can store either MP3 or WMA (Windows Media Audio) files on its 128MB of flash memory. A UK launch is scheduled for later in the year.

Palm boss Carl Jankowski completed a hat-trick of launches from PC-related companies by unveiling the palmtop maker's latest innovation, the E-Wallet.

The system, due to be launched later in the year, enables Palm owners to buy products by beaming information from their PDA to specially made terminals.

Once a person has agreed to a purchase, they send their credit card details, which are held in the Palm, and key in a PIN number. Jankowski believes that US shoppers will appreciate the speed of the system and the way it does away with the need for a signature.

The highlight of Sony's stand was a prototype of its blue laser optical disc recorder. Sony believes that the system, which can archive 22 gigabytes of high- definition video on one DVD (five times as much as current discs), will be on sale within five years.

Sony also unveiled a web tablet that is expected to go on sale in the US later in the year for around $3000, and an AV/IT Gateway that comprises a touch-screen monitor and a base station. Owners can use the Gateway to surf the net, send email and watch video from a number of sources. Neither product is expected to go on sale in the UK.

Britons will however be taking delivery of several DVD and Super Audio CD players, a MiniDisc personal recorder that uses MDLP technology to fit five hours of music on one disc, hi-fi and PC CD-R/CD-RW burners, and two Network Walkmans.

Several of the impressive prototypes that Panasonic showed on its stand last year turned up as real-world products this time round. Americans will soon be able to purchase two digital audio/MP3 players that use SD (Secure Digital) removable storage cards. They take the form of a necklace/wrist band (SV-D75) or a pair of headphones (SV-D05). Both are expected in the UK in the summer.

Panasonic also paraded a DVD-ram based camcorder, the VDR-M10 and its first digital camera - the PV-DC3000.

Almost all the major players displayed DVD video recorder several of which are already on sale in the US. However a re-run of the Betamax-VHS battle now seems a certainty with recorders using three competing formats/discs - DVD-ram (Panasonic, Samsung), DVD-RW (Pioneer) and DVD+RW (Philips) heading for the UK later in the year.

Sony chose to sit on the fence in offering a DVD video recorder that works with DVD+RW and DVD-RW discs. It won't go on sale until 2002.

Other Vegas showstoppers included a portable hard disk from Iomega, a removable flash memory format from Dataplay, MP3-equipped sunglasses from Thomson, an internet/email watch from Timex, and our favourite, a smart frying pan that bleeps when your food is cooked, from Digital Cookware.

webTitle: At this price?  SkyePharma

fields.headline: At this price?  SkyePharma
fields.trailText: Judgment day draws near for SkyePharma. Having promised, and failed, to break even last year, the firm needs to move into the black in 2001 or face the wrath of the City's fund managers.
fields.body:
Judgment day draws near for SkyePharma. Having promised, and failed, to break even last year, the firm needs to move into the black in 2001 or face the wrath of the City's fund managers.

The company develops non-traditional drug delivery methods. Its technology is acclaimed but the jury is out on whether the management can commercialise it.

Ian Gowrie-Smith, the chairman, boosted his chances yesterday through a deal with Paul Capital, a US venture capital firm which is providing $30m (£20m) to fund phase three clinical trials of SkyePharma's painkiller DepoMorphine.

After one injection of DepoMorphine, patients recovering from operations no longer need extra shots of morphine.

Under the terms of the deal, Paul Capital will get a 15% royalty on sales of the product, which could peak at $200m annually, and a portion of revenue from three other drugs. The tie-up means that unsuccessful trials would be less disastrous financially for SkyePharma.

SkyePharma has several promising medicines ready for introduction, most notably Soleraze, a treatment for sun-damaged skin which tackles a $250m market in the US alone. The problem is that the firm's products tend to address crowded markets, and its delivery techniques must show significant benefits to convince doctors.

It relies on big partners to market its drugs and one arrangement, with SmithKline Beecham for a version of the antidepressant Paxil, has already proved a big letdown.

Furthermore, a plethora of acquisitions has left the research pipeline crowded with insignificant projects.

The shares, which touched 190p last year, jumped 9.5p to 82.5p, valuing the business at £425m. If all goes well, analysts expect profits of £18m by 2002.

Risky, but worth a small punt with the prospect of profitability just months away.

webTitle: BAE chiefs left investors flying blind

fields.headline: BAE chiefs left investors flying blind
fields.standfirst: Notebook Warnings were strangely muted
fields.trailText: In mid-1992, the then British Aerospace went into a proverbial tailspin and was forced to write off £1bn of assets. The shares hit an all-time low of 97p and the company shed 60,000 of its 127,000 employees. Dick Evans, then chief executive, spoke of being a pariah in the City and in BAE towns.
fields.body:
In mid-1992, the then British Aerospace went into a proverbial tailspin and was forced to write off £1bn of assets. The shares hit an all-time low of 97p and the company shed 60,000 of its 127,000 employees. Dick Evans, then chief executive, spoke of being a pariah in the City and in BAE towns.

Yesterday's bleak trading statement from what is now BAE Systems was badly received in the City but scarcely compares with the bloodbath of 1992 - and under Mr Evans as chairman and John Weston as chief executive BAE has become the world's biggest defence contractor, with an enviable footprint in the US denied to its European rivals, notably Eads.

But - and it is a big but - Evans, Weston and co bear a heavy responsibility for the City's shock reaction to the news that BAE was taking a £410m hit in the 2000 accounts and at least a further £115m in 2001. The company lost a quarter of its value and, while there was no public cry for the head of Mr Weston, the private grumblings about his stewardship are bound to grow in intensity.

The charge against him and his chairman is that, at the time of the interims on September 14, the warnings about "challenging" tasks in the second half were, as one analyst put it, "muted". Others might say misleading.

The writing was on the wall for losses on the £2bn RAF contract to upgrade 21 Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft and declining orders for the Hawk training air craft. But the letters, let alone the numbers, were blurred. What is more, the impact of falling Ministry of Defence orders - not just because of the peace dividend - was simply an allusion.

Given that background, the question now is whether the promise of renewed earnings growth in big military programmes from 2003-04 stands up to examination. BAE is offering pain today, pain tomorrow and jam the day after.

Pre-tax profits in 2000, forecast to be £1.15bn, are now likely to come in at under £500m; the provisions will have wiped out the whole of second-half earnings. They could be around £850m this year. BAE points to a boost from 2003 when sales on military programmes will be 40% higher and the first of the 620 Eurofighters start to be delivered. It can also hope for extra earnings from the US after last year's $2.3bn purchase of two Lockheed Martin businesses - and greater military spending from the new Bush administration.

BAE has spent a lot of time deriding Eads' over-dependence on civilian aerospace but now must swallow its words: it is now heavily dependent on Airbus and its 20% stake. If the about-to-be-created stand-alone Airbus company, promising huge savings, stumbles on old quarrels and the A380 superjumbo proves to be an expensive chimera, BAE's 1992 woes may return to haunt it.

E- extravagance

If there is one group likely to make e-tailing work it is Dixons. Through PC World alone, you would think, with its nethead customer base, it should be posting out peripherals by the cartload.

But no. In the six months to November it did just £8.9m of sales on the net. Over Christmas, sales were up more than 200% - to, er, £3.2m. As chief executive John Clare concedes, this level of sales is little more than one big shop. A third of these sales are generated from just one business-to-business website operated by PC World.

The group will shortly start net sales in France through its PC City website. For a company that has made millions providing PCs and internet access to ordinary punters, Dixons, under the leadership of Mr Clare and wily old chairman Sir Stanley Kalms, has always been pragmatic about the potential for e-tailing. The two have always maintained the big brands will win in the end and those which offer a true multi-channel retail strategy, where net buyers can pick up or return goods to stores, will be the long term victors.

Given those opinions, Dixons' £30m investment in e-commerce seems a tad extravagant.

Calling time

The phoney war for Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has been raging for so long that staff must be wondering whether they will ever get a new boss.

Leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare has been hanging around since August with a £270m offer to buy the business.

Standing in his way is Wolves' managing director, David Thompson, whose family has run the business for five generations. Tweedy, Winchester-educated Mr Thompson is one of the last relics of the "beerage" which used to control the brewing industry, and he is less than keen to let go.

Mr Thompson is running out of time. Since rebuffing Mr Breare's 500p-a-share offer he has had four months to come up with an alternative. Unless he can better that deal, with real cash, he should be a gentleman and concede defeat.

BAE points to a boost from 2003 when sales on military programmes will be 40% higher and the first of the 620 Eurofighters start to be delivered. It can also hope for extra earnings from the US after last year's $2.3bn purchase of two Lockheed Martin businesses - and greater military spending from the new Bush administration. BAE has spent a lot of time deriding Eads' over-dependence on civilian aerospace but now must swallow its words: it is now heavily dependent on Airbus and its 20% stake. If the about-to-be-created stand-alone Airbus company, promising huge savings, stumbles on old quarrels and the A380 superjumbo proves to be an expensive chimera, BAE's 1992 woes may return to haunt it. E- extravagance If there is one group likely to make e-tailing work it is Dixons. Through PC World alone, you would think, with its nethead customer base, it should be posting out peripherals by the cartload. But no. In the six months to November it did just £8.9m of sales on the net. Over Christmas, sales were up more than 200% - to, er, £3.2m. As chief executive John Clare concedes, this level of sales is little more than one big shop. A third of these sales are generated from just one business-to-business website operated by PC World. The group will shortly start net sales in France through its PC City website. For a company that has made millions providing PCs and internet access to ordinary punters, Dixons, under the leadership of Mr Clare and wily old chairman Sir Stanley Kalms, has always been pragmatic about the potential for e-tailing. The two have always maintained the big brands will win in the end and those which offer a true multi-channel retail strategy, where net buyers can pick up or return goods to stores, will be the long term victors. Given those opinions, Dixons' £30m investment in e-commerce seems a tad extravagant. Calling time The phoney war for Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has been raging for so long that staff must be wondering whether they will ever get a new boss. Leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare has been hanging around since August with a £270m offer to buy the business. Standing in his way is Wolves' managing director, David Thompson, whose family has run the business for five generations. Tweedy, Winchester-educated Mr Thompson is one of the last relics of the "beerage" which used to control the brewing industry, and he is less than keen to let go. Mr Thompson is running out of time. Since rebuffing Mr Breare's 500p-a-share offer he has had four months to come up with an alternative. Unless he can better that deal, with real cash, he should be a gentleman and concede defeat.

webTitle: Market forces

fields.headline: Tide changes at Powergen
fields.trailText: Of all the unusual price movements in the London market yesterday - and there were many - one really caught the eye of market professionals, Powergen.
fields.body:
Of all the unusual price movements in the London market yesterday - and there were many - one really caught the eye of market professionals, Powergen.

It is not often the share price of the electricity group jumps 31p (to 640p) in one trading session, and it is even rarer for nearly 13m shares to change hands. But both happened yesterday and dealers are convinced that something corporate is afoot.

According to whispers in the market yesterday afternoon, Powergen has received an expression of interest from German utility E.ON.

Following the lead set by domestic rival RWE, which snapped up Thames Water last year, it seems E.ON wants to break into the UK power market and sees Powergen as an ideal way to do it.

With the government recently giving up its "golden share", Powergen, which recently moved into the US power market through the £1.8bn acquisition of Kentucky-based LG&E, could be vulnerable to a bid pitched north of 700p.

Powergen was not the only the stock to attract an unusual amount of interest yesterday. Sema, the Anglo-French IT service outfit whose shares fell 74% last year after a shock profits warning and a director share selling scandal, put on 39p, or 15.23%, to 295p.

Chatter among traders suggested that a rival, possibly in North America or Europe, is giving the company the once over. That said, traders also heard a tale that trading in December, the last month of Sema's 2000 fiscal year, had been much stronger than expected.

Equally as puzzling was the move of cable group Telewest, up 14p to 121p, with dealers unable to come up with anything better than vague talk that Colt Telecom, 80p stronger at £17.55, might be considering making an offer. Bombed out online auctioneer QXL - up 2.5, or 23.81%, to 13p after 14.5m shares changed hands - was also in demand as marketmakers filled their books with the stock in anticipation of a bullish press report, expected to appear today.

In the wider market, blue chip shares ended lower for a third consecutive session, undermined by a truly awful performance from the aerospace and defence sector, where BAE Systems fell 87.5p, or 24.58%, to 268.5p, after a horrendous profits warning, and Smiths Group dropped 90p, or 11.36%, to 702p, after worrying news on the proposed disposal of its automotive division.

With banking stocks - like Barclays, off 105p to £20.80, for example - also in the doldrums, the FTSE 100 index of leading shares ended down 27.5 points at 6,060.6, edging ever close to the bottom of the 6,000-6,8000 trading range it held for most of last year.

In fact, without a powerful surge from the likes of BT, up 34p to 676p, and Energis, 30p better at 515p, it probably would have closed below 6,000 for the first time since last April. According to dealers, both stocks were benefiting from the recent strength of US telecom sector. They pointed out that AT&T had for example risen around 30% since the start of the year.

Elsewhere, the FTSE mid 250 index closed 5.1 points higher at 6,597.9, in a session that was dominated by the wild swings in the share price of online yellow pages company Scoot.com.

Early in the session Scoot's share price hit 98p on hopes that French group, and 22.4% shareholder, Vivendi, was about to launch a bid somewhere in the region of 200p-230p a share. However, the stock ended the day just 0.75p better at 75p, after reports that the company had dismissed the speculation.

At the seriously speculative end of the market, dealers were showing an unusual interest in Aim-listed, gold miner Griffin Mining, up 0.5p to 4.5p. According to the gossips Griffin has managed to raise a large amount of cash through the sale of stock to investors at 5p per share.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Going for a song
fields.trailText: Popstars | Brookside | Taggart
fields.body:
It is a publicist's overheated fantasy that I might want to walk about in a black T-shirt with "NIGEL, PICK ME!" sprayed on it in gold.

The T-shirt is part of the merchandising for Popstars (ITV), a 13-part series about the creation of a new pop group, and Nigel Lythgoe, head of entertainment at LWT, was one of the three judges. Nigel loomed largish in the TV programme - and so would you if you were the executive producer. He had, I concede, quite a nice line in careworn wit. They were trawling for talent through six cities, and by Birmingham they would have welcomed death or deafness as a friend.... Nigel said, "This could be like Japanese water torture."(Chinese, surely?) "We get together all the people who sing 'Angels' out of tune and force someone we hate to listen to them."

Another judge, Paul Adam of Polydor Records, wondered innocently why people came to auditions when they couldn't sing. Nigel said, "I put it down to their ears. They must be hearing something different from us."

In Leeds a rejected girl left, bleeping. In Birmingham a rejected boy brushed tears from his lashes. Claire, a big girl with a good voice, was paired - for our amusement I suspect - with Chapman, who was barely big enough for her elevenses. Richard was transfixed with terror like an arrow through the brain. Rejected, he said he would "Get a wee band together."

The judges were looking for something powerful but imprecise. "It's a vibe thing. It's a persona thing."

It's a marketing thing.

In Brookside (Channel 4), a close always notable for necrophilia, Max Farnham has been husbanding his wife's body in the lounge ever since he pushed her down the stairs. I would say living room, but in the circumstances.... Yesterday, he was persuaded to bury her. You could have sold tickets for the service.

As Bev of Bev's Bar put it colourfully, "Max had a huge fight over the coffin. There was blood everywhere." Max did give a funeral oration excoriating half the congregation, and let's just say that Mark Antony would have been livid.

A televised marriage never runs smoothly. I mean, look at the Royals. So when DS Jackie Reid began to plight her troth to some bloke called Brian on Taggart (ITV), you snuggled down in your chair like a hen on the nest. The lad she loved, as the music-hall song goes, was up in the gallery. DI Robbie Ross is the sort of bad lot for whom good women throw their bonnets over the windmill (assuming a bonnet and windmill are readily available), and he had tangoed Jackie torridly round the room to the strains of Jealousy. Each dislocating jerk being punctuated by her startled squeaks.

Just as she got to the bit about taking Brian as her legally wedded husband to the exclusion of all others - the wording was unfamiliar to me - Robbie appeared in the gallery with a hefty modern sculpture with holes in it, purchased by her colleagues as a wedding present. Never let them tell you Scots have no sense of humour. Now, it is rarely safe to allow a smouldering lover onto a gallery during a wedding service, particularly when he is carrying pottery.

Surely he would...?

Well, he didn't.

I don't know when I was more disconcerted. Particularly as the whole story, Falling In Love, simmered with murderous jealousy. The first victim plummeted 3,000ft with his sabotaged parachute into a greenhouse ("One of his legs is over there.") "He was", said his tearful fiancée, "an angel."

Sex does not normally loom large in Taggart. When Jim was running things, a well-chewed ear from his wife in her wheelchair was the most he could hope for. Taggart is more a repository of pawky wisdom - as in Wee Eckie's bizarre remark, "Ye canna pour the blood back into the sheep." This is the sort of proverb with which Khrushchev bamboozled the West for many years. We thought at the time that something must have been lost in translation. In retrospect, I am sure he made them up on his way to work.

One of those long-lost children that are so familiar to soaps is about to surface in Coronation Street (ITV). Adam, whose very existence has been unsuspected - even by the scriptwriters - for 12 years, is the son of Mike Baldwin, the knocking-on-a-bit-now knicker king, and the grandson of Ken "Interesting" Barlow. Now, why do we imagine him as a wrinkled little runt in a woolly?

webTitle: TV and Radio: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which film will take most at the box office this year?
fields.trailText: Which film will take most at the box office this year?
fields.body:
Hannibal 2-1
The Mexican 2-1
Spy Kids 3-1
AI 6-1
Blow 6-1
Fellowship Of The Ring 8-1

This could be a strong year for movies. Scorsese, Spielberg, Soderbergh, Ridley Scott, Kevin Smith, Tim Burton and Sam Mendes all have projects in the offing. There's also the first live-action version of Lord Of The Rings, and Pixar's first non-Toy Story feature.

"But remember that commercial and critical success don't always go hand-in-hand," warns Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. His advice is to look at release dates. For instance, box-office sales are higher in the Easter weekend or if the film is billed as the summer blockbuster.

Miramax's Spy Kids will have a summer release and a huge marketing campaign. It's the first Robert Rodriguez movie since The Faculty, and there's already a sequel in the pipeline.

"The plot has a lot of comedic potential, with secret agent kids protecting parents," says Andy. "And Teri Hatcher and Antonio Banderas make it appealing to both children and adults."

But for pure must-see, it's MGM's Hannibal (starring Anthony Hopkins) and DreamWorks' The Mexican, both of which had good preview screenings.

And what about the already near-legendary AI, originally conceived by the late Stanley Kubrick but now in the hands of Steven Spielberg? And why the longer odds?

"Well, it's a fascinating and unusual plot, but my gut feeling is that Spielberg is going for critical rather than commercial success," says Andy.

So could Ted Demme break into the commercial bigtime with Blow?

"The screenings have gone well in America and it has a solid cast - Johnny Depp Penelope Cruz, Ray Liotta, Dennis Leary. It could be the sleeper hit of the summer."

LOTR fans might be dismayed to see the film running behind in the stakes. "It's going to be great," says Andy. "But fantasy never smashes the box office."

webTitle: Three years after confession, 'Angel of Death' is charged with LA murders

fields.headline: Three years after confession, 'Angel of Death' is charged with LA murders
fields.trailText: A hospital worker who has described himself as the "Angel of Death" and claimed to have killed up to 50 patients has been arrested and charged with six murders.
fields.body:
A hospital worker who has described himself as the "Angel of Death" and claimed to have killed up to 50 patients has been arrested and charged with six murders.

The man, a respiratory therapist, was arrested on Tuesday morning, three years after making and then withdrawing a confession in which he said he took the lives of dozens of patients in hospital who looked "ready to die".

Efren Saldivar, 31, was charged with murdering six people under his care after traces of paralysing drugs were found in the bodies of the patients who had died at Glendale Adventist Medical Centre between 1992 and 1997. Investigators have studied the files of 171 patients who died during Mr Saldivar's shifts and more charges are expected to follow.

Mr Saldivar was arrested as he drove to work at a building site from the home he shares with his parents and brother in Tujunga, north of Los Angeles. He will appear in court in nearby Glendale today.

It was in February 1998 that an anonymous caller told the medical centre that a respiratory therapist had "helped a patient die fast". Mr Saldivar was already under suspicion after a colleague had claimed there were rumours that he had a "magic syringe".

Police were asked to investigate and Mr Saldivar confessed to killing between 40 and 50 patients between 1992 and 1997. He described himself as an "Angel of Death" and said he had used "ethical criteria" to pick victims, only selecting those who looked "like they were ready to die".

At the time, police were unable to find corroborative evidence and Mr Saldivar was released. In April 1998 he went on television and said that he had concocted the entire story because he had been suffering from depression, wanted to die and lacked the courage to do the job himself.

But the investigation continued slowly and it was not until a new Los Angeles county district attorney was elected last November, followed by the appointment of a new prosecuting attorney, that the investigation was speeded up, culminating in this week's arrest.

Mr Saldivar has presented a confused and disturbed picture when he has appeared in public. Born in Brownsville, Texas, in 1969, he moved to Tujunga with his family when he was two and graduated from high school in 1988.

He studied respiratory therapy at college and became a state certified respiratory care practitioner in 1989. He was soon working at the Glendale medical centre where he remained until the scandal first broke three years ago.

Mr Saldivar spoke at the time of his initial arrest of his desire to be executed. As California is one of the states which carries out such penalties, he may yet have his wish granted.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Moral Notes | Costing The Earth
fields.body:
Simon Brett opens a four-part series in which he re-examines those famous Victorian Values. Moral Notes (11.30am, Radio 4) investigates how the social pattern preferred by the queen and her consort won public support through the 19th century's most effective propaganda weapon, its popular songs. Sessions round the piano helped promote anything from imperial ambition to proletarian docility. Brett's opening segment recalls the songwriters' relentless emphasis on the ideal family - quite a way from the reality of life at the palace.

Kirby talks to one householder who has been flooded nine times in 10 years, and considers changes in farming and urban development which might avert future disasters.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Knife In The Water | The Outfit | The Impostors
fields.body:
Knife In The Water
(Roman Polanski, 1962)
2.20pm, Sky Cinema

Polanski's debut feature, made with a camera borrowed from his alma mater, the Lodz film school in Poland, thrust him into the international limelight. Scripted by Jerzy Skolimowsky, it's a brilliantly told drama reeking of menace and submerged emotions. A husband and wife pick up a young hitchhiker on the way

to a day's sailing; on board the stranger with a knife disturbs delicate balances, and a tide of feeling swells to murderous levels. And it's all done with wit and visual élan, to a jazzy rhythm.

The Outfit
(John Flynn, 1974)
11pm, TCM

Most "hardboiled" thrillers are pretty runny compared to this spare, violent version of Richard Stark's novel. Gimlet-eyed hardnut Robert Duvall is an implacable Earl Macklin, a bank robber seeking retribution from syndicate boss Robert

Ryan for the death of his brother. Flynn directs with extreme prejudice, paring dialogue down to the hard moral purpose behind the unrelenting action.

The Impostors
(Stanley Tucci, 1998)
12.05am, Sky Premier

Two roguish, jobless actors (Tucci and Oliver Platt) are conning a living in Depression-era USA. Posing as shop stewards on a luxury liner, they meet a whole host of weird characters (cue entertaining turns from the likes of Billy Connolly and Steve Buscemi). The intent is a 30s-style slapstick comedy, but the results are uneven.

The Flower Of My Secret
(Pedro Almodóvar, 1995)
2.10am, FilmFour

Nothing like the frenetic early comedies with which Almodóvar made his name; this seems to herald his mature period. The story of a novelist who, spurned by her husband, struggles to write something more challenging, it's intelligent, warmly perceptive, packed with rich characters, and still funny.

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Highlands
fields.trailText: Highlands
fields.body:
Some years ago a Charlie McKenzie went to Canada and set up his own Nature Reserve, but he missed the Highland wildlife so much that his sister in Inverness started sending him my Country Diaries.

Then Charlie started sending me some very special Christmas cards. Some time before the end of the year Charlie goes out into his woodlands and cuts a strip of bark off a birch tree, and then proceeds to flatten it, making sure the texture is kept intact. Then he paints onto the bark a different bird each year, so that I get an original and unique painting in the form of a Christmas card.

One of the early birds was a striking adult male grey wagtail, and this was chosen because I mentioned in a Country Diary that it was one of my favourite Highland water birds. Perhaps the most striking and certainly the largest card is that of a great northern diver, which calls over the countryside where he lives. I was so impressed with this diver that I have scanned it onto my headed note paper and onto the computer screen!

Other subjects have included a drake shoveler with a lovely combination of green, white and chestnut, and of course that famous spatulate bill, which is drawn to perfection. The 2000 card was a dunlin with its black belly patch indicating it's a breeding bird. This was an apt one to send as there is cause for concern with the Highlands population, which is declining in some areas because of afforestation, and also predation, firstly by hedgehogs, and now by large numbers of mink, ferrets and rats. All these Christmas card paintings have been framed and are on a wall in my study.

webTitle: 'Designer' pizzas are new weapon in store wars

fields.headline: 'Designer' pizzas are new weapon in store wars
fields.trailText: First it was clothes and perfumes. Then sunglasses and sportsgear. Now stand by for designer label food in your local supermarket.
fields.body:
First it was clothes and perfumes. Then sunglasses and sportsgear.

Now stand by for designer label food in your local supermarket.

Sainsbury's will next week launch a new round in the stores wars by selling pizzas made to recipes from one of Britain's best known restaurant chains.

Pizza Express, which has already dipped into the retail market with salad dressing and Italian olive oil, is aiming for a bigger slice of the action by offering four pizza choices from its eateries at 200 Sainsbury's stores.

The deal follows the same supermarket's partnership with Yo! Sushi, the Japanese fast food chain.

Pizza Express, founded by Italian food lover and entrepreneur Peter Boizot in 1965, feeds 15m people a year at its 250 UK restaurants and is seen to have a strong identity that could help Sainsbury's differentiate itself from its rivals.

The Pizza Express products will be priced from £3.25, slightly less than their equivalents in the restaurants, where VAT has to be paid. Pizzas are a growing part of the ready meal market.

About one in 12 households buys pizza to cook at home each week, while one in 50 orders takeaways.

The cooperation of restaurant brands is in contrast to some other attempts by supermarkets to cash in on designer names.

The European court of justice is determining whether Tesco should have the right to sell Levi Strauss jeans at a discount price, a verdict that will have repercussions for other "grey market" schemes where the supermarkets buy up stocks from outside fashion brands' approved retailers.

The manufacturers maintain that the ambience of a supermarket devalues their product.

webTitle: Arts: The royalties system under threat?

fields.headline: Used notes only
fields.standfirst: Changes to the royalties system spell disaster for new music. Or so the composers claim.  Stephen Moss  reports
fields.trailText: Changes to the royalties system spell disaster for new music. Or so the composers claim. Stephen Moss reports.
fields.body:
Composer George Benjamin calls it "the worst thing that has happened to classical music in my lifetime"; Faber Music vice-chairman Sally Cavender says that "contemporary music publishing in the UK has been undermined and the livelihood of serious classical composers threatened"; composer Michael Berkeley talks of the danger of "irreparable damage to contemporary music in this country".

The "it" refers to a series of changes in the way the Performing Right Society calculates the money due to "serious" music from live performances and broadcasting. The industry insists that the scrapping of the classical music subsidy and the fact that serious music now receives a far smaller share of money from suppliers of piped music has cost it £3m (30% of its income from the PRS) and plunged it into crisis.

The PRS has an unenviable task: to police all music played or broadcast outside the home, charge a fee for it, and relay the money to the copyright owners. Concert halls, pop venues and radio are relatively easy, but it is also responsible for every pub, club, restaurant, clothes shop and hairdresser in the country.

Composers and publishers are, however, in no mood to recognise the Sisyphean nature of the PRS's task. They believe the PRS is waging a concerted attack on serious music. Benjamin made an impassioned speech at the annual general meeting of the PRS in September. The loss of the subsidy and new royalties system, he argued, meant that "one almost has to view the PRS, with considerable sadness, as a determined opponent of the classical music sector".

The phrase the PRS is using to justify the changes is "straightlining". It believes that for the first time it has an accurate idea of what music is being played and how often; it says it cannot be blamed for the fact that pop music is popular, or that most of the money goes to pop composers.

"Under the terms of the subsidy, there was a multiplier to enhance the income of classical composers," explains Terri Anderson, communications director of the PRS. "But the PRS could no longer justify giving more to classical music when it had accurate information."

The classical lobby disputes the PRS's contention that the new system is accurate. "Sampling is fine for pop, but not for classical music," says Cavender. "The system just doesn't meet the needs of our market segment. We don't want handouts - we want payment because our pieces are being played."

Berkeley accepts that it is hard to argue in favour of subsidy without being labelled an elitist. "No one is saying that one art form is better than another - and great pop is better than bad classical," he says. "But what goes into a symphony can't be compared to writing a pop song, and it was right that the PRS recognised this."

In the mid-1990s, the PRS came under pressure from the Office of Fair Trading and sections of its own membership to end its discrimination in favour of classical music, and is adamant that it will not now make cultural distinctions. "We no longer feel we have the right or the duty to redress the perceived undervaluing of classical music in a commercial environment."

Cavender argues that unless the PRS takes a more sympathetic line, publishers will not be able to support up-and-coming composers. Berkeley agrees: "In terms of composition, it has never been harder."

At the heart of the argument is the debate about who has the right to determine what is "art", and whether that art should receive public patronage. The PRS no longer makes judgments about musical forms; it pays on the basis of what plays. Classical composers and publishers want recognition that their music takes longer to compose and larger forces to perform. Serious music, they say, needs serious money.

"A new symphony is the pinnacle of creativity," argues Trevor Glover, of music publisher Boosey and Hawkes, "but to say so will get you hurled out of court. Elite footballers are acceptable, but elite music isn't. I suspect we are buggered."

webTitle: Arts: Harriet Griffey meets Ray Charles

fields.headline: The road less travelled
fields.standfirst: He's a black man from a segregated town who played in apartheid South Africa; a blind man who started a foundation for the deaf. He also happens to have invented soul music. Ray Charles  talks to  Harriet Griffey
fields.trailText: He's a black man from a segregated town who played in apartheid South Africa; a blind man who started a foundation for the deaf. He also happens to have invented soul music. Ray Charles talks to Harriet Griffey.
fields.body:
Ray Charles doesn't often give interviews. He doesn't need the publicity. Sales of his two greatest hits albums last year take care of themselves, although touring for nine months of the year helps. In a career covering 50 years, the singer has only missed the annual tour once, when he checked himself into a hospital in 1965 to overcome a heroin addiction.

Touring has taken him to Israel in the 1970s, where he was a guest of David Ben-Gurion. It took him to South Africa in 1980, where he refused to play to segregated audiences, forcing the authorities to briefly suspend apartheid.

"When I go to these places where there might be turmoil, I'm not trying to send a message through my music," he declares. "That's not me. I'm going there because I'm hoping that for about an hour and a half I can make these people feel happy and they can forget their troubles. For an hour and a half they can be genuinely happy and smile and clap their hands and stomp their feet if they want to."

And now touring has taken him to the Palais des Congrès in Paris. Backstage before the show, Charles gives Al Jackson, his saxophonist and bandleader, the playlist for the night. It's a time-honoured custom: Charles decides earlier in the day what they will play, and lets them know just before they go on. But the 17 musicians are so used to playing together that it's not a problem.

While the band starts up, Charles emerges from his dressing room to sit by the stage, making his own silent preparation. He seems remote, letting the ambience and music wash over him. He's dressed in brown, from his ruffled shirt to his tux to his patent-leather shoes; the shoulders are square, his build spare. The trademark dark glasses are by Calvin Klein, his grey hair is close-cropped.

The band finishes its pieces, and the MC steps up: "And no-o-o-ow, la-a-dies and ge-e-e-ntlem-e-en, I give you ... Ray Charles !" With his arm resting on that of assistant Vernon Troupe, Charles walks from the wings to a tumult of applause, takes his seat at the keyboard and begins the most active performance that can be given by a man sitting down. His hands dance over the keys, his feet do the same on the floor. At times he seems to bounce six inches off his seat. His voice is powerful, resonant, soulful. When he plays Hit the Road Jack, the audience cheers; then again for I Can't Stop Loving You. All too soon it's over. No encores; he's gone.

Ray Charles Robinson was born in Georgia, then a segregated southern state of America, 70 years ago. He was the eldest of two boys born to Retha Robinson. It was after witnessing the accidental drowning of his little brother, when he was six years old, that Charles began to lose his sight. Within a year he was totally blind.

On discovering there was a Florida School for the Deaf and Blind his mother moved hell and high water to make sure he went there. Although this meant he was away from home for up to a year at a time - she couldn't afford his train fare home more than once a year - it also meant he learned the skills necessary for independence.

But it was Mr Pit, the local store owner, whom Charles credits with introducing him to the piano. "Whenever he would start to play this piano, whatever I was doing, I would stop. I would immediately go and jump in the chair and sit by him and bang on those keys. And he said to me, 'You don't hit the keys with your fists, son. You play the piano with each of your fingers.' And he began to show me how to tap out a little melody with one finger, maybe two fingers. I was only three."

There was more formal piano training to come at the school, where Charles studied Beethoven, Sibelius, Rachmaninoff and Bach. At one time Charles thought he might actually stick to classical music. "But I used to get into trouble with my teacher because I would be adding stuff to Chopin and she didn't like it. I was just curious as to what would happen if I did this, if I did that ... And I decided, well, I don't know if I want to play classical music because I can't improvise, I can't put myself into it."

"Putting himself into it" somehow sums up the approach of the man credited by many as the originator of soul, a unique mixture of blues, gospel and jazz. "Each song speaks for itself," he says. "So if I'm singing Georgia, I try to put myself into the lyrics of that song. And if I'm singing I Can't Stop Loving You, I try to make myself think like the guy talking to the girl. You put yourself into the voice of the song so you can feel what the song is dictating."

Charles sang America the Beautiful at Ronald Reagan's inauguration and at a presidential function for Bill Clinton - with carefully selected verses. "It has four verses and two of them, to me, just didn't go. They was talking about white this, white that, and it didn't appeal to me. I took the verses that described the country - you know, the fields, the men who stood up for the country. I used the verses that fitted what I was trying to say."

He talks about his friendship with Martin Luther King, and his decision to visit South Africa. "It was strange in a way, but if you grow up in the south, in a small town, you don't think that much about segregation as it is a way of life. But as you get older you see what's happening. When I played in the south they used to make the black people sit upstairs and the white people sit downstairs. I wouldn't perform as long as the crowd were segregated like that. I got sued, but at least I didn't have to play the concert."

And he talks about his project, the Robinson Foundation, which provides cochlear implant operations for children born deaf. "I had a problem with my ear, and I started thinking, it's impossible for me to be a Helen Keller. I couldn't survive if I couldn't hear and I couldn't see. Oh man, a total disaster. And I don't see nearly as much being done for deaf people as for blind people. There were deaf kids at school and I learned the sign language and all that, so we could talk. So I set up the foundation and it's so gratifying when you see a kid, who's never heard anything in his life, start saying words. It's beautiful, it really is."

It all ties in with another of his passions - chess. "There's no luck in the game. None. That's the great thing about chess: everyone starts with the same amount of pieces."

This is what's so glorious about this man's attitude. You couldn't say for a moment that he started out with the same amount of pieces. He was born black and poor at a time when racism and segregation were rife, saw his brother drown, went blind as a child - and yet he plays the game of life as if the odds hadn't been stacked against him. He is, as the French say, bien dans sa peau - "happy in his skin" - and the world is a richer place for it.

 Harriet Griffey's interview with Ray Charles will be broadcast in the World Service's Arts in Action programme on Saturday.

webTitle: Arts: Stuart Jeffries on the mirror in art

fields.headline: Through the looking-glass
fields.standfirst: There are some elements that hold a strange fascination for the arts: the staircase in opera, the eye in film, the bed in theatre. Over the coming weeks, Guardian writers will be looking at these obscure objects of desire, beginning with  Stuart Jeffries and the mirror in art
fields.trailText: There are some elements that hold a strange fascination for the arts: the staircase in opera, the eye in film, the bed in theatre. Over the coming weeks, Guardian writers will be looking at these obscure objects of desire, beginning with Stuart Jeffries and the mirror in art.
fields.body:
In the sunny sculpture garden of the Musée des Beaux-Arts in the Normandy city of Rouen, some clown has put boxes around the reclining sculptures so you can't see them properly. Or rather you can, but only if you look into the tilted mirror that rests on top of each box like an opened lid.

The walls of each box, however, reflect only the viewer, and so one stands at the threshold of an exhibition devoted to the role of mirror in art looking at oneself - a picture of self-consciousness rather than narcissistic self-absorption.

Letters have been written and angry voices raised about this concealment of beautiful classical statues by some clever clogs post-modernist. But these critics should think again. The boxes are the work of the French artist Daniel Buren; titled Couvrir, Recouvrir, Entrouvrir, Découvrir, they are a brilliant exploration of the role of the mirror in art. Brilliant because mirrors have been such a preoccupation for artists from ancient Egypt to today's New York studios that it's difficult to do anything new with them.

The mirror is everywhere in great art. In Velazquez's Las Meninas we find the painter reflected in a mirror in the corner of the canvas, his steady, hungry, scrupulous gaze bearing down on the subjects of the painting. In Van Eyck's The Arnolfini Marriage, the gruesome, distorted couple are further distorted by the convex mirror above and behind them.

There's a mirror too in Manet's Bar aux Folies-Bergères, the last in a series of paintings in which spectacularly bored women return the artist's and spectator's gaze. You can't miss this mirror. Placed behind the barmaid, it seems to reflect her back as she takes the order from a top-hatted customer, or listens to his shady propositioning. But her reflection is at an impossible angle, leaving us thinking that the barmaid is alienated from everything - including her own reflection.

The mirror in art says too much. It speaks of everything from Narcissus to Big Brother. It talks about the relationship between sex and power, and between men and women. It has been used so much that it raises the question: how can an artist nowadays engage with the mirror and say something that doesn't degenerate into game-playing or banality?

But Buren has succeeded in saying something new and suggestive. His boxes tell the story of the dialectic between the voyeur and the narcissist. The mirror both allows us to look at a human form from a hitherto secret view and confronts us with our own gaze in a disturbing context. It's nicer to look at oneself on the sly in the bathroom mirror, to control the consumption of one's image; rather more upsetting to be confronted with oneself in a very public hall. In a sense, then, Buren's work is revenge on behalf of all those pictures and sculptures that have no choice but to be looked at.

In Kant and the Platypus, Umberto Eco writes that, as well as being a puzzle (everybody from Lucretius to Kant has worried that mirror reverses right and left but not up and down - so your left hand becomes your right but your head does not become your foot), the mirror is also a prosthesis: the first mirrors, after all, were hand mirrors, extensions of one's arms. That is why we trust the ordinary mirror to show us reliably what is there. This is why we allow Buren's mirrors to show us the hitherto unseen - a marble breast from above, or rippling back muscles from a hitherto inaccessible angle.

There were once His and Hers mirrors. In ancient Greece, only women used bronzed mirrors; men instead looked into their wine cups to find themselves. As Aeschylus put it: "The mirror of beauty is the bronze. The wine is that of the soul." But he was a man, so he would say that. In ancient Greece, alcoholic drinks were a man's preserve, and by looking into the reflection of a cup of wine, a man would see himself, at least on the reflective surface. As men drank, the reflective surface disappeared, so Greek potters painted drunken images of men's faces at the bottom of each cup, each one a two-dimensional gargoyle. That, they said, is what you look like when you're pissed.

Rouen's Musée Départemental des Antiquités is holding a related exhibition, Games and Reflections Since Antiquity, which contains models of such antique wine cups, painting ugly mugs in the bottom of the bowls. The exhibition, tells a fascinating story about the mirror's role in the battle of the sexes.

In Olivier de la Marche's 15th-century painted parchment Adornment and Triumph of Women (on show in the same museum), a man holds a mirror up for a lady. He may be on his knees, but he has the power in the form of this moral prosthesis. By this time women were using mirrors to counteract rather than feed their vanity. Mirrors, ideally, would correct a woman's faults, and show her how to cultivate a chaste comportment and modest dress sense. This was a masculine mirror, then, and a restraint on the naturally licentious nature of woman.

It's fascinating to compare this image with Balthus's 1908 painting Les Beaux Jours, at the Beaux-Arts. On the right, a burly half-naked man is on his knees, poking a roaring fire. On the left, Lolita's younger sister reclines on a chaise, one leg raised in such a manner that the hulk need only turn slightly to see up her skirt. She wouldn't mind if he did: after all, she's lost in her hand mirror, contemplating her self-satisfied reflection.

This, we are to suppose, is the feminine mirror, the one that lures women into a sick world of masturbatory self-absorption. At the same time, the painting seethes with heterosexual tension. Will the man turn round and see what he shouldn't? Could he ever be as interested in the girl's image as she is? Of course not - you don't look at the mantelpiece while you're poking the fire.

The painting appears in a section of the Beaux-Arts exhibition called The Mirror and Femininity. All the usual suspects are there: Picasso, Man Ray and André Kertész - the latter stretching nude women's bodies into mercury writhings. There are no works by women in this section. Instead, there is a quotation from Louis Aragon printed on the wall, a message to his lover: "And when you leave I am as unhappy as your mirror."

But, in art, when the mirror is empty, the artist fills it with himself. Artists tend to find themselves endlessly interesting, always reliably there. The French psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan wrote of the mirror stage in which the infant, by looking in the mirror, finds itself coherent and whole for the first time.

But artists don't need actual mirrors to cultivate self-image. Tracey Emin's unmade bed does very well, although the canvas came first. Consider Albrecht Durer's Self-Portrait (1500). There he is, some pretty boy proto-hippy fingering his treated hair (did men use curlers in 1500?), staring out of the canvas. The viewers are his mirror, and we reflect and share his self-absorption. Everyone who paints themselves to their satisfaction in this way sells their soul for their image: in this way, Durer is Dorian Gray's precursor.

But one's self-image becomes an irksome thing. At the Beaux-Arts, a wonderful Super 8 film by Vito Acconi called See Through shows a sad-eyed man, with a woeful feather- cut, slowly shadow-boxing his mirror image. Acconi is locked in a Sisyphean struggle with himself. Narcissus never knew there would be such a downside.

When people write about mirrors, they go on about Narcissus, when they should be writing about his dog. There's the mutt now, licking the water in which his master studies his reflection, in a 1630 book engraving by Blaise de Vigenère to illustrate a text by the Greek Philostratus. Traditionally, the dog hasn't had a name, but let's call him Rebel - he's the one who stands up against Philostratus's boring dictum: "The two Narcissuses are identical and shine with the same beauty." If you look at this illustration, you'll see that Rebel is doing his damnedest to break up Narcissus's image. But Vigenère's engraving won't allow such subversion, and the water stays calm.

Rebel speaks of the other history of the mirror, in which the self-image is not held in reflection forever. Rebel would be pleased to see that there are lots of game-playing art works that misrepresent or refuse to represent the spectator. At the Beaux-Arts, a Gerhard Richter painting of a grey surface that refuses to reflect anything, but instead consumes all glances, is a particularly nice curatorial joke in the context of this exhibition. Anish Kapoor's bronze egg misreflects and, disturbingly, unreflects the spectator through a series of cunning effects.

Before Kapoor, Magritte created lying prostheses: think of his surrealist gag The Forbidden Reproduction, in which the spectator looks at the back of a man's head and beyond the man is a mirror that reflects the back of the same head. But the greatest current artist of the mirror is Bruce Nauman.

A 33-year-old video work, on show at the Beaux-Arts, sees Naumann slowly applying make-up to his face, neck and shoulders while he looks off to the left toward (we suppose) a mirror. In one video he applies white. In another green. A third, pink. In the final one, black. His sad eyes tell the story of a man trapped in his own self-obsessed drama. This new Narcissus is all made up with nowhere to go, and nothing to do but apply more make-up and look at himself for all eternity.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: New York city is to pay $50m (£34m) to settle a lawsuit by up to 50,000 people who were illegally strip-searched by jail guards in Queens and Manhattan in 1996 and 1997.
fields.body:
£34m payout in strip-search suit

New York city is to pay $50m (£34m) to settle a lawsuit by up to 50,000 people who were illegally strip-searched by jail guards in Queens and Manhattan in 1996 and 1997.

The victims were often first-time offenders held for minor infractions like loitering and disorderly conduct.

AP, New York

Phone sparks air emergency

A Slovenian airliner made an emergency landing on Tuesday after a passenger's mobile phone caused its electronics system to malfunction and indicate there was a fire on board.

The state-owned carrier, Adria Airways, said the jet, bound for Sarajevo, turned back soon after takeoff and made an emergency landing in Ljubljana.

Reuters, Ljubljana

MTV tribute to hate victims

The US cable channel MTV began a 17-hour transmission last night - free of music and adverts - scrolling repeatedly through the names of those who have died since the start of the 1990s as a result of ignorance and bigotry.

MTV has been criticised recently for promoting rap artists whose lyrics often incite vicious attitudes towards women, gays and white people.

Martin Kettle, Washington

Pinochet tested for trial fitness

General Augusto Pinochet underwent psychological tests yesterday to see if he is mentally fit to stand trial for alleged human rights abuses during his 1973-1990 dictatorship in Chile.

Judge Juan Guzman, who is leading an investigation into more than 200 cases of violence, plans to interrogate Gen Pinochet on Monday.

Reuters, Santiago

webTitle: Burmese opposition treads carefully

fields.headline: Burmese opposition treads carefully
fields.standfirst: Suu Kyi's party calls for caution as it confirms her secret talks with junta
fields.trailText: Suu Kyi's party calls for caution as it confirms her secret talks with junta.
fields.body:
Burma's main pro-democracy party yesterday confirmed that its leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, has been in secret talks with the military junta since last October, for the first time in more than five years.

Speaking a day after the UN special envoy on Burma, Razali Ismail, broke the news about the dialogue, a National League for Democracy executive member, U Lwin, said the negotiations were at a very early stage. It would take great patience for more substantive discussions on Burma's political future were to develop.

"The meeting is what we have been working for," he said. "Since [news of] it has appeared, the responsibility has become greater on both sides not to interrupt the momentum of the process. Both sides have to be careful not to irritate the process."

Mr Lwin said that the NLD's members were told in December of the meetings between Ms Suu Kyi and senior generals, including the junta's first secretary, Lieutenant General Khin Nyunt.

"The meeting seemed to have achieved some progress then," he said. He refused to give further details. The last time Ms Suu Kyi, a Nobel peace prizewinner, held substantive talks with the junta was in 1994, after she was released from six years in prison.

News of the talks came as a surprise as Ms Suu Kyi has been under virtual house arrest since last September, when she was blocked from leaving the capital Rangoon. Mr Ismail, who has just ended a five-day visit to Burma, was the first foreign diplomat to see her since then.

The military first came to power in 1962 and abolished all state institutions in 1988.

The NLD won an overwhelming majority in the last general election in 1990, but has never been allowed to govern. Its members are harassed, detained and beaten up. Despite this, Ms Suu Kyi has refused to compromise on the restoration of full democracy.

Mr Lwin said both sides were toning down their rhetoric against the other. "The government papers have stopped carrying provocative articles and cartoons and therefore we decided not to do anything that will be provocative," he said.

Some sources in Rangoon say that Gen Nyunt's willingness to meet Ms Suu Kyi could be part of a power struggle between generals jockeying to succeed the ailing supreme leader, General Than Shwe.

"An awful lot is going on behind the scenes in the corridors of power," one diplomat said. "I would not be surprised if this was linked to that."

Public reaction to the dialogue has been mixed. The exiled All Burma Students' Democratic Front hailed the talks as a "historic breakthrough after 12 years of struggle".

"We hope this dialogue will begin to overcome the major problems of civil war and bring about democratisation," it said. "This is the most positive sign we've seen since the election in 1990."

Governments in south-east Asia were also encouraged by the dialogue. Thailand, Singapore and Malaysia said they hoped for further breakthroughs. One diplomat said the progress so far was the result of "doing things quietly, the Asean way" - a reference to the regional group's policy of "constructive engagement" with its member countries, rather than intervention.

It is thought that Malaysia's prime minister, Mahathir Mohammad, stressed to the junta the importance of continuing the talks during a visit to Rangoon last week.

Western governments were less effusive. The British Foreign Office minister John Battle said: "We hope these [talks] will soon lead to a substantive political breakthrough and look forward to the early release of Aung San Suu Kyi and her colleagues. We do not intend to relax our international pressure for respect for democracy and human rights for the Burmese people until we see real progress."

Britain and the US have been leading a global campaign against the junta's oppression of the country's 46m people, including massive forced labour projects.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said it was crucial that Ms Suu Kyi should be "respected as a political leader and not, as was framed to me, as a 'little sister', that they had to take care of by keeping her in her house".

webTitle: Asteroid probe may bite the dust

fields.headline: Asteroid probe may bite the dust
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: After a year of long distance courtship, a spacecraft and its target could be about to come to a touching end.
fields.body:
After a year of long distance courtship, a spacecraft and its target could be about to come to a touching end. A near-Earth asteroid rendezvous probe called Shoemaker could be about to land on the surface of a giant asteroid called Eros - and then die.

Eros is a peanut-shaped lump of rock the size of Manhattan, 21 miles long and eight miles wide and eight miles thick, now tumbling through space 150m miles away, beyond the orbit of Mars.

The $224m (£150m) probe, named for the late Gene Shoemaker, who trained the Apollo astronauts to recognise rocks on the moon, was launched in 1996 to catch up with Eros and take a closer look.

It kept its date in deep space on February 14 last year, and began a stately waltz around its partner, taking ever closer looks at the pitted surface of the lump of rock in orbit around the sun.

Asteroids are thought to be the building blocks of a planet that should have formed somewhere between Mars and Jupiter, but never came together. But a number have become dislodged, and are now seen as potential cosmic traffic accidents.

Shoemaker was the first robot probe to take a long close look at a possible future problem. While Eros tumbled head over heels every five hours, Shoemaker has been swooping to within three miles of the surface to photograph its pockmarked face.

The spacecraft weighs 1,775lb. It will be travelling three feet a second when it hits Eros. "That's jogging speed, but if you hit a brick wall when you're jogging, it hurts," he said. "It's risky, but we will get a lot of bonus science."

Duncan Steel, an asteroid expert at the University of Salford, suggested that Eros could have a surface of fluffy dust. "If the satellite lands in the right place, it might be more like falling on to a feather mattress than a concrete floor," he said.

"Very appropriately, the satellite got to Eros on Valentine's day. Now at last we are going to kiss it properly."

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Ben Elton

fields.headline: No: 1798
fields.standfirst: Ben Elton
fields.trailText: Ben Elton
fields.body:
Age: 41.

Infamous self-description: "Smug git in a shiny suit."

The raw, unvarnished truth: Smug git in a shiny suit.

Occupation: Stand-up comedian, screenwriter, novelist...

That's more than enough. Not for Ben, whose CV also includes being a writer of musicals, film producer and erstwhile talkshow host. And - some naysayers infinitely more jaded and cynical than Pass notes might add - professional turncoat.

Ben Elton a sellout? Surely not. As if the sometime Scourge of Thatcherism's collaboration with Lord Lloyd-Webber on The Beautiful Game - a musical about Ulster - wasn't enough, it emerged yesterday he'd be presenting extracts of it at the inauguration of that epitome of liberal intelligence, president-elect George W Bush.

Not quite up there with Clinton's inaugural bash, is it? Indeed. Bulging with all 73 members of Fleetwood Mac and a bevy of Hollywood's Democratic finest, Bill's party was a riot, apart from the embarrassing moment some random sax-playing Arkansan stumbled on stage. Whereas Bush has...

Charlton Heston? Harrison Ford? Er, ZZ Top and the Backstreet Boys, actually. Hence Ben. And fellow comedians are enraged. "Next stop a Saudi Arabian beheading festival," Mark Thomas muttered to one reporter.

Ben, presumably, disagrees. Absolutely. Choosing one's work collaborators on the basis of political belief is, as he helpfully explained in a recent interview, "a bollocks idea".

What is The Beautiful Game, anyway? It's about a Belfast football team but, somewhat confusingly, deals with "issues" - Elton likes "issues" - relevant to Kosovo and Afghanistan. Still, there's no reason to suspect that Dubya is going to have any difficulty in separating all the different countries in his mind, is there?

Not to be confused with: Ben Elton, firebrand leftie comic; Ben Elton, green campaigner; Ben Elton, pro-choice activist.
