webTitle: Archaeological find near Seahenge

fields.headline: Riddle of the sands
fields.standfirst: Archaeological find near Seahenge
fields.trailText: Archaeological find near Seahenge
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Another timber structure has been discovered on the beach off Holme-next-the-Sea, Norfolk, near the site of Seahenge, the 4,000-year-old timber circle revealed by a storm two years ago.

The discovery suggests the entire beach is an important prehistoric ritual landscape, with dozens more timber monuments waiting to be exposed and destroyed by storms, archaeologist Francis Pryor said last night.

Dr Pryor is an authority on wetland archaeology, who worked on the conservation of the Seahenge timbers after they were removed from the beach by English Heritage against bitter local opposition.

The new find, two logs surrounded by traces of wickerwork and post holes, was exposed in the sand last year but, in the wake of controversy over Seahenge, it was not publicised.

The Norfolk Archaeology Unit, which is completing a survey for English Heritage, has also found traces of other ancient timbers, including posts which may have supported trackways across what was, 4,000 years ago, a freshwater swamp.

English Heritage said reports on all the timbers were being studied, and no decision had been taken yet on what to do with the site, 200 metres from Seahenge.

Dr Pryor predicted the entire site would prove to be studded with monuments to the Bronze Age dead.

"It is now absolutely imperative that English Heritage and English Nature agree a management plan for the entire area, involving the local council, local people and the local archaeology unit, and permanent archaeological monitoring of the beach," he said.

Dr Pryor believes the new find is the remains of a barrow. "To me the two logs are very suggestive of supports for an oak coffin, which has already been lost."

He said it was probable there were perhaps hundreds of other structures.

Dr Pryor led the excavation over 30 years of a similar site, Flag Fen at Peterborough, where Bronze Age swords, bowls, jewellery and the oldest wooden wheel in Europe were uncovered. He believes there are similar deposits waiting to be found in the sand and silt at Holme.

webTitle: Leader: Composers earn little. It may soon be less

fields.headline: Air on a shoestring
fields.standfirst: Composers earn little. It may soon be less
fields.trailText: Composers earn little. It may soon be less.
fields.body:
Tracey and Damien are coining it, and good luck to them. Martin, Jeanette and Salman are very comfortable, thank you. But spare a thought, if you will, for Britain's young composers, very few of whom are making much money and who may now get much less. The business of contemporary music is in crisis.

Very few composers of serious classical music have ever survived on the income from their works. Publishing music by living composers is almost invariably a non-profit making activity in which any returns normally materialise only after a 10- or 20-year period. Until recently composers in this country got some modest relief from a special Performing Right Society (PRS) subsidy which was - according to your point of view - either enlightened or elitist.

That classical musical subsidy has now been scrapped. Worse, the PRS has devised a complex new way of calculating and distributing royalties which looks certain to do further damage to the prospects of young composers. George Benjamin, one of our most extraordinary musical talents, recently warned the PRS that many composers whose works were played in smaller halls risked losing their royalties altogether. He also warned that composers writing for small chamber ensembles risked earning nothing in performing rights. The PRS's approach, which links box-office success to the likelihood of a composer being rewarded, will encourage a play-safe approach and discourage risk-taking. As our article in G2 makes plain, many distinguished figures in music regard the new system as cultural vandalism.

They are right. The last 10 years have seen a terrible decline in a once proud tradition of musical tuition in this country. Until recently we could at least boast a music publishing scene which drew international admiration for its seriousness, diversity and imagination. All that is now threatened. Should publishers throw in the towel, it will become even harder for young and talented composers to have their pieces published and get their first works performed.

The sums involved in the loss of the classical music subsidy and other changes - some £3m - are by the standards of the PRS (annual turnover £227m) pretty insignificant. But to the composers who are losing out, the sums are very significant. As the government's guardian of culture, Chris Smith should ask the PRS to think again.

webTitle: Letters: Helping charities to achieve their aims

fields.headline: Helping charities to achieve their aims
fields.trailText: We would like to make clear that the Pavarotti Music Centre in Mostar is, sadly, not as yet being funded in a major way by Future Trust (A charity caught up in chaos, January 10).
fields.body:
We would like to make clear that the Pavarotti Music Centre in Mostar is, sadly, not as yet being funded in a major way by Future Trust (A charity caught up in chaos, January 10). We are very young, but with the support of Brian Eno, Maestro Pavarotti and other artists, did organise a concert at the centre last October which is being webcast in Japan and hopefully soon throughout the world. We have provided the music centre with initial funding and will offer greater support in the future when we receive income from our webcasting and from further concerts.

We are now planning a large festival in Belgrade and a concert tour that will take in many cities of former Yugoslavia, including Pristina. We are working with people in the music business who have not given up on the notion that music and cultural aid is a vital part of post-war reconstruction.
David Wilson (Co-founder, War Child)
Hiroshi Kato
Future Trust
Dwil45@aol.com

 War Child has had serious problems. Your piece, fairly, gave prominence both to the problems and to the efforts that the charity has made to correct them. The charity commission's understanding, contrary to your own, is that the two men named in your leader are no longer connected with the charity.

Because the trustees were ready when they called us in to recognise their problems and try to resolve them, the charity commission has been able to work with them without a statutory inquiry or publishing formal reports. The commission's involvement was intensive from the start. Suggestions in your leader of delay and inaction on the part of the commission are misplaced and not supported by the current trustees. The priority has been to help the charity to strengthen its ability to pursue its charitable aims. The trustees are implementing improvements that their own auditors have suggested.

The trustees have acted responsibly, and with the commission's support, they have made progress in restructuring management and financial systems. They were right to seek the advice of the charity commission when they found themselves in honest difficulty. Charities which do so can expect a helpful response.
John Stoker
Chief charity commissioner

webTitle: Letter: Saddam is to blame

fields.headline: Saddam is to blame
fields.trailText: As a member of the leadership council of the Iraqi National Congress, representing political forces united in opposition to Saddam Hussein's regime, I read with interest the comments made by Hans von Sponeck (Foreign Office challenged on the UN's Iraq sanctions, January 4, and Letters, January 8).
fields.body:
As a member of the leadership council of the Iraqi National Congress, representing political forces united in opposition to Saddam Hussein's regime, I read with interest the comments made by Hans von Sponeck (Foreign Office challenged on the UN's Iraq sanctions, January 4, and Letters, January 8).

There is no doubt that the population of Iraq is suffering. But it is disingenuous to suggest that this suffering is a result of the terms of the sanctions regime imposed upon Iraq. The blame for this suffering must be levelled directly at Saddam Hussein

Sufficient resources are available to enable Saddam Hussein to alleviate the suffering endured by the Iraqi people. Yet he chooses not to. Under the oil for food programme, the UN recommended that Iraq set aside $91m for nutrition; Iraq allocated only $24m. Indeed, Iraq is actually exporting foodstuffs to other countries. Any attempt to absolve Saddam Hussein from blame only strengthens his position in Iraq, and does nothing to help the people of Iraq.

Recent speculation surrounding Saddam Hussein's health highlights the need to have in place a transition strategy so that the power vacuum left by Saddam is not filled by another military dictator, but rather by an orderly process that will lead to a democratic Iraq at peace with itself and its neighbours. This goal is the raison d'etre of the INC and we are preparing for such an inevitability.
Sharif Ali
Iraqi National Congress

webTitle: Letters: Where's the beef?

fields.headline: Where's the beef?
fields.trailText: You report it was "an overripe beef tomato" that hit the prime minister (Blair's day more fruitful than expected, January 10), but failed to see the wider political significance.
fields.body:
You report it was "an overripe beef tomato" that hit the prime minister (Blair's day more fruitful than expected, January 10), but failed to see the wider political significance. Most beef tomatoes sold in this country at this time of year are produced not far from Brussels. Chris White
Eurofruit Magazine

 Pundits seem to think that because no bald man has been prime minister since Attlee, then slaphead Hague has no chance. But on a recent trip to the continent, my wife and I both remarked how few trichologically challenged males were in evidence, whereas at Heathrow the glare was blinding. Does Hague perhaps have a shiny new secret weapon?
Mick Rennie
Dundee

 Jacqui Smith MP is wrong (Letters, January 10) there are 6,998 more teachers now than two years ago. My partner and I have just left.
Robert Ferry
Builth Wells

 The three panellists in favour of making the morning after pill available in schools (G2, January 10) all appear in their photographs as relaxed and smiling. The two against don't. Any connection?
Michael Calvert
Coldstream, Berwickshire

 You report (Society, January 10) that snowmen have been accused of reinforcing gender stereotypes that man's territory is outdoors. My wife and I would like to know how you determine the sex of a snowperson? Is it something to do with the carrot?
Dr David Harper
Cambridge

 Accenture could not be a word in any dialect of Finnish, rural or otherwise (If the name fits, January 8), as the letter C does not exist in the Finnish language, except in loan words such as "cockup".
Guy Buncombe
Cambridge

webTitle: Letter: Pay key to police numbers

fields.headline: Pay key to police numbers
fields.trailText: Not all police officers in the home counties have been offered an extra £2,000 a year as you claim ('Byzantine' body delays police pay rise, January 8). Some have only been offered £1,000 and some nothing at all, even when working in the same force.
fields.body:
Not all police officers in the home counties have been offered an extra £2,000 a year as you claim ('Byzantine' body delays police pay rise, January 8). Some have only been offered £1,000 and some nothing at all, even when working in the same force. This proposal is both divisive and detrimental to the flexibility of police deployment.

Second, there has been no delay by the Police Negotiating Board (PNB). The so-called "Home Office proposal" was met by an alternative proposal by the staff side which represented a more complete solution to the service's recruitment and retention problems. By the time of its next scheduled meeting in early, not late February, the PNB will have had three additional meetings to discuss both sets of proposals. This is negotiation not procrastination.

The truth is the government's national campaign to recruit 9,000 additional police officers above replacements over three years is already running woefully short of target: 3,000 additional officers were planned for 2000-01 and at this stage it looks as if only around half of that number will materialise. Recruitment problems are being experienced throughout the country.

Police remuneration, stripped of housing allowance for those joining after 1994, is insufficient to attract 9,000 additional officers above replacements. Finding the resources to fund the staff side's claim for a regional allowance payable to all officer's not in receipt of housing allowance is the only way that the government will reach its recruitment targets.
Jeff Moseley
Staff side secretary, Police Negotiating Board

webTitle: Letter: Disturbing sanitation at Kumbh Mela festival

fields.headline: Untouched
fields.trailText: The cavalier reference to "8,000 turd-pickers" in Luke Harding's report on the Kumbh Mela festival in India (Take me to the river, January 10), masks a grimmer reality.
fields.body:
The cavalier reference to "8,000 turd-pickers" in Luke Harding's report on the Kumbh Mela festival in India (Take me to the river, January 10), masks a grimmer reality. They are some of the hundreds of thousands of Dalits (the old "untouchables"), who are still designated as the toilet cleaners of Indian society. Their health is poor, they are regarded as polluted and their "trade" is passed on from generation to generation.

"Scavenging", as it is politely known, is outlawed in India and vast sums have been promised to end it. However, the money rarely seems to get to the Dalits themselves. It is to be hoped Kumbh Mela pricks the consciences of all those in India responsible for perpetrating the continuing lot of the turd-pickers.
Rev David Haslam
Dalit Solidarity
davidhaslam@easynet.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Halt use of uranium arms

fields.headline: Halt use of uranium arms
fields.trailText: We welcome the programme to screen Balkans veterans for signs of depleted uranium contamination. But this does not go far enough (UN holds back on uranium warnings, January 10).
fields.body:
We welcome the programme to screen Balkans veterans for signs of depleted uranium contamination. But this does not go far enough. If Nato governments are serious in their desire to find out the risks, they must release information on where DU was used in the Balkans and which troops were deployed in those locations (UN holds back on uranium warnings, January 10).

They should test the health of a sample of those troops and carry out parallel tests on a control group. This screening must be carried out by an institution that is seen to be neutral; has the capacity to check for DU effects, rather than uranium effects; takes into account recent findings in radiobiology that risks of alpha emitters such as DU may be greater than previously thought because of their effects on DNA; and takes into account exposure to other toxic agents, particularly chemicals released by the Nato bombing. Establishing where DU missiles were used will also be important information for the local populations.

Information on DU and health tests available must then be provided to GPs. As you suggest, a way must also be found to include Gulf war veterans in the studies. Their concerns have so far not been met, and as time goes on it becomes ever more difficult to identify the true causes of their illness. Until the results of these studies are known, we believe that there must be a moratorium on the use of DU weapons.

Nuclear Hazards Group

 The scope of the problem is even wider than hitherto admitted. The use of DU was not confined to anti-tank shells. Most of the Tomahawk missiles contained approximately 3kg of depleted uranium and these weapons were used against all parts of Serbia - not just Kosovo.

Great Kingshill, Bucks

 Having worked on the chemistry of uranium for over 30 years, I am disturbed by the misinformation being circulated. However, it is still toxic and radioactive. The effect of the radioctivity depends on how the uranium is contained, but if, as is feasible with uranium shells, some uranium compound becomes absorbed by the body it could be fatal.

Coimbra, Portugal
burrows@ci.uc.pt

This follows the revelation that as bombs fell in Macedonia, unprotected Macedonian policemen investigated, whilst Nato soldiers turned up in protective suits. Nato must have therefore known of possible risks.
Julian Pack
Skopje, Macedonia
daymonk@yahoo.co.uk

 Depleted uranium munitions are not just used in war; like all other weapons they have to be used in practice and according to the technical press are used in the UK on a regular basis. It is time for the military to come clean about both the risks to which they are exposing our armed forces and about what parts of our country they are making radioactive.
Richard Leach
Sheffield
kaktus_nome@hotmail.com

webTitle: Merry Christmas and a revolutionary New Year

fields.headline: Merry Christmas and a revolutionary New Year
fields.trailText: In Quivican, just outside Havana, the millennium arrived not so much with anticipation for the new century as with reminders of triumph for the revolution's 42nd year.
fields.body:
In Quivican, just outside Havana, the millennium arrived not so much with anticipation for the new century as with reminders of triumph for the revolution's 42nd year.

All day on New Year's Eve the two state television channels ran montages of the revolution's finest moments: student marches along the seafront, a crowd of thousands flicking bright national flags in rhythm; Fidel Castro delivering speeches in the fields and plazas; Che Guevara electrifying the factories and streets.

And then there was Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old boy plucked from the sea off Florida and subjected to a tug-of-war before being returned to Cuba. In one televised ceremony Elian smiled at Fidel, and Fidel smiled back from the podium, a huge grin. In his fatigues Castro looked grandfatherly, glowing with affection. It was a personal moment completely out of context. This boy is a celebrity here, a national hero. I'd even say he is marked for office.

At first the wealth of scratchy film archiving the revolution's birth was riveting. It is, after all, rare stuff. But after so much repetition it became just television. I wandered out of Uncle's house and on to the dirt streets.

Quivican is a town of about 5,000, mostly mechanics and field hands, and a few doctors and merchants. Everyone seemed to know something about engines. Dilapidated Chevrolets and Pontiacs had someone bent over them, or under them, or were just sitting there with a hood up, waiting.

At Uncle's house the day was spent around a '67 Land Rover. Friends had stopped by to sip a glass of rum and give advice. That's how the morning went: drinking and hot-wiring the engine, and testing it, running the idle high, trying to get rid of those choking white exhaust fumes that ruin so much of the air here.

Whatever trick they used worked, and we even got a little drunk in the process, smeared with grease and oil and dirt.

One old fellow, a percussionist dressed from head to toe in white, started showing off on the Land Rover's hood, slapping out a song once famous. He made music out of that hood, the rest of us watching and sipping, digging it. A goat watched from the neighbour's roof.

By afternoon the town plaza was full. There was an open-air market, and about 300 people were milling around makeshift kiosks and lean-tos selling enormous amounts of roast pig, chicken, churros (fried dough with sugar), beer and bread and rum. The browned, severed heads of pigs were piling up.

Huge, ancient diesel trucks lumbered through the crowd between tractors and horse-drawn carts. Chickens darted back and forth, and small dogs investigated. At one corner of the plaza, across from the church, there was more pig, dangling from hooks, gutted and shaved and ready for purchase. There were in fact an unsettling number of dead pigs around if you are not used to that kind of thing.

At another corner a pipa de cerveza sold beer brought over from a provincial brewery. The pipa is basically a small trailer with a tank of beer inside. Painted on the panels was a voluptuous woman in a transparent negligee, who had nothing whatsoever to do with the beer. "It's to get your attention," one man explained. "You check her out, and then you want a beer."

I had more than a little of all of it, the lukewarm pig and the rum and the beer and the chicharrón (fried chitlins or crackling) . . . perhaps too much too quickly, because soon I felt a little weird. "What you need is rum, or beer," Uncle said. "I'm dehydrated. I need water," I replied. "You need liquids," he insisted. "Beer is liquid, and it settles the stomach."

Not the best of advice . . . by midnight I had a fever and a tight stomach. But I headed out into the cold, and watched the effigies of the 20th century being burned. Big Dolls of the Old Year, they were called, and they are best described as scarecrows about a metre tall, dressed and painted up like old men, and set on fire. Some dolls burned taller than others, but most had died out by 2am. Back at Uncle's place, another televised hodgepodge of revolutionary memories lulled me to sleep.

All next day neighbours came over to wish us Happy New Year. Somehow they had found out I was sick. An old woman brought a popular remedy, a glass two-thirds full of juice from some unpronounceable kind of orange from her yard, mixed with a third of salt. "Drink it quickly," her husband warned me. He was a doctor. "No", she said, "drink it slowly. Your body's never had this. It doesn't know it." So I drank it slowly, that bitter, stinging witch-potion, and discovered how it works: you feel the pain of it destroying whatever it is inside you that is making you sick. You feel sicker, then somehow you emerge feeling suddenly light and rested. It really was a miracle.

Another old woman came over and rubbed at the glands and knots in my legs, which apparently communicate with the stomach, and the illness soon abated. Not once did anyone suggest medicine.

Outside, Uncle was back at work, on a Lada this time, tinkering with a panel. Was he excited about the new millennium, I asked. "I don't really see what all the fuss is about. What's to celebrate? You're born in the 20th century, you die in the 21st. There."

webTitle: Ferguson attacks 'ego-trip' agents

fields.headline: Ferguson attacks 'ego-trip' agents
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson yesterday accused agents of being on "an ego trip" as he insisted that Manchester United would not pay exorbitant wages to the five senior players, David Beckham, Ryan Giggs, Andy Cole, Jaap Stam and Dwight Yorke, with whom they are negotiating new contracts.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson yesterday accused agents of being on "an ego trip" as he insisted that Manchester United would not pay exorbitant wages to the five senior players, David Beckham, Ryan Giggs, Andy Cole, Jaap Stam and Dwight Yorke, with whom they are negotiating new contracts.

Ferguson indicated that the salaries reportedly being sought by Beckham (£4m) and Cole (£3m) were excessive and being bandied about solely by their agents. "It is more important for them to get huge salaries for their players than it is for the players themselves," said the manager.

It means that agents, he added, "can go around to their other clients and say, 'I got this for so and so.' Agents asking for such and such is just rubbish. It's just an ego trip for them."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Reviews: Perfect harmony for Swan Lake

fields.headline: Perfect harmony for Swan Lake
fields.standfirst:
Swan Lake
Coliseum, London
****
fields.trailText:
Swan Lake
Coliseum, London
****
fields.body:
Derek Deane's spectacular production of Swan Lake, created in the round for the Albert Hall, has found its way back to conventional theatres where its staging not only looks less overblown but also more genuinely poetic.

A few remnants of the old circus act persist - in the dumb-show prologue that shows Odette being magicked into a swan princess, in the swampy quantities of dry ice that billow over the lake scenes, and in the preponderance of circular figures and turns within Deane's choreography (necessary in the Albert Hall, to give audiences seated at the back an occasional view of the dancers' faces).

Otherwise, though, the production has reverted to a pleasantly fresh and efficient version of the old ballet. Peter Farmer's designs now supply a traditionally Gothic castle and blasted lakeside. An extra choreographic treat for Ashton fans is the restoration of the latter's wittily nuanced pas de quatre in Act 1. It's a relief to watch the dancers doing what they've been trained to do, which is articulate their steps from within the logical frame of the proscenium arch.

This was particularly crucial on the first night as English National Ballet's most precious asset, the husband and wife partnership of Thomas Edur and Agnes Oaks, were dancing the principal roles. Individually, both dancers are perfectly suited to Swan Lake. Edur as the prince is one of those rare men who can pull out all the technical stops without looking as if he's trying to gatecrash his ballerina's party. In Act 1 his dancing is all fine detail and musical rectitude, a dreamy monologue that charts the prince's growing awareness of his romantic desires.

In the bravura variations of Act 3, Edur allows his jump to fly vauntingly free and his pirouettes to whistle at high speed, but there's a joyous lift to his bearing which never shouts "Look at me" but rather proclaims his character's thrill at having fallen in love. Oaks's fragile build and legato phrasing are made to measure for Odette, lending a feathery delicacy to her feet and arms and a deep vibrato melancholy to her line.

As Odette's evil double Odile, she flips into a wickedly alternative mode, slapping off the prince's hopeful attentions and flaunting her powers. Even with a persistent ankle injury, Oaks dominates the stage. But it's in their pas de deux that this couple are truly astonishing. Dancing together constantly for 10 years, they have become uncannily tuned to each other's minds and bodies. They hear the music identically, their limbs fall naturally into the same line, and Edur seems not to physically lift Oaks but simply hold her up with his breath. In some respects this eerie accord lacks the edge and chemistry that can spark between less familiar partners, but it also gives us a sense of listening to a story that's been told so many times it's settled into a perfect ritual.

 In rep until January 20. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

webTitle: Reviews: Theatre: Spinning into Butter

fields.headline: Liberals with a racist heart
fields.standfirst:
Spinning into Butter
Royal Court Theatre Upstairs, London
****
fields.trailText:
Spinning into Butter
Royal Court Theatre Upstairs, London
****
fields.body:
It is rare to find an American playwright dealing with ideas as well as emotions. Rebecca Gilman, who wrote a fine de-glamourised account of Bonnie and Clyde called The Glory of Living, here confronts the topic of racism. Even if her conclusion - that it's a crime of which we're all guilty - is less likely to come as a shock-horror revelation in Britain, the play still generates a prickly unease.

Gilman's setting is a Vermont liberal arts college, Belmont. And, misquoting Shakespeare, one might say in Belmont is a lady slightly left. Her name is Sarah Matthews, she is the dean of students and, when a black freshman is threatened with racist graffiti, she is the first to spring into action. While her colleagues pompously assemble public forums, she informs the police. But, as the racist notes continue and she herself is accused of being patronising, her liberal facade crumbles. In a long scene with her ex-lover, she confesses she fled to Vermont to escape black students and that she is a covert racist like everyone else.

Where Gilman scores is in her damning portrait of the evasions of political correctness. Just as David Mamet's Oleanna was really about the American tendency to address social problems through litigation, so this play is partly about verbal camouflage. Sarah's academic colleagues believe that as long as you've formed a committee or issued 10-point proposals, you've dealt with endemic racism. But I wish Gilman took the argument even further. Some years ago a New Yorker article drew a crucial distinction between racial equality and racial civility: action is preferable to words. Although Gilman touches on this obliquely, she never quite clinches the point that the real problem lies in a higher educational system that reinforces white privilege.

Her play also has technical flaws: Sarah's unstoppable confession leaves little room for argument and the ending has a strained optimism. But I can forgive Gilman's faults for her attack on the timorousness of a society where political correctness takes precedence over legislation and where to criticise black writer Toni Morrison is tantamount to racism. She also has several moments guaranteed to make white liberals wince, not least Sarah's belated realisation that "to idealise is not to respect".

Gilman is well served by Dominic Cooke's tight, focused production and by Emma Fielding's outstanding performance as Sarah. The nervous flickers behind her eyes and the tension of her body language belies her laundered efficiency and implies from the start that her liberalism is only skin-deep. David Horovitch as a posturing faculty boss, Robert Bowman as Sarah's deceitful lover and Susan Engel as a status-conscious establishment toady all reinforce the impression that liberal arts colleges are part of the racial problem rather than the solution. As Americans say, it's better to walk the walk than to talk the talk.

 Until January 27. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

webTitle: Reviews: Bracing Berkoff

fields.headline: Bracing Berkoff
fields.standfirst:
Greek
Riverside Studios, London
***
fields.trailText:
Greek
Riverside Studios, London
***
fields.body:
Steven Berkoff's work has become such a staple of student and Edinburgh Fringe groups that you are inclined to assume you've seen it all before. But in fact this modern reworking of the Oedipus myth has seldom been seen in London in recent years.

Martin Webb's production may be patchy in places, but both it and the play are so fresh and alive they provide a forceful reminder of why paying money to sit in the dark can give you a real thrill. Berkoff transposes the story from Thebes to London's East End, where young Eddy, plucked from the river after the Southend-bound paddle steamer hits a mine, grows up unaware that his parents are not his natural kin.

When a fairground Gypsy tells them that Eddy will kill his father and bed his mother, they can't get the young man out of the house fast enough. But within hours Eddy has killed the owner of a greasy-spoon cafe and settled down with the dead man's wife, who many years previously lost her son in an accident.

Where Sophocles is spare, Berkoff is showy. The language is foul, bloated, swag-bellied, tumescent. It is like an extended orgasm. Though there are times - particularly as the story thunders towards its climax - when you think "Oh just get on with it", the effect is both exhausting and enormously satisfying. In part it is because Berkoff's descriptive powers are so strong.

In a few phrases he summons up Eddy's adoptive home: the smell of lard, the picture on the mantelpiece of granny "looking like Mussolini in drag", Eddy's sister in her room "meditating over some juicy blackhead". But it is also because the munificence of the language demands a suitably ornamental response from the actors. It is like watching skaters attempting a fiendishly difficult jump on very thin ice.

Oliver Lansley is near perfect as the hapless Eddy, only flagging slightly towards the close. But the distinctiveness of Berkoff's language and the expressionistic physical style of the piece are so familiar that they can pose other difficulties. There are occasions, particularly with the writing is at its most florid, when Berkoff seems almost to be parodying himself. I was struck, as by other Berkoff revivals, that I am seeing a very clever copy rather than an original masterpiece. But it is a bracing evening, and anyone unfamiliar with Berkoff's scurrilous, sulphurous and gloriously theatrical play should head west.

 Until January 27. Box office: 020-8237 1111.
fields.bodyText: Steven Berkoff's work has become such a staple of student and Edinburgh Fringe groups that you are inclined to assume you've seen it all before. But in fact this modern reworking of the Oedipus myth has seldom been seen in London in recent years. Martin Webb's production may be patchy in places, but both it and the play are so fresh and alive they provide a forceful reminder of why paying money to sit in the dark can give you a real thrill. Berkoff transposes the story from Thebes to London's East End, where young Eddy, plucked from the river after the Southend-bound paddle steamer hits a mine, grows up unaware that his parents are not his natural kin. When a fairground Gypsy tells them that Eddy will kill his father and bed his mother, they can't get the young man out of the house fast enough. But within hours Eddy has killed the owner of a greasy-spoon cafe and settled down with the dead man's wife, who many years previously lost her son in an accident. Where Sophocles is spare, Berkoff is showy. The language is foul, bloated, swag-bellied, tumescent. It is like an extended orgasm. Though there are times - particularly as the story thunders towards its climax - when you think "Oh just get on with it", the effect is both exhausting and enormously satisfying. In part it is because Berkoff's descriptive powers are so strong. In a few phrases he summons up Eddy's adoptive home: the smell of lard, the picture on the mantelpiece of granny "looking like Mussolini in drag", Eddy's sister in her room "meditating over some juicy blackhead". But it is also because the munificence of the language demands a suitably ornamental response from the actors. It is like watching skaters attempting a fiendishly difficult jump on very thin ice. Oliver Lansley is near perfect as the hapless Eddy, only flagging slightly towards the close. But the distinctiveness of Berkoff's language and the expressionistic physical style of the piece are so familiar that they can pose other difficulties. There are occasions, particularly with the writing is at its most florid, when Berkoff seems almost to be parodying himself. I was struck, as by other Berkoff revivals, that I am seeing a very clever copy rather than an original masterpiece. But it is a bracing evening, and anyone unfamiliar with Berkoff's scurrilous, sulphurous and gloriously theatrical play should head west.  Until January 27. Box office: 020-8237 1111.

webTitle: Reviews:  Classical: Park Lane Young Artists

fields.headline: Park Lane Young Artists
fields.standfirst:
Purcell Room, London
****
fields.trailText:
Purcell Room, London
****
fields.body:
Even in terms of bald statistics, it's impossible not to be impressed by the Park Lane Group's annual Young Artists Series. By the end of this week, 33 young players will have performed 60 20th-century works - the vast majority written in the last decade - including 11 world premieres.

And going by the quality of the first two days of concerts, there is cause for celebration at the excellence of the next generation of performers, and their dedication to new music. Two solo recitals by 18-year-old So-Ock Kim on violin and 16-year-old Wu Qian on piano were outstanding. Both featured some of the most challenging music of the last 20 years, with performances that would grace any of the world's new music stages.

What was so remarkable about Kim's playing was not only her technical mastery, but also the tenderness and warmth she found in music such as Elliott Carter's aphoristic Riconoscenza. And in Brian Ferneyhough's Intermedio alla Ciaccona - a touchstone of contemporary complexity - she created a wildly expressive polyphony at the extremes of the violin's register. This was an immediate, almost romantic, interpretation. The unashamed grandiosity of Nicholas Maw's Solo Sonata completed her programme.

The culmination of Wu Qian's recital was another Carter piece, Night Fantasies for solo piano, an enormous, 25-minute meditation on the elusive imagery of darkness. Qian's performance transcended the work's extraordinary difficulties, illuminating the poetry of Carter's vision with laser-like clarity. Earlier in her programme, Qian performed two of Gyorgy Ligeti's mercurial Etudes, and gave the world premiere of Malcolm Singer's Franco's Gone - Gifts of Tones: A Toccata, an ostinato-obsessed movement in memory of the Italian composer Franco Donatoni, who died last year.

Throughout her and Kim's recitals, there was an unmistakable sense of a personal, emotional involvement with the music, revealing astonishing musical maturity. The featured composer of this year's Young Artists Series is 37-year-old Philip Cashian. Sarah James on saxophone gave the first performance of Cashian's Songs from a Still World, which slowly grew from an eerie whisper to a passionate declamation. Another reflective Cashian piece, Strobod's Violin, for violin and piano, was played by the compelling Ukrainians Dmytro Tkachenko and Alexei Grynyuk.

On the other side of Cashian's creative spectrum was Dancing with Venus for cello and piano. Naomi Williams and Alasdair Beatson relished the music's ghoulish energy. Williams and Beatson also gave the premiere of Luke Bedford's Through Mazes Running, a study in idiomatic, elegiac melody. But there is still room for older classics on the Park Lane programme. Josep Sancho on clarinet and Lila Gailling on piano were engaging advocates of the austerity of Harrison Birtwistle's 1966 Verses, as well as the explosiveness of Peter Maxwell Davies's 1967 Hymnos.

 The series continues until Friday. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

webTitle: Interest rates kept on hold at 6%

fields.headline: Interest rates kept on hold at 6%
fields.standfirst: Comment by Charlotte Denny
fields.trailText:
Interest rates have been kept on hold at 6% for the 11th consecutive month, the Bank of England's monetary policy committee confirmed today.
More business news
fields.body:
The Bank of England today kept interest rates on hold at 6% for the 11th consecutive month, despite strong pressure from industry and unions for a cut.

City analysts had predicted the "no change" decision from the Bank's nine-member monetary policy committee which was announced following their monthly meeting.

However, pressure for a reduction in the cost of borrowing had intensified since last week's surprise rate cut by the US federal reserve to counter the weakening of the American economy.

The Confederation of British Industry and the British Chambers of Commerce had urged the Bank of England to follow suit in order to protect the UK from a global economic downturn.

Two MPC members, DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani, had called for a "pre-emptive" quarter-point rate cut at the last meeting in December, citing the slowdown in the world economy.

But the hawks on the committee fear that continuing falls in the level of unemployment will lead to calls for higher wages, which would in turn fuel inflation.

While City experts expected that the Bank would retain its "wait and see" stance for another month, most expect that it will cut rates before the spring.

webTitle: Babe theme talking dog promotes stakeholder pensions

fields.headline: Babe theme talking dog promotes stakeholder pensions
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is enlisting the help of talking dogs, Jane Horrocks and the Royle Family's Craig Cash in a £6.5m television advertising campaign beginning tonight that it hopes will encourage viewers to take out stakeholder pensions, writes Patrick Collinson .
fields.body:
The government is enlisting the help of talking dogs, Jane Horrocks and the Royle Family's Craig Cash in a £6.5m television advertising campaign beginning tonight that it hopes will encourage viewers to take out stakeholder pensions, writes Patrick Collinson .

It also hopes the adverts, based on the Babe films featuring talking animals, will not backfire in the way of the last big government pensions promotion in 1988. The now notorious "straitjacket" adverts, introduced by the then DHSS minister Norman Fowler to promote the first personal pensions, were widely blamed for provoking the £13.5bn pensions mis-selling scandal.

The adverts will run until March, preparing for the April 6 launch day of stakeholder pensions. They will steer viewers to a new website, pensionguide.gov.uk, which will set out retirement options for working people.

The DSS says the Babe theme is being used to counter disinterest among younger people. "People think pensions are boring. The adverts will use Babe-style technology, with talking dogs rounding up sheep and dreaming of a happy retirement in their kennels, with the voices of Jane Horrocks and Craig Cash," said a DSS spokesman.

Research released yesterday by Legal & General revealed that only one in six people aged 16-24 are aware of stakeholders. This is likely to be transformed in the spring as a raft of pension providers begin advertising campaigns.

Stakeholder pensions are an important plank in the strategy to encourage particularly the lower paid to boost retirement income by saving in a private plan as a top-up to the state pension.

webTitle: Room to move as UK economy weathers storm

fields.headline: Room to move as UK economy weathers storm
fields.standfirst:
The Bank of England doesn't need to be panicked into cutting interest rates, argues Charlotte Denny
More business news
fields.trailText:
The Bank of England doesn't need to be panicked into cutting interest rates, argues Charlotte Denny.

More business news
fields.body:
The Bank of England's decision to keep interest rates on hold for the 11th month in a row - despite the cut to American borrowing rates last week - demonstrates that Threadneedle Street believes the UK economy is in better shape than the US, where the dramatic collapse in consumer and business confidence since December has alarmed policymakers.

The deputy governor, Mervyn King, declared last week that the Bank would not be influenced by any moves to lower borrowing costs in the US. His remarks came just hours before the surprise decision by the federal reserve to cut American interest rates by half a percentage point.

The Fed had to act because the American economy has slowed down sharply over the last two months as households, dented by the collapse in share prices, have slashed spending. Retailers are reporting dreadful sales over the critical Christmas period and firms are shelving investment plans and hunkering down for what is expected to be a rough ride.

The Bank is well aware that the UK economy usually follows the US lead. The governor, Sir Eddie George, warned in December that "if the US sneezes, we all catch a cold". But there are few signs that the US slowdown has infected the UK yet. British retailers are reporting robust Christmas sales, the service sector generally is doing well, and even the manufacturing sector is reporting higher sales.

Until Threadneedle Street's rate setters see concrete evidence that the UK economy is turning down, rates are likely to stay on hold. However, the Bank has shown before that it is prepared to move quickly to avoid a collapse in confidence. When the Russian debt default in autumn 1998 threatened meltdown in global financial markets, the Bank quickly followed the US lead in slashing interest rates.

Britain is in better shape than many economies to weather the stormy economic outlook. Inflation is below the government's 2.5% target and the public sector is running a healthy surplus for the first time in more than a decade. If the Bank needs to move in a hurry, it has room to manoeuvre.

webTitle: Reviews: Theatre: Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill

fields.headline: Billie sings the car park blues
fields.standfirst:
Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill
Playhouse, Derby
****
fields.trailText:
Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill
Playhouse, Derby
****
fields.body:
The colourful version of Billie Holiday's break has it that she staggered, wild and hungry, into a Harlem speakeasy and danced so appallingly that the pianist was moved to ask: "Honey, do you sing?" The more mundane truth is that she probably started performing in a small club on New York's Upper West Side around 1932. What is certain is that she never appeared in a subterranean car park in Derby. She can be found there now - or at least her earthly representative, in the form of the musical actress Dawn Hope, can be.

Heroin, hunger and love gone wrong set a strange agenda for seasonal entertainment, but Playhouse artistic director Mark Clements has had a strange season, hosting Cinderella upstairs and Billie in the basement. Derby Playhouse being located in a shopping precinct, it stands to reason that the studio should be a short detour across an underground car park. Yet for 90 intense, unbroken minutes, you are prepared to believe that this bunker is a smoky enclave of Southside Philadelphia.

The year is 1959, the place Emerson's pokey jazz joint, where Philadelphia's most famous singing export has come full circle. A dizzy descent from jazz diva to jailbird has seen the singer they called Lady Day degenerate to Lady Yesterday - a convicted drug felon legally prohibited from earning a crust. Back home to croak again through the songs she no longer cares about, Holiday keeps singing because it's the only way she can be sure she's still alive.

Clements caught the original production of Lanie Robertson's compelling musical monologue off Broadway and, having spent time in Harlem and Philadephia, his mesmerising production has the ring of authenticity. Dawn Hope produces a sensationally well-modulated performance, never allowing the sparkling transcendence of the songs to become tarnished by the morass of misery that surrounds them.

Holiday always insisted that the right accompanist was the one who would help you feel your way through the songs, in which case Warren Wills is a more than reliable guide. Exuding a sullen presence as Holiday's current partner, he stares mournfully at the piano keys while the singer, in her reverie, addresses him as her fatal first love, the spineless husband who introduced her to heroin.

Holiday's mother said her special talent was to pick out the rottenest apple and cling to it - but then Strange Fruit was always Billie's taste.

 Until January 20. Box office: 0133-236 3275.
